PROCTEXT.PARA: The House met at 10 a.m.
The Clerk-I inform the House of the unavoidable absence of the Speaker. In accordance with standing order 14, the Chairman of Committees will take the chair as Acting Speaker.
Mr ACTING SPEAKER (Mr Leo McLeay) thereupon took the chair, and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do.
—The honourable member may proceed.
—I might say by way of preface that I trust that Madam Speaker and those in the car with her are making a reasonable recovery. I am sure that my colleagues would agree with that.
—They are fine, thank you.

—At a meeting yesterday of the Joint House Committee, Madam Speaker's colleague, Senator Sibraa, alleged that I had made a complaint in this ongoing issue of the old aerobics class. On Tuesday, in the House, I said that I found such an allegation made elsewhere to be inexplicable. I may have found the answer. On Tuesday I said that I had mentioned to the manager that two members had complained to me but I took the matter no further. In fact, as I said in the House on Tuesday:

SPEECH.PARA: Two members complained to me and I mentioned that to the manager. I took the matter no further. I did not; I would not; I have not; and I will not do anything about this sort of thing.

It appears that this conversation with the manager about others was interpreted as a complaint by me. As I have said, it was not. The officer who reported to Senator Sibraa, evidently a Mr David Hood, never contacted me. Indeed, no one contacted me. He apparently interpreted my reporting of my colleagues' concerns as a formal objection from me. As I said, it was not and should never have been interpreted in this way. It is a pity that officers did not contact me as the alleged complainant, for the whole nonsense would never have occurred and they would have ascertained that I made no complaint at all. I reiterate: the officer's belief that I complained is ill-founded.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Drugs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens showeth:

that your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 Pharmaceutical drugs from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme including the best available for the treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat and place them for cost saving reasons only on a special list requiring Authority from a Canberra bureaucrat, and;

that we believe a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medication needed for their particular illness and that it is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to seek permission from a bureaucrat in Canberra who has no personal knowledge of that case.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will call on the Government to immediately abandon the proposal and keep its election promise of high quality and universal health care for all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Baldwin (from 27 citizens), Mr N.A. Brown (from 69 citizens), Mr Robert Brown (from 27 citizens), Mr Donald Cameron (from 164 citizens), Mr Ewen Cameron (from 27 citizens), Mr Campbell (from 80 citizens), Mr Cohen (from 34 citizens), Mr Cowan (from 27 citizens), Ms Crawford (from 37 citizens), Mr Downer (from 27 citizens), Ms Fatin (from 52 citizens), Mr Fife (from 56 citizens), Mr Fitzgibbon (from 108 citizens), Mr Hand (from 27 citizens), Dr Hewson (from 111 citizens), Mr Hicks (from 63 citizens), Mr Hollis (from 82 citizens), Mr Jenkins (from 185 citizens), Mr Johns (from 119 citizens), Mr Barry Jones (from 108 citizens), Mr Jull (from 77 citizens), Mr Kerin (from 98 citizens), Mr Kerr (from 27 citizens), Mr Lamb (from 27 citizens), Mr MacKellar (from 27 citizens), Mr Leo McLeay (from 53 citizens), Mr Millar (from 82 citizens), Mr Peacock (from 67 citizens), Mr Pratt (from 244 citizens), Mr Reith (from 81 citizens), Mr Ian Robinson (from 27 citizens), Mr Rocher (from 27 citizens), Mr Shack (from 107 citizens), Mr Shipton (from 111 citizens), Mr Webster (from 152 citizens), Mr White (from 53 citizens) and Mr Wilson (from two citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Anti-Epileptic Medication
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain citizens and residents of Australia draws to the attention of the House that the Federal Government proposes to place the anti-epileptic medication sodium valproate (`Epilim') on the `Authority only' listing as of 1st August 1988. Your petitioners believe that this may well cause great problems for the people who take Epilim, for whom no effective alternative medication is available.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will rescind the decision to place sodium valproate (`Epilim') on the `Authority only' listing.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ewen Cameron (from 81 citizens), Mr Cunningham (from 30 citizens) and Mr McGauran (from 30 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Drugs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That whilst acknowledging the Government's desire to contain the growth in health costs, the introduction of 61 new drugs to the `Authority Required' listing will result in potentially serious delays in patients receiving medication prescribed by their doctors.
Your petitioners request the House to immediately reverse the Government's decision and withdraw these drugs from the `Authorities Required' list.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ewen Cameron (from 104 citizens), Mr McGauran (from 72 citizens) and Mr White (from 139 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Romania: Human Rights
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of Australia assembled. We the undersigned, are appalled that the Rumanian Government plans the commencement of the destruction in September of 7000 villages, hundreds of thousands of peaceful homes and homesteads, thousands of churches, historic monuments and cemeteries. With this barbaric action millions of people will be disadvantaged, even sent to their death with these Totalitarian actions.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give these matters earnest consideration and request the Rumanian Government to abandon these horrific acts against the Rumanian Community and its minorities.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Duffy (from 77 citizens) and Mr Shipton (from four citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Crime and Violence on Television
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House
There is too much crime and violence on TV and this is breaking down the standards and codes of behaviour in our society.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House compel TV stations to improve the standards of shows, news and current affairs programs by reducing the incidence of crime and violence broadcast every day into people's homes, by fifty per cent.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Fife (from 15 citizens) and Mr Tim Fischer (from 382 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Advertising of Alcohol
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that:
Alcohol is recognised as Australia's number one drug problem which is responsible for at least 50% of all road fatalities; a high percentage of serious crime and vandalism.
Hospital beds are filled with sufferers of the many alcohol related diseases including: cirrhosis of the liver; heart disease; stomach ulcers; various forms of cancer and mental illness.
Alcohol causes much family unhappiness and marriage breakdown, as well as being involved in some cases of child abuse and molestation.
Television and radio have a persuasive effect on children and young people.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to ban all advertising of alcohol on television and radio.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Fife (from 40 citizens) and Mr Miles (from 137 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Advertising of Alcohol on Television
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows: We oppose the advertising of alcohol in any form.

Alcohol is recognised as Australia's number one drug problem which is responsible for at least 50% of all road fatalities; a high percentage of serious crime and vandalism. Hospital beds are filled with sufferers of the many alcohol related diseases including: cirrhosis of the liver; heart disease; stomach ulcers; various forms of cancer and mental illness. Alcohol also causes much family unhappiness and marriage breakdown, as well as being involved in some cases of child abuse and molestation.

Your petitioners request that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should ban all advertising of alcohol on television and radio because of its persuasive effect on children and young people.

PETITION.TITLE: X and R Rated Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned,

note that a majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material has strongly opposed the proposition that a new NVE category will contain that material as defined in the current `X' classification.

call upon the House of Representatives to request the Government immediately to implement the recommendation of the majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material by introducing substantive legislation to ensure that X rated video material (and its R rated equivalent) is refused classification for the purpose of Commonwealth laws.
And Your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Kerr (from 671 citizens) and Mr Pratt (from 40 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Non-Violent Erotica Video Classification
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The petition of citizens of Australia points out to the House that the ACT Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983 has:
degraded men;
lowered the status of women;
affected the safety of children; and
escalated crime including sexual crime.
Because the Parliament has a role to play in the well-being of the people of this Nation, your petitioners therefore request that the House:
1. not adopt a Non-Violent Erotica (NVE) Video classification;
2. not permit NVE in cinemas;
3. retain section 13 of the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations as it is;
4. control ALL Censorship criteria by substantive legislation; and

5. give earnest consideration to these matters, in order that NO Attorney General shall ever again have the power to change our social and home environment for generations to come, without thorough and full debate in both Houses of Parliament.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Rocher (from 99 citizens) and Mr Shack (from 73 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Non-Violent Erotica Video Classification
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The petition of certain residents of the State of Western Australia points out to the House that the ACT Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983 has:
degraded men;
lowered the status of women;
affected the safety of children; and
escalated crime including sexual crime.
Because the Parliament has a role to play in the well-being of the people of this Nation, your petitioners therefore request that the House:
1. not adopt a Non-Violent Erotica (NVE) Video classification;
2. not permit NVE in cinemas;
3. retain section 13 of the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations as it is;
4. control ALL Censorship criteria by substantive legislation; and

5. give earnest consideration to these matters, in order that NO Attorney-General shall ever again have the power to change our social and home environment for generations to come, without thorough and full debate in both Houses of Parliament.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain citizens in Australia, draws to the attention of the House that the irradiation of food by any means degrades the nutritional value of food and is potentially harmful to the health of all consumers and to the environment.
Your petitioners therefore request that your honourable House:
1. Withdraw from the Asian Regional Co-operative Project on Food Irradiation and from the International Consultative Group on Food Irradiation.
2. Take all possible steps to prevent and disallow the irradiation of food in Australia.
3. Ban the export and importation of irradiated foods and animal feeds.
4. Take steps to obtain a testing device to make possible the identification of irradiation foods, as soon as one becomes available.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Scott (from 66 citizens) and Mr Webster (from 17 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Two-Dollar Coin
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of Australia assembled in Parliament.
The Petition of the undersigned electors in the State of Queensland respectfully showeth:-

that the introduction of the two dollar coin as a replacement for two dollar note does not have the support of the Australian people and is too easily confused with the existing five cent coin, thereby causing much confusion for both the very young and the elderly in Australia.
Your Petitioners, therefore, Humbly Pray that the Parliament of Australia will act immediately to remove the coin from circulation and reinstate the two dollar note as the only two dollar currency.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever Pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Pensions Income Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned draws attention to the House of the inequitable attack on pensioners of the Federal Government's proposed changes to the pension income test.
The changes will penalise those who have genuinely attempted self-provision in retirement and will eventually produce more dependency on Governments in the future.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will call on the Government to immediately abandon the proposal.

PETITION.TITLE: Distribution of Videotapes featuring Sex, Violence and Obscene Language
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of the members of the Country Women's Association of Victoria Inc. Benalla Branch in the Division of Indi draws to the attention of the House:
That this organisation protests strongly about the sex, violence and murder being shown on our television screens.
Your petitions therefore pray that the House be urged to prohibit the distribution of video tapes featuring sex, violence and obscene language.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card
PETITION.PARA: To The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, your humble petitioners showeth:
1. The proposed Australia Card will have a dramatic impact on the lives of all Australians.
2. Therefore your petitioners request a national referendum on the Australia Card bill before the proposal is re-submitted to Parliament.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament: The petition of certain electors of the Division of Indi:

Draws to the attention of the House the current inadequate level of funding for road construction and maintenance and express concern that the House may have placed before it, as part of the government economic strategy, options to further reduce such expenditure, and in so doing placing an increased financial burden upon local government ratepayers.

Your petitioners therefore respectfully call upon the House to ensure an increase over current road funding levels through a clear dedication of a proportion of fuel excise collected, indexed for inflation, towards roadworks and that such funding arrangements provide for a clear and reliable method of distribution to local government.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Indi electorate respectfully showeth that:
Australians living in rural and non-urban areas rely to a great degree on the local road network for all facets of their lives.
Funding for roads is an essential part of the Commonwealth's responsibilities for the maintenance of the transport infrastructure.
Road funding under the Hawke Government has decreased significantly in real terms and local government is particularly disadvantaged by this decline.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled urge the Government to:

immediately address the serious problem of a rapidly deteriorating road network which is confronting local government by allocating more resources, along with State Governments, to local road funding.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Immigration
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth that:
The subject of immigration is of deep concern, and supports the following significant community views placed before the Fitzgerald Committee on Immigration:
(1) That Asians accounting for 40% of the total migrant intake is viewed with considerable concern by the Australian people;

(2) The Anglo-Australian sense of superiority of their culture previously manifest in the policy of assimilation remains a significant factor in the community and should be taken into account as the wishes of the people on this important matter;
(3) It is a matter of concern that 43% of one million of those residentially qualified migrants to take out citizenship have not done so;

(4) It is a major recommendation that the Federal Government consult the Australia people by Referendum on the subject of Asian immigration, and then affirm its commitment to the immigration policies which conform to the general wishes of the majority of the people, and should be recognised by Government as such.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled urge the Parliament to:
Protect our national identity, and preserve the Australian way of life.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Land and Property Freehold Titles
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:
(a) We have nothing against the Japanese people, or any other people, but we object to them attempting to make Australia an economic and financial colony of Japan, or that of any other nation.

(b) We realise that the economics of nations is a global issue. However, we cannot allow ``predatory'' countries, such as Japan, control over our economic future in Australia. Japan already owns meatworks and large grazing areas of our rural land.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House:
(i) will immediately introduce legislation so that freehold titles to Australian land and property can be held and transacted only by Australians by birth or naturalisation/citizenship.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Chile
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that since 11th September, 1973 the Chilean people have been suffering under one of the cruellest and bloodiest dictatorships in Latin America. During these 15 years, the military rulers and their police have made torture, murder and disappearance a common practice. The Chilean military regime has violated all international standards for the respect of human rights, has prohibited freedom of expression, freedom of assembly and freedom of thought. It has violated international labour agreements, ignoring the rights of unions and organisations to represent workers in their just demand for better wages and conditions.

Many Chileans are persecuted or exiled for their political beliefs, and political prisoners in Chilean jails can languish for months or years before their cases are heard. No elections have been held since 1973.

Recently, Australian companies Bond Corporation, Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and Ansett (part-owned by Rupert Murdoch) have invested in Chile, thereby helping to prop up the dictatorship and prolong the suffering of the Chilean people. We strongly condemn these unscrupulous capitalists that are trying to reap benefits from the Chilean people's tragedy.

During 15 years of dictatorship, hundreds of thousands of people have become victims of the barbarity of the Pinochet regime, the most dramatic case being that which was perpetrated on the 2nd July, 1986 against two young people-Carmen Gloria Quintana and Rodrigo Rojas Denegri. They were detained by a military patrol, doused with gasoline, set on fire and later dumped on the outskirts of Santiago, Rodrigo Rojas died four days later and Carmen Gloria was left with shocking burns to 60% of her body. In April 1988, she will be in Australia on a speaking tour, to expose very clearly through her words and experiences the modus operandi of the Pinochet military dictatorship.
In light of the above, your petitioners therefore respectfully urge the House to:
1. Intervene on behalf of the hundreds of political prisoners condemned to the prisons of the dictatorship, and particularly those condemned to death for their beliefs.
2. Exert diplomatic pressure on the Chilean military regime demanding the release of all political prisoners, the return to democratic elections and the respect of human rights.
3. Publicly condemn investment by Australian companies in Chile until democratic elections are held and human rights are respected.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Casino in the Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That we are totally opposed to the proposal for the establishment of a gambling casino in Canberra or the Australian Capital Territory.
(2) That a casino in Canberra would detract from the unique character and status of our National Capital.
Your petitioners therefore most humbly request the House of Representatives to reject any proposal or legislation which would permit the establishment of a casino in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your humble petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Hire and Sale of R, X and Non-Violent Erotica Rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that:
The video industry has no right to promote anti-social behaviour.
Community and professional concern has been publicly expressed over video violence and anti-social content.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House ban the hire and sale of all R-rated, X-rated and proposed Non-violent Erotica rated videos from all outlets patronised by the general public.

PETITION.TITLE: National Song
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned,
request that the last line in each chorus of the National Song be altered from:
Advance Australia Fair
to
God Bless Australia Fair.
And Your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Age Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
This petition of certain citizens of Australia points out to the House:

That we welcome Parliament's decision to increase the Pensioner Tax Rebate to $430 but point out this still leaves the allowable earnings before tax has to be paid to be less than applied in March 1983 and by June next year will be very small indeed.

We also point out that the pension has not increased in real terms since 1983 and the six weeks delay from May and November to June and December further deprives pensioners of their just entitlements. We therefore call on the Parliament to:
1. To immediately restore the May/November adjustment dates for the Pension and move quickly to implement the Government's promise of 1983 to reduce the delay to only one month.
2. To increase the Pensioner Tax Rebate to $800 and index this rebate.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Noise Levels at Brisbane Domestic Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain electors in the Division of Griffith draw to the attention of the House the increase in noise pollution and the subsequent effect on the quality of life of residents in certain southern suburbs of Brisbane, caused by the opening of the new Brisbane domestic airport.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to take steps to minimise noise levels and alter aircraft flight paths to enable a return to the lifestyle previously enjoyed by the affected residents.

PETITION.TITLE: Importation of Radioactive Substances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the House to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Importation of Radioactive Substances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That we most strongly oppose the process of `food irradiation' by Cobalt 60, cesium 137, cesium 134 or any machine sources.
That we oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process being permitted in Australia.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Federal Parliament ban the importation of any radioactive substances or machinery for the purposes of food irradiation, disallow regulations permitting the irradiation of food in this country, and ban the irradiation of food in this country, and also ban the importation of food treated by irradiation.

We also call upon the parliament to advise the Federal Government to withdraw from the Asian Regional Co-operative Project on Food Irradiation and the International Consultative Group on Food Irradiation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Importation of Radioactive Substances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That we most strongly oppose the process of `food irradiation' by Cobalt 60, cesium 137, cesium 134 or any machine sources.
That we oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process being permitted by State governments.

We call on the House to ban the importation of any radioactive substances, or machinery for the purposes of food irradiation; disallow regulations permitting the irradiation of food in this country; ban the irradiation of food in this country; and also ban the importation of food treated by irradiation.
We also call upon the House to request the Government to withdraw from the Asian Regional Co-operative Project on Food Irradiation and the International Consultative Group on Food Irradiation.

PETITION.TITLE: ACTION Bus Fares
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The Humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that there is an immediate need for the review of all action bus fares throughout Canberra.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House reviews and lowers all Action bus fares in Canberra to the level of thirty cents for students and pensioners and sixty cents for all adults.

The Citizens below feel that the recent substantial rise in bus fares (some as much as seven dollars) has greatly disadvantaged specific groups in the community and affected all commuters unnecessarily and your petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: The Last Temptation of Christ
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain residents of the State of Tasmania draws to the attention of the House the concern of certain citizens at the possibility that the film `The Last Temptation of Christ' will be permitted to enter Australia for screening.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House rejects the entry into Australia of the film `The Last Temptation of Christ', which has been described as blasphemous by Christians in other countries.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Electoral Commission: Burnie, Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the petition of certain electors of the Division of Braddon draws the attention of the House to the proposal to close the Burnie Office of the Australian Electoral Commission.
We believe:
1. That the proposed closure is not in the best interests of democracy.
2. That closure will further erode jobs in regional areas of Australia.
3. That we oppose the further centralisation of government services at the expense of rural and isolated communities.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will oppose the closure.

PETITION.TITLE: The Last Temptation of Christ
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. That the film by its false and indecent portrayal of characters and conversations, does injury to the person of Jesus Christ (recognised and worshipped as God by Christians), obscenely and blasphemously misrepresenting His nature and His teachings.
2. That the film discriminates against all who hold to the truth of Christianity, by its public false depiction of their faith and the Christ who is the object of their worship.
3. That the film is likely to be injurious to the general understanding and practice of morality through its attempted discreditation of Christianity, which espouses a high view of morality.
4. That the film, in falsifying the truth of an historically based faith, is not in the public interest as it obscures both the content and purpose of Christianity from those who may seek to know it.
5. This film, although portraying real, historical figures has displayed complete disregard for the truth.

Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will do everything possible to prevent the film, ``The Last Temptation of Christ'', from being registered for screening in Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Crime and Violence on Television
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of certain electors of the Division of Barker points out to the House that there is too much crime and violence on TV and this is breaking down the standards and codes of behaviour in our society.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House urge TV stations to clean up their act and improve the standards of shows, news and current affairs programs by reducing the incidence of crime and violence broadcast every day into people's homes.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pension Entitlements
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We are gravely concerned at the Government's proposal to reduce significantly the pension and access to fringe benefits of persons who, in good faith, bought market linked insurance bonds, friendly society bonds, approved deposit funds, deferred annuities and unit trusts to protect their savings.

Your petitioners request that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled amend the proposed legislation to ensure that it will not apply retrospectively and that provision is made to protect savings against inflation.

PETITION.TITLE: Television Reception: Mornington Peninsula, Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of concerned citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the House to the fact that residents in the Rosebud area, south of Arthur' Seat on the Mornington Peninsula, are disadvantaged by the lack of television reception due to inadequate telecommunications equipment in that area.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House request the Minister for Communications to take the necessary steps to restore and improve the standard of television reception in this area as a matter of urgency.

PETITION.TITLE: Buckland Hill, Western Australia
PETITION.PARA: The honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: the petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that we believe the Commonwealth owned land at Buckland Hill and the river foreshore reserves from point direction to Chine Street should be declared `A' class reserve for conservation and passive recreation.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
1. Retain the land at Buckland Hill in Commonwealth ownership and declare it `A' class reserve.
2. Make arrangements for a draft management plan to be drawn up by a biologist for public comment
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Invermay Post Office: Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
That the present Invermay Post Office serves a large number of residents in the Invermay area and its closure will cause great inconvenience and hardship to many.
We therefore request that the Invermay Post Office be retained in its present state.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Newnham Court Newsagency Post Office: Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
That the Newnham Court Newsagency Post Office be retained to service the needs of a growing community.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Non-Discriminatory Selection Criteria for Migrants
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
This petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the Report of the Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies.

Your petitioners humbly request the House to consider the hardship that will be endured by citizens who have come to Australia from countries in the Middle East in any shift away from the Family Reunion Program. We are concerned that recent changes to the points test for migrant selection already discriminates against people from non-English speaking backgrounds, and makes family reunions increasingly difficult to achieve.
We urge the House to maintain a commitment to non-discriminatory selection criteria for migrants, and to the concept of a multi-cultural Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: National Day of Prayer
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker, House of Representatives and Parliament assembled.
`Righteousness exalts a nation,
but sin is a disgrace to any people.'
Proverbs 14:34
Considering:
1. the loss of hope among the youth of the nation.
2. the breakdown of the family unit.
3. the increase of corruption in our society.
4. the increasing weight or our national debt.
5. the emerging divisions in our community.
We petition to you:
1. encourage every Australian to see his/her responsibility to live uprightly before God and others;
2. encourage commitment in marriage and encourage fathers and mothers to love and cherish their children;
3. encourage the members of Parliament to live and legislate according to Biblical principles;
4. encourage business in Australia to pursue their transactions in generosity-without greed;
5. support the Christian Church in expressing the friendship of God, and in carrying out its practical responsibilities to the poor, needy and dispossessed.
by calling a National Day of Prayer for Australia, to seek God's help to heal our land.
We as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: The Last Temptation of Christ
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the proposed showing in this country of the film `The Last Temptation of Christ'.
This film is offensive to Australians because of its anti-christian blasphemous and sacreligious nature.
Your petitioners therefore humbly request that the House take action to ensure that the viewing of this film in Australia is rejected by the Film Censorship Board.

PETITION.TITLE: Participation in Government Statistical Surveys
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that the surveys of the Australian Bureau of Statistics represent:
1. an unnecessary demand on the time of certain Australians;
2. an intrusion into the private affairs of individuals and families; and
3. excessive penalties for non-compliance.

Your petitioners therefore request that the House take action to pass legislation making government statistical surveys voluntary and to ensure the protection of the privacy of Australians from government departments and authorities.
Your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pension Income Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the Government's decision to impose the pension income test on money received from market linked investment products.
This decision represents yet another attack on the Australian pensions.
Your petitioners therefore humbly request that the House take action to ensure this decision is revoked.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Pornography
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of Australia assembled. We, the undersigned, being appalled that the Government has set no penalty for importing unclassified child pornography, do ask that Parliament urgently legislate to:
make the importation of child pornography, and the possession of child pornography, and all tapes and goods banned by Customs, to be a criminal offence, with deterrent penalties, and
close the Customs barriers to pornography in the A.C.T., in respect of X rated videos, (and ER) and end the shameful Canberra trade, and the Mafia connections.
Because 98% of Australians in other States have banned X rated videos.
Because the trade is still flourishing, and it's availability escalates sexual crime.
Because importers of child pornography face only a fine for lying.
Because child pornography peddlers are safe if they cross a border, and cannot be extradited for a summary offence.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Madam Speaker, I present the report of the Commonwealth of Australia Branch delegation to the Thirty-third Commonwealth Parliamentary Conference, held in Kuala Lumpur in September 1987.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure in this enlarged chamber to have so many more people in the galleries than we used to have in the old House.
—And fewer in the House.

—I am not sure about that. I think there are about the same number in the House as there used to be. One of the real delights of this new chamber is that so many more people can participate in Parliament by being present in the galleries.

SPEECH.PARA: The Thirty-third Commonwealth Parliamentary Conference, held in Kuala Lumpur in September 1987, was a most useful conference. It was only a discussion conference, but all the subjects discussed were important. There were five plenary sessions: one on the International Year of the Homeless which was under way at that time; a second was on world trade and protectionism; a third was on another world plague, acquired immune deficiency syndrome; a fourth was on the role of television in the media in promoting respect for parliament and the understanding of parliamentary democracy; and a fifth on safeguarding human rights which I had the honour to introduce to the conference. All of those sessions were of real value. Discussion was lively and conclusions were reached. There were panel discussions on a range of other subjects of importance to both industrialised and developing countries within the Commonwealth. I congratulate the organisers of that conference, particularly the chairman of the organising committee, Dato' Sharir bin Abdul Samad, who recently gained notoriety for resigning and re-standing for election in his electorate and for being resoundingly successful and therefore influencing the state of body politic in Malaysia.

I particularly draw attention to the speech in this report by the Secretary-General of the Commonwealth, Sir Shridath Ramphal, who made an outstanding speech referring to many aspects of Commonwealth activity, particularly to the state of the global economy. He referred to the danger of a global economic decline which appeared very likely in 1987. Since he made that speech there has been a rapid decline in some of the developing parts of the Commonwealth, despite the recovery in much of the industrialised countries of the West. I would like to dwell on that for a moment. Within Australia the extent of the decline in developing countries is not well understood. The 1980s have been a lost decade for development, but during the 1980s the Third World has experienced a depression more severe than even the Great Depression in the industrialised countries in the 1930s. Living standards have fallen by about 15 per cent in many parts of south Asia, sub-Saharan Africa and Latin America.

Western countries were the principal cause of that depression. The contradictory monetarist policies, introduced at the end of the 1970s by conservative Western governments, depressed demand, reduced their commodity imports and commodity prices, and sharply increased interest rates. Developing countries, which had for the previous five years been deluged with recycled petrodollars, suddenly found themselves squeezed from every direction. Exports collapsed, interest payments multiplied and after August 1982 new lending stopped. Total resources, including aid, lending and trade credits to developing countries, fell from $US120 billion in 1980 to $US68 billion in 1986-nearly a halving in the total resource flows to developing countries over those six years. Net resource flows are now negative. The developing countries pay almost $35 billion a year to Western countries more than they receive.

To cope, developing countries have been forced to impose austere domestic economic policies and to borrow from the International Monetary Fund, which imposes harsh conditionalities. The consequences have been economic decline, rising unemployment, escalating inflation and growing poverty. Not only have incomes fallen, but also services have deteriorated. In some places, both in the Commonwealth and outside, such as Brazil, where a decade ago there were primary schools and medical centres, no education or health care is now available. In such places people have lost hope. They no longer believe that their struggle for survival will make life for their children any better than it has been for them.

The situation now is that 950 million people are estimated by the World Bank to be living in absolute poverty. By `absolute poverty' the World Bank means a condition of life so degraded by disease, illiteracy, malnutrition and squalor as to deny its victims basic human necessities. Absolute poverty was common before the depression of the 1980s but has become more widespread during the decade. About 350 million of those impoverished people live in south Asia, within our own region, another 280 million in the largely rural areas of sub-Saharan Africa, and about 80 million in Latin America. Many Australians, often those who have travelled to east Asian countries such as Singapore, Hong Kong, Taiwan and Korea, are impressed by the growth there, forgetting that elsewhere terrible poverty has been increasing, largely because of the policies of our allies, the United States, Japan and Western Europe.

There is much that Australia can do about those terrible problems. Many of those alternative policies were discussed at the Commonwealth Parliamentary Conference. They include increasing aid, reorienting our international financial policies and improving trading opportunities for the developing countries. Now is not the moment to go into those in detail. But I draw the attention of the House to the importance of Sir Shridath Ramphal's speech. He made another excellent speech at the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association Conference here in Canberra about three weeks ago. The problems he drew attention to are enormous. They require our closest attention. I hope that the House will give them attention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a delegate to the Thirty-third Commonwealth Parliamentary Conference, held in Kuala Lumpur in September last year, I join my colleague the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) in congratulating the Malaysian branch for the excellent organisation of the conference and thanking it for the hospitality extended to our delegation. The pre-conference tours organised by the host country enabled the delegates to learn something about Malaysia and the friendliness and diversity of its people. They also enabled us to mix informally with our Malayan colleagues and members of parliament from regional legislatures.

SPEECH.PARA: Further, I wish to thank our High Commissioner in Kuala Lumpur, Gavan Hogue, and his staff who gave us every assistance during the conference. It is the first CPA conference that I have attended and I observed the easy and friendly tone of the meeting. While there was some criticism of the richer nations in the Commonwealth, the tone remained cordial.

I took part in the debate concerning tariffs, world trade and the international debt situation, and of course I cannot but agree with the sentiments expressed by many Third World delegates that the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank are tools for the exploitation of the Third World by the developed industrialised countries. My colleague the honourable member for Fraser drew attention to the situation that exists today in the Third World countries so I shall not deal with that aspect of the conference.

In hindsight, I am also very conscious of the expression of Malaysia's enthusiasm for parliamentary democracy by the CPA President, Dato Sharir, in his speech and I remember Dr Mahathir, the Malaysian Prime Minister, complaining in his address about the `carping criticism for being not democratic enough' directed by the rich countries toward's the poor, as though he was foreshadowing events which makes the above criticism very valid in the case of Mahathir's regime.

Soon after the conference, on 28 October 1987, the Government of Dr Mahathir swooped on its opponents, rounding up and gaoling 90 persons under section 73 of the Internal Security Act. Those arrested were Government critics, social activists and conservationists who were involved in exposing poverty, governmental corruption and environmental vandalism. They included members of parliament from both the Government and opposition parties who had dared to criticise the Government, including the leader of the Opposition Democratic Action Party, Mr Lim Kit Siang, and his son, Mr Lim Guang Eng.

Also arrested was the Democratic Action Party member of parliament and barrister, Mr Karpal Singh-a man known to Australians through his defence of Barlow and Chambers in their trial on drug charges. Dr Chandra Muzaffar, leader of the respected public interest group Aliran, and numerous other academics, trade union leaders, consumer rights activists and antinuclear and native rights lobbyists were also arrested. These arrests took place late at night, when Special Branch police swooped on these people's houses and dragged them from their beds. Many of the detainees have had to suffer appalling treatment in prison, including torture.

The Malaysian Government has closed down three opposition newspapers-the Star, Sin Chew Jit Poh and Watan. The laws under which these arrests and newspaper closures have been made are an affront to democratic nations and have the aim of silencing the Opposition. Mahathir's action cannot be described as `not democratic enough' but as outright despotism and it is time that the Commonwealth nations, including Australia, condemned it in the strongest terms. Wherever human rights are violated we all have a duty to speak up and condemn the oppressors.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to participate briefly in this discussion of the report of the Commonwealth of Australia Branch delegation to the Thirty-third Commonwealth Parliamentary Conference, Kuala Lumpur, and to make some comments on behalf of the Opposition members of the delegation, that is, the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) and myself. I am sure the honourable member for Franklin would want to participate as well but, as members of the Parliament will know, he is currently suffering from laryngitis and unable to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: I appreciated the role of the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) in leading the delegation. Clearly he had gone to some trouble to be well briefed and to participate in the debates. I felt that other members of the delegation would have had a more useful role to play had we too been as diligent as the honourable member for Fraser in our briefing. I have to say that I felt that in many ways our delegation was somewhat overshadowed by the United Kingdom delegation in the briefing its members had clearly been prepared to submit themselves to prior to participating in the conference.

This was the first experience I had had of a CPA conference and I was very anxious to see just how the CPA functioned, particularly in view of the present involvement of its Secretary-General, Mr David Tonkin, who was formerly Premier of my home State, South Australia. As one who arrived just a shade cynical about the whole role of CPA conferences and as one who wondered whether conferences like this were little more than a parliamentary junket, I was converted from that cynical viewpoint to an appreciation of the purpose of the organisation and in fact to a sense of justification of what the CPA is about. Anyone who has participated in CPA conferences and seen the way in which diverse nations from around the Commonwealth come together, and particularly the way in which the CPA gives an opportunity for the black African nations to involve themselves as Commonwealth nations with other Commonwealth nations, will appreciate, as I did, the important role of the CPA in building bridges across what are cultural gaps.

As a member of the delegation I was grateful to the CPA for its agenda and grateful to the Malaysian Government for its hospitality, for the way in which it made every one of us feel welcome, and for the way in which the conference was conducted so that all participants could feel they had made a real contribution to building a bridge between neighbours.
In my concluding remarks I want once again to thank the honourable member for Fraser for his role in leading the delegation and for his participation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) recognises the serious environmental threat posed by the greenhouse effect; and
(2) believes that urgent steps should be taken to implement and maintain research into the greenhouse effect and that such research should be funded by means of a levy on polluters and pollutants.
On 19 August 1987 I wrote to Senator Richardson, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, and I would like to read from that letter:
Dear Graham,
I am writing to draw your attention to what I believe is an extremely serious environmental problem which will not be addressed unless funding for research is provided.

The catastrophic effects of any small change in temperature or decrease in the ozone layer could cause huge losses in primary industries and the coastal environment, i.e. flooding, change in climate, increase of up to one metre in sea levels around Australia, and if the ozone layer drops by 1%, an estimated increase of over 40,000 skin cancers in the US alone. These effects will not be felt by us but our children will suffer these problems.

To cut research into this vital area of our very existence would be gross neglect of the future. It is a problem that may be rectified by modification of our present methods of releasing pollutants into the atmosphere, but that modification will come about only by research and education.
Could you use your best endeavours to convince those who oppose spending on research of the importance of this matter.

That was a letter I wrote over a year ago. On 19 September 1987 I asked the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), who is at the table, a question in relation to the greenhouse effect. The Minister said:
Potentially, the greatest environmental disaster of all time.

He was referring to the greenhouse effect. Then on 2 October 1987 I asked another question on chlorofluorocarbons. On 8 October 1987 in the debate on the Appropriation Bills I made a speech on chlorofluorocarbons. What I was trying to do over a year ago was to raise the profile of this issue. I am glad to say that scientists and many other people throughout the world have also raised it to such a height that people are starting to look at it and take a little notice of it. Last night some retired people who joined me for dinner talked about what could occur because of the greenhouse effect.

I would like to quote from some newspaper cuttings which relate to weather effects in the last 12 months. We do not know whether they result from the greenhouse effect or whether they merely provide anecdotal evidence of various things which could lead up to it. I quote from the newspaper cuttings:
Bangladesh is reaping a bitter monsoon of harvest.

. . . two-thirds of the rice harvest has been lost, 21 million people are homeless, 1200 are dead, 30,000 in the capital of Dhaka are suffering from water-borne diseases and the repair bill for road and rail infrastructure will be at least $A200 million.
Bangladesh is battling to save millions of people facing starvation and disease in the wake of floods that have claimed more than 500 lives.
10 killed as fierce storm lashes NSW.
Ten people were killed and many families fled their homes during 24 hours of fierce rain and winds in Sydney.
The strong winds and heavy rain throughout most of Tuesday developed into a wild storm yesterday morning in which the roof of a Manly unit block was ripped off.
Many families had lucky escapes. . .
Bangladesh-A Country Under Water.
`I don't know why God should punish us like this,' sighed the weary President of Bangladesh, Hussain Mohammed Ershad, as he looked out a helicopter window at the devastation below.

. . . three-quarters of Bangladesh-a country the size of Wisconsin crowded with 110 million people-lay under water after it and neighbouring India, Bhutan and Nepal were pelted by what may have been the heaviest monsoon rains in 70 years.
This year's flood's follow a devastating inundation in 1987 and worse may be in store.
Sudan-Drowning in a River of Woe.

For centuries the Nile has brought life to Sudan's impoverished inhabitants. But torrential thunderstorms this summer have turned the river into a killer. More than 8 inches of rain-twice the average for an entire year-fell on Sudan in 13 hours last month. The combination sent the river raging over its banks, killing nearly 100 people and leaving 1.5 million homeless.
Alarm at Indian's snow melt plan.
Water management authorities in India have tried to melt the Himalayan snows by blackening them with charcoal after a third year of disastrous drought and late monsoons.
Floods kill more than 300.
New Delhi, Wednesday: Fresh floods devastated many areas in northern India this week, killing more than 300 people and destroying crops and property.
. . . nearly 300,000 people have been affected by the floods.
Big death toll predicted as US heat wave drags on.
A heat wave has continued to fry the American Midwest with enervating 38-degree temperatures that one environmental expert said might claim thousands of victims by the end of summer.
Late last July, Victoria and Tasmania experienced 24 hours of gales, blizzards and driving rain which caused some flooding, damage to houses and widespread loss of electricity.
Tullamarine airport recorded a wind gust of 92 km/h . . . In Bass Strait, the Abel Tasman faced 10m waves and was forced to `tread' water for an hour in gusts exceeding 128 km/h.
Flood-stricken Sudan threatened by locusts.
Fierce storm hits Canberra.
A fierce storm ripped through Canberra last night, lifting roofs from two public buildings, uprooting trees and blowing yachts off their moorings on Lake Burley Griffin.
Stock, crop losses in big floods.
Farmers around Horsham were last night bracing themselves for the biggest floods of the Wimmera River in more than 65 years.
New Yorkers lose their cool in longest, hottest summer.
When the Empire State Building caught fire yesterday for the second time in a week, no one was surprised. Everyone in New York knows the world is coming to an end.
A sense of impending doom has seeped into the souls of New Yorkers over the past month as the city has suffered the most relentlessly torrid summer in its history.
US back to dust bowl
The rising risk of superfloods
If the Warragamba Dam failed, the floodwaters of the Nepean River would destroy 20,000 houses that lie immediately beneath the dam . . .
Rising oceans will force islanders to flee
As many as 300,000 people living on South Pacific and Indian Ocean islands may be forced to abandon their homes and seek refuge in countries such as Australia because of rising sea levels . . .
Boffins baffled as ocean warms up
Something is pumping huge amounts of heat into the Indian Ocean.
Scientists are baffled by the warm-up which is bringing southern Western Australia its wettest winter for years.

The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) has just passed me a note saying that he was in Boston in August when Harvard University was closed down for the first time in 352 years because of heat and pollution. These are some of the things that are happening. The same signs can be seen globally. Floods affected 5.2 million people in a year in the 1960s and 15.4 million people were affected in 1984. This year's count is still on. These are some of the things that are happening to our weather.

Are they pointers to the greenhouse effect? I do not know. I am no scientist. I have no idea. But I do know that we are not spending enough money on research into this effect. The Government, the people, are not putting in enough money to find out what will happen in the future. Some of the little things which could happen are very important. For example, global warming could wipe out wildlife. I can hear everyone cry, `How could this happen?' At the moment small pockets of areas are set aside for endangered animals. If the climate changes in those areas and the types of plants that grow in them cannot grow there any more, those animals would have to shift out of that particular park. However, the face of Australia has shifted and changed. We do not have corridors for those animals to move, say, further north. There are houses, farms and roads, so those animals are locked into small areas. We could lose many, many species just because of the greenhouse effect. These simple little effects have not been looked at. What would happen if the sea rose a metre or so? How would it affect all our seashore? We do not know.

One of the things we do know is that we are putting a lot of carbon and various gases into the air. It is not only the chemical companies and the petrol companies that are doing it; it is all of us. We use up air. We create carbon dioxide when we use our cars. The average car puts four times its own weight in carbon dioxide into the atmosphere every year. A car that weighs a ton puts four tons of gases into the air. I do not know how much gas weighs in terms of volume. It is not very much, so four tons is a lot of gas. There is probably a ton of gas in this whole chamber. I do not know how much it would weigh. Perhaps the Minister could give me a more accurate idea. But it is not very much. Our cars, us, we are all contributing. We are all doing our bit to actually create the greenhouse effect. The amount of carbon dioxide released globally from coal, oil and gas burning is more than 200 billion tons annually. That is a huge amount of gas that is going into the atmosphere. What are we doing about it? We are just letting it happen.

A table that was produced in 1980 gives approximate carbon emissions per person. In the United States the average emission of carbon per person per year is 5.7 tons. In the Union of Soviet Socialist Republic, it is 3.4 tons; in Germany, 3.3 tons; in the United Kingdom, 2.9 tons; in Australia, about 2.7 tons. As to the developing countries, in Bolivia, it is 0.2 tons; in Venezuela it is 1.5 tons, and so on. These are the types of figures that are starting to come out and people are starting to look at them. We must reduce the amount of gases going into the atmosphere, and not just by 10 per cent or 15 per cent. Dr Pearman, who is a Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation scientist, said that a 20 per cent reduction would not solve the problem, nor would a 50 per cent reduction. He went on to say:
In the longer term, emissions must be cut by 75 to 80 per cent of their present levels merely to stabilise carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere.

Australia is the world's largest exporter of coal, so I can assure honourable members that we are doing our bit to help pollute the world. The science writer for the Age newspaper, Graeme O'Neill, summed it up very well when he said:

We are locked into a runaway experiment in remodelling our planet's climate, set in motion by our industrious grandfathers and given powerful impetus by the energy-hungry generations of the present century. Our grandchildren will live with its consequences.

How can we, as individuals, do our little bit? Individuals can do a great deal. First of all, they can write to their local member of parliament and harangue him or her to look at the situation. They can send in petitions. A good one was handed in on 30 August headed `Kids against CFC'. It says:
We, the children and Friends of St Francis Xavier school, Montmorency-would like all production and use of CFC to cease in Australia. Help us protect the Ozone layer.

Those are the simple things that can be done and everyone can do them. We can change our lifestyle, use less energy, drive our cars less, use smaller engined motor cars, stop using CFCs and plant more trees, which is most important. The levy which I propose in this motion means that we would all be taxed, even if only a couple of dollars once a year. If 15 million people in Australia were taxed $2 each just for research into looking after our future, it would create a fund of about $30m. That would enable everyone to help solve this problem.

There are many things I would like to say but, finally, it is important that we get our researchers to estimate the regional climatic changes in Australia. I wonder whether the scientific scrooges who control the money for research will heed a warning given by Sir Macfarlane Burnet, who said:
We must plan for five years ahead and 20 years and 100 years.

But because there are no votes in these projects 20 years into the future, let alone 100 years, I doubt whether we will see any money. All Australians must make certain that money for research is obtained and that it goes to all areas to find out exactly what is going on so that we and our children can live in a safe and pleasant place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dubois Mr S.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and am pleased to support it in the House today. There has been much publicity recently about the greenhouse effect, but like all disasters, accidents and bad luck we think that it will affect others and not ourselves. We all live on this fragile planet so we will all be affected. It is a problem that can be traced to the developed nations and, as usual, it will be the people of the developing nations who will be its first victims.

SPEECH.PARA: The greenhouse effect is a widely accepted theory that the earth's temperature will continue to rise and thus raise the sea level and produce other climatic changes. It is an effect of the increase in carbon dioxide, chlorofluorocarbons, commonly known as CFCs, and other trace gases in the atmosphere which form a blanket, or greenhouse, around the earth. This allows the sun's rays to penetrate but does not allow its heat to escape as easily. The result is global warming and, if the present trend continues, even with an increase of only a few degrees before next century this earth will face very serious problems.

The earth's average temperature has rarely varied by more than one or two degrees over the past 10,000 years. If we-that is, the entire earth's population-take no action we can expect an increase in global mean temperatures of between 1.5 and 4.5 degrees Celsius. A global heating of even 2.5 degrees Celsius would thus exceed any climatic changes that have occurred in the historical past, bearing in mind that the earth's average temperature during the most recent ice age was only about 5 degrees colder than it is now. This temperature rise is not expected to be sufficient to melt the ice cover of the Antarctic and the Arctic regions. However, the thermal expansion of the oceans would produce an estimated rise in sea levels between 200 millimetres and 1,400 millimetres, that is, between about eight inches and four feet eight inches. This would cause major problems for the third of the world's population which lives within 60 kilometres of a coastline. A great number of people may have to leave low-lying areas. Large areas of Bangladesh may disappear. The Maldives and Kirabati may become submerged.

The developed nations are the culprits when it comes to the causes of this phenomenon. Human activity such as the burning of fossil fuels, coal, oil and gases which result in the discharge of waste carbon dioxide is a major contributing factor to this problem. Other trace gases which produce this greenhouse effect are methane, nitrous oxide, CFCs, and ozone which are a natural constituent of the atmosphere. Because these trace gases are present in the atmosphere in only small amounts they will not produce as large a global warming effect as carbon dioxide. The reason we should all be concerned is that, 40 or 50 years hence, the combined effect of those other trace gases is likely to equal that of carbon dioxide alone, thus doubling the warming effect which will be caused by carbon dioxide. These higher temperatures will increase in the tropics but sub-tropical regions might become drier. Increased evaporation rates would lead to drier soils and the implications for Australia are devastating. The Kakadu National Park could well become a swamp and the drier parts of Australia could become a desert.

One thing is certain: we need to carry out more scientific research into its effects. I was pleased to hear the Chairman of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, Mr Neville Wran, state that the CSIRO would not cut back its research in this field. We must research Southern Hemisphere changes that would affect Australia. We also need a greater commitment from the private sector to play its part in research and developing coping strategies. Action to reduce emissions from these gases has barely begun. Australia has signed the Montreal protocol. The protocol is a minimum position only and we will go beyond that. I understand that legislation will be introduced to control the ozone depleting substances. Australia has participated in international scientific conferences. We have agreed to pool our research effort with New Zealand. We have organised conferences in Australia to increase public awareness of the greenhouse issue.

I commend the Australian aerosol industry plan to reduce the use of that man-made substance, CFC, at a rate faster than that called for by the Montreal protocol. We must ensure that the production of CFCs is not transferred from developed countries like Australia to developing countries in the Third World. We must remember that this is a global problem and that there would be no benefit if the emission of CFCs was just transferred from one corner of the globe to another. We must reduce its production and ban its export if we want to reduce overall consumption and, thus, emission. There is little prospect of reducing methane release which is closely linked with agriculture, animal husbandry and mining. We can however take steps to reduce the level of carbon dioxide emissions. We need to develop energy policies that emphasise conservation and the use of fuels with the least greenhouse effect. Natural gas is better than coal; solar and wind energy are better again. Perhaps electricity produced by nuclear power plants is preferable to fossil fuel burning plants.

We certainly must make a firm commitment to study these serious environmental threats posed by the greenhouse effect. All Australians should be aware of the effects on each and every one of us. I mentioned earlier the climatic changes. There is also the likelihood of an increase in skin cancer resulting from the increased level of rays coming through the depleted ozone layer. In a country with an already very high incidence of skin cancer this presents a very serious challenge indeed. Perhaps we should start glamourising covered bodies instead of exposed ones. But research costs money and a greater commitment in our existence must be made not only from governments but also from the non-government sector. An obvious source of additional funds is to levy the pollution, the polluters and the pollutants-the abuser pays principle. The Government can set standards and legislate but that must have the support of the community. It is only with the support of that community that these measures can succeed. We must all understand the alternative. Make no mistake, this is one of the most serious challenges we face. We can meet it. We have to change.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been made patently obvious by the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) and the honourable member for St George (Mr Dubois), but it needs to be repeated, that today we are discussing what has become known as the greenhouse effect. I thank the honourable member for Dunkley for bringing this matter to the attention of the Parliament again. It is a very important topic and even a critical environmental policy challenge that we all need to look at very carefully. The honourable member for St George has mentioned things that I will be mentioning, as has the honourable member for Dunkley, and I am sure that the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) and the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher) also will be mentioning similar matters in the discussion this morning.

SPEECH.PARA: `The greenhouse effect' is the name given to scientific scenarios which have been developed on the basis of certain environmental and climatic trends which have been emerging since the early 1980s, and I think there were some suspicions of them even before then. It is a shorthand way of describing the warming of the earth's atmosphere as a result of the steady increase in the level of carbon dioxide from the burning of fossil fuels and other gases such as methane, nitrous oxide and chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs). To put it simply, these gases are trapping more and more heat from the sun within the earth's atmosphere. They are acting as a sort of insulation and, very simply, that is the reason why we have this great concern about the warming of the surface of the earth, even by just a few degrees as I will mention in a moment.

Early studies by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO)-which is very much to the fore in this matter, as far as we in Australia are concerned anyway-of the possible impact on Australia of these trends by the year 2030 have suggested, and I will briefly go through these: a temperature rise of up to three degrees; a 50 per cent increase in rainfall in summer and a 20 per cent decrease in winter; large regional changes in soil moisture and water supplies and, therefore, agricultural capacity; tropical cyclones occurring further south and more frequently; a rising sea level; a receding snowline; and extremes of flood and drought.

I want to offer seven basic premises which I believe should guide parliamentary and community discussions on the greenhouse effect. Firstly, we are dealing at the moment with early research and hypotheses and fairly primitive models. Not all scientists support the theory that we now call `the greenhouse effect'. I refer honourable members, for example, to the position and arguments of Dr Edward Bryant from the Wollongong University Geography Department. Nevertheless, while not conclusive, the greenhouse effect hypothesis is consistent with the evidence available and appears to reflect the majority view among scientists with expertise in this area. The prudent course of action, naturally, then is for the community, government and the international community to assume that the model or hypothesis is accurate and to take appropriate political and economic action.

Secondly, there will be both regional winners and losers as weather patterns, and rainfall in particular, shift. Just as some areas of agricultural production will suffer, other areas will gain from new rainfall and temperature levels. Recently, the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory painted a very vivid picture of how the Territory could benefit from the forecast changes.

Thirdly, the environmental problems which confront us in this greenhouse effect are part of a complex, interdependent environmental challenge facing this country and the whole international community. The gases, including chlorofluorocarbons or CFCs-better known for their role in that other potentially disastrous problem, ozone depletion-also contribute to the greenhouse effect, and so does the problem of deforestation and the loss of rainforests in particular. Of course, the degradation of grasslands that is occurring to some extent in this country and certainly in other parts of the world is also contributing to this problem. People do not realise that grass probably plays a more significant part in the conversion of carbon dioxide to oxygen than do the forests of the world. So, a realistic response to the greenhouse effect will involve a wholistic approach to environmental policy and societal readjustment.

Fourthly, this environmental problem does not involve polluting companies creating problems for non-polluting citizens. It is not a matter of just regulating and sanctioning companies. We are all polluting culprits when it comes to the greenhouse effect. For example, whenever we use our cars rather than take public transport, or whenever we turn on lights or electrical appliances and leave them on unnecessarily we boost the level of fossil fuel pollution. All these things might sound minor on their own but, collectively, they contribute significantly to this problem. The problem is one of the standard of living in industrially developed nations. The key to political action, therefore, is to make all citizens realise their personal responsibility in the task of tackling environmental degradation. Here I make the point to my honourable colleagues that, unless individual citizens are caught up in the endeavour to change lifestyle and energy consumption, the problem will end up being dealt with by a reliance on non-fossil fuels, such as nuclear fuel, with all the environmental problems that that will pose.
