Fifthly, policy steps should be taken to tackle major producers of pollutants or problem gases such as CFCs. The response should not be taxes but requirements for companies to use the most efficient and clean technology available. Sixthly, such solutions will not be cheap and, realistically, the cost will have to be borne by all of us. If the public sector electricity producers have to use more expensive but cleaner equipment, taxes or charges will go up. If the private sector has to do the same, the costs will be passed on. That is as it should be, because one of the ways to bring the message home to the average appliance user or energy consumer is to make the price or charge reflect the real cost-the production costs, safeguard costs and the clean-up costs-of their lifestyles.

Seventhly, the fundamental challenge we face is not environmental but political and educational. In the long term we will have to deal with new geopolitical realities, whether they be the decline of once productive regions, the need for population and infrastructure shifts, for example, from coast to centre, or the need to resettle whole Pacific island populations. I mention at this point the very real possibility that the populations of, for example, Kiribati, Tuvalu and the Maldives could find themselves facing sinking islands. Australia, as a Pacific neighbour, would then face an obligation to deal with a unique refugee problem. There would be political and educational problems, too, because the real task for us is to get the message through about what the challenge is and about the significant economic and lifestyle changes required corporately and individually.

On the basis of those seven points, I support the motion. As the motion states, first we must recognise the problem and, secondly, we must urgently fund and maintain research into the greenhouse effect. I note here that the Government's cuts to CSIRO funding are totally counterproductive in this respect. Environmental and atmospheric research and staffing have been seriously affected by cuts to funding this year and in previous years. So, I support the call of the motion for more research support and I note that, in effect, it is an indirect criticism of the Government's shortsightedness in this area of environmental preventative action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I congratulate the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) for his thoughtful summary of the problems of the greenhouse effect. One of his points was that there needed to be a greater emphasis on education both at the community level and at the political level. How true! Not many people are in the chamber today to hear a debate about the fundamental, the most important environmental problem of our world; not just of Australia, not just of Canberra, but of our world. I compliment the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), who is at the table-I know he must be frustrated that he cannot participate in the debate about science this morning-for he is one who at least recognises the difficulties that we face with this problem. Education of political people on both sides of the chamber is very much lacking. The honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) needs to be commended for having brought this motion to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: Much information is available on the greenhouse effect. It has been discussed on television programs and in the media. People now have a reasonable understanding of the extent of the problem. The difficulty for us in this chamber is in deciding what we, as the legislature, the people who are elected by the people of Australia to deal with problems, are going to do about it. These are the types of issues facing legislatures around the world. It is particularly vexing to note, as one of my colleagues mentioned, the result when a senior Minister in this Government went to Cabinet to ask for funds to do greater research into the greenhouse effect. What was the result? I have the newspaper cutting here, the headline of which reads `Greenhouse, research cash bid fails'. One million dollars was all that Senator Richardson asked for to try to coordinate our response to greenhouse research. The answer from Cabinet was no. If this community needs a demonstration of the lack of care and lack of vision about where we are going with this problem-and with many problems in the science area-that answer is indicative. It is a disgrace. I hope that very soon we will see it remedied. There is a growing wealth of opinion that clearly indicates that unless we start doing something about it we will be the losers.

The bible on greenhouse and its associated problems and effects has been prepared by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO), the very body that has been attacked with funding cuts. It is an excellent book edited by Graham Pearman of the Division of Atmospherics in Melbourne which is headed by Dr Tucker. I know that those who have looked at this book-and I can see the Minister nodding his head-will know that it is a masterpiece. It has absolutely everything in it that people need to know about the greenhouse effect. If those listening to this debate take the opportunity to look at this book I am sure they will find it well worth while in trying to understand the policy dilemmas that we Australian legislators face in trying to determine in which direction we should go. Dr Pittock of the CSIRO stated recently:

We're putting into the atmosphere far more than the natural systems which used to cleanse the atmosphere can cope with so that, for example, we're putting in roughly twice as much carbon dioxide as the oceans can remove every year.
This must stop or the effect on our lifestyle and our future may well be catastrophic. The clock has struck, the warning has been delivered, and what are we going to do about it?

In November last year I visited an interesting place in Australia, which I know the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business has visited, called Cape Grim in Tasmania's far north-west. At Cape Grim we have the foremost baseline air pollution monitoring station in the world. Because of the air that is flowing across the Indian Ocean and the readings taken from that station we have a fair indication of what chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs), the freons 11 and 12, are doing to the atmosphere. It is interesting to look at those readings. The carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere rose from 330 parts per million in 1976 to 347 parts per million in 1987 compared with pre-industrial levels estimated at 280 parts per million. The station predicts that by the year 2020 the concentration will be 400 parts per million.

That indicates that there is a rapid increase in the level of carbon dioxide. We also know that the chlorofluorocarbons-the man made gases discovered by General-Motors in 1928 and which we now know deplete ozone and contribute to the greenhouse gases effect-are helping to deplete the ozone layer. There has been a build-up of those chemicals from 250 parts per million in 1978 to 425 parts per million in 1987, and it is growing. Those figures are very worrying. The trend is there. The results have been indicated by several of my colleagues.

For Australia there will be a rise in the snowline. What happens to the ski tube to Mount Kosciusko? By the year 2020 will it be a train ride to nowhere? What about rainfall levels? They will be varied right around the nation. What about the rise in sea levels? It was indicated by the honourable member for Dunkley, I think, that the rise in sea levels would affect many of the Pacific islands. Has anyone given a thought to Brisbane Airport? Brisbane Airport in the year 2020, that $700m monolith, may well be knee deep in water. Has anyone given any thought to that? How many members of this House saw the article in the property pages of the Australian about the insurance industry's concern about the new building at Circular Quay in Sydney? The builders did not take into account the effects of rising sea levels in the year 2020 or before. Is it able to be insured? I ask honourable members to go to the book as it will tell them some of the problems we face.

What are we doing in this Parliament? This is the first debate we have had of any substance about the ozone depletion and the greenhouse effect. This Government has turned its back on providing a minimal amount of funding to coordinate it. It has turned its back on the CSIRO. It has turned its back on the Atmospherics Division of the CSIRO in such a way that major and important work is not being carried out; work that needs to be carried out to indicate where we will go in the future and what policy responses may be available to us. It is quite clear that there is major concern about this problem.

As I mentioned earlier, other legislatures are trying to cope with it. In the United States, Senator Wirth, a Democrat from Colorado who is on the Energy and Natural Resources Committee, introduced into the United States Congress a Bill to limit the emissions of carbon dioxide, which is the main cause of the greenhouse effect, by 20 per cent by the year 2000. That is one response. There has been a response proposed in this motion that I think is worthy of investigation, although at the end of the day I wonder whether that is the best way to go. Who will pay the levy? The producers, the manufacturers, the users? What about the importers? How do we apportion the levy? Why should Tasmania, which relies largely on hydroelectricity and which has banned some CFCs, pay as much as Victoria, the brown coal capital of Australia. Interestingly, the Tasmanian Parliament has taken an innovative step-the first in the world-and introduced a Bill called the Chlorofluorocarbon and other Ozone Depleting Substances Control Bill 1988 to limit the amount of CFCs going into the atmosphere. One might criticise it, but at the end of the day we have to recognise that at least one legislature has seen the wisdom in pursuing legislative responses to these problems. That is what we have to do. When is the Montreal Convention coming to this Parliament? It has been signed by the American Congress. It is supposed to come here to be ratified.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not ratified by the Parliament.
—I understand that there is supposed to be legislation attached to it.
—We have signed it.
—We have signed it but we have not ratified it here by way of a unanimous motion, as has the United States Congress. Why cannot we do that?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Barry Jones

TALK.START.PARA: —Because our treaties-- Mr SMITH-The Minister can explain, but it has not come here. There has been no legislation such as the Tasmanian legislation. It is about time that the Government took a far more positive step. It was only in March this year that we received more research that indicated that the ozone depletion in the northern hemisphere is taking place as it has done over Antarctica.

INTERJECT.PARA: There are alternatives to the use of chlorofluorocarbons and those honourable members in the chamber will see this gadget I have here. It works. It is not to kill the moths; it is air freshener. It is an Australian Life product called Mistlon and it is powered by a pump and not by hydrocarbons. That is the type of dispenser that we need to find in our supermarkets. The use of hydrocarbons as propellants in dispensers do not have to be relied on. The producer of this one apparently ran into some difficulty. This was sent to us by a community minded citizen called John Payne in Victoria for which we thank him. It highlights the problems we are facing. These are the alternatives we need to be pursuing. It is one of the policy options that we as a legislature can try to put into place by introducing legislation to bring about less use of and less reliance on hydrocarbons, CFCs, to provide the propellants for dispensers.

In conclusion, I reiterate the importance of dealing with these issues in this chamber. Unless we do soon, we Australians will be left behind and the rest of the world will be in front. We will end up contributing mightily towards the depletion of ozone and the enhancement of greenhouse gases. All the options that are available to us-cleaner energy sources, such as nuclear-need to be considered seriously now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Saunderson Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion. I congratulate the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) on bringing this matter before the House. It is probably of second-most importance in terms of world concern, the first being pollution caused by the nuclear industry. In trying to tackle the problems of pollution and the greenhouse effect, we must not tolerate the simplistic argument that we should increase the nuclear industry as a solution.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, some Opposition speakers failed to address the second half of the motion. It is one thing to be critical of the amount of funds the Government puts into research, but the heart of the second part of the motion is that we should be looking at ways of making the polluters pay for the research that is required and the solutions that are necessary to overcome the impact they have had on the ozone layer and the greenhouse effect in general.

I have recently returned from a parliamentary delegation to the European parliamentary institutions. One of the things that stuck in my mind was the tremendous pollution problem that exists in Europe and the lack of action by different parliamentary groups to overcome it. I was most disappointed to find out, for instance, that the European commissioners have recently bowed to pressure from industry to the extent that they have not implemented the Montreal protocol in relation to chlorofluorocarbons-although they have an extended program to reduce CFCs-simply because European industry has argued that it could not meet the time frame.

When one goes to Europe one sees the enormous problems caused by car pollution. In Italy, for instance, motor vehicles with an engine capacity of 50cc or less are not registered. There is a proliferation of cars that have no emission controls and run on leaded petrol, a problem which the Italian Government, and other governments in Europe which have the same problem, have yet to tackle properly. The reason that the Italian Government does not require these vehicles to be registered and has not required the fitting of pollution controls is that it is worried that this local industry will go out of business. That is a very short-sighted policy.

Tremendous damage is being done by pollution to the marvellous historic buildings of Europe. Acid rain is depleting the Black Forest. Venice, which is famous for its canals, faces the enormous problem of rising seawater. The Italian Government is failing to tackle it. However, it is trying to solve the problem of pollution of historic sites.

We visited the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation establishment in Brussels and were informed that its research department has been carrying out extensive work on developing films which can cover glass-to protect, for instance, stained glass windows. Yet it is not doing any research into overcoming the causes of the problem. Rather, it is saying, `We can live with the pollution if we can cover the buildings and prevent them from being damaged'. The effort being made in Europe is being misdirected.

Because industry in Europe is a major polluter, it is depleting the ozone layer. We are the ones who are suffering to the greatest extent from the initial depletion of the ozone layer. We are suffering at first hand what the Europeans have yet to suffer themselves. We are more conscious of the problems because a hole is appearing in the ozone layer here. We are aware of the resultant health problems such as rising rates of skin cancer. In Europe the population and, in particular, the politicians have failed to recognise the seriousness of the problem. They are still allowing industry to create enormous pollution without properly tackling it.

The motion should be applauded. We should be looking at ways of making those companies manufacturing the atmospheric pollutants pay for the research and the necessary solutions. It is one thing to argue that governments should be putting money into research. I think we should, and we are doing so. It is another thing to say that industry can be reckless about what it is doing, that it can continue to pollute the atmosphere, and not have to bear any responsibility for the solutions; that the taxpayers and others have to bear the responsibility for curing the problems that are caused by industry.

There are alternatives to the use of gases such as CFCs, but the industry has been slow in coming to the fore. It has been mainly people outside the industry who have recommended alternatives. Industries think it is easy to keep using pollutants. They believe that they should still be able to profit from the marketing of those gases and not have to bear any of the cost of overcoming the problems.

As I said, I thoroughly support the motion. I hope that the Government will take the initiative and impose levies on companies that continue to use pollutants, knowing that they are pollutants, and use that revenue for the purposes of research to help us overcome the problems that are being caused by the greenhouse effect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) for bringing this important motion before the House. Human activity over the last century or more has brought about massive changes on a global scale. Natural systems, including the atmosphere, land and sea, and even life on earth, are clearly being changed. For some 100 years we have known that carbon dioxide and other gases in the atmosphere can cause a global warming. This greenhouse effect has become a matter for discussion and growing concern during the last two decades. Important questions include whether the predicted effects are occurring and, if so, whether they can be controlled or reversed.

SPEECH.PARA: As the effects on earth are potentially dramatic, research must be undertaken immediately to determine the extent and ramifications of any changes. We understand that some of the changes may result in massive rises in sea-levels, changes in the distribution and the intensity of storms, changes in rainfall patterns and growth rates and changes in the distribution of plants. Any understanding of the possible effects and problems will require considerable primary research into the earth's climate. We need a database and accurate models to be developed so that the magnitude of the changes we are observing can be determined.

We have to understand the vast differences between climates and the weather. There are many causes of climatic change other than the impact of the human on the environment. There is considerable evidence that solar output varies in a number of cyclical ways. Changes in the earth's orbit around the sun are able to affect the climate over time periods of 1,000 years or more. These effects, whilst generally local, may have up to a 10 per cent variation. Volcanic eruptions inject considerable amounts of aerosols such as dust and sulphur compounds into the atmosphere, which can affect global climate.

The composition of the atmosphere itself has a considerable effect on climate, and many gases are active and absorb and irradiate both short and long wave lengths. The most important gases we are discussing are ozone, carbon dioxide, nitrous oxide, methane and chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs), as well as water. Some are mainly internal to the natural system, as is water, while others, for example, CFCs, are man-made in origin and strictly external. The majority are naturally produced but have had their relative levels altered by man's activities-particularly ozone, carbon dioxide, nitrous oxide and methane. The changes produced by man are the ones causing this Parliament concern and resulting in the warming that is taking place.

The greenhouse effect, therefore, is a predicted global warming expected to result from an increase in the concentration of carbon dioxide and other gases in the atmosphere. This increased level of certain gases in the atmosphere allows sunlight to the earth's surface, but reduces the amount of radiation that escapes into space. The greenhouse effect becomes more serious with the dramatic increase in the use of fossil fuels as a source of heat and energy, and particularly this century, this is what has been happening. The level of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere has been increasing at a reasonably steady rate since reliable records began.

There is a wide range of chemicals with a number of important and widespread application for human activity such as propellants in aerosols, mentioned by the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), refrigerants, foam blowing agents and solvents. They are most dangerous due to their effect on the stratospheric ozone, but they also have a role as a greenhouse gas. CFCs, in particular, are extremely long-lived-up to 110 years-and therefore their build-up is a long term cause of concern. I have already referred to methane, which is a naturally occurring gas. Nitrous oxide is produced in considerable quantities by industrial processes. The two main sources of nitrous oxide are microbial breakdown of agricultural fertilisers and combustion processes. This gas is less well understood in the context of the greenhouse effect than other gases, but nitrous oxide clearly has the potential to be an important contributor to the problem.

What does all this mean and what effect would a greenhouse gas-induced temperature rise have on Australia, particularly on agricultural industries? The changes would vary very much between regions. Some areas may be advantaged. Generally, however, it is believed that agricultural regions would be more disadvantaged. Implications for rainfall in south-eastern Australia are not clear, but we could expect an increase in rainfall especially during the summer months. It is expected that the maximum level of daily rainfall would probably increase. This would increase the intensity and frequency of flooding and have important ramifications for the design of dams and flood drainage systems.

A particular problem could be that dams designed to cope with 100-year floods under previous climatic regions would no longer be safe at that level. Rainfall in south-western Australia would probably decrease, causing further increased problems with drought. We could expect an increase in tropical cyclone frequency and intensity. We could expect that higher temperatures would raise the equilibrium snowline by about 100 metres per degree. The predicted temperature rise would initially reduce the snow season in Australia and a relatively small rise could eliminate it completely. Any rise in sea levels would be a serious problem for Australia as so many Australians live in coastal regions. A rise could have a disproportionate effect on our nation.

There could well be a number of effects on the biosphere. Those likely include increased growth of various plant species, but not necessarily crop species or the edible portion of plants. Due to increased efficiency of water use by plants in a high carbon dioxide environment, some would probably extend their range into more arid areas, as shown by the pinus radiata display in the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) exhibition in Parliament House today.

If restrictions on the production of greenhouse gases are put in place, there will be a significant constraint on Australia's coal and chemical industries. As a change to nuclear power would be one of the ways to reduce the emission of carbon dioxide, the increased demand for uranium may well be to Australia's benefit. There are a number of other effects, including changes to the water table, possible increases in salinity and so forth. The result of the greenhouse effect on plants is difficult to predict. Problems arise because there are many factors involved and it is difficult to estimate the relative importance of each.
In conclusion, the Chairman of the CSIRO, Mr Neville Wran, said in a recent address to the Australian Conservation Foundation:

It could well be that if we go on burning fossil fuels in the absence of practical alternatives, the world will be forced to rely on nuclear energy . . . Many authorities have even been saying that 50 years out, we will be praying for nuclear energy.

Of course, Mr Wran did not say in his address to the Foundation that the massive cutback in funds for the CSIRO and for general research and development programs throughout Australia is a tragedy for which this Government should be condemned, and such condemnation should be part of this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the few seconds available to me I would like to congratulate the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) on bringing forth this motion. It is an extremely important question that needs the fullest debate not only throughout Australia but also in the international forum. It is a problem of global and international dimensions caused by many factors that have been outlined in the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The two points to the motion should have the full agreement of the House. There is a need to continue the research because many aspects of this problem are not understood and if companies using the chemicals in question do not play their part in further discovery, they will have to pay because governments alone cannot be forced to put funds towards seeking solutions to this very important problem. We have to understand that temperature changes and changes in climate have occurred naturally and we are getting to know more about those natural occurrences.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House acknowledges the debt of the Australian community to veterans and the need to compensate them for their sacrifices, and notes the achievements of the Government in providing for the welfare of veterans in times of restraint in public expenditure.

The best way I can illustrate the current practice and policy of the Government with respect to veterans is by pointing out that the Government has made a response to a report of what is called the Veterans' Entitlements Act Monitoring Committee. In the last couple of years the new Act, the Veterans' Entitlements Act, has been established and the Government agreed to have that Act and its implementation monitored by the veteran community. That Monitoring Committee has now brought down its report and the Government has responded-and responded extremely generously.

I would like to detail five areas in which there has been a recommendation from the Committee and the Government has responded positively. The first matter from the Committee concerned intermediate and special rate pensions. It was felt by the Committee that it was too much to ask that a pensioner should first have a 100 per cent general rate pension before he could become eligible for a special rate pension. The Government was not able to agree entirely with this recommendation by the Committee because it has been held since 1920 that a special rate pension should be granted because a veteran could not work. In other words, it was a workers compensation-type award, and frequently we are now finding that veterans have an entire working life, retire, and, despite their disablement, are not eligible for a special rate pension because they have completed a lifetime of work. Nevertheless we agree with the Committee that it may have been a little too harsh to expect a pensioner who was near retirement to be on a 100 per cent general rate of pension. It was agreed, and I think most generously, by the Government that we would lower the requirement for the general rate of pension to 70 per cent. That is, if a veteran received 70 per cent of the general rate of pension he would be eligible to be considered for the totally and permanently incapacitated (TPI) pension or special rate pension. I think that is a most generous response by the Government to the report.

Secondly, it has been a concern of the Committee that when a veteran is applying for a special rate pension or an intermediate rate pension often the board, whether it is the Veterans' Review Board (VRB) or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, makes an assessment only on the day on which the veteran makes his application. An application may have been made two years prior to a board considering the matter and that two-year period has not been able to be considered, at least in the minds of some of the decision makers. I must admit that when I was on the board it was always my view that we could assess up to date. Nevertheless, the Government has recognised the possible problem here and has agreed with the Committee that, where a veteran makes application for a special rate of pension, where that rate is to be assessed the Board can consider the matter right up to the day of consideration. For instance, if a pensioner is nearing early retirement due to ill health he can place his application for TPI pension. If it is knocked back by the Repatriation Commission and the Veterans' Review Board seeks to review it some years later, the Board can assess all matters right up to date. Of course, if the TPI pension is granted then the grant will be made way back to the original date of application. Again, I think it is an excellent response by the Government to a real concern of the Committee.

The third area of concern by the Committee is that there are pensioners who after retirement are not only 100 per cent disabled, according to the general rate of pension, but extremely disabled. They may be, in a sense, 150 per cent or 200 per cent disabled but are unable to receive a TPI pension because they are past retirement age. I reiterate for the veteran community that the TPI pension has always been acknowledged as recompense for a person being unable to work. Nevertheless, the Government realises that there are people beyond retirement age who are severely disabled. The Committee recommended that there should be introduced a halfway house-that is, a rate of pension beyond the general rate but not the TPI. It also recommended that there should be an extreme disablement adjustment rate which should be set at 150 per cent of the general rate. Again, the Government has accepted that recommendation and I believe it is a very generous decision.

The fourth area of concern is the new guide to assessment of the rate of veterans' pensions. This guide was introduced some two years ago, from memory. There was some concern, mainly that the guide had been used to lower the assessment of veterans' incapacity. I reject that. Again, having worked on the Veterans' Review Board I can tell honourable members that under the old system where there was no guide, frequently the three members of the Board would get into a bidding situation. It was not unusual-and it was not with malintent-for the veterans' representative on the Board to suggest a fairly high rate of pension but for other members on the Board to recommend a lesser rate of pension. Inevitably there was a compromise. In other words, a bidding process went on. With the introduction of what we know as the guide to assessment of rates of veterans' pensions (GARP), there are now clear criteria by which we can make an assessment. So the bidding process is not nearly as important now. We can, with great finality, make a clear decision.

The other important aspect here, of course, is that decisions are comparable across the States. They do not depend on the composition of the Board or on practices of the Board that may have grown up in particular States. GARP has brought to the whole determining process a sense of fairness between the States and between all panels of the Board that sit around Australia. We have gone from a position of a bidding process, which was no way to conduct a review of the merits of a veteran's incapacity, to one where we have a guide that is acceptable to all. There were several criticisms of the way the guide assessed incapacity and the Government has responded by rewriting the guide. There now is what we call GARP 2, the new guide which has just been released.

I must say that I read a column by Ian Gollings, the Secretary of the Returned Services League, slating the Government for being a little tardy in not recognising the urgency of various matters in the veterans area and I found it somewhat negative and frankly uninspiring. The fact is that we received the report from the Committee in May and we have acted on the recommendations. Of some 58 recommendations, we have put 28 immediately into practice as of the last Budget, and have been outlining the five most important areas. The response has been swift and generous, and I want the veteran community to understand that. So much for the guide to the assessment of the rates of veterans' pensions.

Lastly, the determining system as it now stands has been in operation for only three years and the most important new element is the Veterans' Review Board. The Committee was concerned that, for instance, at the primary level of determination-the Repatriation Commission-there was a fear that delays in assessments could be further cut back. The Committee acknowledged that there had already been substantial cutbacks in delays. The queue of people waiting to receive their decision has been knocked down enormously in the past few years and the Committee was generous enough to indicate that.

Further, I might say that the Committee also sought at the Veterans' Review Board level the notion of a single member hearing, that is, rather than having three people on a panel, just have one. I must admit that, talking to veterans, they seem to have a fear of single member panels. I remind them that it was the Committee, and there were veterans on that Committee, which recommended single member panels. We found that the VRB has been using single member panels for 18 months or more and that has been a very useful method of cutting back the delays in hearings.

I end my contribution by saying that the veterans' community in Australia deserves this Government's support. We have listened to the Monitoring Committee and we have responded swiftly and generously.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded.
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns) shows that he is not far behind the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) when it comes to unmitigated gall. I concede that his response as a former bureaucrat had certain technical properties and charm. However, in moving this motion he maintained the arrogant tradition of this Government in blowing its own bags, usually because no-one else will. It is one thing to say, as is said in this motion, that the House acknowledges our debt to veterans and the need to compensate them for their sacrifices. That is common ground. It has, of course, bipartisan support. However, it is another matter entirely to marry a widely acknowledged debt of honour to veterans with self-serving claims to achievements by the Government, as the motion does. The sensitivity of the mover of the motion and his Government is to be found in the motion which, after the motherhood opening and self-congratulations, concludes with the following words:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . providing for the welfare of veterans in times of restraint in public expenditure.

There you have it: that is the cop-out. The sensitivity of the Government is encapsulated in the words `in times of restraint in public expenditure'. It has good reason to be sensitive. I can think of no other section of our community that has been more disadvantaged during the term of this Government than retirees and those approaching retirement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Cutbacks after cutbacks.

—Cutbacks upon cutbacks upon cutbacks. Included in that group are veterans. Is the Government serious in crowing about achievement in compensating veterans for our debt of honour to them? What sort of achievement was it to change the onus of proof, making it more difficult for veterans to claim for war-caused disabilities? This Government did that. What sort of achievement was it to make veterans' entitlements subject to an assets test with the deliberate intent of reducing veterans' entitlements? This Government did that. What sort of achievement was it to tighten the criteria affecting entitlement to the totally and permanently incapacitated pension? This Government did that. How can gross interference with war widows' pensions and medical benefits be said to be an achievement?

SPEECH.PARA: What is so great about the debacle surrounding war service home loans? Does the House remember the massive chopping and changing after the 1987 Budget announcement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that the $25,000 maximum war service home loan was to be replaced by a $10,000 grant? That was some achievement, I do not think! A week after that announcement the loan entitlement was reinstated. A few months later, in December 1987, the $10,000 grant was scrapped. The maximum term of the loan was then reduced from 32 to 25 years. Some achievement!

What sort of achievement in providing for the welfare of veterans are the events that I have just mentioned? What about the betrayal of servicemen's and servicewomen's organisations in 1985 when the first major inroads into veterans' and war widows' entitlements were mooted? Surely, it has not been forgotten that the solemn promise of the then Minister for Veterans' Affairs to consult with veterans' representatives was so blatantly broken. The Veterans' Entitlements Bill 1985 began the slide which now sees veterans' and war widows' entitlements greatly reduced and the qualifying criteria more stringent than ever before. To pretend otherwise is to practise blatant deceit.

I ask the House to remember that these events came hard on the heels of one of the Prime Minister's most infamous broken promises. Mr Deputy Speaker, you know the one that I am talking about. Government members must cringe when we recall that statesmanlike pronouncement of the Prime Minister that his Government would not take money out of pensioners' cheques. It has continued to do just that ever since. No amount of smarmy words, such as those used in the motion that is before the House, will cause us to forget the series of betrayals foisted upon the aged and retirees; nor will we be persuaded to overlook the fact that veterans and war widows suffered as much and possibly more than most.

It is a source of some concern that war widows do not even rate a mention in the motion. By that omission the mover of the motion and the Government of which he is a member again illustrate a sensitivity which is not born of achievement, as the motion would have us believe, but of lack of achievement, in providing for the welfare of war widows. War widows have been hit hard by this Government. Take as an example the $60 freeze on the social security component of a war widow's pension entitlement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ask the honourable member for Bass.

—The honourable member for Bass understands that as well. On top of that, there is the further loss of benefits in the form of prescription drugs which were so recently removed from the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits list. These are just some of the matters which make it perfectly clear that what the Government has achieved is a reduction in benefits and entitlements for veterans and war widows.

SPEECH.PARA: I would have thought that the Government would leave the subject well alone. After all, even the present Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) knows enough to keep silent. We never hear a peep from him in this House. The Australian Labor Party (ALP) must be particularly uncomfortable with the words of its Prime Minister, Ben Chifley, who, after the conclusion of World War II, when referring to his Party's then commitment to veterans, said:

The careers of hundreds of thousands of young men have been interrupted and, in some instances, partially ruined. It is perfectly true that experience is gained, but that is not material to an ordinary civil vocation. On this Parliament rests the responsibility of seeing that the right thing shall be done.
That was an entirely appropriate response to the sentiments expressed by the Commander-in-Chief of the Australian Military Forces, Sir Thomas Blamey, who, at the end of hostilities in 1945, said:
We are now to go to our homes having done our part in ensuring freedom for which we have fought for so long and successfully.

How the once compassionately great ALP has slipped! In its treatment of veterans we can find no better evidence of how it has lost its way in government. It is a classic example. Further evidence of its stagnation, mindlessness and craven approach to retaining government was to be found in the 1988 Budget measure to count non-cash investment growth as part of the income test applied in determining pension and related entitlements. We all know that that part of the proposal to count growth over the past three years was scrapped-not for equity reasons or because it would have had a retrospective effect, but for the most blatant political reasons in the run-up to the Victorian State election.

I summarise my reaction to this motion by breaking it up into three parts. The first part calls for the House to acknowledge the debt of the Australian community to veterans. I wholeheartedly do so, although I would want to include reference to our debt to war widows. They also served who endured the pain and uncertainty of not knowing how their loved ones who saw active service were faring. I reject the second part of the motion which calls on the House to note the achievements of this Government in providing for the welfare of veterans. Not one additional benefit has been granted by this Government during its almost six years in government, while countless entitlements have been removed or reduced. That is a mean and negative achievement, not one which confers credit on this Government. In regard to the third part of the motion, which mentions times of restraint in public expenditure, I simply repeat that that is a cop-out. It is rationalisation on the part of the mover and on the part of Government supporters for its failure to achieve improvements in the lot of war veterans and war widows.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have much pleasure in seconding this motion. I will not bother wasting the precious time available to me by rebutting what has been said by the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher). In fact, for a person who supposedly wants to establish and reaffirm the debt that this country owes its veterans, he spent nine minutes on rubbishing the Government and trying to score some cheap political points, and one minute on looking at the motion. I congratulate the mover of the motion, my colleague from Queensland the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns). His motion is an excellent one. The evidence of that is the fact that prior to his election to this House he was a member of the Veterans' Review Board.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia does owe a substantial debt to its veteran community. I refer to the veterans of all wars, including those of the Vietnam war. I will have something to say about that later. The contribution made by veterans and the debt that we owe them should never be forgotten. Veterans should receive the benefits that they so richly deserve. They should receive them by way of compensation, not, as some cynical, arrogant or ignorant people in the community may suggest, by some sort of handout. That is not the case. They are owed compensation and it should always be that way.

This is the first occasion since my election to this House that I have had the opportunity of speaking on matters relating to veterans' affairs. It is an area which I have always held in high regard. In other words. I have held a very high regard for veterans ever since I was old enough to think. Over the past 14 months, this has been strengthened because of the various contacts that I have had with the community, particularly in my own electorate. In my electorate of Bowman, some 7,000 people receive some form of repatriation benefit. As a group, they number about 10 per cent of my total electorate, and they are certainly an important section of my community. They are regarded by me, and, I hope, by other members of the community, as such. Two excellent Returned Services League (RSL) clubs service the electorate of Bowman, one at Cleveland and another at Wynnum. The Wynnum RSL is probably one of the largest in Queensland. RSL clubs generally perform the function of a meeting place for veterans to visit in a social way and mix socially with members of the veteran community. I do not think there is anyone who is not moved every time he visits an RSL club when the ceremony for fallen comrades is performed. I am certainly still so moved and it is a great way of remembering those comrades who have fallen in wars.

I was proud and honoured to be invited to several Anzac Day ceremonies that were conducted this year. Contrary to what my colleagues in the Opposition might expect, I hope to go to many of these ceremonies in future years. I am sure I will be just as proud standing there at dawn ceremonies as I was the last time.

It would be very remiss of me on this first occasion that I have talked on veterans' affairs not to spend a little time in mentioning those people who give endless hours of their own time in assisting other veterans who need help. I refer to people who act as advocates for the RSL, advocates for veterans in the community. I have met a number of these people, as I am sure my colleagues have in other electorates and these people do a magnificent job.

On this occasion I want specifically to mention the following people: Mr Stan MacPherson, Mr Tom Troy, Mr Bob Drevesen, Mr Robert Long and Mr Cec Medcraf. I have had a lot to do with these people over the last 14 months. They do everything they possibly can to help in preparing cases before veterans review boards and that sort of thing. Their dedication to the task not only of assisting other veterans who need some help in one way or another, but also in trying to maintain and improve the lot of veterans, is an inspiration, certainly to me, and, I am sure, to all of us. I say thank you from the bottom of my heart on behalf of those veterans who live in my electorate and I say thank you to all those people throughout the whole of Australia who carry out a similar job.
In the last four or five minutes at my disposal I want to talk about the Vietnam veterans.

TALK.START.PARA: —One.

—No, I have longer than that. During the last 14 months I have been very fortunate in being a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs, which, in effect, has looked at the benefits of the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service. I am not going to pre-empt what that report will say; it will come out very shortly. Australia owes a substantial debt to those people who served in the Vietnam war. I was very fortunate-or unfortunate, whatever one likes to call it-not to have my number pulled out. I was born on 13 June and those born on 12 June went.

SPEECH.PARA: I was at that time, as I have always been, against the Vietnam war. I marched in demonstrations. But I would have gone. Because I was against the Vietnam war, I can only say this: those boys went for their country; they did what they were told to do-the way I would have done if I had to. In many ways, Australian society should be frankly ashamed of the way it treated its veterans, because, although they may not have won what has been described as a dirty, unwinnable war, nevertheless they were just as much heroes as those who returned from the wars that were won.

I am extremely pleased to say that the welcome back march of a year ago was the turning point. We as a government have looked at that and we have generally tried to improve the benefits of Vietnam veterans. I hope that the report of the Committee will be acted upon by the Government and that some of the reforms which I am sure will be accepted by the majority of the Committee, will, in fact, be accepted.

Angus House in Brisbane, for instance, was a pilot program of a half-way house for Vietnam veterans. It has worked extremely well. It has been magnificent in what it has been able to achieve. One of the best ways of assessing the house's worth is to look at the human side of it. Some people have commented as follows: `It saved my marriage'; `I did not realise anyone could be so helpful and friendly'. Most importantly, some people have said, `I have managed to stay out of hospital because of Angus House'. The Government has made available about $400,000 to try to do something about increasing this type of accommodation. It is a nonsense to say, as has been said in this House, that the Government has no thought or caring consideration for the veteran community. Quite the opposite! If I had time, I would talk about the fact that allocations to the Veterans' Affairs portfolio since 1983 have increased from $2.5 billion to $4.5 billion. I would say that a major program of public works totalling $109m over the past five years has continued the expansion, modernisation and improvement of the repatriation hospital system. I could go on.

Sure, more could be done for the veterans. More could be done for everybody. But the fact is, we have been under tight economic restraints. I, for one, recognise the need to look after the veterans of our community and we will be vigilant to ensure that wherever possible these benefits are in no way eroded. I give the veterans my complete support. Australia as a nation owes them at least that. They have done their bit. It is now up to the Australian community and the Government, of whatever political persuasion, to do its bit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for the debate has expired. The debate is adjourned. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) recognises the importance of science and research to the future economic and social well-being of Australia;
(2) acknowledges the contribution made to Australia's economic growth by the flagship of Australian science, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO); and
(3) notes the rapid decline in support for science, including the CSIRO, by the Government and accepts an urgency to address the appalling situation.

This is perhaps a very historic day because this is the first debate we have had on science in this chamber in more than 12 months which has formally been designated as a debate on science. The debate occurs at a time when the science community, the Government and concerned members on both sides of this chamber are very worried about the direction in which science policy is going.

My motion is in three parts. The first part states that we should recognise the importance of science and research to the future economic and social well-being of Australia. Indeed, this morning, when the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) was in the chamber, he came to me and said that he regretted very much that he could not be here because he, like me, has been frustrated with the approach that this Parliament, from both sides of the chamber, has taken to science. I hope this debate will focus attention on science in the minds of the media and of other members because it is about time that we recognised that science is indeed important. It has played a most important economic role in the community over many, many years and the decline of the flagship of science, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, the CSIRO, and the treatment it has received in recent years is really an abysmal performance.

During the Olympic Games I was vividly reminded of the differences between sport and science. The Olympics were watched by millions in Australia. None who watched could make the grade himself; few could even direct the events; but most understood enough about the events they watched to applaud where appropriate. How different is our understanding of science.

Recent surveys have shown that few Australians, and that includes our leaders in business, government and trade unions, feel well informed about science and technology. Although we rate new technology as one of the most important means of solving problems, in our ignorance we do not think technological changes will change much in our own lives. How wrong we are. The findings of recent surveys help to explain why Australia's scientific and technological resources are underutilised, why Australian industry's capability in the area of research and development is among the poorest in the world and why government has seen little need to do anything about the situation. This in turn explains why we are now facing such serious economic problems. That is another difference between sport and science. How much the audience applauds the play should not affect the outcome of the event. In science the applause, or lack of it, does affect the outcome.

Most Australians have positive attitudes to science-one only has to look at the popularity of television shows such as Quantum and Towards 2000 and the excellent Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio program The Science Show, by Robyn Williams. But interestingly, we finally see that scientists themselves are beginning to take on the task of winning the political debate-and long overdue that is. However, it seems that few politicians are listening-although, Mr Deputy Speaker, you and certain other honourable members took the opportunity to visit yesterday the historic display in the House by the Division of Forest Products of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. Indeed I saw the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) and the Minister for Science at that display. It was interesting that those Ministers gave lip service by attending, but did they respond to the needs of that particular division? Do they realise that forestry is Australia's second biggest manufacturing industry, employs about 90,000 people and last year exported forest products worth about $428m? Yet forest products also accounted for $1.5 billion of our trade deficit, in a country which could easily be self-sufficient in forestry. There is much more that we could be doing. The Division is underfunded, as are so many divisions in the CSIRO.
In an article that appeared yesterday in the Canberra Times, the frustration of many of our scientists was ably encapsulated in the remarks of one of the divisional assistant directors. He said:

I feel there is a cloud of anxiety and shortsightedness descending over science, not only in forestry but also science as a whole. My concern is larger than concern for my division or for CSIRO. We have seen the general decline in morale of those involved in the pursuit of science. And we are seeing Australia's incapacity to capitalise on the wonderful minds of so many brilliant scientists who are living in uncertainty. This is an incredible loss to a nation like ours.

That is an indictment of this chamber and of this Government. We have as our Minister for Science a man who is perhaps one of the most well-known proponents of science, but he has been a total failure. He has not won any of the political battles. It is all right to be erudite on science, but this chamber judges people on their ability to achieve policy goals.

In the science policy area this Government has failed and failed dismally to the extent where we see our scientists, the best and the brightest in our community, standing up in revolt. It is interesting to see that the science community now plans to launch a popular front for the liberation of science next year. The Australian Science and Technology Information Service will offer journalists, politicians and educators ready access to more than 1,000 leading scientists and technologists. The support from the scientific research institutions, to the tune of more than $50,000 in a few weeks, is testament to the fact that something is dreadfully wrong with science and technology in Australia. This House needs to recognise, and behave as though it does recognise, the importance of science in the future economic and social well-being of Australia. The current economic ills facing Australia will not be overcome without much stronger leadership from government and a much greater commitment by industry to research and development in all sectors. Indeed, it was interesting that only this week the Australian Science and Technology Council issued its annual report, in which it said:
Unless decisive action is taken to redress these problems our basic research effort will only be valuable as a cultural activity.

All of a sudden the experts are telling us that science is headed towards being a useful cultural activity. There is no longer the linking and recognition of science as a basic underpinning of economic success. The CSIRO began in the 1920s when we were suffering similar balance of payments difficulties. In those days we turned to science and we set up the CSIRO. Now we turn our backs. This Government shows no vision. It has a leader who has no vision and it would appear that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has had no business experience whatsoever. One would wonder whether he has the capability to run a pie cart.

What is happening to science? One only need look at another report that was released this week-that of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. That Committee, which had bipartisan membership, inquired into manufacturing industry revitalisation-a topic that is dear to all of us-and made the following recommendation:
the Commonwealth Government's direct expenditure on R&, through the CSIRO and other agencies be maintained and, when possible, increased.

Be maintained! There has been a 32 per cent cumulative decrease in funding to the CSIRO in five years. At present funding to the CSIRO is only 72 per cent of what it was in 1982-83. This is an abysmal performance. No wonder we have on our hands a revolt from the scientists. We as a parliament must respond-it is not just up to the Government. The other part of my motion says that the House:
notes the rapid decline in support for science, including the CSIRO, by the Government and accepts an urgency to address the appalling situation.

The decline in support for science is indicated primarily by the demise of the Department of Science. Now we have elements of science in about seven different Government departments and there is no champion for science in the bureaucracy and no focus for science to take issues to Cabinet. That is to be lamented. Comparatively speaking our international spending on science is lower than it was 20 years ago. Moreover, in relative terms Australia is far weaker than other nations because the others have recognised the importance of science and as a community we have not.

The question now is: will the CSIRO, Australia's premier scientific organisation, become the captive of industry? Indeed, will industry, with its abysmal contribution to research and development in this country, be a willing participant in Senator Button's plans? If so, what sections of industry are most likely to contribute and what divisions are most likely to benefit? The Minister for Science has recently pointed out that most of the outside funding is tied to certain areas. It cannot be transferred to others. The Government is taking an enormous risk. Long range basic research is at risk. The most economically significant sectors of CSIRO-agriculture, mining, fisheries and the environment-are at risk. Dr Green, Director of the Institute of Natural Resources and Environment, has said that the environmental sciences will probably not attract big money from industry and neither are their research results likely to lead to new products or industries for Australia. But this research is vital to the protection and management of our unique resources in the future. An example of the work done by the Institute is research into the greenhouse effect, on which I have spoken already this morning, and the inability of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, to get from the Government even $1m to enhance that research. I think that the fallout from successive budgetary cuts to the CSIRO is there for all to see. Indeed, to have the officers of that organisation passing an unprecedented vote of no confidence in their executive, to see the directors of the different institutes writing to the Chairman of the CSIRO in the terms that they have, calling for greater recognition of their work is something that we have never seen before in this country and it should be a lesson to all of us that things are not well.
The third part of my motion states that this House:
acknowledges the contribution made to Australia's economic growth by the flagship of Australian science, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation . . .

Each and every one of us can probably point to examples of what the CSIRO has done. Probably the most known achievement involves the range of discoveries which have helped the wool industry to survive intensive competition from synthetic fibres. These include self-twisting spinning, permanent creasing, shrink proofing and lightweight wools. The very successful application of research into the production, processing and marketing stages has meant that not only has wool survived, but it has also attracted record prices. Also we have seen the development of `siroscour' which has given the opportunity to develop further downstream processing of wool into clean wool ready for spinning. This has been achieved as a result of the work of the CSIRO.

A development of significance in the mineral industry was the research that led to the development of optical and computing techniques for enhancing satellite images that are the most advanced in the world. This enabled our mineral industries to perceive the surface features of the earth's crust and better interpret the underlying mineralisation. I could cite many examples, but I am sure each and every one of us knows of examples because the CSIRO, with 7,000 personnel, is represented in nearly every part of Australia. Those who have not visited it should do so because the people there need all the support we can possibly give them. It would be a shame if this Government did not recognise the importance of the CSIRO and get off its bottom and start supporting it.

I have been saying for some 18 months that we need to be supporting science and finally we had some light. The Minister for Science released a statement to say that an interdepartmental committee (IDC) had been set up. What does that committee do? That committee does what the other three inquiries did or were asked to do. It identifies ways in which we can support research and development. We know the answers. We know what needs to be done. People have been telling us for 12 months what needs to be done. We have been telling the Government and others have been telling the Government. The National Farmers Federation (NFF) told the Government yet again in an excellent speech last week that it needs to be supporting science and rural science. What do we get from the Minister? We get an IDC. Do it all again, Barry. To blame the bureaucrats is not good enough. The Government is there to lead and give vision and it is not doing that.

This committee that is to report in November is asked under its terms of reference to identify key elements to link science and technology policy to government policies already formulated on structural adjustments for industry and education. There are so many committees that have told us what we have to do that the question now is: Is the Government going to fund the relevant research that needs to be done in such a way that it can be done? At present that is not the case. Australia has had a brain drain and major losses in the CSIRO. Dr Scott of the Division of Animal Production recently indicated that he is no longer prepared to head that Division. There are many other examples which I have quoted at length to this House. We are seeing scientists leaving in frustration. It may well be too late. All that has happened is that we are finally to get an inquiry, and not even a formal inquiry at that. It is just an interdepartmental inquiry.

It is quoted in the press as being a victory for Minister Jones. He would have to be the Minister for Science who is the single biggest failure of this Government. He has achieved nothing for science. Science has gone backwards. His epitaph will be `the man who in this chamber presided over the demise of science'. We are seeing science galloping towards crisis in this country. Unless we take stock and do something quickly we will all be the losers. I have on many occasions suggested to the Minister that the best thing he could do for science is resign. If the Minister were to resign what would happen is this: he could draw attention finally to the plight of science because all other avenues have failed. I suggested to him that he might like to go and talk to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), as obviously several other Ministers have in recent days, and say to him, `Look, unless I get a fair cut for science I will cause a by-election'. Another by-election in Victoria, of course, would be of no joy to the Government because it would lose that as well.

I believe we should start looking positively at ways to support science. I have suggested in my four point plan the following items that should be done immediately. Firstly, Neville Wran should be replaced. Neville Wran is a publicist; he is not a scientist. CSIRO's most successful years were when its head was a scientist, the very first, Sir David Rivett. If we go back to that formula we will get far more positive results and that should be done forthwith. Secondly, we should be allocating substantial funds to the CSIRO. Figures, of course, can be plucked out of the air. On my estimation, to maintain, to make up and to put the CSIRO in the place that it was in in 1982-83 we would need to provide somewhere in the vicinity of $50m this year. That is how far CSIRO has slipped. Thirdly, we need to re-establish the science department. There has to be a focus. Science has to be represented at Cabinet level. There is no focus any more. Barry Jones is Minister for Science in name only. All his time is taken up pursuing customs matters. He knows it, we know it, and the community knows it. More importantly, the science community knows it. Members of the science community have lost faith in this Government. Generally apolitical, they are the ones who are saying that this Government has failed them and they ask what the Government is going to do about it. Finally, we ought to put in place and start preparing a national science strategy for Australia linking our research and development needs and indicating the path ahead.

We should show a little bit of vision for a change instead of looking over our shoulders and applauding ourselves from whence we have come. It is where we are going that we need to know about. It is what the science community needs to know about. This is a government that lacks vision. Is there anyone on the Government side of the House who has any vision of where science will and should go and the areas that we need to develop? Unless we start to hear something positive from the Government it will find that we will have the best and the brightest in this country leave. It has already had some leave but it will have many more stand in revolt. A Government that chooses to ignore deliberately the best and brightest advice in this country is a government that has become arrogant. It has become obsessed with obtaining and keeping power. It is no longer concerned about where this country is going.

If we turn our backs on science as we are I think that all of us, especially those of us who are younger in this chamber and have more stake in the future about where we ought to be going as a nation, will be the ones who will carry the burden. This Government has failed us dramatically. It is not just the honourable member for Bass who is saying this, it is those people out in the community who are saying it. It will be interesting to hear how the Government responds. The only lamentable thing about this debate is that it took so long to get here and that the Minister for Science is precluded by the rules of the House from being called to account in the chamber and giving an explanation for his abysmal performance in what has been nothing more than the demise of science in our community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose I would agree with the comment that was made by the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) towards the end of his speech when he said that the tragedy is that this debate has not occurred earlier. Since the honourable member for Bass was the shadow Minister for Science it is ironic that today he is not sitting on the front bench, given the fact that he was considered by many in the community who deal with science issues to have been a good shadow Minister. As the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), who is at the table, said in this chamber the other day, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) must have shot the wrong Tasmanian when he sent the honourable member--
—They got the wrong telephone number and sacked the wrong bloke.

—They got the wrong telephone number, as the Minister suggests. It is interesting to ask several questions. Why is this the first time that there has been an opportunity in the chamber to debate these very important issues? If the Opposition thought that these were as important as some people have suggested, why has the Opposition not been raising matters of public importance? Why has the Opposition not been seeking to encourage more debate in this chamber? I do not deny that the honourable member for Bass sought to use the procedures of the House on many occasions in grievance debates and on the adjournment to raise these issues. If it is such an important issue for the Opposition, why has the honourable member for Bass been such a lone voice in its ranks in seeking to raise these issues? Those are certainly some questions which I hope the new shadow Minister for science and energy, the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), will try to address. I am sure that he will find great difficulty in seeking to match the performance of the honourable member for Bass.

SPEECH.PARA: I just touch on some other points that the honourable member for Bass made. During his speech he mentioned that in the 1920s Australia decided to invest a large amount of money in the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) because we were having some balance of payments difficulties. In fact, late last night I was watching a television program. It was interrupted by a program called Bicentennial Minutes, which is produced by Peter Luck. In that program there was a short one minute feature on the prickly pear plague in the 1920s. In fact, many of us would know that the CSIRO pioneered the way and introduced into Australia the cactoblastis cactorum moth to combat the prickly pear. Given the recent plague of bogong moths in this chamber, throughout this building, in my own electorate of Dobell in New South Wales, and also in Sydney, I suggest that there is perhaps an even greater need for CSIRO to look at a way to combat, if not the prickly pear, then the bogong moth. I would be interested to know whether the bogong moth descended from the cactoblastis cactorum.

TALK.START.PARA: —Probably on their mother's side.

—That is possible. Let us not forget the fact that CSIRO has done a lot of good work in the years that it has been established. The honourable member for Bass quoted figures which demonstrated that CSIRO needs more money. I do not challenge that fact but let us not forget that the Government cannot foot the entire bill for Australia's research and development. In fact, in other countries the private sector carries much more of the load in funding research and development. At this stage, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard four tables which I will use to demonstrate this point.
