TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The first of these tables is a list of six countries whose gross domestic expenditure on research and development is expressed as a percentage of gross domestic product. Of course, the higher the figure the larger the amount of money these countries are spending on research and development. The United States of America spends 2.88 per cent of its gross domestic product on research and development. Japan spends 2.81 per cent. Australia has the relatively low figure of 1.16 per cent. That is the sort of figure that the honourable member for Bass used in claiming that Australia is not doing enough and, therefore, the Government should spend more money on the CSIRO.

SPEECH.PARA: When we look at the research and development funds which are provided by business enterprises as a percentage of gross domestic product we see some very interesting figures. In Japan, which carries out a great deal of research and development, business enterprises provide 1.93 per cent of gross domestic product for research and development. In Australia, we have the embarrassingly low figure of only 0.36 per cent of our gross domestic product being provided by business for research and development. The third table shows the research and development funds provided by government civil authorities as a percentage of gross domestic product. Australia does surprisingly well in this area. New Zealand tops the poll with 0.77 per cent of gross domestic product. Australia is second, with 0.70 per cent of our gross domestic product being provided by the Government to organisations such as the CSIRO. Some people believe that the Japanese Government is funding large amounts of research and development, but Japan comes in with the relatively low figure of only 0.57 per cent of its gross domestic product being provided by the Government. At the bottom of the tree is Margaret Thatcher, the pin-up girl of the Opposition conservative parties. Her Government provides only 0.33 per cent of gross domestic product for research and development from civil sources.

When we look at the government sector and the contribution which the Government of Australia is making towards science research and development, we see that Australia stands up to comparison with Western industrialised countries. That does not mean that the CSIRO does not need more money to carry out the important research which is necessary for our long term economic development. I think it is unfortunate that some people are seeking to suggest that it is the Government's fault that we are not spending more on research and development and that business enterprises do not have to do more. I hope that the Opposition will support the Government's attempts. I see the honourable member for Bass signifying his agreement by nodding his head, and I recognise that. I believe that the Government has to ensure that business carries a greater share of the load so that more research and development is carried out in Australia.

The Government's historic decision to introduce 150 per cent tax deductibility for some areas of commercial research and development is a decision which I think will go down as one of the landmark decisions of government in this policy area of research and development. While some people have been critical of the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), I think that decision is a real feather in his cap. In many ways it just goes to show that all of the years that he has spent seeking to raise the Australian people's understanding of science issues is finally bearing rewards. I pay tribute to him for those sorts of achievements.

At one stage the honourable member for Bass got a bit carried away and made certain allegations that the Government is not spending enough on science because the Treasurer (Mr Keating) does not have a business background. I was not quite sure how that fitted into the argument. He even made the outrageous claim that the Treasurer could not run a pie cart. Perhaps the Treasurer is an interesting case study. He left school at 15 years of age, which I think was called third form in those days, and went back to complete his leaving certificate at night school. Then he proceeded to obtain an electrical engineering degree in part time study. Given that I am an electrical engineer, it is quite interesting for me to relate those details to the House. These days the Treasurer is accepted by everyone who has a good understanding of economic matters as one of this country's greatest Treasurer's. He has clocked up these achievements, having left school at 15 and taken the trouble to go back and conclude his learning at night. Perhaps those people in this House who have been able to prove that they can complete a law degree by writing lots of essays would have done better to have gone back to night school to do an engineering degree.

I, as a fifth form student, had the honour of being selected to attend one of Professor Harry Messel's science foundation for physics courses at the University of Sydney. There we were privileged to receive lectures from a then unknown astronomer, Carl Sagan, who has since gone on to achieve fame and fortune on television, and also a great human being, Professor Julius Sumner Miller, who, for better or worse, is still appearing in Cadbury's television advertisements. I am not sure that that is something I would support. Like the Minister, Professor Julius Sumner Miller greatly encouraged an understanding of, and enthusiasm for, science. I certainly recall those efforts at the University of Sydney.

Before completing my engineering degree and while doing a science degree at the University of New South Wales I remember sometimes not understanding why we had to study such esoteric subjects as quantum physics with quarks, electrons, neutrinos and all sorts of bizarre concepts which were totally theoretical. These days, Mr Deputy Speaker, you and I can turn on our computers in Parliament House to do a search on the Hansard database, but the little integrated circuit microchips that are doing those calculations would not work if people had not gained a thorough understanding of quantum physics and if Einstein had not made those great predictions and analyses in the early 1900s.

I accept that often theoretical research which some people think is not cost effective can have unexpected spin-offs. That is why I do not argue that there should be no theoretical research. Theoretical research is important. However, Australia's great weakness in the past has been that some organisations, often the CSIRO, have made important discoveries and they have not been developed. Australian companies have not followed through and funded the economic development of these products. I suppose that the most common example quoted here is Interscan. Dr Paul Wild, the former Head of CSIRO, did a lot of work on it. In fact, Australia led the world in developing this system, which enables aeroplanes to land safely at international airports. Yet Australia let that great discovery slip through its fingers in many ways. I know that Minister Jones is very proud of the fact that he has been able to persuade the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer and other senior Ministers to establish a committee to review our science capacity. The honourable member for Bass was very critical and said it is yet another committee which will not come up with any results. I suspect that he might be surprised at the result that comes out.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been surprised a lot lately.

—I acknowledge the interjection. Given that the committee is expected to produce a report by the end of November, we will be able to make judgments in the very near future. I hope that the Minister will be successful in persuading Cabinet that Australia needs to do more and that our economic circumstances will permit us to carry out more work in funding research and development.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I wish to quote one figure for members of the conservative parties opposite who have sought to suggest that the Labor Government is the only one responsible for the downturn in research and development. There is an interesting figure on page 45 of the science and technology statement for 1987-88. The honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), the shadow Minister who is at the table, was here when the Fraser Government was elected in 1975. In the Whitlam years of 1973 and 1974 the level of funding for research and development, as a percentage of gross domestic product, was 1.21 per cent. By the time the Fraser Government left office it had fallen to one per cent of gross domestic product. So I do not think that either side of politics is totally innocent in this matter. I would have thought that it would have been better for either side of politics to support a substantial increase in funding in this area.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Port Hacking-Kurnell Peninsula-Sutherland Shire: Bushfires-Joint Committee on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation: Appointment of Member-Public Education Program-Myalgic Encephalomyelitis-Road System-Consumer Indebtedness-Australia-Britain Relationship-Daylight Saving: Queensland

That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dobie The Hon J.D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Chairman of the Opposition's back bench committee on environment, recreation, sport and the arts, I rise here today to congratulate my New South Wales State Government colleagues on a recent environmental decision which they have made in my own backyard, and that is the decision not to proceed with a tombolo in Port Hacking.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members from interstate and, indeed, from other parts of Sydney, and in fact the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) who has just spoken, would agree that Port Hacking is, without doubt, Sydney's most beautiful stretch of waterway, nestled as it is at the top of the Royal National Park, south of Sydney. I am sure the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner), whose electorate also bounds the Port, will agree with me on this point, although some honourable members on my own side may have other ideas. Of course, the name of Port Hacking was elevated to even greater prominence recently when that magnificent rugby team of the same name won the Sydney rugby union premiership but that, of course, is another matter. Nevertheless, as one of its club's life members, I would be abrogating my duty if I did not take this nationwide opportunity of congratulating the team most heartily. But I return to the subject of the Port itself.

Port Hacking has, for many years now, been subject to shoaling which has threatened both commercial and recreational pursuits on this beautifully situated waterway. For the information of members, in nautical terms a tombolo is, to quote the Macquarie Dictionary, `a spit of sand or shingle thrown up by the tide linking an island or rock with the mainland'. Under the direction of the previous Unsworth Labor Government, the New South Wales Department of Public Works produced a report recommending the construction of such a tombolo as a means of combating the shoaling problem. The tombolo was seen as a permanent fixture and, though it may have been a solution to the problem, it would have significantly changed the shape and very nature of the Port as we know it. Naturally, the future of Port Hacking has been the subject of much debate in my electorate since the tombolo idea was first mooted. This issue was raised when I was first elected to this Parliament in 1966. The debate as to what should happen is not new and has been going on for a long time. In fact, for those who are not aware, the problem is the result of a series of severe cyclonic storms which destroyed a natural sandbar across the front of the port more than 30 years ago.

Last month the Greiner Government announced that the tombolo proposal would not proceed. This news has been well received by the local community and credit must go to the four local State Liberal members, Kerr, Phillips, C. Downy and Andrews, who have been active and responsible contributors to the debate on Port Hacking. The new Liberal Government's decision to withdraw the development application for the tombolo will also save taxpayers the considerable expense involved in the public inquiry that was to have taken place. At the same time, the commitment of the Greiner Government, and the four local Liberal members in particular, for immediate dredging of the estuary will be honoured. The Greiner Government will meet the full cost for the once-off dredging costs of the channel up to a maximum of $500,000. Sutherland Shire Council will be responsible for carrying out the work and seeking the necessary approvals. Although this may seem parochial, I raise this matter in this House because those of us who are interested in the environment should acknowledge the efforts of any party that tries to do something positive for the environment.

The Greiner State Government has acted with due consideration to all the environmental concerns; it has listened to the people of the Sutherland Shire and acted accordingly. I regret to say that this is a change from the position of the previous Unsworth Labor Government, which sought to bulldoze through its ideas, whatever they were, on environmental matters with little or no debate, acting only with political expediency. The woodchip industry comes to mind during those long, dark Labor years. One could always tell there was a State election in the air. The Wran and Unsworth Labor governments would suddenly make great overtures about the need to dredge Port Hacking. What Labor did not and still does not recognise is that Port Hacking is a great natural resource, which has to be protected and preserved not only for our generation, but for future generations; not only for the people living around it, but for people living throughout Sydney, throughout Australia.

If Port Hacking had had an industrial base perhaps the situation would have been different in that industrial pressure could have been brought to bear. It is because Port Hacking is and always has been a basically recreational facility, that previous governments, Labor and Liberal, have allowed it to become so neglected. The valiant attempt by my constituent, Mr Bob Killick, for example, to run a commercial pleasure cruising operation in Port Hacking was sadly terminated because of lack of navigable water. One can only hope that the enterprising Bob Killick will consider returning to Port Hacking to provide a very enjoyable and worthwhile service once this dredging operation is completed.

So, again, congratulations to my four State colleagues, whom I have mentioned already, to Wal Murray, the New South Wales Minister for Public Works, to Environment Minister Tim Moore, who has long taken a great interest in the environmental problems of the Sutherland Shire, and to David Hay, the new Minister for Local Government and Planning. In August, David Hay made an official announcement that Kurnell Peninsula will be rezoned in a matter of weeks to stop any toxic industry being established there. This is a great victory not only for the Kurnell Action Committee, but also for the environmentally aware people of Sydney and Australia.

Many honourable members have heard me speak before on the problems of the Kurnell Peninsula, on the battle by residents to prevent this birthplace of the nation from being turned into a toxic industrial wasteland. The previous Labor Government and the then Labor Environment Minister who now leads his Party, Mr Carr, gave every indication of doing nothing to stop the Peninsula becoming a wasteland. It was only with an election looming and public outrage over the future of Kurnell growing that the Unsworth Government backed off and tried a last minute change of attitude which was all too late. In contrast, the position of the Liberal-National coalition in New South Wales has been principled and consistent. It has now carried through with its commitment to replace the 4 (C) 4 zoning with general and light industrial zonings, and to require full environmental assessments for any major development proposals.

In conclusion, it is interesting to note, in light of what I have been saying, that it was a Labor Minister, Pat Hills, who advocated Towra Point-part of the Kurnell Peninsula-as Sydney's second major airport way back in 1962. Many people forget this. Towra Point is a wetlands area which plays host to many rare birds and concern for its future was one of the major reasons the Kurnell Action Committee took its stand against toxic industry. I pay tribute to the role taken by the Whitlam Government in seeing that this area became a reserve. I congratulate the New South Wales Government which, in this year of our bicentennial celebrations, has shown a fine example of the active application of environmental responsibility.

In the few minutes remaining to me I wish to refer to the tragic bushfires in my own electorate and in the electorate of my friend, the honourable member for Hughes. I pay tribute to the 13 bushfire brigades in the Sutherland Shire and the 650 members of this voluntary bushfire brigade. We think it is one of the best equipped bushfire brigades in the country. I pay tribute to the work being done by these people. I would be abrogating my personal regard for them if I did not mention now that we had two tragic accidents: one on 3 November 1980 when a bushfire claimed the lives of five members of our bushfire brigade; and another on 9 January 1983 when the Grays Point bushfire claimed three lives and seriously injured seven people.

When we are looking at the headlines and watching these bushfires raging in the southern parts of Sydney, it does us well to remember that the members of the bushfire brigades are not gung ho people. They devote their lives, their time, their recreation time, to protect their own communities and their own districts. As I indicated, they do so at the cost not just of their time and effort but of their lives, as we have seen in two tragic accidents in the last several years. So I hope that honourable members, as they watch these bushfires on television-and they are continuing today-will give consideration, thought and remembrance to the brave people who have worked to save their own communities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Simultaneously, a fortnight ago today attacks were launched on me and the Federal Government by Mr B. A. Santamaria in the Australian newspaper and by Mr Michael Barnard in the Age newspaper criticising my appointment as a member of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO). At the same time, in the News Weekly Magazine, recognised widely as the journal of the National Civic Council, Mr Santamaria made a more lengthy attack on me and set out what he described as my unorthodox curriculum vitae as a guardian of Australia's security. Both he and Mr Barnard then listed a series of activities in which I had participated over the past 10 years, the first one being two years before I was actually elected as the member for La Trobe.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst it could be viewed as somewhat sinister that these two well-known right wing reactionaries should publish a critique of my credentials for being a member of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on ASIO on the same day, it was also interesting that Alan Jones of radio 2UE in Sydney had his attention drawn to the list of my so-called dubious political activities and conducted a rather one-sided interview with me on air on his Monday morning program. After giving me little time to reply to his questions, he told his listeners that he was sure that Australians would find me a most unsatisfactory person to be a member of the Joint Committee.

In some respects I am indebted to these three commentators, who have given some prominence to activities which I have been proud to be associated with over the years. Of course, it is a selective list, and if that was all I had done over the past 10 years I would not be very satisfied with the work I have undertaken on behalf of the Australian people as a whole and particularly for the people who live in my electorate of La Trobe. If a study is made of my activities listed by Mr Santamaria and Mr Barnard, it will be seen that they are all in support of the human rights of individuals or the peoples of subject nations; or in support of an independent foreign policy for Australia which would make us a far more worthwhile friend and ally.

I would like to go through the list in more detail. In 1987, Christopher Boyce, who was convicted of releasing United States military secrets to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) had been in solitary confinement for many years under inhumane conditions and was in considerable ill health. I called for his parole release. In 1981 Irish Republican Army hunger strikers were also protesting about inhumane prison conditions and I called for a proper recognition of their status and their rights. I stand by my statement that the Palestinians are being treated as prisoners in their own land and only the Palestine Liberation Organisation (PLO) is the true representative of the Palestine people. The brutal beating and killing of Palestinians by Israeli settlers can only be classified as zionist terrorism. It is inevitable that the Australian Government and indeed, Israel will eventually recognise the PLO, as has been done by many European governments. I also stand by my view that the 1983 United States invasion of Grenada was one of the black chapters in United States history. It was not a brutal dictatorship, but it was a communist country. Did this give the United States the right to invade the country without provocation?

The presence in Angola of Cuban troops has prevented the takeover of that country by South African troops and the installation of a puppet South African government. Does anybody really believe that South Africa would install democracy in Angola for the black population of that country? Messrs Santamaria and Barnard appear to have forgotten that, prior to the Castro-led revolution in 1969, Cuba was controlled by the Batista dictatorship, which was one of the most fascist and bloody dictatorships of all Latin American countries at the time. Of course, I was willing to support the twenty-fifth anniversary of a revolution which has given the Cuban people reforms which have been unprecedented in Latin America. I wonder whether Mr Santamaria or Mr Barnard have ever visited countries in Latin America, as I have done, and made comparisons of the conditions of the people in, say, Cuba, Nicaragua, Mexico and Venezuela.

Before I end my comments on my human rights record, let me also point out that I have criticised the Soviet presence in Afghanistan and have supported the call for those people who wish to leave countries in eastern Europe and the USSR for political reasons to be able to gain refugee status.

Let me now turn to my various actions in support of an independent foreign policy for Australia. I have proposed a policy which is independent of both the United States and the USSR but which recognises, as Messrs Santamaria and Barnard are unable to do because of their atrophied, cold war 1960s mentality, that the United States and the USSR are now talking to each other in terms, if not of friendship, at least grudging respect for the power of each country to destroy the world if they do not have a mutual accord. When I call for an end to United States military bases in Australia, for withdrawal from military ties with the Association of South East Asian Nations and an end to all military alliances-and not just with the United States-I am seeking an independent role for Australia in international affairs. At present we are a nuclear target because of our military alliances. In calling for an end to our military involvement I am seeking a release from the fear and insecurity which many Australians, particularly young Australians, feel in the world of the late twentieth century.

Have Messrs Santamaria and Barnard ever read any of the letters of the young school children which express their fear of a nuclear war and their call for the United States and the USSR to have friendly relations? Obviously, our two self-appointed guardians of Australia's security are unaware that Australia has a cultural activities agreement with the USSR which promotes the friendly exchange between our two countries of dancers, musicians, actors, artists, students and academics. In fact, I owe Messrs Santamaria and Barnard a service, because since the publication of the two articles I have received many messages of congratulation and support on my stand on human rights and the denunciation of military alliances.

Let me now turn to their objections to my proposal in 1983 that the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation should be abolished. What I do believe is that if ASIO is carrying out its surveillance work in the same incompetent and inept manner as in the late 1970s and early 1980s when I wrote my 1983 submission to the royal commission conducted by Mr Justice Hope, then it should be abolished. The reason my parliamentary colleagues proposed to the Federal Government that I be a nominee for membership of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation was that they had faith in my ability to exercise the necessary scrutiny of ASIO surveillance of Australian citizens; that I would ensure that ASIO is not subjecting to surveillance people such as socialists, advocates of constitutional change, ministers of religion espousing radical causes, civil rights activists and demonstrators. This was the situation in the late 1970s. In 1977 Mr Justice Hope stated:

I am bound to record that I found ASIO's files in such disorder that in the time that has been made available to me I have been quite unable to establish the truth or otherwise of many of the particulars of matters alleged in evidence or raised with ASIO as the result of other inquiries.

In my 1983 submission I stated to Mr Justice Hope that it must be of great concern to all Australians that ASIO has undertaken surveillance of a number of classes of loyal citizens whose only crime was that they were of perceived left political bent. I point out that democracy thrives on non-violent differences of opinion and attitudes and ASIO must be careful to avoid mistaking mere dissent or non-conformity for subversion.

I also submitted that the conflict of ideas does not represent a threat to Australian society and the more open the individual relations of Australians with foreign powers, the easier it will be to compare and contrast and reject or accept political and economic ideas as part of inevitable evolutionary change in the Australian social fabric. This is the problem with Messrs Santamaria and Barnard. They are voices from the grave. They represent political thinking of the 1950s and the early 1960s, which is a lifetime away.

TALK.START.PARA: —Santamaria dodged national service.

—That is an interesting point made by the honourable member for Hindmarsh. One has only to look at the articles written by both men over the past year to see how they view the world in an unreal black and white picture, as either communist or non-communist. There is no in-between for such people. When the United States turns to diplomacy instead of military force with Nicaragua, El Salvador or Panama, Mr Barnard, as in an Age article of 28 June 1988, criticises the United States and refers to bungling and indecisions.

SPEECH.PARA: This same correspondent in his articles savages peace and humanitarian activists and opponents of South African apartheid with impunity. Articles in the Age of 24 May 1988, 23 February 1988 and 10 November 1987 support South Africa. On 12 March, 19 March 1988 and 13 October 1987 he attacked the peace and humanitarian movement. All his articles are notable for shallow thinking and guilt by association. Any thorough and intelligent analyses of background and factual circumstances are discarded for ideological bigotry. Selective reporting and quotations are the order of the day.

So it is for Mr Santamaria also. His articles in the Australian are notable for their invective against trade unions and what he perceives as the ever-present danger of communism. His political reactionary activities over the past 30 years and his hatred of the Australian Labor Party are well known to all Australians. What is appalling about the attack on me by these two reactionary correspondents from a past age is their charge that because I support individual human rights and the right of people to enjoy their own type of government free from outside interference, I am somehow disqualified to be a member of the Joint Committee.

My record of objection to transgressions of human rights, whether here or overseas, puts me in a strong position to be a member of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. Australians can be assured that I will be particularly vigilant in ensuring that ASIO does not subject Australian citizens to surveillance, just because they challenge the established order. ASIO has nothing to fear from my overseeing of its activities if it is performing its duties in a proper manner.

It is an insult to my colleagues and me, and indeed this Parliament, to suggest that my appointment represents a threat to Australian security. One also wonders what organisation or group is keeping a list of certain of my political activities, and did so even before I became a member of parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, the Government is currently considering ways of having a public education program, pursuant to the FitzGerald report, Immigration A Commitment to Australia. I want to suggest to the Government that that public education program should be even broader than it is now contemplating. It should cover the whole spectrum of issues that impinge upon people's understanding of the evolving Australian culture and our place in the world. I include amongst that issues such as foreign students, which we know to be beneficial to Australia, as well as to the students concerned, but many people in the country are not aware of that. Foreign investment is another contentious issue, about which I will say a little in a moment. And of course, the implications of the fact that we are in the Indian and Pacific oceans are not as readily understood by a lot of Australians as they should be. I think all of these factors impinge on people's perception of what an intake of migrants on a non-discriminatory basis really means.

SPEECH.PARA: I have said enough about immigration and I do not intend to repeat that today, but I would commend to the House a speech by my friend and colleague the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson) on Tuesday in the debate on the Treasury estimates, in which he questioned whether we should have unlimited foreign investment when it is so closely misunderstood. I would say that, while I see the virtue of having a free flow of people, ideas and capital, if in fact we are to jeopardise a free flow of the immigrants whom we want on a non-discriminatory basis by the rate and nature of foreign investment, then there may be an argument for even greater curbs on foreign investment than is now the case.

There was a letter in the Australian Financial Review last week from Mr Peter Frankel, a well-known Australian businessman who won an export award last year, saying precisely that Mr Peter Isaacson, one of our few independent publishers in Australia of newspapers and magazines, is a very liberal man, if I may say so, in his whole approach and a very modern thinker-a progressive man in all respects. He said in his editorial in his Southern Cross newspaper on 28 September:
In future, Australians will rue the fact that so many Australian buildings, so many Australian companies and so much Australian land have been sold to non-Australian people and companies.
Profits from the sales are shared by a few but the loss of the land to overseas owners affects all Australians.

Of course, what Mr Isaacson is saying there reflects a very widespread concern. It has been evident on the Gold Coast, but it is also throughout the community. In the South China Morning Post recently there was an advertisement which concerned your State, Mr Deputy Speaker: `Land available in Perth for redevelopment, subdivision and sale'. The heading on this advertisement seeking Hong Kong investment was `Australia up for grabs'. That has been circulating in my electorate. I am not sure who got hold of it and circulated it, but clearly there is a perception that Australia is being taken over, and that is one of the ingredients in the misunderstandings in the debate on immigration. Real estate prices in the community have risen and are now going beyond the reach of many Australian families, simply because overseas owners were buying properties until the recent restriction of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). They were often never even seeing the properties, let alone living in them, and selling them for a considerable capital gain. I think these are real factors in the apprehensions people have.

I want to raise also, as part of the need for a public education campaign, the fact that in this Bicentenary we have been looking back a good deal. We have not been looking forward as much as we should have. The fact is that 40 years after World War II, the former colonies in the Indian and Pacific oceans are well-established, with new problems and new evolving relationships. We are the natural leader of the South Pacific, especially the micro-states, and without any paternalism we can in many ways be representing them in Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN) conferences and in other forums that we attend around the world.

The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) has recently made a sweep through that region and that illustrates how belated this Government's action has been in respect of the South Pacific. We have not, with credibility, led and represented those states and we have not, therefore, made our contribution to the stability of the world because we have neglected our own backyard. In the Fraser Government, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Foreign Minister and many other Ministers visited our micro-state neighbours frequently. But in the wider Indian and Pacific regions, we should also be striving to forge close links with the nations of those regions.

There are new and important bilateral relationships being formed all the time and we have to be part of them. I think a barrier to our doing that is the understandable feeling amongst many Australians that we are emotionally, culturally and even strategically part of the North Atlantic community. We still tend to see our two-ocean region through the eyes of nations of a third ocean. The best contribution which we can make to the Western Alliance is to play a positive role, to bring stability to the South Pacific and by understanding and being part of the north Pacific and the Indian Ocean region and sharing our perspectives of those regions with the Atlantic allies.

The present Foreign Minister on the Channel 10 program Face to Face a couple of weeks ago actually said that north Asia is not in our geopolitical sphere of interest. He is very wrong indeed because the shifting relationships of North Asia impact directly upon us and upon our neighbours in South and South East Asia and in all parts of the Pacific. We must assess our national interest in north Asia as well as in the other regions in terms of what is going on between countries as to their politics, their diplomacy, their trade and what it is that we should be getting out of those changing relationships too.

Last week I made a speech in Hobart to the Australian Institute of International Affairs, and I was quite critical of the Government in a number of foreign policy res-pects. But for my purposes today, I merely want to say that in recent years, both the present Government and the Fraser Government addressed many of the issues in our region of both the Indian and Pacific oceans: areas like Zimbabwe; South Africa; nuclear testing; the dumping of nuclear waste; self-determination of colonies in the region; fishing bases for the Union of Soviet Socialist Republic and tuna fishing by the United States of America; and the Kampuchean settlement.

We addressed all of those issues in ways that were not necessarily those of the North Atlantic powers but to some extent, both governments have acted ahead of public opinion. Menzies and McEwen of course did that on the Japan trade agreement; Holt did that on the question of Asian immigration. But I believe if we are talking of a major public education program now, we must ensure that people realise it is not simply about the question of immigration; it is about Australia's part in the world and all aspects of the relationship that come from that.

Only 10 per cent of Australian students do a second language at the higher school certificate (HSC) level. It is critical if we are really to play a part and understand other cultures that we acquire other languages. Languages of key economic importance are not even adequately represented in that 10 per cent at the HSC level and our economic competitors, of course, are putting much more into language skills than we are. Increasingly, companies are putting some money in but companies are also demanding that if people want promotion, they must have a second language. So many Australian adults are racing out to do crash courses at universities where they learn to speak but not to read another language. But we should be tackling it at the primary and secondary school levels much more than we are.

Some progress is being made, but if the Government educates the public to understand the need, the public will sanction greater expenditure priority to be given to the area of language. At the moment, funds are just redistributed and expectations are not fully met. The Government has proclaimed that it is going to do all sorts of great things in the area of language training and inevitably it has disappointed people in many areas.

It is not giving sufficient attention to the training of teachers, to the availability of library facilities and to the Saturday schools that cover so many important second and third languages to Australia. We will never understand our neighbours if we do not understand their language, and through their language their culture. We will never be successful in trade negotiations if we do not understand their temperament and their cultural viewpoints. We will never make a major contribution diplomatically by using our good offices as a middle power if we do not have language facilities. So I call very strongly upon the Government not only to have this wider public education program, but to educate for languages too.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take the opportunity provided to me today to draw the attention of the Parliament and the population at large to an illness which is little understood in the community and possibly even less understood in the medical profession, despite the fact that a significant proportion of its victims are themselves medical practitioners or their families. There is no known cure, except possibly time, for this illness, and no attributable cause. Its victims are frequently men and women of hardworking persuasion and lifestyle in the prime of their lives.

SPEECH.PARA: The illness has a variety of names, which tends to exacerbate the confusion with which it is surrounded. The names themselves are evidence of the range of medical thinking on its nature and cause, as well as providing a clue to its arguably epidemic qualities and the propensity for geographically confined outbreaks. The disease is myalgic encephalomyelitis; ME for short. Benign myalgic encephalomyelitis is another name. Epidemic neuromyastenia, post-viral fatigue syndrome, chronic fatigue syndrome, Epstein-Barr syndrome, Icelandic disease, Royal Free disease, Tapanui flu, Lake Tahoe disease and yuppie flu are other names.

While ME may not be the most medically correct term for the disease, it is certainly the one by which it is most commonly known. Recent literature tends to refer to it as post-viral fatigue syndrome on the basis that it frequently follows on the heels of another viral infection, such as glandular fever or hepatitis, or it can be called chronic fatigue syndrome on the basis that its symptoms are invariably those associated with extreme fatigue and that no consistent evidence exists to link the disease with viral illness.

I first came across the consequences of this disease in 1984. When holidaying in the South Island of New Zealand I visited my cousin in Tapanui and was appalled to discover that she had fallen victim to an unknown fatigue which was causing her immense distress. As a 36-year-old mother of three young children, which would be enough to fatigue one in itself, she was normally noted for her good humour and energy and was undoubtedly accustomed to very hard work. She had been a nurse for most of her working life and was happily married to a farmer in a small community.

The depression and lack of energy which plagued her was totally inexplicable to me. To see such a person struck down for no apparent reason in the prime of life was a great shock. There was certainly no suggestion of hypochondria or psychological disorder. In August this year I had the opportunity to see my cousin again. She has now recovered, but her husband, normally a fit hardworking farmer of pleasant disposition, has fallen victim to the same illness to the extent that he is now able to undertake the labour on his farm only spasmodically so as not to subject himself to a relapse. Furthermore, an older aunt by marriage is very ill with the disease and is hardly able to go out at all without exhausting herself and therefore risking a serious relapse.

I determined to look further at this disease from a lay person's perspective, because of its obviously distressing effects to the sufferer and his or her family. Its quasi-epidemic quality intrigues me, and I believe if it is not viral it may be an immune system disorder which is exacerbated by environmental stresses. To assist interested members and others in the community I shall use my time today to outline a brief and possibly incomplete chronology of outbreaks of the disease, together with what seems to be the most relevant research on the subject.

In 1955 an outbreak occurred at the Royal Free Hospital in London when 292 doctors, nurses and ancillary workers were struck down, hence the title Royal Free disease which appears in some subsequent research. Dr Melvin Ramsey, the then head of the hospital's infectious diseases unit, was convinced that it was a physical problem, probably of viral origin.

In 1983 there was a large outbreak of this disease at Tapanui, which is where my cousin lives, in New Zealand. This was looked at by Dr Les Simpson, who is the senior research pathologist at the University of Otago. He described how the blood from Tapanui victims tended to filter more slowly than normal blood. In 1985 Drs Paul Cheney and Daniel Peterson documented an outbreak of the disease at Incline Village, Nevada, on the north shore of Lake Tahoe, which is a popular resort attracting thousands of visitors a year; hence obviously the use of the term Lake Tahoe syndrome.

Cheney and Peterson perused the medical literature in search of a cause. They concluded that the most likely culprit was the Epstein-Barr virus, which I think has something to do with the herpes virus. The National Centre for Disease Control, however, did not endorse their findings. Subsequently blood samples from some of the Lake Tahoe patients were sent to the National Cancer Institute laboratory for analysis and Dr Robert Gallo discovered a new virus which he names HBLV, or the human B lymphotropic virus. It is another member of the herpes family and studies have shown that herpes viruses can be activated by stress. This might explain the prevalence of the disease amongst high achievers, hence the yuppie disease title.

In 1986-87 outbreaks were documented in the Narrabeen areas of New South Wales by a local general practitioner, Dr Garnet Simpson. Dr Simpson believed that HBLV would prove to be the trigger virus which reactivated other types of herpes viruses lying dormant in cells in the immune and central nervous systems.

The 1983 findings of Dr Les Simpson, however, were recently picked up by an Adelaide general practitioner, Dr Kathleen Maros, who had been struck by the prospect of the fatigue symptom being related to a red blood cell disorder and consequent reduction in the delivery of oxygen to the muscles, rather than a muscle disorder per se. Her interest in ME had arisen as a consequence of its being contracted by her son whilst on a visit to Europe. I know that the disease has been dogged by the suggestion that it is psychosomatic or hysterical in its nature; hence the medical practitioners' failure to give it due credence when people have presented with the problem. But I believe that this diagnosis is now well and truly on the way to being put aside.

The point is that people who have this disease often are high achievers in their own right. They generally come from the middle age period of their life; they are often in small communities and it appears to have some epidemic quality. I would very much like to see the medical profession in Australia take this disease seriously and I am sure that there are people within their ranks, such as Dr Maros in South Australia, who are capable of isolating the problems involved in this disease and doing the nation and the world a service by finding out what the cause is.

I do not think that this can happen without an environment of support for the people who are suffering from the disease and proper attention by the medical profession to their symptoms. Certainly I have had the matter drawn to my attention by a letter received from a person in Queensland, whom I imagine also wrote to other members of the House on the matter. I have no intention of letting it go at this. I want to follow it myself, again from a lay person's perspective, in order to ascertain as much as I can about it because of its worrying consequences for all the people in our society, especially if it is environmentally related.

To conclude, I would very much like to acknowledge the assistance I have received from Dr Rod Panter of the legislative research section of the Parliamentary Library in assembling a variety of articles on this topic. Of those articles I have particularly drawn upon the Lancet extract of 4 June 88 called `What is myalgic encephalomyelitis', the British Medical Journal extract of 5 March 88 called `Post Viral Fatigue Syndrome-Time for a new approach', and a Time Australia article dated 21 September 87 entitled `Chronic Bug Fatigue'. I thank the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no more valuable asset to a trading and productive nation like Australia than an adequate and efficient road system. Earlier governments recognised this and gave a high priority to road construction and expansion to meet the needs of the motorist and resource industries. In my State of Victoria an excellent road system was developed, bringing reasonable and equitable access to the whole population. I remind the House that much of this work was carried out in times of limited technology and limited economic capacity but with a high level of commitment.

SPEECH.PARA: However, in 1988 when we can blast men off to the moon and when this Government massively taxes road users to the tune of $7,000m annually, we find that there has been a 25 per cent reduction in road funding. Using gross non-farm product price deflation calculations, common road funds have declined from $1,127m in 1982-83 to $1,059.5m in 1988-89. The rape by the Hawke Government, aided and abetted by Premier Cain in Victoria, is so clearly identified when we see that in March 1983 a barrel of oil cost $38.69, on which 6.15c excise was added.

In September 1988 the cost of a barrel of oil dropped to $17.44 and in the last few days has dropped even further to about $13. This Government through a system of indexation has increased excise to 21.53c. Every time motorists fill the tank of an average size car they pay almost $20 in tax; somewhere in the vicinity of $1,000 per year tax for every motorist in Australia.

Then, of course, there are import duties, sales taxes or State charges such as licensing, registration, stamp duty and State petrol tax that owners must pay. This financial year fuel taxes will account for 9 per cent of Federal Government revenue. Last year these taxes represented the second largest source of Federal Government revenue after personal income tax. However, spending on roads accounts for only 1.6 per cent of Federal Government outlays. As costs for maintaining the existing overworked systems increase, funds for new and better roads decline.

State road authorities themselves presently spend 60 per cent of works expenditure on maintenance alone. By the year 2000 they are expected to have to increase this figure to 80 per cent. Already more than half of our major roads have pavements at least 20 years old, which is their generally expected lifespan. This Government has recently reclassified such luxury items as jewellery, cosmetics, cameras and stereo equipment and reduced their sales tax to 20 per cent. Yet fuel attracts 150 per cent tax on its wholesale value. In this nation where we are so dependent on fuel it is taxed as a super luxury.

When we consider the state of our roads and the demands expected in the near future, this contribution is a national scandal. For those of us who live in rural regions of Australia, producing large proportions of the States' income, the problems are threefold. Firstly, the Federal Government has initiated legislative changes which have forced grants commissions in each State to change their existing revenue-sharing formula. Each State grants commission must comply with more stringent Federal guidelines for the allocation of general revenue-sharing funds.

The plight of rural shires as a result of these changes becomes acute and will limit their capacity to meet the level of their responsibilities, which includes roads. Secondly, the size of the overall allocation of road funds is already shown to be inadequate and declining. Third is the actual distribution of moneys available for roads. The method of distribution of these limited funds is not equitable, it is not just, and it is certainly not fair. Municipalities in the North Western Municipalities Association, which takes in all of my Mallee electorate and other parts of western Victoria, are seriously disadvantaged by the formula.

With respect to weighted road length, population and the 10 per cent discounting factor for topography and rainfall, under this 10 per cent variation for topography and rainfall there are 13 councils that receive 10 per cent more than their basic entitlement and 10 councils, all members of the North Western Municipalities Association, that are penalised by 10 per cent.

It is often argued that the 10 per cent variation is not a significant amount of money. No doubt the proponents of this policy would share the same feeling in regard to a salary cut. The member councils of the North Western Municipalities Association cover 30.7 per cent of the area of the State of Victoria. With the existence of low density population and low rainfall, it is therefore plausible that the region will be served and will have to be served by long lengths of gravel and earthen formations.

These roads serve as a vital link in the provision of the infrastructure to rural industry. The rural properties within the North Western Municipalities Association in 1985-86 were responsible for producing 17.8 per cent of Victoria's gross agricultural production. This Hawke Government has therefore presided over four consecutive years of real road funding decline. It has consistently reneged on its pledge to index fully the hypothecated amount of fuel excise in the old Australian land transport program (ALTP). I am concerned that it will not keep its pledge under the new Australian centennial road development (ACRD) program to index a share of funds to the rate of inflation. Even if this does happen, the Government itself acknowledges that funding for local roads will be maintained only for the first three years of the program and if taken in conjunction with the cut in overall funds, it is clear that other important road categories will be squeezed.

A recent report says reconstruction work on the existing major road network must be doubled by the year 2000 just to keep pace with the growing travel needs and demands of Australians. The Australian Roads Outlook Report prepared by the National Association of State Road Authorities puts into context the issue of road maintenance and road funding. Amongst the findings of the report was that 77 per cent of all domestic freight was moved by road, which highlights the overwhelming importance of road transport to both national and State economies.

Australia's roads are a $100 billion asset-an asset which is ageing and therefore requires a higher level of funding upkeep in order to contain road user costs to acceptable levels. By the turn of the century road travel will increase by more than 50 per cent and the tonne/kilometre freight movement will nearly double. The number of passenger cars and stations wagons is expected to increase by 27 per cent to 10.2 million and, of course, the freight loading itself will increase by two-thirds.

Better roads, therefore, are an immediate and basic need for private motorists and industry. Of course, there is the question of safety. Road crashes claimed 2,755 lives and injured 30,137 people last year. The Federal Government's own Office of Road Safety estimates that they cost Australia almost $5.7 billion in property damage, lost wages, hospital and rehabilitation costs last year. Crashes today are the single largest cause of death for all Australians under 45-not heart disease and not cancer. Since 1980 road crashes have claimed 24,700 lives in this country and a further 247,898 people have been injured.

Mr Deputy Speaker, roads are not just a benefit to the productive sector. All kinds of people and groups benefit. Better roads save lives and reduce injuries. They ease the demands on the health system; they reduce labour, maintenance and fuel costs for business and individuals. They create jobs; they ease the burden of demands on the social security system; they stimulate tourism and, of course, better roads improve the environment. This Parliament, therefore, has a responsibility to address the major contemporary issues involving roads.

The road system is wearing out more rapidly than anticipated under the strain of heavier vehicles and more traffic than ever before and will soon need to be completely redesigned and rebuilt. There is an urgent need to impress the Federal decision-makers that any cuts in road investment will very seriously inhibit Australia's economic interests. Victoria's share of the Federal road funds must be increased to a point where equity is reached between Victoria's contribution to the Federal Treasury and Victoria's justifiable road demands.

Changes in the Australian economy are creating new road demands from an essentially mobile society which are not being met by a suitable and complementary level of road investment. There are many deficiencies in the road system which create heavy added cost to this society, affecting a wide range of programs from tourism to welfare and social communications to the infrastructure for new exports. There is a national disaster taking place before our eyes which, if not corrected, will return transportation and communications in this nation to the eighteenth century.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this debate to raise the issue of consumer indebtedness, an issue which I believe is becoming one of national importance and heading to a point where one might say we have a credit crisis. I express personal concern at the practices of a number of credit providers, practices which in my opinion are causing poverty to tens of thousands of Australians in this country. I am concerned also that because of the moves for deregulation in the marketplace this in fact could become a crisis of such moment that we will have not a few thousand but hundreds of thousands of people affected, unless of course the responsibility can be put very clearly on the lenders.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that consumers have responsibilities-they have very great responsibilities-but it is clear from the practices that are taking place that the lenders, the credit providers, have a special responsibility. It has been estimated that of the 10,000 bankruptcies that are occurring each year, around 70 per cent, are consumer related. They are non-business related, they are involving consumers and almost half of these are being caused because of over-commitment and because people are getting caught up and becoming the guarantors for loans of other people.

It would appear that lenders are lending virtually to anyone. They do not care what the risk is. There is an instant credit arrangement in many stores which I will comment on briefly, but they are just prepared to lend to anyone. It is not a new problem; I accept that. It has been going on for a long, long time. I recall the `dare to be great' groups and the `pyramid' selling groups that would lend, either through banks or finance companies, to anyone to get in this `dare to be great' scheme that was simply selling people. But the problems are immense and we need to place on record the concern of this Parliament.

I had a case brought to me of two adults in their middle twenties. They had an income of $469; they were buying land, and had no equity in it; they were buying a car, again without equity. They had four loans and a total indebtedness of $33,800. They were paying $192 a week or 40 per cent of their income, not counting their rent and other costs that they have. Another family of four, two adults and two children, had a weekly income of $303. Their total debt repayments per week were $156 and then they had to find money for rent. They had three finance company debts; they had two store credit cards. They owed something like $12,000. This is the sort of example that I think is indicative of what is taking place right across the nation.

A young person of 25 years of age owed $7,000 but he had a car refinanced three times. Just imagine that-three times. His income was $150 per week. Another fellow of 22 years of age with an income of $260 had debts of over $7,000 and he was given a personal loan from a bank for a car. Another person of 21 years of age who was unemployed and whose only asset was a car worth about $1,000 owed over $5,000 but had a bank loan refinanced to buy a new car. Another person of the age of 20 was on unemployment benefits with an income of just over $180 per fortnight-per fortnight mind you, because this person was on unemployment benefits-owed $19,000 and has now gone into bankruptcy at 20 years of age. Another person of 18 years of age was working, lost a job and owes $7,000 just on credit cards. This is indicative of the problem that is right across this country, as I said.

Another case concerns an 18-year-old, unemployed youth who was sold a $13,000 second-hand car on no deposit. His monthly repayments were $50 more than his monthly unemployment benefits. He did not have a licence. No identification was sought. He even put his age up to 19 at the time. He lied about working but no check was made and there was no deposit paid on the vehicle. Yet the finance company and the car firm got him into a car worth $13,000, even though he was unemployed. Another case involves a family of two people with three kids, three store credit cards, bank cards, two personal loans with a weekly income of $341, but repayments of $293 including their rent and they still had to buy food, clothing, electricity and so on. Recently they have been given a store credit card.

Another couple purchased a home using building society finance. They had this home valued and a loan approved for $48,000. They paid no deposit and now after a domestic breakup the house has been revalued-and it is only 13 months later-at $27,000. It is sinister, it is evil and it is no wonder we have a crisis.

There have been some in-depth studies carried out right across this country, particularly by the Australian Finance Counsellors Credit Reform Association. A campaign is being waged in Victoria by Tom Roper and others trying to come to grips with this problem. Our own Minister for Consumer Affairs, Senator Bolkus, is also endeavouring to awaken people to the indebtedness crisis but the responsibility must go back to those who are providing this credit. There is a need for this Parliament and for the States to come together and work, as their Ministers are trying to do, to bring down uniform credit laws, to bring about a system of tribunals where these issues can be fought out, also to ensure that there are guidelines and codes of conduct for those in the industry.

As people realise, we have four major lending areas: the banks, the finance companies, the credit unions and also the building societies. I cite a recent case of a fellow in New South Wales on an invalid pension. He had been injured and he got a compensation payment. He used that to buy a house. He got into so much trouble with his debt that he went to a credit union. It gave him $15,000 to consolidate his debts and the repayments were more than the invalid pension he received. The credit union ultimately sold him up.

Cases are coming to me in my role in consumer affairs of stores giving instant credit to young people in the stores. They go to the counter where they can get instant credit. There is no assessment of their performance or capacity to pay. All they need is proof of identity. They fill in a form and sometimes, I am told, and only sometimes, there is a phone check back on the person. It is no wonder that a recent survey carried out in Victoria showed that of all of the young people surveyed some 16 per cent had debts in excess of $12,000. We are talking about young people; we are talking about people 18 and 19 years of age.

It is no wonder that the bankruptcies, and I take Victoria's figures as an example, in the 18 to 25-year age group have jumped from 10 per cent of all bankruptcies in 1984 to almost 17 per cent last year. Our youth in this country are being encouraged to borrow; they are being encouraged to borrow regardless of their capacity to pay. They have been encouraged to get into all sorts of credit cards. There are over 400 different credit cards available in this country and it is no wonder, again, that the consumer debt is now in excess of $23 billion; $23 billion is owed by the families across the nation.

I support the moves for uniform credit laws. I support the tribunals that have been set up in a number of States. I believe there needs to be, however, a low cost tribunal structure similar to Victoria's to allow credit problems to be dealt with very quickly. We need to come to grips with the unjust loans that are being forced upon people-the unconscionable contracts. We need to ensure that people's rights are preserved.

In Queensland a family went in and borrowed money at 21 per cent for a home but because they missed one payment, and were a week behind, that interest rate rose from 21 per cent to 31 per cent and stayed at 31 per cent. They are the sorts of activities that are taking place from some providers, some lenders in this nation. It is time that these lenders rethought their obligations; it is time they took upon themselves a proper duty to consider the capacity of consumers to pay. It is time we had clear codes of conduct that were accepted by all those players in the industry.

It is time, also, that we targeted the schools because we have a generation coming through of people who are going to be borrowers and users of credit. I accept how credit can increase, improve and enhance one's quality of life, but it can turn a family to poverty. It can destroy families. It creates domestic problems that are unbelievable. Then there is a cost on the taxpayer, because when that family breakdown is there, there is a cost in the support systems that governments have to supply. There is a cost of debt recovery and 50 per cent of local court matters relate to recovery of debts.

In Western Australia, I am told, it is higher. As honourable members know, in Western Australia people can actually go to gaol for debt. I am told again that in the last three years something like 120 people have gone to gaol for debt there. So there is a cost we are bearing in the court system, in the health system, in our efforts to try to support children caught up in poverty, trying to provide counselling services for people-a cost that has to be overcome; but we overcome it, I suggest, by attacking the problem.

It is time that the lenders of this nation accepted their responsibility as credit providers. It is time that they accepted that we are going to face a national crisis unless they take on a new integrity in the lending practices that they pursue. We ought not to allow this to continue regardless of the values of having a move towards a deregulated marketplace. There must be protection for the borrowers' money, there must be protection for the users of credit and I would suggest there is a need for a national strategy and a national campaign to endeavour to solve this national crisis.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In today's grievance debate I wish to examine the question of the Australia-Britain relationship, as Britain goes further into Europe and also to reflect on Mrs Margaret Thatcher, the British Prime Minister, and her most successful bicentennial visit to Australia in August of this year. Mrs Thatcher said and did a number of things when she visited this Parliament and World Expo 88. In one of her speeches she said that Britain and Australia have followed divergent paths in the last 20 years and neither of us can neglect our geographic position. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: We in Britain know that a large part of our future lies in Europe, not a united states of Europe but nonetheless, a Europe market by a steadily closer cooperation between separate nation states, each with their own history, traditions and interest.

We agree with that but I think Australia has global interests, and whilst very much of our future lies in the dynamic Pacific rim of the Asian region of the world in terms of trade and economic activity, the world does get smaller every day; the trading world gets smaller every day, the real world gets smaller every day and I think we have to resuscitate our relationship with the United Kingdom. Margaret Thatcher's visit to Australia does offer the opportunity for us to do that. It provides Australia with the opportunity for a re-birth and a re-envigoration of the Australian-British relationship.

Her visit could well herald and be the start of a new era in a new and vibrant relationship, reflecting the good things of the past but taking new things into the future. I would hope that Mrs Thatcher, as she examines the relationship with Australia-as I understand she undertook to do when she went back to the United Kingdom-could take steps and in fact, end the discrimination that exists against Australia in Britain in a number of fields. I hope that this discrimination can end as we grasp this new opportunity for Australia. I think Mrs Thatcher can do much to end the discrimination against us in Europe in the current agricultural policy and I will come to that. But I think that she can take action in England immediately to improve the relationship. I think her visit provides perhaps the last opportunity for Australia to put right the massive discrimination at the government level that does exist in Britain against Australia.
When an Australian arrives in Britain for the first time, he goes through the `Alien Gate'.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is disgraceful.

—It is, and I feel it when I go through the `Alien Gate', as I am sure all Australians do. Australians did not fight in two world wars for freedom and democracy, shoulder-by-shoulder with British soldiers, to be treated as aliens. I think it is unreasonable, unfair and I appeal to Mrs Thatcher to end this discrimination against Australians immediately. We get no credit for having fought side by side. I have recently visited the Somme, I have seen Australian war graves, I have been to Gallipoli. Australians laid down their lives for those same freedoms, but I think those Australians would turn in their graves as their sons, daughters and grandchildren are treated as aliens as they arrive in the United Kingdom.

SPEECH.PARA: Mrs Thatcher is a plain-speaking person and it is time for plain speaking on both sides of this globe. Britain has to remedy these discriminations. Another discrimination is perhaps a small one in many respects, but I think it is massive in others, that Australian students who wish to study at British universities are virtually denied this opportunity. They must be sponsored, have rich parents, make great sacrifices or receive scholarships, because they have to pay three and four times the fees of British students, whereas students in the Common Market can enter British universities almost free. I think it is time for some plain and frank speaking, and I do not see why the German students in the Common Market should be favoured. Germany did lose the Second World War and it is time we raised some of the issues.

Why should the sons, daughters and grandchildren of Australians who fought against Germany be denied access to United Kingdom tertiary institutions and the grandchildren of those against whom they fought have free access? I hope the world has changed, but I do not think it has changed for the better in that respect. The other massive discrimination is one I think Mrs Thatcher acknowledges and recognises and I congratulate her for that, because the United Kingdom, for historical reasons, is a party principal to that massive discrimination against Australia; that is, the Common Market itself and the common agricultural policy which is an aspect of the Common Market. It is very serious, as we move to see Europe, a united states of Europe when the single Act comes into effect at the end of 1992, virtually a united states of Europe, looking inward. Mrs Thatcher is the last hope that that single Act, that that European united states, will relate to the real world and the rest of the world.

I refer to a speech she made at the College of Europe on 20 September this year, because I think it is very significant and it adds to what she said when she was in Australia. She said that the British have in a very special way contributed to Europe. She said that only miles from where she was speaking in Belgium lay the bodies of 120,000 British soldiers who died in the First World War. Had it not been for that willingness to fight and to die, Europe would have been united long before now, but not in liberty and not in justice.

They were Australian troops, Mrs Thatcher, who lay down and died alongside those British soldiers for that freedom and democracy and are now finding that their country for which they fought and died is discriminated against in the United Kingdom. But Mrs Thatcher does give us hope opposite the single Act and opposite the common agricultural policy and the Common Market, because she says the European Community belongs to all its members and it must reflect the traditions and aspirations of those members.

She is quite right when she says that Britain does not dream of some cosy isolated existence on the fringes of the European Community. Our destiny is in Europe as part of the Community. But she says other things. She says: `The Community is not an end in itself, it is not an institutional device to be constantly modified according to the dictates of some abstract intellectual concept'. She acknowledges others, and this is particularly important. She says, `The European Community is a practical means by which Europe can ensure the future prosperity and security of its people, in a world in which there are many other powerful nations and groups of nations'.

Australia is one such nation that I suggest needs acknowledgment in the terms of Mrs Thatcher's recent speech in Europe. Australia is one of these nations. In that speech, I think, she very forcefully, very accurately, very correctly, set out a number of guiding principles in relation to Britain and Europe. I think we in Australia can congratulate her on that; we can endorse those guiding principles, because some of those guiding principles are very applicable and very important to Australia in the world today. She attacks the European bureaucracy. I have been to Brussels on two occasions and the frightening thing about the European Community is that there are bureaucrats living and working in Brussels who are responsible to no-one.

There is no parliament, there is no Westminster system. There is a European Parliament, but all the European Parliament can do is refuse a budget or sack all the commissioners; acts that are not taken lightly. So it is powerless. This bureaucracy is growing up in Brussels, Luxembourg and Strasbourg controlling Europe, taking away powers from individual parliaments; taking away power from the House of Commons and all the other parliaments of Europe.

Mrs Thatcher is the first leader to stand up and recognise that and she is criticised by those same bureaucrats for doing it, but in doing it she is to be congratulated, because she sees a Europe outward looking; one that is prosperous for itself, but in prospering takes into account the needs of other nations so that they can prosper also. Mrs Thatcher does provide us, that strong British leader, in Australia, with the last opportunity, I think, for a new hope for Australia in Europe and a great new opportunity. I say, let Australia accept Mrs Thatcher's offer. Let her be our Trojan Horse. Let us fight alongside her for rights for Australia in Europe. Let us take the step forward together, not only to a better relationship but for a better world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lavarch Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —When Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen was Premier of Queensland he often tried to play up supposed differences between Queensland and the other States and between Queenslanders and the rest of Australians. He did this for political purposes, inasmuch as if Queensland was different, and the National Party was the guardian of this difference, he tried to claim some sort of State nationalism to gain support for the National Party. In this way Queenslanders were urged to equate the National Party with pride or at least consciousness of being a Queenslander.

SPEECH.PARA: One device which the Premier used was to ignore the benefits which the other States adopt on 31 October each year when they go on to a system of daylight saving. Queensland, despite a trial period in 1971, has steadfastly refused in the years since that trial to adopt the system of daylight saving. On 31 October of this year, New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Tasmania will again go on daylight saving time, while both Queensland and Western Australia will remain on pre-daylight saving time scales. The States which have adopted daylight saving are in very fine company. Some 57 countries around the world have adopted daylight saving. These nations include Canada, France, Germany, United Kingdom, parts of the United States, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, parts of China, Argentina, Uruguay and even New Zealand.

Now that Sir Joh is no longer Premier I think it is time for Queenslanders to think again about the issue of daylight saving. One month ago I launched a campaign to bring public focus onto this issue. I tried to outline to Queenslanders the benefits of adopting a system of daylight saving. Those benefits are both economic and in questions of quality of life. The economic issues, put simply, concern savings in power. It must be remembered that initially daylight saving was introduced in Australia at the time of the first and second world wars purely as a saving power measure.

It has been estimated that Queenslanders could save at least several million dollars during the summer months in reduced lighting costs. This has been the experience of both New South Wales and Victoria. It is interesting to note that Queensland has the second highest energy consumption level per capita in Australia. There are considerable advantages to businesses and in direct economic gains for service industries, including sporting clubs and the tourist industry.

It is interesting to note that Mr Keith Williams, a well-known tourist entrepreneur in Queensland, and certainly no friend of the Labor Party, has made a very strong statement in support of daylight saving. In fact, his resorts run on what he calls `island time' which is, in effect, daylight saving. For the rest of Queensland business there is considerable disruption as many Queensland businesses trade with the major centres in New South Wales and Victoria. An hour is lost each morning, an hour is lost each afternoon and there is confusion during the lunch break through which Queenslanders, in effect, are severely disadvantaged.

This disadvantage to Queensland business has been recognised by the Queensland Chamber of Commerce. The President of the Chamber of Commerce, Mr Roger Bryce, again has made a very clear and firm statement that Queensland should adopt daylight saving. Most important, is the issue of family life and the benefits which daylight saving affords. What it basically means is that there are more usable daylight hours for families to spend together. That has significant benefits and I think that in itself is sufficient justification for at least putting to the Queensland public a referendum on this question.

In response to the campaign I started, many thousands of Queenslanders have signed petitions which have been circulating throughout the State. Polls taken by media groups have shown extremely strong support for the concept. As I have indicated, many prominent Queenslanders have made a commitment and this includes the Lord Mayor of Brisbane, Sallyanne Atkinson.

Unfortunately the response of the new Queensland Premier has been to reject the suggestion out of hand. Privately he is understood to support it, but Mr Ahern cannot bring himself out of the shadow of Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen. He is a prisoner of the most conservative elements in Queensland. He is prisoner of those people who have now opposed him.
