DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Human Rights: Columbia-Wollongong City Council-Northfield High School-Alderman Ann Ashwood-Visits by Warships: Industrial Actions-Christine Hill and Helen Gordon-Indonesia-Ocean reef Festival-Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business-Radiation

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Amnesty International's world awareness campaign regarding the deplorable record of political deaths and other human rights violations in Columbia. I do this, not only as a member of the parliamentary group of Amnesty International, but on behalf of the very active Sandringham Chapter of that body in my electorate. Two hundred people disappeared in 1985 after being seized by security forces in Columbia. Over 1,000 are still unaccounted for as at last November; 140 death squads have been publicly identified by the authorities in Columbia, but not one person has been convicted of a political killing. I support very strongly the call by Amnesty International for the Australian Government repeatedly to raise the matter in the United Nations, with the Human Rights Commission of the United Nations, with the Organisation of American States and bilaterally with all governments which might have influence with the Columbian Government.

SPEECH.PARA: We in Australia tend to overlook the importance of South and Central America to us. I think it is very important that there be the maximum public awareness in Australia of the atrocities being perpetrated in Columbia. We must do all that we can as a civilised country to bring pressure to bear on a government which demonstrably is uncivilised and betraying its citizens' welfare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, events in Wollongong during the past week concern me greatly with the election of committee chairpeople and also the Deputy Mayor of Wollongong City Council. It concerns me because of what I perceive to be the growing alliance between the so-called Independents under Frank Arkell, the Lord Mayor, and the Liberal Party of New South Wales. That has been clearly demonstrated by two significant events; one, the appointment of the only Liberal Party alderman on Wollongong City Council to the second most influential chairmanship of a committee; second the appointment of my former opponent in the last election to the position of mall manager in the city of Wollongong.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite clearly there are forces at work within Wollongong City Council and within the Lord Mayor's office that would have Liberal Party and prominent Liberal Party people appointed to positions in Wollongong City Council, either on its staff or within the organisation itself. It is quite interesting to note that, as I understand it, the particular person appointed as the mall manager has nominated to stand against one of our colleagues in the seat of Throsby in the forthcoming federal election in another 18 months time. I find the actions of the so-called Independent-controlled council reprehensible. If they are Liberals in disguise, they should come out and say so and not keep fooling the people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pratt Mr M.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Northfield High School is a remarkable example of initiative and achievement at work in my electorate of Adelaide. Back in the late 1970s a Commonwealth grant from the Liberal government of the day enabled the school to establish a specialist agricultural course. Under the current guidance of principal Ivan Hill, the agricultural course has been so successful that Northfield High has in fact a growing waiting list. The school's standing in the community is so high that it is staging the Australian Bicentennial sheep dog championships this weekend.

SPEECH.PARA: I take this opportunity to congratulate Northfield High School, its council and students for the example they have set the community at large. Unfortunately limited resources allow Northfield High to run its course only to year 11. To extend the agricultural program to the matriculation level the school needs a further four hectares of land. As it happens, the school adjoins the Northfield Agricultural Research Establishment which is in the process of being shut down by the State Government. It is planned that more than 300 hectares of Adelaide's green belt will be turned over to housing development. Despite repeated lobbying, the Bannon Government has turned a deaf ear to pleas that four hectares require to be given to Northfield High School. Environment Minister, Don Hopgood, quick to accuse me of deceit when it was proved that there were drugs in our schools, has danced around the matter on a number of occasions. I stand in this House today to ask the Government to consider a special one-off grant of necessary funds to allow Northfield High to take advantage of this unique opportunity by buying the land from the Bannon Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons Mr D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I live in the City of Bathurst. Bathurst is the oldest inland country city in Australia, going back to 1815. It was actually declared a city in 1885 and it has had a very proud history of local government over that period of time. I was delighted, Mr Deputy Speaker, to learn several weeks ago that Bathurst has a new mayor; in fact the first woman to be a mayor in the City of Bathurst since the declaration of the City of Bathurst in 1885. I take the opportunity to mark the occasion and to place on record the contribution made by Alderman Ann Ashwood as the first woman to be elected to the mayoralty of the Council of the City of Bathurst.

SPEECH.PARA: She has been on the Bathurst City Council since July 1978 and has been re-elected on several occasions since that time. She has chaired a number of committees and, I believe, given her experience on the Council, she will make a very fine mayor indeed for a city that has a very proud record in many aspects, particularly its service as far as local government is concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to voice my concern at the continuing waterfront trade union gangsterlike measures being taken during the present Australian port visits by warships of many nations for the bicentennial naval salute. In particular, I am concerned about actions taken over recent weeks in the ports of Newcastle and Port Kembla and this week in the port of Melbourne, where vessels from Australia, Great Britain, New Zealand, the United States, France and Italy are involved. Ships of the Royal Navy and the United States Navy are being singled out for denial of port services because of their so-called nuclear capability, actions which not only must place at risk the well-being of those on board but also must question the credibility of the Hawke Government which invited them in the first place.

SPEECH.PARA: It is therefore incumbent on the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) and Victorian Premier Cain to overcome the unreasonable industrial actions in Melbourne now and for the Minister for Defence to seek assurances from Premiers Bannon and Dowding that such regrettable and internationally embarrassing situations are not repeated in South Australia and Western Australia in the coming weeks.

Mr Deputy Speaker, whilst a very small but unduly vociferous minority would like to see such port visits discontinue, it is my judgment that the vast majority of thinking Australians welcome these as a measure of international cooperation and mutual understanding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to pay tribute to two women within my electorate-Christine Hill and Helen Gordon-who have taken the opportunity to use the Nursing Mothers Association of Woodridge to offer programs of assertiveness and self-confidence training for women in the area. As honourable members may know, this area is severely disadvantaged and has very little State government infrastructure. It is a city of 130,000; it has no hospital, no public transport and very few services are offered. These two women have taken, through this Nursing Mothers Association, a giant step for the individuals involved.

SPEECH.PARA: They have turned the Association into a support group. They offer personal support and also offer a central focus for the community whereby we, as a community, may give both parents and children in this group support and determination to develop a lifestyle which will make them independent in the long term.

So it is important that we acknowledge the efforts of these two individuals because they are contributing very much to the community as a whole and ensuring that people who have, at some stage, become dependent on us are now living independent, worthwhile and meaningful lives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prosser Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) will visit Indonesia next week during his South East Asian tour. I urge the Minister to raise the concerns of many ordinary Australians in regard to Indonesia's recent attitude towards this country. Indeed, the historical prominence of Australia in this region appears to be under challenge. But apart from the odd whimper we have not come to terms with the muscle flexing that characterises the Indonesians' attitude.

SPEECH.PARA: Without doubt Indonesia is a very important neighbour with which we should have positive and amicable relations. But on what terms? To date the good neighbour attitude has been all one way. For example, the Indonesian Government's responses to a number of recent events have been of great concern. We have seen a procession of Indonesian fishermen blatantly poaching in Australian northern waters and landing on our shores. We have seen an attempt to smuggle illegal immigrants into Australia, and recently, the tragic shooting of a Queensland yachtsman, David Blenkinsop. In the latest incident the Indonesian authorities were prepared yet again to ignore Australia's concerns until the Federal Government finally got dinkum and demanded action. If we are serious about our role and our responsibilities, we have to reassert our leadership with strong and fair policies. Over the last years, Australia has supported Indonesia with development aid totalling more than $300m, with a further $80m this year. Mr Deputy Speaker, quite clearly respect cannot be bought. We have to earn it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to congratulate the Ocean Reef festival coordinating committee. Ocean Reef is a suburb within the city of Wanneroo-a very rapidly growing suburb-and on Sunday last it had its first festival. It was a well organised festival, and I think the leaders deserve praise, certainly from the local people. In particular I want to mention Rudi Steffens, who was chairman of the coordinating committee, as well as Eric Wilson, who is the president of the Ocean Reef Ratepayers Association.

SPEECH.PARA: My own contribution to the festival was to take part in the distribution of prizes to a number of people whose gardens were adjudged the best in the area. I think this is always a worthwhile project, because we do need to cultivate community pride. By the award of certificates of merit and by the award of plaques we can so encourage our community. I wish them well. They propose to continue in the coming years and I am sure they will do well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The attention of this chamber and the electorate at large in recent days has focused on the extraordinary spectacle of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) being reduced to the status of lame duck leader through the efforts of both the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating), and rightly so. The fact that the Prime Minister of this country has been crippled and reduced to lame duck leadership status is of great interest, but he is not the only Minister of this Government who has been reduced to worthlessness.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), for whom, I have to admit, I have a degree of affection. On a personal basis I have no argument with the Minister, but within the political and scientific communities he is held up as a laughing stock, the reason being that he cannot deliver for his constituency, namely, the scientific community. It is being cut and slashed on a daily basis, and what solution does the Minister offer that bedevilled community? It is simply this: another inquiry, an inquiry into research and development, which flies in the face of logic, almost defying belief, given the number of inquiries that have already been printed and distributed to government in recent days.

The poor old Minister for Science has been rolled again. He will be rolled again and again in the future and, sadly, he has hinted in the past that he should resign as the ultimate statement of his failure to service science. I frankly think now is the time for him to fulfil that as a final gesture to the community he is supposed to represent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw the Parliament's attention to an article in the British Medical Journal of 28 May 1988 regarding radiological problems. The article states that the National Radiological Protection Board of the United Kingdom has issued new guidelines on applying protection standards and has recommended individual radiation workers should not be exposed to more than an average of 15 millisieverts a year. This average is less than one-third of the current limit for effective dose equivalent in one year of 50 millisieverts.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to draw to the Parliament's attention the need for Australia to adopt a lower standard for exposure to radiation. Exposure to radiation levels has been dropping over a period of about 50 years, but it still leaves workers in the industries, particularly those in the uranium mining industry, exposed to the dangers that asbestos workers have suddenly found themselves caught up with.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2.00 p.m., in accordance with sessional order 106a, the time for members' statements has concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, before Question Time commences I want to raise with you a matter concerning the conduct of Question Time. Before I begin, on behalf of all members of the Opposition we certainly wish Madam Speaker a speedy return and trust that she has not suffered any injuries as a result of her accident last night. Yesterday during Question Time Madam Speaker ruled out of order two questions that I sought to put to the Acting Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) concerning his alleged approach to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) asking the Prime Minister to resign his leadership of the Government of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask you, Mr Acting Speaker, whether it would be your disposition to rule in a similar fashion as the Speaker if those questions were again addressed to the Acting Treasurer today during Question Time. If it is your disposition to rule in the same manner as did Madam Speaker yesterday-and you, I gather, were present during Question Time yesterday, so you would be familiar both with the substance of the question and the nature of Madam Speaker's response-would you be good enough to inform me and the House of the circumstances under Standing Orders, as you see them, which prevent members from questioning Ministers on matters similar to those I raised yesterday? I put it to you that it is, to say the least, a matter of supreme public importance that a senior Minister in this Government should have asked the head of this Government to resign his position as the head of the Government and it passes our understanding how we are denied the opportunity of questioning the Minister regarding the accuracy of those reports.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr ACTING SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding of the Standing Orders is that Ministers can be questioned on matters to do with their administration and matters for which they are responsible to the Parliament, not matters of a personal nature or conversations that they may have had outside of their area of responsibility to the Parliament. I would take the same view, as I recall the Speaker's view yesterday, that questions along the lines of those asked yesterday would not be in order.

INTERJECT.PARA: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, in light of your ruling I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the questioning by members of this House of the Acting Treasurer regarding the conversation he had with the Prime Minister in which he advised the Prime Minister that it was his view the Prime Minister should resign so that the Treasurer might take his place.
I raise this as an important matter--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, I raise a point of order. The substance of this matter was raised by way of censure motion yesterday and the matter was resolved by a vote of the House. The procedure now being sought constitutes a reflection on a decision of the House; it is plainly out of order and I ask you so to rule.
—Order! There is no point of order. It is within the wish of the House, if it so desires, to suspend Standing Orders to deal with the matter.

—In concurring with the ruling you have just given, Mr Acting Speaker, can I explain to the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Holding), whose knowledge and understanding of this Parliament is still so obviously inadequate, that we seek to ensure that the circumstances on which you have ruled and on which Madam Speaker has ruled are such that we can proceed to a line of questioning of the Acting Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) which we believe is important from the point of view of public knowledge. As you know, Sir, and you referred to it in your ruling, standing order 142 relates to the manner and form of questions that can be directed to Ministers. That standing order reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Questions may be put to a Minister relating to public affairs with which he is officially connected, to proceedings pending in the House, or to any matter of administration for which he is responsible.

It would have been possible for us to dissent from your ruling or in some way seek another interpretation, but we simply put it that there is no more important issue relating to public affairs, which is the first of the three areas about which questions may be directed. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is sitting there smirking. I wonder whether his colleagues are smirking to the same degree.

The reason we must suspend Standing Orders is that the people in the gallery and those elsewhere in Australia want to know why the Acting Treasurer asked the Prime Minister to stand down. Did the campaign director for the Treasurer (Mr Keating) go along to the Prime Minister and say, `Look, we are all buddy pals together. We are all a happy band of brothers. We would like you to stay there.'? No, he did not. The reason Standing Orders must be suspended is that it is important that the people at large know why the Acting Treasurer said, `You, my friend, need to stand down'.

The Prime Minister is the senior office-bearer in the Australian Parliament. Our Constitution requires that after an election the person who is in a position to command a majority in this Parliament go along to the Governor-General and say, `I am in a position to exercise a majority in the House of Representatives'. We are getting to the position where Old Silver cannot exercise that majority. `Hi ho, Silver', I said yesterday.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the National Party--

—I withdraw the remark, Mr Acting Speaker. The Prime Minister has a concern that he can demonstrate to the Governor-General that he has a majority. With the campaign director for the Grim Reaper out there at work, there is a problem. The Prime Minister's majority is beginning to fail within Caucus. We know how the left wing regards the Prime Minister. We know that within the factions of the Australian Labor Party a few of those aspirants for power whose bark is more significant than their bite would love to be Ministers in that rather inept, incompetent group sitting behind the Prime Minister. Yesterday seven Ministers were absent during Question Time and today the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) and the Treasurer-the power base of the Government-are away from the Parliament. We know the Treasurer is overseas; he has addressed the International Monetary Fund and is paying back a little bit of debt; meanwhile, back home the Australian taxpayer knows his gross indebtedness is growing. I wonder what will be the September balance of payments figure.

SPEECH.PARA: Standing Orders must be suspended because we wish to ask the Acting Treasurer why he wants the Prime Minister to go. That is what it is all about. Members of the Government can laugh. We sat here all through yesterday without getting any answers. This is a pretty good headline in the Australian, and it poses the questions we want the answers to. It says:
Perhaps Keating will go-maybe there will be another reshuffle-the only certainty is uncertainty.

We want to ask the Acting Treasurer questions pertaining to his dinner meeting, about that Chinese meal. Did they use chopsticks? Were they talking about Old Silver, or the Grim Reaper; were they talking about the power play? Where does Simon Crean come into it? Whose seat is Simon Crean going to take over?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, I raise a point of order. What on earth has this to do with the matter before the House? This is a rerun of what was said yesterday. This is a nonsense and a disruption of Parliament.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—You have ruled that there is no point of order, Mr Acting Speaker, and the people of Australia have a right to know the answers to these questions. That is what this is about. We want Standing Orders suspended so the Acting Treasurer can properly answer questions. We moved two motions yesterday. The Acting Treasurer has not responded to them. We asked two questions in this place yesterday. Both were ruled out of order. The Acting Treasurer has a responsibility to this place to say just why he did that. Can he read? We got it blown up. He is getting a bit old; he needs glasses. Can he read? `Why Dawkins and Hawke have split'. The article says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . he felt obliged to tell Hawke to his face what he was saying to others.
I do not really think that anyone in the Australian public would doubt that that is really what it is about: `Why Dawkins and Hawke have split'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I might draw everyone's attention to the fact that newspapers should not be read in the House. We will have some order in the House.

—I know that the Government is embarrassed about the issue, and this is not a laughing matter. The people of Australia have a right to know. The Prime Minister laughs and carries on and pretends to be a friend. We believe that this is an important matter relating to public affairs. Mr Acting Speaker, you have advised the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) today that he cannot ask a question on the matter. We were advised yesterday by your colleague Madam Speaker on two occasions that questions were out of order. My colleague the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) yesterday morning asked the Acting Treasurer to come into the House and make a statement telling us why he made those comments that were reported as a result of that dinnertime discussion between Paul Kelly and himself at a Chinese restaurant in the city. We moved for the suspension of Standing Orders yesterday afternoon. The Acting Treasurer responded. He did not deny the article. He confirmed the article. He confirmed that he wants the Prime Minister to go.

SPEECH.PARA: There is little doubt that of all the prime matters relating to public affairs there is none more important than how long the lame duck Prime Minister is going to sit in that seat. There is no doubt that there is nothing more important. We know that the Grim Reaper, who is enjoying the perks and lurks of his journeys abroad, is going to come back and get the backing of the numbers. The reality is that this is an important matter relating to public affairs and the only way by which we can ask questions, the only way we can get an answer from the Acting Treasurer, is for the Standing Orders to be suspended. Instead of smiling, instead of trying to move away from answering the question, the Acting Treasurer can in fact respond. Why did he ask the man at the front to step down? Why does he no longer have any confidence in the Prime Minister? Why is he backing the Treasurer to take over his office? Is it just his personal ambition? Is it just that he wants to be Treasurer? Or does he really believe, as do most Australians, that the Prime Minister is no longer competent, that the Prime Minister no longer has the confidence of the members of this House? It is important that our Standing Orders permit the man who now seeks to interject to get on his feet and respond properly to questions we want to direct to him on important matters of public affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The right honourable member's time has expired. Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion, Mr Acting Speaker. There are three components primarily to this Parliament, notwithstanding the views of many that it is a place of only Opposition and Government business. The third component just happens to be the people of Australia. The people of Australia have many rights in this place and the first right they have through their elected membership is the right to know. They are entitled to be reassured when issues are raised in our media and, as has occurred in this case, they have not been denied. Notwithstanding the opportunities offered yesterday morning to the Acting Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) by the Opposition, when we gave him the opportunity through suspension of Standing Orders to explain to us clearly his attitude to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and, more importantly, the opportunity to deny that such a meeting ever took place, to deny that he did not personally leak that information to the media and notwithstanding giving him the opportunity to come forward and give us an answer during a censure motion, he was about as forthcoming with information during that censure motion as he usually is with his tax accountant. He told us nothing.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue for the people is to know whether or not the facts on the disruptions that have now been reported in the media are to be given to the people of Australia. In truth, that is a real problem. Let us get back to some of the other reasons why people need to know. It would be interesting if the back bench members of the Australian Labor Party were entitled to know. It was very clear from looking at their faces yesterday that the first they knew about it was when they looked at the newspaper and saw Paul Kelly's article. We have a Treasurer (Mr Keating) and an Acting Treasurer with arrogant disregard for their lame duck Prime Minister. They want him out. The people of Australia do not know what is going on and the opportunities that are available are being ignored. We might ask, if the Government is so confident, if this is not a real problem within its ranks, why it is that again the Opposition has to give the Acting Treasurer the opportunity to talk about it. Why is he so embarrassed? Why is he ducking the issue? He is ducking the issue because, fact No. 1, the Acting Treasurer on the twenty-ninth did go and tell his Prime Minister, `It is time you went'.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you know?

—I know quite simply because he has now had 24 hours to deny it, and we know how quickly he would deny it if he thought he had an ounce of opportunity of getting away with it. He knows very clearly. We had the Acting Treasurer telling us yesterday, `You don't believe everything you read in the newspapers'. Why did he not just stand up and say, `I didn't ever go to the Prime Minister'? Why did he not deny it, like the Treasurer, who completely disregarded reports of a very insulting telephone call between himself and Senator Richardson about our Prime Minister? Why? Because, firstly, it happened; and, secondly, they do not care. They do not care about the extent to which they embarrass the Prime Minister and they will go on doing it as part of a campaign to get rid of him. The point about all this is--
—Where is the proof?
—Did the Minister ask where the proof is?
—Yes.

—Where is his denial? Why would he not do it? He came in here and denied that he was a tax cheat. He denied that he was a tax cheat time and again. He was pretty quick to do that. This time he will not deny it because it is true. It is true and he does not care. He has no respect for his Prime Minister-probably even less than does the Treasurer. He wants his job; he is determined to have it. More importantly, in speaking to this motion, the matter must be resolved in the public interest. Section 142 is clear. It says that the Minister is responsible for matters relating to public affairs with which he is officially connected. He clearly thought he was officially connected with the campaign to get rid of the Prime Minister. He went and told him to leave, and he is the self-appointed campaign manager for the Treasurer. As such we offer him the opportunity: Stand up like a man and take it. Or is he going to hide behind Standing Orders?
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, we will of course not be suspending Standing and Sessional Orders for this ridiculous little motion the Opposition has got together. There is a leadership problem in this House but it is not addressed by the substance of the motion. It is not a leadership problem that arises out of the fact that, after a period of 5 1/2 years in office, we have on this side of the House the most popular, well respected and trusted Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that, historically, this country has had. The leadership problem, and this motion is a reflection of it, lies in the fact that on the Opposition side we have a leader who is out of control of his Party. Do not think that we do not know what goes on in the Opposition's parliamentary tactics meetings. We do. We know very well that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has opposed this line of activity-in this instance sensibly, almost uniquely-because he recognises how ridiculous he looks in this Parliament standing up here and moving what is effectively a dissent motion from Speaker's ruling yesterday, which is when he should have moved that dissent motion.

SPEECH.PARA: All that the Opposition has done is to confess to the pathetic nature of its parliamentary tactics. The Opposition is absurd. It has been demonstrated to be absurd not only on this occasion but also in regard to all the other parliamentary tactics that it has designed to disrupt the proceedings of this House. The time has come for the Opposition to look seriously at whether its parliamentary tactics ought to be run by the competent people on its front bench, such as the official Manager of Opposition Business, the honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife), or whether it wants this perambulating idiocy from the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) to persist as the style of dealing with Opposition front bench business for time foreseeable; and it will be for a very long time indeed.

It is absurd to hear the honourable member for O'Connor ask the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) whether he ought to make some public comments about what are alleged to have been his views about his Leader when we look at the published views of the honourable member for O'Connor about his Leader. He was asked by the Northern Advocate, that devastating journal of political investigation, whether he had any nice comment to make about his Leader. He first asked the journal, `Can we give this off the record?'. The Northern Advocate said that it would be on the record. When the honourable member learnt that it would be on the record he had nothing to say. That is helpful as far as the Opposition is concerned, because even though his opinion of his Leader is obviously totally contemptuous-which is why this motion is before us, against his Leader's advice-other members of the Opposition in leading positions are not quite so unforthcoming on the public record.

Another thing that the Opposition might learn at its parliamentary tactics meetings is that when an Opposition member has something to raise in the House, he should make sure that he is a clean skin and that no-one on the other side of the House has anything to wave at the same time. If Opposition members had done a bit of reading this morning, instead of being involved in an Opposition tactics committee meeting, in their own little whirlpool of fatuousness, they might have taken time to read the views of the Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate (Senator Stone). What did he write today about the quality of conservative leadership in this country? I suppose that he has a view not only about the Leader of the Opposition but also about the Leader of the National Party of Australia. Senator Stone said:
People today wish to vote conservative-
that is a view with which we on this side of the House would not necessarily agree, but it is a lead-in that might be expected-

However, they will not vote for parties which they perceive to be poorly led; in particular, they have no intention of exchanging any reasonably moderate Labor government for a Liberal, or Liberal-National alternative led by someone who, for whatever reason, commands no respect (as distinct, however, from popularity).
He then qualified his remark slightly by saying:
Thus the key lesson of Victoria is that you can't win with losers.
Indeed, that is true.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—That was said by the Leader of the National Party in the Senate, a person who takes a leading position in the affairs of the coalition. How can the Leader of the National Party in this place bring forward this sort of proposition with these sorts of remarks hanging over his head? It is not just a problem for John Howard's leadership; it is a problem for the Leader of the National Party. What does he lead? His equivalent in the Senate is capable of writing something like that about conservative leadership in this country in which he referred not only to the Leader of the Opposition but also to the Leader of the National Party. He could not have been more specific: the Leader of the National Party is incompetent. That is what he has said. The Leader of the National Party is not only unpopular; he is incompetent. He is unprincipled and incompetent, yet he has the hide to suggest in this place that we have something to explain on the leadership issue.
—Mick Young would have been into the jokes by now.

—I do not have to be a Mick Young to deal with honourable members opposite. That is one thing that I have learnt pretty rapidly over the last few months. A former secretary to the Leader of the Opposition, on a recent radio program, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I think it's unwise to consider the Coalition's problem of both parties is only a leadership problem.
We think that it is fairly wise, but he thinks that it is a bit unwise to say that that is the only issue. He continued:

It goes much deeper than that. There's a problem of leadership succession. There's a problem of front bench performance. There's a problem of backbench performance. There's a problem of party administration performance. There's very deep-seated problems and the discussion whether from Senator Chaney or anyone else about the leadership issue really confuses the real issue, which goes much more deeper than leadership.

Indeed, it does, as the Opposition's parliamentary tactics today confirms. I ought to make one or two other points about the way in which the Opposition conducts its parliamentary tactics. Ever since it has given the honourable member for O'Connor a bit of a run in this place it has just put itself into one ridiculous position after another. This is only the latest formation. Honourable members opposite have had something to say about whether we answer enough questions. It made a complaint about whether parliamentary business was being allowed to proceed in a sensible, normal fashion. Let me point out a few statistics: in 1982-at the high point of the discussion of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, we, then in opposition, showed the then Government how an Opposition could operate, which the present Opposition has never managed to achieve in the 5 1/2 years in which it has been in that position-61 points of order were taken during Question Time. The reason that we did not have to rely on points of order was that we raised matters of substance which were very different from the matters raised by the present Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Dawkins on tax.
—Last year, when the Leader of the National Party was in control of Opposition tactics, 144 points of order were taken during Question Time.
—Total hypocrisy.
—I warn the honourable member for O'Connor.

—A change of about three. The Opposition's tactics in this place have been disruptive, and nothing else. Why? The answer is simple: the Opposition has no policies and no leadership. The only resort for an opposition that cannot ask questions in this place, that cannot dispute matters in this place, is to try to disrupt the parliamentary proceedings. Consistently, over the last few months, honourable members opposite have challenged the Speaker's authority. They have consistently reflected on the Chair. What amazes me about the performance today, given their past record of disorderly behaviour, is that they did not take theopportunity to raise this as a matter of question-ing--

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Spender interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I warn the honourable member for North Sydney.

—As a matter of questioning the way in which the Speaker made her interpretation of those affairs yesterday. The fact that they have not done so gives a pretty fair indication of how far behind the game they are. They are absolutely absurd. Their tactics today have continued that absurdity. As I look at the glum faces of back bench Opposition members as they contemplate years and years in opposition ahead of them, we on this side of the House develop a certain degree of sympathy for their agony, but not enough for me to allow this ridiculous nonsense to continue.

—Will the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce inform the House what new initiatives the Government has taken to ensure that unnecessary existing business regulations are removed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Fowler for his question. As announced in the Prime Minister's speech to the Business Council of Australia on Tuesday night, the Federal Government has introduced a major new initiative to ensure that unnecessary existing business regulation is removed. Business or professional associations, unions and interested groups or individual firms will be able to apply to have a case heard for review if there are regulations that they consider unreasonable.

ANSWER.PARA: The initiative is essentially a request/response procedure. In the past we have introduced procedures which minimised both the introduction and the costs of new regulation. Already Cabinet has agreed that the Business Regulation Review Unit may require departments wishing to develop new regulations to produce a regulation impact statement. New regulations may contain sunset provisions and, wherever possible, laws must be expressed in simple English. In the past the Government has set its own priorities for the review of existing regulation. The new procedure will allow business and other interested groups to put forward their points of view.

Guidelines elaborating on the requests will be developed by the Government in consultation with business associations and other concerned groups. It is expected that the submissions for review will identify the body of regulation concerned and the nature of the problem-for example, excessive complexity, overlap or duplication or administrative burden-quantify the costs imposed by the regulations concerned, indicate the extent of consultation on and support for the proposed review and, most important, propose solutions.

TALK.START.PARA: —No one believes you.

—But we actually do it. No government has done more than this Government to address the problems of business, to restructure the economy. It is interesting to go back to the period between November 1985 and March 1983 to find out what the mob opposite ever did about the economy. What did they do about restructuring?

—Mr Acting Speaker, I take a point of order. The section in Standing Orders relating to questions refers to government policy and is clearly put in there for the purpose of stopping Ministers making statements during Question Time and consequently avoiding the appropriate response from the Opposition. This is a gross waste of Question Time. I would ask you to follow the precedent set by previous Speakers and ask the Minister to bring his answer to a close and to use the appropriate forums of the Parliament.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—This will of course mean a much greater degree of public scrutiny on the need for regulation. But it puts the onus where it ought to be-on business itself. Business cannot just moan and groan. Business has to be able to document what the problem is, make it specific and then put the case for the removal of regulation.

ANSWER.PARA: Requests for such reviews will be coordinated by the Commonwealth's Business Regulation Review Unit. Those requests which are considered to be sufficiently substantiated will be forwarded to the responsible Minister, who then will be required to seek agreement from the Structural Adjustment Committee of Cabinet to any proposed response. A time limit of two months has been set for the initial response, which will be extended in the event of a detailed review being considered necessary. In conducting the reviews, the resources of independent agencies such as the Industries Assistance Commission, the Inter-State Commission or the various research bureaus may be employed. This procedure has advantages over earlier alternatives in being priority driven. But it puts the opportunity squarely in front of business. If business wants to take it up, it ought to take advantage of it.

I repeat what I interpolated before: this Government has done more in its 5 1/2 years in office to create a more favourable business environment and to create the opportunity for business to reach its full potential than was ever done before. I cannot imagine what those opposite ever did in the 7 1/2 years they were in government. Their record in industrial restructuring and in strengthening the economy was pathetic.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Did the Minister have prior knowledge of the intention of the Secretary of his own Department to take action in his capacity as Acting Commissioner of the Aboriginal Development Commission against the Chairman and the General Manager of the ADC at the meeting of the Commission in Adelaide this week?
—No.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. What progress has there been in award restructuring, and what specific measures is the Government undertaking within its own programs to assist this process?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say at the outset that this program of award restructuring in workplace reform is one of the most important and fundamental initiatives ever undertaken by any Australian Government. The purpose of that program is to remove inefficiencies and inequities that have been created by existing award arrangements, to improve labour market flexibility and productivity and, essentially, to ensure that Australian products and Australian services become more competitive, both at home and abroad.

ANSWER.PARA: I should quote to the House the progress that is being made. The objective in the metals industry is to reduce some 350 job classifications to about eight levels. This involves training and multiskilling for the work force and change in the workplace. But that change will take place with the involvement and participation of the employees themselves. In essence, what we want to achieve is a safer, more secure and satisfying work-place and jobs that have career paths for the employees involved. The reception that has been given to this program by industry and by the trade union movement has been, in my view, nothing less than enthusiastic. There has been a very good response. I have been surprised at the strength and support which have come in particular from leaders of industry and the manner in which they are progressing through the difficult negotiations that are involved in a change of this kind.

I can say to the honourable member, who I note has taken an interest in this subject in the past, that, unlike the Opposition, we approach this matter on a tripartite basis. Industry, the work force and government are working together in cooperation to achieve change of a magnitude that has never happened in the workplace in this country before. It is the kind of change that is needed if this country is to become competitive, both at home and abroad. The three industries that stand out in this process are the metal trades, textiles, clothing and footwear industry and vehicle building. I am confident that the progress that is being made will bring significant results.

A package which we have in place and which was announced earlier in the Budget Papers includes, in part, the new Industrial Relations Bill. In this respect I want to pay a tribute to my colleague the Minister for Transport and Communications, the former Minister for Industrial Relations. That Bill finally passed through the Senate last night after a long period of difficulty and I hope it will be in this place on Monday afternoon. It will then pass through this chamber. An amount of $3.9m has been allocated for the new workplace reform package. That package has as a key feature a workplace resources scheme, a work change support scheme and an industrial participation training scheme. In addition to that, a comprehensive workplace industrial relations survey is being undertaken to provide essential information in this area for the first time in the history of this country.

So, overall, I can say to the honourable member that this legislation is the first of its kind, and this package is the most important that has ever been put forward in the process of industry reform by any government in this country. The objectives are going to be achieved because of the cooperative approach by this Government, by the industries themselves, by the work force and by the trade unions involved.
