DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr ACTING SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The crippling effect of the Government's economic policies on Australians trying to buy their own homes.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Members of this House know that housing is at the very essence of Australian society. The quality of housing, its price and its availability are fundamental measures of the living standards of the people of our country. Yet, last night, 50,000 people slept outside or in refuges. That is twice as many people as did in March 1983. Thousands more Australians today, this week, are unable to afford to buy their own homes or in some cases are threatening to sell their own homes because they can no longer afford the mortgage repayments on those houses. They cannot afford the growing burden of interest rates. This tragedy in the housing industry is another example of the way over the last 5 1/2 years the living standards of people in Australia have gradually fallen.

SPEECH.PARA: Since March 1983 the higher home ownership costs in Australia have added in real terms a burden of $14 a week to the average family, that is, $14 a week on top of the $56 a week decline in real living standards that the Opposition has so accurately calculated. When we look at the statistics as to why there has been this enormous increase in the cost of housing in Australia we can see how truly tragic the story really is. The cost of buying a house in Australia has nearly doubled since 1983. In 1984 the average monthly home loan repayment was $335. In 1988 the average is $620-a massive increase. The real estate industry survey of home loan affordability once more tells the tragic story of what has happened to the living standards of home owners in this country. The average Australian family in 1983 was paying 18 per cent of household income for its home. In 1988 it is paying 28.4 per cent of that family income and in New South Wales the figure is an incredible 34.3 per cent of family income. That is a 58 per cent increase in costs taken as a proportion of household income over the last 5 1/2 years. We can see from those figures that living standards using housing as a measure have plunged since March 1983.

The Commonwealth Bank-Housing Industry Association study of average annual family disposable income needed in order to get a home loan reveals some fascinating figures. The study estimated that the average family's disposable income is about $34,500 a year. Yet that family needs $39,500 a year to qualify for a loan for the average family house-an enormous difference and a demonstration again of how fewer and fewer people in this country are able to afford decent housing. Of course, these statistics do not come as a dramatic surprise to us on this side of the House. We have seen the way interest rates have risen. Home loan interest rates have risen in particular from 11 1/2 per cent when Labor came to power to 14 1/2 per cent. Indeed, in the case of some banks the figure is 15 per cent, particularly in the case of Citibank Ltd in Melbourne.

We know there is continuing upward pressure today on home loan interest rates. We said before the Victorian election that after that election home loan interest rates would go up. The Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples), who is at the table, said they would not. The next week the State Bank of South Australia and Citibank both increased their home loan interest rates. This morning on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation news we heard that the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, which has so many home lenders, is considering increasing its home loan interest rates in the near future. Many building societies have said the same thing. Many economists and many financial institutions have said there is a real danger that home loan interest rates will rise even beyond their current level. If they rise by one per cent that will impose yet another burden, in this case of $45 a month, on the average home loan. The reason that interest rates have risen so much and the reason that home owners have been discriminated against by this Government is that interest rate management has been almost the sole instrument of its economic policy. It is very well if one is sitting in the executive wing of this grand building and dictating as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) does that interest rates might go up a bit in order to help us resolve our balance of payments problems. But it is not all right if you happen to be living in the suburbs of Australia trying to afford the mortgage repayments or, worse still, it is not all right for a young married couple desperately trying to buy their first home.

One of the consequences, of course, of using interest rates as an instrument of economic policy and thereby forcing up costs to home owners, is that more people cannot afford to buy their own home and that leads to longer queues of the homeless. Today 600,000 people in Australia are simply without a home. The public housing waiting lists alone in this country have risen in the last five years from 120,000 to nearly 180,000 people. In Australia 160,000 people at the moment are living in caravan parks. Some of them live in them out of choice but most of them live in them because they cannot afford to buy their own home or because they cannot get into public housing as a result of the long waiting lists. As I have said already, 50,000 people just last night slept outside or in homeless refuges, which is twice as many as five years ago. If ever there was an indication of falling living standards, of a tragedy of living standards in this country, that is the clearest demonstration anybody could give.

This, of course, does not apply to every member of the Australian Labor Party. It was revealed yesterday that one member of the Labor Party, Senator Devlin from Tasmania, is somebody who apparently is not suffering a housing problem. Senator Devlin has a household income of some $80,000 a year. That is his back bench salary as a member of the Senate. In addition to that, his wife has an income as a member of his electoral staff. Senator Devlin rents a Housing Department house for $74 a week in the town of Burnie. He pays $74 a week! How many people in Burnie are waiting for public housing? There are 400 people in Burnie wanting public housing. Senator Devlin is taking a house from one of those families. There are 900 people in north-west Tasmania waiting for public housing and Senator Devlin is taking a house or a unit from one of those families. It is a matter of shame for the Labor Party that one of its members should treat with such contempt those who do not have housing. Yet, the statistical record of the Government over the last 5 1/2 years just indicates how inevitably that must have been the case. The Labor Party has an almost ideological opposition to the concept of home ownership. It has an obsession against home ownership.

Look at what it has done with its first home owners scheme, which is a scheme to help people purchase their first homes. We just have to look at the figures. In 1984-85 it spent $300m on the scheme; in 1988-89, $178m-a massive decline; and by 1990-91, only $146m. Providing less and less money for people who want to purchase their own homes, as interest rate burdens go up and as the cost of housing goes up, is the worst thing any government could possibly do.

But we know just from looking at the words of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that this Government is not really serious about the whole philosophy of Australians owning their own homes. I really was not surprised to read some words of the Prime Minister in the Adelaide Advertiser of a couple of weeks ago. This is what was in the Advertiser:

. . . faced with a recent report that 60 p.c. of Australians may soon be able to afford to buy their own home, Mr Hawke added his support to those who argue increasing housing prices and interest rates could see Australia finally joining a worldwide trend in which most people rent their homes.

So the Prime Minister has just surrendered. He does not care. The Government will not bother any more about people owning their own homes. It is not part of the Labor Party's philosophy or ideology. It is trying to force more and more people into dependency, into public housing and into renting their own homes. It does not matter if they cannot buy them. That is why this Government is cutting out the first home owners scheme. That is why it does not care about using interest rates as its sole instrument of economic policy. That is why it does not care about the increasing proportion of people's income which is just being absorbed by high interest rates on their home loans and the high cost of housing. The consequence of it all is that this Government's housing policies and its approach to such a fundamental indicator of people's living standards have become little more than a shambles.

I thought that Senator Walsh made an extraordinarily revealing remark back in June which once more confirmed what the Prime Minister said in the quote I read from the Advertiser. He said that Australia spends far too much money on housing. Actually, we spend less than the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development average, but Senator Walsh does not care. This Government is saying, `Let us spend less money on housing. Let us get people out of their own homes. Let us make them dependent'.

To give the Government its due, at least it has come up with one recent initiative. But will this initiative raise living standards or will it lower them? We discover that it will lower them. The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) has announced that the Government has a new housing scheme whereby people will be able to get smaller houses on smaller blocks and they will be able to save $15,000 on the purchase of such houses. In other words, if we reduce the quality of housing people might be able to buy a house. That is the Government's latest policy. That is its latest offering, which we had last week. Lower living standards mean worse housing, and that is what this Government advocates. So, as costs and interest rates rise the Government's solution is to give people smaller houses on smaller blocks of land with less space and repeated statements that the Australian dream of owning one's own home with one's own backyard is something of the past. If ever there was an indication of how the living standards of ordinary Australians are falling, that approach from the Government, which confirms their feelings, is it.

The Government's housing policy has become nothing more than a shambles, and the Government itself recognises this. It has had about 28 different housing policies in the last 5 1/2 years, which is quite a few, and the Minister is now reviewing all of the Government's housing policies. He would not be reviewing those housing policies if he thought that they were an enormous and overwhelming success. So, all sorts of left wing academics around Australia are being sent off to come up with new schemes which will somehow provide for more public housing. There will not be any solutions that will provide for an extension of home ownership such as the one the State Government in New South Wales is trying to offer; there will not be anything of that sort coming from Canberra. There will be more of the philosophy of dependency, more of the economics of higher interest rates, more of the economics of higher home purchase costs and nothing at all for the living standards of ordinary people.

We have seen a whole series of disasters which have done so much damage to ordinary people. We saw the great negative gearing fiasco which led to a total collapse in the private rental market. People just were not prepared to build rental accommodation any more. To give the Government its due, it admitted that it was wrong; but the housing industry will say again and again that that decision by the Government in the first place to take away negative gearing had a catastrophic effect on that market. So did the capital gains tax. The industry will also tell honourable members of the devastating effect that that has had on the private rental market. It is picking up again; but it is not picking up as it should, because those statistics that I have read out already only confirm the failure of those policies-the 50,000 people who had to sleep out last night, the 600,000 people who have no home at all, the 180,000 people who are on the public housing waiting lists and all those Australians who are facing higher and higher costs even if they have been able to purchase their own homes. If ever there was an indicator, that is a clear indicator of living standards in this country plunging for everybody-with the sole exception of Senator Devlin from Tasmania.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr STAPLES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Housing and Aged Care)

TALK.START.PARA: —The shadow Minister for housing, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), has expressed to this House his great concern for those on public housing waiting lists and the homeless in Australia today. Members of the Opposition are now telling us that public housing and rental accommodation should be cut for those with the lowest incomes in Australia who cannot afford to buy their own homes. The Opposition, when in government, did not have any scheme which was effective enough to cope with the need for crisis accommodation or the needs of those needing supported accommodation. Where was its crisis accommodation program? Where was its supported accommodation assistance program (SAAP)? They did not exist. The Opposition, when in government, had a whole lot of pilot programs which were scattered across the country. It had no real or substantial program such as the Commonwealth State Housing Agreement that has been operating in this country since it was brought in by this Government in 1984.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the record relating to home ownership. Home ownership in Australia was lower in the 1981 census than it was in the 1986 census. That is a national fact. And that was at a time of inordinately high growth in households. I will come back to that later. Under the previous coalition Government, first home buyers were assisted under the home deposit assistance scheme and a special tax rebate was available. Neither of those schemes was well targeted. Many people received assistance to buy their first home, but they did not need it. This Government introduced the first home owners scheme and it has been accepted, I believe, by honourable members on both sides of the House, by the industry, and certainly by the community as one of the great achievements in assisting people into home ownership. The first home owners scheme is far better targeted than anything that was created by honourable members opposite.

Seventy per cent of beneficiaries have incomes below average weekly earnings. More than $1,300m has been approved since the inception of the first home owners scheme and that has assisted over 300,000 households. That is a considerable number of people. In fact, all the home ownership and housing assistance programs of this Government have assisted a total of about 1.4 million people which is equivalent to the whole of the population of SA, the home State of the honourable member for Mayo, or to the total population of the city of Perth. That is a considerable number of Australians who have been assisted into home ownership or into living in their own homes in Australia. The Opposition wants to chop it all to ribbons. We have a high level of home ownership in Australia because we now have, under the deregulatory financial policies of this Government, a very large supply of housing finance available.

In the three months to June 1988, secured housing finance commitments by all significant lenders was $6.5 billion. In March 1986 when total regulation applied the figure was $1.9 billion. In terms of the number of dwelling commencements, the honourable member for Mayo was very keen to point out the problems in the industry. In 1982-83 when the coalition left government, how many commencements were there? There were 105,000. Over the period of this Government the figure has consistently been well over 120,000 or 130,000. The honourable member knows very well what the state of the industry is today, yet the honourable member is challenging us to believe that we are now in a state of crisis. How many commencements are expected for next year? Over 150,000 commencements are expected. So much for the crisis. What happened in the period in which the Opposition was in government? The number of commencements has risen from 105,000 to almost 150,000 since we have been in government. That is the difference.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ask the welfare groups about the crisis.
—Order! The honourable member will not interject. He was heard in silence. He should extend the same courtesy to the Minister.

—We have a better housing situation than was the case when the Opposition was in government because this Government has taken a total, across the board approach to housing. We have not just considered home ownership, which this Government totally supports, but we have looked right across the board at the public housing rental sector and at the private rental sector. We have also taken into consideration the first home owner who is at the point of interface between private rental and home ownership. No-one in this House can seriously challenge the overall success of those policies.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Mayo expressed concern about public housing. Let us look at the Opposition's record in public housing. Let us look at its concern for working people on low incomes for pensioners and for social security beneficiaries. When the Opposition left government its expenditure on public housing, in real terms, amounted to $1.7 billion. We have increased that to $5.3 billion. In 1987-88 the Federal Government made a total commitment of $1.114 billion to the States and the Northern Territory for public housing. That is an increase of 40 per cent in real terms, not in inflated terms, on the measly $552m provided in 1982-83. Two hundred and twenty thousand households have been accommodated in public housing in the five years of this Government compared with the Opposition's record of, not a measly, rotten 220,000 or even 100,000 but 165,000. That is the Opposition's commitment to public housing. It is a farce.

Opposition members talk about assisting people on lower incomes into home ownership. Let us look at the record again. They say that when they get back into government they will cut government spending. When they were in government 50,000 households on low incomes were provided with home loans. This Government has provided home loans to 72,000 households. How many houses did the Opposition assist with rental accommodation in its five years? It added 40,000. How many has this Government added? It has added 70,000. That is the difference and it is well and truly seen by the people out there. They know where first home ownership support comes from. They know where public housing support comes from. Those opposite, who bleat and carry on and shed crocodile tears for people on low incomes who need housing assistance, had their opportunity in government, but they blew it because they really do not care.

We have the supported accommodation assistance program to help people who are homeless, to help young people and older people in housing crisis or in personal crisis and in need of shelter, to help women who are suffering from domestic violence or sexual abuse. What did the Opposition do when it was in government to show it cared about those people? Where was the supported accommodation assistance program? Where was the full crisis accommodation program? It was not there. Funding under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement has grown to over $100m in 1987-88.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is declining in real terms.

—It is supporting people which is more than the honourable member's government did when it was in office. This Government's record in economic management is internationally recognised as remarkable. This Government has worked to improve the economic and financial conditions which will benefit home owners. That is the reality. People in public housing, people in need of crisis accommodation, people in private rental accommodation, people trying to get their first home, and people living in homes know very well-they elected us to government and have returned us to government at two subsequent elections-that they cannot trust the Opposition to put together policies. The Opposition cannot put together a tax policy; it cannot put together a health policy; it cannot put together a housing policy that people can trust. That is the difference.
—We have put together a housing policy and the people trust it.

—They do not trust it because the Opposition cannot add up. Its housing policy is just a simple wish list and a collection of pious intentions and words. Its repayment assistance proposal is vague to the point of being meaningless. We have to turn to the press for details rather than to the Opposition's policy document. How does the Opposition expect people on incomes of $15,000 to buy properties in Sydney or on the Gold Coast? Yet it says that they should be able to take out loans of up to 100 per cent of the value of the properties. The reality does not have a comprehensive approach to housing assistance or rental assistance. The Opposition will cut social security benefits. It will cut government spending. This Government has policies on social security, incomes support, employment, taxation and housing. These policies cannot be matched by honourable members opposite.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the facts. There is more to do with housing in this country than simply provide Commonwealth funding. If one reads the front pages of the Daily Telegraph or one of the other newspapers in Sydney one would think that there is a housing crisis, an affordability crisis, right across Australia. In some sections of Sydney and in some parts of the Gold Coast there are very expensive costs associated with going into housing. That is the reality.

TALK.START.PARA: —Doesn't that worry you?

—Of course that worries us. But there has been a lot of investment in property over the last couple of years for a variety of reasons and that has put tremendous stress on the availability of land, particularly in desirable areas and in a way as desirable as Sydney. It has put tremendous stress on property values in places such as the Gold Coast. We have to disaggregate the market, not simply rely upon one figure. That masks the national figures. National figures are masked by some of the affordability problems and the overheating problems that exist in Sydney and on the Gold Coast. Those problems need to be addressed by State and local governments as well.
—Duck the issue when it suits you.
—No. The honourable member, who is also from Sydney, realises that the shortage of serviced land in Sydney puts pressures on costs.
—So you cut State Government budgets.

—The honourable member would also realise, I am sure, that there are pressures on local governments in zoning regulations. When Opposition members stand up and talk about housing they expose their weakness. They do not understand the totality of the market. That was evident in the criticism from the honourable member for Mayo of the joint venture for more affordable housing. As we approach the twenty-first century, we have to look at--
—Lower living standards.

—Not lower living standards. We have to look at the issues that are changing our society-changing lifestyles and needs. Many young people who are looking for accommodation-the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) would probably correct me-do not necessarily want the quarter-acre block. I am not quite sure what it is in metric. He told us the other day that there is not so great a need for the quarter-acre block for everyone in Australia.
—But you are denying it to them.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Mayo.

—There is not a reduction in quality. There is not a reduction in standards. There are ways of finding more affordable housing of good standards, and ways to build houses better and cheaper. There are changing lifestyles. That is being demanded by the population. The issues surrounding, particularly with our ageing population, de-institutionalisation, and the effects of State and local government will be addressed in the housing review. The Opposition does not have the policies that will take it into government.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —All around Australia the very dogs are barking that this Government is totally out of touch with what the people of Australia are thinking. The Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) comes in here not like a barking dog, but like a little pussy cat, saying, `Miaow, miaow, miaow'. The Minister is also totally out of touch with the reality of the lives of ordinary Australians. He is out of touch with the 50,000 people sleeping in the streets. He is out of touch with the young Australians who cannot possibly buy their own homes. Regrettably, the Minister's response to this matter of public importance was weak and pathetic. He talked about the stale pastry of what happened under previous governments. He then went on, as is the standard procedure of his Government, to blow his own trumpet. He does that very well. He is not out of touch with that. Honourable members opposite come in here and endlessly blow their own trumpets about how they are the best at this and the greatest at that. The Minister is certainly the best at being out of touch with the ordinary people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: There was no substance in the Minister's response. Yet he did say, `There is more to do with housing than Commonwealth funding'. That is why we are having this debate today. There is more to do with housing than Commonwealth funding. The terms of this matter of public importance are `The crippling effect of the Government's economic policies on Australians trying to buy their own home'. If we boil that down to the reality faced by ordinary Australians who want to own their own homes, it comes down to two factors: inflation and interest rates. I remind the House of what was said in the Australian Financial Review only last Monday under the headline `Pressure builds on home mortgages':
The major banks are under pressure to review housing mortgage rates as Citibank Savings Ltd increases its mortgage rate to 15 per cent from today.
According to ANZ Banking Group Ltd's general manager of retail banking, Mr Rupert Thomas, the bank was `conscious' of the upward pressure on interest rates.
`If interest rate pressures hold next week there is strong likelihood that the bank will be forced to move our housing rate upwards,' he said.

The honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) confirmed something that was said on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio this morning about the strong possibility of interest rates going up once again. last week an article in the Sydney Morning Herald headed `Big slump in home sales blamed on dearer loans' stated:
Climbing interest rates knocked the wind out of the New South Wales housing market in August with sales plummeting by 16 per cent . . .

That is what is happening because of the Government's economic policies. Its economic policies have failed. They have undermined the confidence of the housing industry and of home buyers and have put housing beyond the reach of tens of thousands of Australians. They have put more people in the public housing queues than ever before. Existing Federal spending on housing programs has not resolved the housing crisis. In fact, it continues to grow. Housing related poverty has become a way of life for more than two million Australians, including 850,000 children. But the Minister and the rest of the Government would not be aware of that, because they are out of touch. The Hawke Government is totally out of touch with the reality of life for the Australians they seek to serve. We have had continual policy reversals and inadequate overall economic policy. The housing and construction industries are of great importance to Australia's economy and to the people who want to own their own homes. They account for over $20 billion of annual gross fixed capital expenditure. They employ almost half a million people directly and have significant multiplier effects.

Residential housing construction contributes only 4 per cent of Australia's gross domestic product. But that does not mean that its importance is only 4 per cent. To a young couple without a house it is of 100 per cent importance. The Government does not realise that because it is out of touch. It does not care. As a result of Government policy over the last five years, thousands of young Australians have not been able to afford to buy their first homes. Labor has no-one but itself to blame for the chaos in the housing market with record numbers of people unable to purchase or rent accommodation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has left the House before the debate has finished.
—I said earlier that he does not know and he does not care. He is out of touch.
—He doesn't want to know.

—He does not. We have had five years of Old Silver's Government, five years of record high inflation and record high interest rates, together with Labor's capital gains tax and negative gearing reaping a harvest of spiralling house prices and skyrocketing rents. At least we convinced the Government to see the error of its ways with negative gearing. But as I said, it is totally out of touch.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to talk about a specific example-the average price of a house in Sydney and what one had to pay for a loan to buy it when Labor came to office compared to what one has to pay now. Let us take an average priced house in Sydney and a loan over 25 years, which is reasonable, with a 25 per cent deposit. If a person got the money from a savings bank in March 1983, when Labor came to power, the interest rate was 12.5 per cent. In August 1988 the interest rate was 14.5 per cent. We have heard that it is likely to rise again.

But more important than the interest rate-that is a mere percentage-are the people we are talking about. We are talking about Australians-real people. Let us put it into dollar terms. In March 1983 if one borrowed the money from a savings bank to buy that average-priced house in Sydney, the monthly repayment was $658. But now it is $1,411. That is what Labor's crippling economic policies have done to the people of Australia. This affects not only new home buyers, but also the people who bought houses when we had the great value, the great benefit, of a coalition government. Then they paid $658 a month. Now, after five years of hard Labor, after five years of a government totally out of touch with the people of Australia they pay $1,411. If one borrowed the money from a building society the story is much the same. The monthly repayment when Labor came to office was $721 a month. Now it is $1,350. So it does not matter whether one gets one's money from a savings bank or a building society. Under labor one pays nearly three times as much for an average house.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the extra taxes they have to fork out?

—As the honourable member says, there is the extra taxation. It has been demonstrated conclusively-and never once denied in this House-that for the average Australian to get back to where he was in terms of taxation in 1983, when Labor came to power it will take over $50 a week in tax cuts. The Government makes such a lot of fuss about its alleged care and concern about first home buyers, but it has cut the first home owners scheme every year since 1984-85. The Government cut it by $44m this year. In the past three years it has cut the first home owners scheme by $128m; yet it says it cares. It does not care. This Government is totally out of touch with the reality of the life of ordinary Australians who are trying to survive, let alone buy a house, under Labor.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important that I state here and now that the Federal coalition, the Liberal Party and the National Party, recognises and supports the aspirations of all Australians to own their own homes. A home provides a stable family environment, a share in the nation's wealth and a source of personal security. In today's press we see that one out of three people is afraid to walk on the streets at night. A home is security and an investment. All Australian families deserve the right to own their own home. They will not get it from this Government because it is totally out of touch.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the first occasion on which I have been fortunate enough to debate a matter of public importance. I though we might at least get some sort of debate from the Opposition this time, but as usual we have another dramatic non-event-just like Question Time yesterday and just like Question Time today. Members of the Opposition are making a farce of parliamentary procedures. They are unable to debate the issues of the day in an appropriate manner, cognisant of the facts. The honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) has shown no understanding of this Government's economic policies. I suggest he talk to the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), because the honourable member for Wentworth has publicly acknowledged, as the honourable member for Mayo well knows, the capabilities of the front bench and therefore tacitly acknowledged the policies of this Government-and he is the shadow Minister for Finance. I suggest the honourable member for Mayo have a yarn with the honourable member for Wentworth after this debate; it might teach him a thing or two.

SPEECH.PARA: As usual, what do we have from the Opposition? There is not one scintilla of evidence to support the claims which have been made by the Opposition. Let us examine for a moment housing starts. In 1982-83, the last year under the control of the previous Treasurer, there were 105,000 housing starts. Last year there were 140,000 and this year there is expected to be 155,000. It might seem incredible to the honourable member for Mayo but that is an increase of around 50 per cent. In August this year housing approvals were the highest for fifteen years. I know the honourable member for Mayo is not noted for his great intellectual capabilities but he might at least be able to understand those facts. So too might the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), who unfortunately has left the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not.

—He is about to leave the chamber. He should come back and listen because he might learn something. I would like to ask the Opposition, which has been bleating about the inadequacy of Government policy, how these figures indicate that people cannot get into housing. They do not. In fact they demonstrate a marked improvement in the public's ability to obtain housing in this country, and that has been brought about by the Hawke Labor Government. The Opposition knows it and the community knows it.

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberals do not understand how the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement works. It is not all for public housing-a large share is devoted to home ownership assistance. Last year Commonwealth State housing money totalled $2 billion and of this, $560m went to home purchase assistance. When that is invested in the more innovative schemes designed by the Victorian and New South Wales labor governments-and unfortunately there is no longer a labor Government in New South Wales-the amount available is boosted from $560 to $780m. It is pleasing to see that the people of Victoria have learnt the error of the ways of the people of New South Wales, and fortunately for them they will be able to take advantage of the positive housing policies implemented by the Victorian Labor Government.

In 1988-89 Commonwealth-State housing approvals money will total $2 billion. The amount going to home purchases has increased to $600m and when that amount is added to the private funds available, a figure of $820m, we find that $1,420m is available for home purchases via the scheme. That is what the Liberals cannot comprehend. The honourable member for Mayo and the honourable member for Cowper come to this place and bleat about this Government's performance but they do not understand the policies. They do not understand the economic facts and they do not understand what is happening throughout Australia. They have no comprehension of reality, and that has been demonstrated time and again by the way they operate in this House. The Australian Labor Party, at both Federal and State levels, is about making the financial system work better, about economic efficiency and about using our dynamic economy to meet social objectives like housing.

Unfortunately the Opposition has no comprehension of social justice. I will reiterate what social justice means to this Government and what our programs are aimed at alleviating. The four elements of a just and equitable society as seen by this Government are: equity and the distribution of economic resources-that is not understood by the Opposition; equality of civil, legal and industrial rights-not understood by the Opposition; fair and equal access to essential services such as housing, health and education-again not understood by the Opposition; and the opportunity for participation by all in personal development, community life and decision-making. We know what the Opposition thinks about that. It does not believe in consultation at any level of government.

Labor is also concerned about the plight of people who are unable as yet to afford their own homes, through no fault of their own. We have increased assistance in the last Budget to private renters to give them a stake in the great Australian dream. Direct assistance is provided through the family allowance package-an innovation of this Government, a policy introduced by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe). Low income families renting privately who are receiving family allowance supplement, parents on unemployment benefit and pensioners now receive up to $15 a week rent assistance. What did we have when the coalition parties were in power? When the maestro, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), was on the treasury bench in charge of the till, what did we have? We had absolutely nothing. This is the first time that rental assistance has been provided to working families on low incomes.

Further changes to the Department of Social Security program announced in the 1988 Budget will also help reduce the incidence of housing related poverty in the private rental sector. The rental assistance program has been re-focused to recognise the higher housing costs faced by families with children, target assistance to those paying higher rents; and remove the inequities in assistance levels between pensioners and beneficiaries without children. Overall, the package will provide increases in rental assistance for more than 440,000 social security recipients. That should be justly applauded by the Opposition but it has not been. All that we hear is carping criticism. Do members of the Opposition have any policies? Not a one.

In essence, rental assistance for pensioners, beneficiaries and family allowance supplement recipients will rise progressively to a maximum of $30 a week for large families by June 1990. By June 1990 pensioners and beneficiaries without children will have received a 100 per cent increase in the maximum rate of rental assistance since 1983, while those with children will have received an increase of 150 to 200 per cent. This Government's policy initiatives and agenda are aimed at setting preconditions and providing scope for interest rate reductions over time. We will meet these objectives. Our economic policies have already delivered a significant Budget surplus, for the first time in 35 years. What in the name of all the economic geniuses opposite were the coalition parties doing when they occupied the Treasury bench? Nothing but getting us deeper in debt. In 1983 they left us with a Budget deficit of $9.6m.

We are fixing the fundamentals. By the June quarter next year, inflation will be down to 4 1/2 per cent. The Budget surplus has taken pressure off financial markets and has given us a zero public sector borrowing requirement. The Budget outlays will be reduced to 2 1/2 per cent of the economy next year. Just look at the Government's performance in job creation. It might seem astounding but this Government has created 1.1 million jobs since 1982-83. I would have thought that one of the basic ingredients of enabling people to afford public housing was to provide them with an income, to give them a job.

The abysmal performance we saw when the Opposition was on the Treasury bench has been fixed up by this Government, and we will do better. The average number of unemployment beneficiaries during September 1988 was 448,118 compared with 463,721 in August 1988.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are supposed to be talking about housing.

—I would have thought that the honourable member for Cowper would have recognised that when people earn an income they are able to purchase more. It is a very fundamental lesson that he has yet to learn. If we give someone some money, when he earns an income he may well be able to purchase something. It is very difficult for the Opposition to understand, I know, and I would like to suggest that the honourable member for Cowper, along with the honourable member for Mayo and perhaps the honourable member for Bennelong, seek some instruction from someone who knows-perhaps the honourable member for Wentworth, who has obviously got some credibility, at least in terms of recognising the realities of this Government's performance.

SPEECH.PARA: In September 1989 the average number of unemployment beneficiaries was 448,118. That is the lowest figure recorded in any month over the last six years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The discussion is concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Customs Tariff Proposals No. 11 (1988) and Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Proposals No. 1 (1988).

The tariff proposals I have just tabled relate to proposed alterations to the Customs Tariff Act 1987 and the Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Act 1975. Customs Tariff Proposals No. 11 (1988), operative on and from 14 October 1988, introduces a tariff alteration in respect of certain spray heads used for various types of spray dispensers in the toiletries and household cleaner fields. The change to these goods of tariff subheading 9616.0.00 has taken place in order to restore assistance to local production of these goods, which was lost as a result of a decision by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal on classification. The Industries Assistance Commission considered this matter in its final report on mining, construction and agricultural equipment and has recommended restoration of assistance, although at 10 per cent rather than the original rate of 15 per cent.

The Government considered that restoration of this level, now down to 14 per cent and phasing to 10 per cent under the tariff rate reduction scheme, is more appropriate, especially as the local manufacturer produces similar goods, classified elsewhere in the tariff, which are now dutiable at 14 per cent when imported. This will avoid distortions in production and consumption as well as restoring the level of assistance intended by the Government.

A new subheading, 9616.10.90, with a 14 per cent duty rate phasing to a long term rate of 10 per cent, is being implemented to distinguish spray bottle caps of a more general use from those of the more traditional scent and perfume dispensers which will retain a free rate of duty. Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Proposals No. 1 (1988), operative on and from 1 July 1988, amends the Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Act 1975 to continue an existing exemption from liability to pay coal export duty in respect of certain coal where that exempt coal is blended with other coal. Coal export duty is paid at the rate of $3.50 per tonne on exports of high quality coking coal extracted from a depth of less than 60 metres from open cut coal mines that were in production before 30 June 1980.

Previous amendments to this Act in 1984 had conferred export duty free status on high quality coking coal from two mines, Moura and South Blackwater in Queensland, where that high quality coking coal was made up of a specific blend of open cut and underground coal for each mine. The 1984 amendments were framed in such a way that Moura and South Blackwater coal blends, which would be exempt from coal export duty if exported as single blends, lose the exemption if they are further blended with coal from other mines before export. This has limited the export potential as buyer's requirements may entail the blending of other coals with those of Moura and South Blackwater. The Government has therefore decided to alter the Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Act to provide that coal blends from the Moura and South Blackwater mines will not lose their exempt status by reason of being further blended with coal from other mines before export.
Summaries of alterations contained in these proposals have been prepared and are being circulated for the benefit of honourable members. I commend the proposals to the House.
