That the Bill be now read a second time.
upon which Mr Blunt had moved by way of amendment:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House-

(1) regrets that Qantas has been prevented from selling shares to Qantas employees and the Australian people to provide a capital increase to facilitate expansion of the airline to cope with increasing passengers and freight; and
(2) notes that the Australian Taxation Office has issued a statement on debt defeasance, a procedure adopted by Qantas to finance the acquisition of new aircraft'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Qantas Airways Limited (Loan Guarantee) Bill, about which we were speaking last night, authorises the Treasurer on behalf of the Commonwealth to guarantee borrowings raised by Qantas Airways Ltd to finance the purchase of three Boeing 767-300 extended range aircraft. It is not controversial legislation and indeed is supported by honourable members on the other side of the House. It provided them with an opportunity to jump on the privatisation band wagon and, indeed, to put their views in that regard. An amendment was moved by the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt).

SPEECH.PARA: The most salient point, and I suppose the major point made by the members of the Opposition, is that there is within Qantas a need for a massive capital injection. That is not something that is denied by honourable members on this side of the House. Indeed, one does not have to be top of the class to work out that that is the case. It is a point that is made very honestly and forthrightly by the Government and it has been made in a number of papers produced on this side of the House.

I pointed out last night to members of the Opposition that their rhetoric now was not matched by their performance when they were in government. Indeed, between 1976 and 1983 when they had their hands on the levers, the state of Qantas was abysmal. There was certainly a need for capital injection. There was certainly a need for Qantas in that time to receive assistance. If they believed at that stage that the most appropriate course was for Qantas to be privatised, I wonder why they did not take that course of action. If they did not believe that, then certainly Qantas would have been benefited by a significant capital injection from Consolidated Revenue. They did not take that course of action. During that period, if we look at the figures, we find that between 1976 and 1983 in only one of those years did Qantas pay a dividend to the Government.

Since we came to office there has been a significant capital injection into Qantas, and indeed in the four years of operating since then that capital investment has been repaid in the form of dividends, plus some. When one considers the outstanding performance by Qantas at the moment, I would imagine that in the next report one will see an even greater return to the Government for its support of Qantas.

I asked this question yesterday: What did the Opposition do when Qantas was in that position during its time in government? It did nothing; it sat on its hands. The record of this great champion of private enterprise in respect of domestic aviation is even worse. During its time in government it left us with the regulated two-airline agreement which effectively imposed a straitjacket on competition in that industry. Once again it is this Government that has moved to remove that straightjacket and to provide for a more deregulated and competitive domestic airline industry.

This Government has moved to provide a macro-environment in which Qantas can be successful. This Government has poured resources into tourist development and the promotion of Australia as a tourist destination. As a result, Qantas is reaping the benefits. Its success and its future prospects are clearly an indication of the success of the policies of this Government. Indeed, the need for a further capital injection is not denied by those on this side of the House but we will not be precipitated into making a hasty decision. We have already taken moves to improve further the competitiveness and functioning of Qantas.

On 25 May the Government's proposals for the reshaping of Government business enterprises were released and new planning and accountability mechanisms were outlined. Certainly there will be a modification of the major strategic controls on Qantas. I refer to controls on its borrowings. Loan Council borrowing limits need to be re- examined and reshaped. There are controls on industrial relations issues. Qantas needs more autonomy in wage and employment proposals. Once again, the Government has taken initiatives in that area. Of course, the removal of simple day-to-day controls on the functioning of Qantas further streamline and revise the functioning of the airline in a micro-economic way. This Government has faced up to the issue. When one looks at the record of the Opposition, clearly the rhetoric of honourable members opposite last night was indicative of a group of people who failed when they had a chance to do something and who now, with hindsight, are trying to take a cheap shot at this Government.

The new aeroplanes are important because they reflect an increasing need for Qantas to supply air passage on routes between New Zealand and Australia and Japan and Australia-demand for which is growing most rapidly. The new planes have a greater range, they are more fuel efficient, more comfortable and they can cut down flight times on those routes. Those are just part of the requirements for a modern and developing airline. Qantas has increasing competition. In 1948, soon after Qantas became a wholly Australian-owned company, five airlines were flying into Australia. There are now 33, including Qantas. That is an indication of the amount of competition which it faces. It is certainly an indication that Qantas needs to grow and improve. Certainly, Qantas needs new aircraft. To allow that to happen, there is a need for a further capital injection. When the Government feels that, given the wider economic circumstances, it is able to provide the necessary capital-or when it takes the view that, given those economic circumstances, Commonwealth ownership of the airline represents the best use of public funds-it will take that course of action. If the view of the Government is that there should be privatisation, the appropriate response will be made.

I have previously expressed my view that floating a minority interest in Qantas is the most appropriate way in which to proceed at the moment. Certainly, it would lower the capital injections required by the Government. It would provide for stock exchange disciplines within Qantas, which would be important to its functioning. It would allow for remuneration packages which are related to its performance. Certainly, that is something that I believe is very important to the running of a successful business. One of the issues which was raised last night was employee participation. In my experience businesses in which the employees have a say and a stake function in a very effective and efficient way.

Finally, I would like to comment on one or two matters that have been raised by honourable members opposite. The honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) suggested that this Government's action in not allowing Qantas to be privatised had forced it-his own words-to become involved in very sophisticated financial techniques to finance these aeroplanes. He suggested that he agreed with those techniques, but that in some way they were aberrant. I am not sure that it is possible for him to justify that view. The techniques used to finance these aircraft are used by a large number of airlines throughout the world. If Qantas is to compete with them, it would seem appropriate that it have access to the same financing techniques. The techniques have been used before in purchasing planes, and have been approved by the Australian Taxation Office. I doubt the veracity of the comments by the Opposition with respect to these techniques.

In regard to aggregation, honourable members opposite believe that Qantas should move in that direction and that it is important for it to be involved in economies of scale. Yet they question the approach of Qantas to tendering for a stake in Air New Zealand. In July I spoke with officials of Cathay Pacific Airways in Hong Kong. They expressed a great deal of interest in Air New Zealand and in having part of the action in that area of the Pacific. It seems to me that if Qantas does not take this opportunity to extend its route and to rationalise its operation with Air New Zealand, we will have missed an opportunity and, as a result, Qantas may suffer in the long term.

I have no doubt that the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull), who will follow me in this debate, will present some interesting views. He always has much to say about Qantas. Indeed, in his speech on the adjournment last night he made one or two salient points in respect of planning by Qantas for increased passages to Australia this year. One must be very careful when one hears the airlines claim that they have passengers waiting in ports outside Australia. It is one of the negotiating tools used by those airlines to improve their position in negotiating future deals with respect to air travel into Australia. Certainly, those airlines would like to expand their routes and have the opportunity to fly into Australia more often. One must be careful about the sort of claims that are being made. I am only too aware of the fact that in the past some of those claims have been vastly exaggerated.

This legislation has the support of honourable members on both sides of the House. As I have mentioned, when the Government feels that it is appropriate, I have no doubt that a decision will be made as to which direction Qantas should take. The Opposition's help is not required. It does not have any credentials, when one looks at its record, on aviation or on tourism. I reject its second reading amendment, and I am quite happy to support the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the honourable member for Fadden, I might say that I am sure that the House welcomes the return of the honourable member for Perth from the Olympic Games. The honourable member might be aware that this House passed a motion expressing its appreciation to all Australian Olympic athletes for their efforts in representing this country. I am sure that both the Opposition, which moved that motion, and the Government welcome back the honourable member. I call the honourable member for Fadden.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome back the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth). I thank him for some of the comments that he has made. They were preliminary to a number of comments that I would like to make about the present situation in terms of airline regimes, not only in Australia but also overseas, and the role that Qantas Airways Ltd now sees for itself in terms of its initial takeover bid for 25 per cent of Air New Zealand. In fact, I shall try to bring to the attention of the House simply the fact that the development of aviation and tourism in this country is probably at its most critical point. The decisions that will be made by this Government and organisations such as Qantas over the next 12 or 18 months or so will determine whether we continue our tourist boom and whether we will continue to reap the rewards that tourism can provide to our economy and provide to this country in employment opportunities.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, while this Bill may be involved only in the sale or leasing of three Qantas 767 300 series aircraft, I think the ramifications of this debate can be much more than that. It is an appropriate time to begin looking at some of the implications of the decisions now facing Qantas, and indeed, this Government over the next 12 months or so.

I said it was a critical time because major changes are occurring in the international airlines of the world right now. Those changes have seen the amalgamation and the takeover of a number of airlines from the United States to the point that there are virtually five megacarriers operating out of the United States. That is a huge block because it incorporates some of the biggest airlines in the world. Already we are seeing a great deal of discussion between the countries of the European Community on rationalisations of various services within Europe. We have already seen a number of airlines from Europe make bids for carriers in other parts of the world, and a number of bids are going on at the moment for a number of South American carriers.

What will basically happen in Europe is fairly obvious. There will be a huge block there to counter that American block. What we must determine in Australia now is whether we want to be part of the action, or will we see our national carrier perhaps decline to a small regional operator. That is really what it is all about.

I can fully understand the desire of Qantas to try to get that 25 per cent shareholding in Air New Zealand. It is probably the right move from its point of view. I would have been concerned had British Airways managed to buy that percentage of Air New Zealand, because it would have given quite an interesting connection between that big conglomerate that will evolve out of Europe and this part of the world.

Right now the Qantas people have to make that decision on whether they will lead the way to try to get either a South Pacific block or perhaps, even more importantly, a South East Asian block, because with the aggressive nature of the South East Asian carriers and carriers such as All Nippon and Japan Airlines now, there is a potential situation where that block could be evolved and it could squeeze us out. That is a very real concern.

As I say, the decisions that will be made by Qantas over the next 18 months on its particular niche in the world are extremely important, but that is not to say that all things are well with Qantas at present. I am glad that the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) raised the matter of the financing of Qantas and the need for the injection of $600m into Qantas, because that is true. At the moment Qantas is talking of the need to have 52 aircraft within a few years' time. That is an additional 18 aircraft that Qantas wants to buy, and frankly, it does not have the money to do it. It is not incumbent on the taxpayers of Australia to reach deeply into their pockets to finance that expansion that must indeed happen to Qantas.

I make no secret of the fact that it is now more than 10 years since I first suggested in the House the privatisation of Qantas if we wanted to see the airline grow and prosper and bring Australia into the forefront of aviation again. The argument is even more valid now than perhaps it was 10 years ago. The fact of the situation-I trust the Government realises this-is that in most Western countries now governments are in fact moving towards privatisation of their airlines. It has happened through Europe. There has been the most remarkable transformation of British Airways in the United Kingdom. We have now seen a number of the Asian carriers privatising their operations, and all for this reason: that the demands upon the airlines at the moment to re-equip and meet the increased growth in traffic are very real indeed. Not many countries can afford to continue to top up the tank of those airlines to give them enough money to expand.

The interesting thing about the whole situation with Qantas is that the Qantas board and management are now begging to be privatised, because they know they cannot reach their full potential unless they have access to that money. I am sure members of the Government and the Ministry have had discussions with the board of directors and the managers of Qantas. I am sure they have been told the same story that I have been told: that unless something happens, Qantas is facing the situation of perhaps becoming a very small regional carrier and a regional carrier only.

However, there is another reason why the privatisation of Qantas now and the rapid injection of capital into Qantas is absolutely critical. I mentioned last night, and it is worth mentioning again, that there is no doubt that 12 months ago there was a very real crisis on our hands and that crisis evolved because of the incredible demand for seats into Australia. Honourable members might remember that 12 months ago we were told it was purely seasonal, that the demand would go away, we would put on a couple of supplementary flights and everything would be hunky-dory; we would not have to worry any more. The situation became so critical that Qantas had to lease two aircraft in a hurry, one from Qatar and one from one of the Dutch companies, to handle the business. It is not true to say that the demands for seats into Australia were exaggerated by carriers who wanted a few extra landing rights, because what has happened throughout this bicentennial year, this year of World Expo 88, is that the seat situation has been very tight all year, and we are now reaching crisis point again.

Unless someone from Qantas comes back and says I do not know what I am talking about, let me give the House a little information that has been leaked to me from Qantas. We all have our sources! The word has gone out that at the moment Qantas staff cannot take their holidays and expect to get staff concession tickets on Qantas aircraft. That is fine; if Qantas is attracting all those full first-class fares, that is great. That is what it is all about. But if the situation is not critical at present, why do Qantas staff travelling on company business have to travel on another airline? That is good economic sense too, because it frees up those seats to allow full paying passengers to come into Australia on Qantas and the concessional fares that have been paid for Qantas staff to go overseas are being used on other carriers that may have a few seats to spare. However, we are now really entering the crunch period, and my estimate is that between now and the end of January we will face a very similar situation to the one we faced last year when people just could not get seats into Australia.

One of the sad things that has happened with Expo 88 is the fact that so many people who wanted to come into Australia could not get seats and therefore did not come. Despite that, Expo has broken all records and all expectations, and that is great. But perhaps we could have done a little better if we had been more flexible in the supply of seats right through this year. It is sad that the revised timetable that was brought about by this particular expansion only came into effect on 1 October. Indeed, we could have done with a lot more flights into Brisbane between April and October, but that did not happen.

One of the things I mentioned last night was that although we have this tremendous growth of tourism in Australia, we must make sure that there is some sense of coordination between government departments, not only to make sure that we have enough airline seats but in fact that we have enough infrastructure to handle the tourists. If any condemnation is to be made about what has happened with the tourism boom, that condemnation should be on the Government because of its failure to provide infrastructure. There is no doubt that the situation existing at Sydney international airport is a disgrace. The aircraft numbers are up, the passenger numbers are up, and the present facility cannot handle them.

Let us not forget that eight years ago in the Boeing Corporation report that was commissioned on the State of the growth of international air travel into Australia, we were told that that growth factor would be there. Nobody took any notice of it. Another Boeing report-a second report, issued earlier this year-says that in fact we are going to see that growth continue right through until the 1990s. Qantas has decided that once again perhaps that Boeing report is in fact conservative. So what are we going to do? Are we going to ignore all those reports again? Are all of these interdepartmental committees going to say, `Oh yes, there is a report; let us have a meeting', and then nothing happens? That in fact is what has happened in Australia during the last eight years while the tourist boom has been building up.

We have really been caught in a situation where the international airport terminal in Sydney is inadequate, the terminal in Melbourne can probably handle the situation and the terminal at Brisbane is an absolute farce. The Brisbane terminal is still a tin shed despite the fact that the domestic terminal is magnificent. The international terminal at Brisbane cannot handle the traffic. Yet the Federal Airports Corporation is talking about extending the tin shed as an interim measure. Such a move will solve nothing. Some people believe that traffic into and out of Brisbane will decline after Expo. It might go down a few points but the traffic will continually build up. About two years down the track we are looking at an international Lions convention, with 33,000 people coming in and out of the terminal in one afternoon. But we are not really making any effort to solve these problems.

The Cairns international airport is probably one of the most interesting examples of what can be achieved by non-government involvement in infrastructure. All of the pessimists around the place said that this arrangement would not work. But the Cairns airport is now busier than Perth or Adelaide with more and more international travellers coming in there. The Cairns Port Authority, which owns and operates the airport, has the capacity to make snap decisions. It is already building a new terminal and extending the runway so the airport can handle the traffic. But nothing is happening in Sydney, which is the major entry point to Australia. Obviously nothing is going to happen in Brisbane. Do we have to sit back and wait until the whole system collapses while the situation becomes more and more farcical?

While ideologically some members of the Government might be concerned about privatisation, I must admit that I have no problems with it whatsoever. I believe that if we are to meet the demands that are going to be made on our international airline services, not only in terms of Qantas but in terms of the infrastructure, private involvement in the whole operation is the only way to go. What better way to go than to privatise completely the airport terminal operation, and not go through the interim step of having a Federal Airports Corporation. This has been done very successfully overseas. I think one of the great attractions is simply that it does not cost the Australian taxpayer one brass solitary cent. At the moment consortia in Queensland are saying, `Look, we will build you a new international terminal provided that we can build a hotel next door'. I think that is great. The experiences overseas is that private industry which has been involved in providing infrastructure has been very successful and profitable. As I say, the real attraction is that the pressure is taken off the taxpayers of Australia.

Perhaps I am getting away a little from the substance of this Bill, which is about Qantas leasing three 767 aircraft. But more and more Bills such as this one will have to come into the House if Qantas is to almost double its fleet in the next 10 years to handle the number of international visitors coming to Australia. I just wonder how much longer the taxpayers of Australia will go guarantor for some of these loans. The crunch is certainly on in the international aviation scene at the moment, and the crunch is certainly on Qantas if it is to stay in business. My suggestion would be to members of the Government and members of the Ministry in particular including the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown), who is at the table: let Qantas be able to do its thing and let us make sure that we stay in that international airline race.

If an injection of $600m of capital is not made into Qantas very soon, if Qantas management does not have the capacity to be able to manage its operations properly, if it does not have the flexibility to be able to adjust to certain market situations, obviously we will be overtaken by events. The amalgamations, the takeovers and the emergence of the megacarriers are happening right now around the world. The American bloc is in place; the European bloc is almost in place. The Europeans are taking over the South Americans, and the Asian carriers are expanding at a very great rate. Huge developments are taking place in the Japanese arena. If we are not careful and if we do not give Qantas that flexibility and management capacity, we really may see Qantas turn into a small regional carrier. Despite all the criticisms that have been made in this place about Qantas, I am sure that the last thing we want to see is the demise of our airline. If we do not give Qantas a fair go, if we do not move down the road of privatisation, I am afraid that that is exactly what we will allow to happen to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some members of this House concentrate on certain areas and their knowledge is of great benefit to us. The honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) is no exception. He assists both sides of the House in the work that he does on airlines and the aviation industry. We welcome that fact. One of the problems with his party is that it thinks it has the perfect answer to anything which comes up in relation to government enterprises-that is, sell them. This has not always been the case. One would hope that those opposite would do in practice what they have always done in government and generally maintain these enterprises.

SPEECH.PARA: Privatisation is not always the answer. It was interesting yesterday to listen to the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) talk about the problems of Qantas Airways Ltd being solvable by selling the airline off. He indicated that it could be sold to pensioners or to Qantas stewards. This sounds a little bit like what happened to British Telecom in respect of which Mrs Thatcher said that every man will be a capitalist. Apparently she was to be the only woman capitalist. But her aim was for every Britisher to be a capitalist. What would happen if Qantas were privatised? The same as happened with British Telecom. Qantas would be sold to the little people, the little people would mostly sell to the big people and Qantas would no longer by the people's airline.

Apart from some members like the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee), the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) and Senator Baume, the Opposition's attitude towards government enterprises is becoming almost fanatical. Although members of the Opposition are divided, the majority seem to favour privatisation. They work on a premise that people, through governments, should not own enterprises. We are told that we should get rid of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. Today's Australian Financial Review reports that the Commonwealth Bank has made a substantial profit. But so what if the best competitor in banking in country towns is lost through privatisation? Members of the Opposition say, `Get rid of the lucrative parts of Australia Post and Telecom'. So what if that means loss of services in the country, more costly services to country people or higher taxes to all Australians so that these bodies can be maintained? They say, `Get rid of the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation'. So what if it has made a profit for government in this last financial year and if jobs would be lost in Cooma? They say, `Get rid of Qantas'. So what if we lose the profits which are being used to strengthen the airline and adding to revenue?

They are wrong. Privatisation may well be the opiate of the doctrinaire dries, but the prime aim we ought to have and the prime aim we ought to be looking at if we are to address the questions raised by the honourable member for Fadden is to develop enterprises, government or private, which are efficient and which can provide services at a reasonable cost to the consumer. Using that premise, taxpayers-the shareholders-can be called on for extra capital, as can happen in any business. If efficiency would be better served by having some, not necessarily all, private equity, that is another option that can be considered. If efficiency would be better served through equity trusts, that is another alternative that we can look at. But there is no real conclusive evidence to support claims that private enterprises are inherently more efficient than their public sector counterparts.

The competitive environment in which the enterprise operates rather than the nature of the ownership of the enterprise is a more significant determinant of efficiency. The designation of Qantas as the sole Australian international carrier bestows clear advantages. The company faces aggressive competition on all its major routes. We need to ask what are the best ways of addressing it. It is not necessarily through privatisation. Nor is deregulation the answer unless it is paralleled by some regulation, particularly in the safety area. As we have seen in the United States of America there have been queries about safety, about cancelled flights and drastically reduced services as companies try to compete on price. We need to look very carefully at how we address the needs of our airlines in a big country. In some cases we need to provide services particularly in country areas where they may not be profitable but where they support important industries which comprise about half of our total exports. These questions need to be addressed. We need to look at the points which have been raised by the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth), the honourable member for Fadden, and all other honourable members who have spoken in this debate.

We have to be concerned about equity and borrowing. Borrowings and interest always have to be repaid irrespective of what the trading conditions are. It is interesting that in the four years to 1983 Qantas lost $112m. In that period it paid interest and lease costs of $180m. Lack of capital was the biggest cause of loss in those difficult trading years. A bigger Qantas poorly capitalised becomes very vulnerable to those losses. The profit in the 1986-87 financial year was $104m. Interest charges are now $150m, before loans, for the four Boeing 767 aircraft in 1988 and the four Boeing 747 aircraft in 1989.

The directors have an obligation to conduct the company's affairs in a manner that will enable commitments to be met when they fall due. But, in a general downturn in economic conditions governments, of course, have wider problems and are not always necessarily ready to give a hand in supporting Qantas. To avoid general instability in Qantas and the sorts of things that the honourable member for Fadden was talking about last evening, for example, a decline in staff morale, a reduction in jobs, a decline in working conditions and a greater pressure on the airline generally, we need to look at the whole problem. We ought to be looking at what some of the airlines are doing. For instance, Air New Zealand Ltd has a debt equity ratio of 55 to 45; Singapore Airlines Ltd has a debt ratio of 58 to 42. Qantas has a debt ratio about 50 per cent higher-it is actually 79 to 21.

We need to have a close look at the operation of our enterprises. That is what the Government has done. The principal factor necessary to maintain Qantas in public ownership is to give it a guaranteed injection of the necessary capital requirements essential to maintain its overall viability and to keep it competitive. If Qantas is to be kept in full public ownership the Government, in other words the shareholders-the taxpayers-must provide capital of the order of $600m over the next two years with further injections in the years beyond. The competitors of Qantas are increasingly large in scale and are moving extensively into new fields of technology, for example, a computerised reservation system. This heightens the importance of Qantas possessing up-to-date technology as it has greater flexibility and cost efficiency.

It is extremely important as we look at the future of Qantas that we take into account this need for large amounts of capital. I have tried to point out that it would be futile for us to say, `Let Qantas borrow more'. If we look at its competitors we cannot afford to let Qantas borrow more. We have to tackle that problem head on. We need to look at the alternatives for Qantas. It probably does need more commercial freedom for the reasons we have been discussing. On the Government's transport and communications Caucus policy committee, the controls through the Loan Council, the superannuation ties of Qantas, the remuneration which is given by Qantas to its executives and employees, and to industrial relations generally, are all issues which are discussed.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about staff share ownership?

—There may be no objection to staff share ownership. I see no real objection to it. It ought to be taken into account. I do not see the importance of privatising the airline holus-bolus. The best interests of a country like Australia are served by having an international airline which is at least half, preferably more, owned by the Government; in other words, by the people of the country. Qantas can respond to business opportunities by taking that attitude. We can relax the controls and take measures which will solve the equity shortage which has been properly identified to us by the Qantas board. There has been a great contribution to the development of aviation policies by this Government. It has caught up with some of the problems which arose due to the failure of the previous Government to take those attitudes into account.

SPEECH.PARA: I welcome the appointment of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) as we come into this difficult stage of looking at a number of areas which confront our enterprise, including one within his own area of expertise, that is, industrial relations. I welcome the appointment of the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support (Mr Punch), who, along with the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), is taking a great interest in Badgerys Creek and the need to address that issue very quickly. I also welcome the appointment of the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown), who has a grasp on some very important issues which the Government has to tackle in road transport, particularly in rail transport and the immense concerns that we have over shipping.

The Government realises that in dealing with the aviation, telecommunications and broadcasting industries we have only just started on some very important issues in transport and communications which have to be solved. They will not be solved by conservative governments; they have shown us that. We have to do it without prejudice against private enterprise and government enterprise but in the interests of efficiency and consumers.

So it is with great pleasure that I support this Bill which will finance the purchase of three Boeing 767-300s which are extended range aircraft. These will be delivered in October, November and December of this year. The Minister has already told us that these aircraft are the latest development of the Boeing 767 series and will give Qantas greater flexibility in meeting the requirements of the rapidly growing inbound tourist market. Qantas itself has pointed out that we can expect two million visitors from Asia over the next five years if we can straighten out the problems that the Opposition has given us in diminishing the respectability that Australia has in our rapidly growing Asian markets through its migration policy and its failure to declare properly its policies and attitudes. Qantas, which is training people to speak languages that are spoken in Asia so that more tourists will come to Australia, has said that the expected increase of two million in the number of tourists over the next five years is threatened by the lack of respect which is being shown by the Opposition to our migration policy.

The measures that have been taken by the Government will enable Qantas to provide for first class passengers and 231 ordinary passengers compared with 208 previously. Primarily, these aircraft will be utilised on the Tasman and Japanese routes-two important markets for Qantas and Australia. I believe that the Opposition needs to consider its position on migration in relation to our economic interests, if it is not prepared to look at it from the point of view of other interests. Qantas has brought forward the delivery of these aircraft to meet the end of year peak demand for travel and it plans to operate 154 extra round trips this summer to accommodate the anticipated higher demand. Let us keep it that way. I am pleased to support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Qantas Airways Limited (Loan Guarantee) Bill, which is an important piece of legislation, I would like to make some brief comments about the speech just made by my neighbour the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow). I will deal later in my address with his comments on immigration, which I thought were unfortunate. Suffice it to say at this time that the newly-industrialised countries of Asia should not judge Australians other than by taking into account their own performances across a range of key issues.

SPEECH.PARA: It is time that we injected some reality into this debate. It is inevitable that Qantas Airways Ltd will be privatised. The Liberal and National Parties have shown some dynamic initiatives by moving to a policy position of 100 per cent privatised ownership of Qantas from the previous position of 49 per cent, whereas the Government is in a policy stalemate as it inches towards 49 per cent or even more. But the members of a famous troika-the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent), the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton) and the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott)-are bringing about yet another left wing veto of progress along a sensible path towards privatising and re-energising Qantas. I think it is a pity that the honourable member for Eden-Monaro did not reject the position of his left wing troika colleagues on that policy issue. I hope there will be a bit more reality in this debate in the speeches of subsequent speakers because, I say again, it is inevitable that Qantas will be privatised. I am sure that the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) would not deny that. The question is one of timing and percentage.

The honourable member for Eden-Monaro made the mistake of mentioning the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch), who is the new Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support. He has done more than any other member of this House to create congestion in aviation in this country at the key gateway point of Sydney by his activities in blocking of the development at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport of a short take-off and landing runway, and he knows it. In fact, he advertises this in his electorate as a proud achievement. I will tell honourable members what his achievement is doing: it is forcing planes to stack up above Sydney suburbs. It is adding massively to the fuel burden costs of airline companies and, in turn, to the costs of the users of those companies. The ordinary man and woman on the street who wants to use aircraft or has to attend a funeral suddenly arising in Melbourne or Brisbane and wants to get out of Sydney has this add-on cost built into the air fare by the very action of the new Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support.

It was a terrible signal for the aviation industry and the tourist industry when the Government appointed the honourable member for Barton as Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support. It is an appointment which the Government will rue whenever this matter comes up at tourist industry meetings around the place. Already many people are saying that they simply cannot work out why the honourable member for Barton was given a role relating to aviation, given his sabotaging of the logical development of Sydney's international airport.

I turn now to the Bill. Last month I had the privilege of visiting Blackall and Longreach in central Queensland with a number of colleagues and of conducting a series of meetings with people in that part of the country. I also took the opportunity to inspect a replica of the original office of Qantas-that is, the original office of Queensland and Northern Territory Aerial Services. It was a small, one-room office with a little veranda which, frankly, would fit within the area encompassed by the table in the new House of Representatives. That is how tiny the office was. That is where Qantas started and that is where it has expanded from, albeit with the help of legislation and 101 changes along the path.

I guess it is food for thought that, whilst Qantas has leapt forward and taken off from that starting point in Longreach and Winton in central Queensland, the people whose forefathers helped to sponsor Qantas-the pioneers of aviation in that part of our nation-still face massive problems with getting into towns such as Blackall, Longreach or Winton because of the deteriorating conditions of their roads. In one sense, Qantas has taken off from that region, but in 1988 many people are yet to have an all-weather road from their small business unit, otherwise known as a farm or station, to their nearest town, particularly in the Longreach area. This is affecting not only primary production but also tourist operations.

I make the point that Qantas had very humble beginnings. Qantas has made enormous progress over the decades and we, as a nation, have a right to be proud of what it has achieved. I give full credit to Qantas for soldiering on as our national flag carrier, in many ways in a restricted manner because of the Government's failure to grasp the nettle and resolve the ownership conundrum to which other speakers have referred, particularly speakers on the coalition side of the House.

In a sense, Qantas today is not dissimilar to a magnificent Rolls Royce motor car with a Ford Falcon gearbox. I am not being critical of Ford Falcon gearboxes; indeed, they are made in my electorate by Borg-Warner (Australia) Ltd and are of a very good standard. But it is a gearbox that is geared to the operation of a Ford Falcon and if we were to put it into a Rolls Royce we would have tremendous underperformance. In fact, I would venture to suggest that we would quickly have a motoring disaster. But that is exactly what is happening with Qantas because the Government is failing to recognise what is happening internationally with the massive enlargement of airlines which are in competition with Qantas-those five megacarriers in the United States of America. The Government is keeping Qantas restricted. It is keeping the ownership gearbox of Qantas in the dark ages, rather than taking the chance to leap forward with a positive initiative in line with the policy of the Liberal and National parties. The Government will pay a price for restricting the onward progress of Qantas at a crucial time of aviation development.

In emphasising the importance of Qantas, it is so much a part of our economic activity that even in a country electorate like Farrer which has no international airport but which has a series of airports from Khancoban, Albury and Deniliquin to as far out as Wentworth there are many industries which rely on the performance of Qantas, both in respect of the tourist industry and in respect of air cargo, the export industries and related industries. I have a valid and deeply held interest in aviation policy, in particular with regard to providing the right basis for Qantas to sweep into the 1990s. This Government has failed to provide the right basis to sweep Qantas into the 1990s with the right ownership and the right capitalisation so that it can buy extra aircraft to allow it to take up the huge expansion in trade.

I will now focus on another aspect related to this Qantas legislation. Clearly there is a need for this nation to continue to build its Asian connections in the cultural, political and economic sense. While I have been a member of Federal Parliament, by my own deed, determination and decision, I have decided to focus-to the extent that one can spend time on foreign affairs and trade relations-in particular on Thailand and its neighbours.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is certainly to your credit.

—I thank the honourable member for Lyne for his kindly comment. I remind the House that Thailand is a country of 56 million people. For the most recent three years its economic growth has coasted along at just a shade under 10 per cent. Thailand is a dynamic nation which will be the next major newly industrialised country (NIC) in our part of the world. Bangkok will become the next Hong Kong, the dynamic economic centre of South East Asia in the 1990s. Let us recognise that positively by seeing that Qantas fulfils the additional role it has carved out for itself in helping to spearhead Asian orientation of our nation.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend Qantas for its incentives and activities with regard to language training. This country is languishing in terms of the ability of our younger generation to speak more than one language, namely English. That is partly an outcome of having no adjoining boundaries with other nations of different languages unlike in Europe, where in one afternoon train ride from say Paris to Amsterdam one will travel through two other countries with their own tongues. The ability to speak an additional language in Europe is almost second nature. That is certainly not the case here. It is something to be regretted. It is something that Qantas and other organisations with a similar role to play should and must do something about. I hope that Qantas will continue to expand its language incentives and training not only for its own employees but in a broader sense.

I also commend Qantas for reorientating its flights to Asia. By the end of this month it will shift its famous QF1 flight from the very traditional route of Sydney, Singapore, Bahrain and Europe, to Sydney to Bangkok-the new emerging hub-and then non-stop to London. That was a very big decision. It involves massive logistical changes, but it recognises economic trends. From Sunday, 30 October, QF1 will be operating, every day of the year, the Sydney, Bangkok, London route rather than the more traditional kangaroo route.

To be fair to Qantas, it is taking steps to reorientate more and more to Asia and re- orientate in particular more and more to Thailand. I welcome this. I say again that unless Australia takes on board an increasing Asian orientation in terms of its cultural, political and economic links, we will perish in the future. That should be done on the basis of mutual respect between the Asian nations and Australia and vice versa. In recent months there has been controversy in our relations with various Asian countries. As one who has fought in Asia I believe that should be seen in its proper context. I remind the House that there are many Australians buried on Asian soil; in Burma, in Bangladesh, in Thailand. That points to some of our links with Asia in World War I and World War II. But there are links more recent than that. Let us also be reminded that it was Australia, well ahead of many so-called Western nations, that backed Indonesia in its battle for independence from the Dutch in the late 1940s and early 1950s. So our bona fides in our region in a formal and in a historical sense are very good, but we have to do more. I appeal for a more mature approach, on a broader front, in considering our relations with Asia.

Australia should not allow any one issue, negative or positive, to dominate our bilateral or multilateral relations with Asian nations or the Asian region. Australia should highlight its many good deeds in dealing with the region. We should highlight the positive contributions that we have made to the Asian region be they through private enterprise joint ventures, government overseas aid or the many other initiatives which we have taken. For its part Asia, particularly the newly industrialised countries of Asia, should not judge Australia on any one issue. The NICs of Asia should not judge Asia other than by taking into account their own performance across a wide range of issues. Asians should take fair account of Australia's achievements in the region over the years. Whilst we could and should have done more, real progress has been made to date and that cannot be ignored.

As a relatively new member of Federal Parliament-although I note that over 40 members and senators have departed from Parliament since 1 December 1984 when I entered the Parliament-I am far more interested in Asia than in Europe or in North America. I take the opportunity, when speaking on this legislation, to remind the House, the Parliament and the nation that we must all be far more interested in Asia than in Europe or in North America if we are to survive in the cruel economic climate on the international front. It is extremely important that Qantas be given the resources, the ownership infrastructure and, above all, the capitalisation necessary to provide for its re-equipment and expansion so that it can move through to the 1990s in a positive and truly competitive way. Qantas does not have much time to sit back and think about it. It has to get moving.

Let us take Thai Airways International Ltd. I know honourable members would not always read the Bangkok Business Post which is in the Parliamentary Library, but on Monday, 10 October, this week, it was reported:
Thai International is expected to increase its flights between Thailand and Australia to eight a week when its 1989 summer timetable comes into effect to meet the growing traffic demand.

It is noted in the same statement that Thai's average passenger load factor to and from Australia is 85 per cent and the airline's revenue in 1987 just for Thai-Australian routes was some $A75m. That is just one airline that operates to and from Australia. It is an extremely competitive airline. Due to the fluke of geography and the structure of passenger movement authorisations it has a tremendous add-on benefit of being able to operate from Australia to its home base and from its home base to Europe, and even to Japan and beyond. It is facing the chill winds of fierce competition, especially from the mega-airlines flying out of the United States reconstruction of aviation. We are fools if we do not provide the basis for Qantas to proceed into the next decade. We are missing the opportunity of doing just that in the legislation before the House.

I commend to the House the amendment which has been ably moved by my colleague the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt). I particularly commend the first part of that amendment, which regrets that Qantas has been prevented from selling shares to Qantas employees and the Australian people to provide a capital increase to facilitate the expansion which is so necessary to help our tourist industry and to help the increasing requirements of air freight. Where other airlines have done this overseas, such as British Airways, the staff who have taken up shares-in this case British Airways employees-have been laughing all the way to the bank with massive growth in their portfolios, whether they have 22 shares, 40 shares or however small a number.

This Government would deny Qantas employees, in this bicentennial year, the right to take up shares in Qantas. That is a negative approach, it is a disappointing approach but, above all, it is a dangerous approach because it denies Qantas the wherewithal to compete fairly and competitively with the other international aviation operators. It is denying Qantas the right to fulfil its important and vital charter. I support the amendment to the Bill before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to respond to some of the remarks made by the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer). He used some code words, particularly in his references to Asia. He mentioned the Asian countries with which we wish to deal, in which we see a great deal of potential, the newly emerging Asian countries. In particular he mentioned Thailand, and I support that part of his remarks. As I said, he used some code words. He said, `Do not judge us on any one issue'. The real meaning of those words was, `Do not judge us by the position of the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, on immigration'. That is what that really meant-`We want to trade with you, we want to deal with you, but you are not good enough to emigrate to Australia'. The Opposition has shamelessly exaggerated the number of Asians who constitute part of the Australian population and the number who are likely to want to emigrate to Australia in future. I am sure that people in Asian countries will respond to those double standards when they see the speech by the honourable member for Farrer.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member also asked why the Government would not give shares to Qantas employees. At the moment Qantas is wholly owned by the Government of Australia. Effectively, this means that every Australian is a shareholder of Qantas, whether employed by Qantas or not.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is almost as bad as Keir Hardie.

—I hear the shadow Minister interjecting. His great contribution was that Qantas needs to be privatised. In the Opposition's contribution to this debate its members have talked about the loony ideologues on this side of the House. It does not matter what statutory authority, or what company fully owned by the Australian people one looks at, the Opposition's policy is to privatise it. I repeatedly sought from the honourable member for Farrer the reason he advocates 100 per cent privatisation of Qantas. The nearest he came to any sort of disclosure was to say that he wants to energise Qantas.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government wants to place on record the tremendous contribution Qantas has made to civil aviation in this country, from its humble beginnings. I have a high regard for the employees of Qantas and the tremendous job they are doing earning export dollars for Australia. I am not here to knock Qantas-unlike members of the Opposition. They feel that Qantas needs a different structure, that if it were fully privatised it would do all sorts of things from a management point of view that it is not doing now, and that its performance would be lifted, presumably. Opposition members do not spell it out. They display a continuing double standard-`Qantas is great but we need to privatise it 100 per cent'.

The people of Australia ought to be aware of what the real depth of the Opposition's concern was when Qantas suffered a severe downturn in the number of passengers carried. What did the Opposition do when it was in government in 1981-82 when there was a $112m loss by an under-capitalised Qantas? What were the effects on Qantas? The Government at the time did absolutely nothing. The Opposition will never want to privatise an organisation that is losing money. Its classic approach is always to privatise the profits and socialise the losses. That is the attraction for the Opposition. That approach has been consistent throughout.

What was the effect on Qantas of the previous Government's inertia, its inactivity and its lack of concern about what was happening to Qantas when it suffered a downturn in traffic? The previous Government was quite happy to see 2,000 employees lose their jobs. What did the Government do for those 2,000 people? It did absolutely nothing. What happened to the organisation? Not only did it lose 2,000 of what must be its most precious resource-the people who work for it-but also it had to sell off major assets. It had to sell what is now the Sheraton Wentworth Hotel. That has gone. What happened concerning competition? Qantas voluntarily had to relinquish a capacity on the kangaroo route, which was absolutely devastating. Its competitors moved in straight away to take up that capacity. Yet Opposition members come in here and say, `We are concerned about the lack of capital. We want to privatise Qantas. That is the way it should go'. In 1981-82, Qantas had a far greater capital problem than it has now and the government of the day did absolutely nothing. That is the essential hypocrisy of Opposition members when they come into this chamber talking about their concern for Qantas.

In these debates we have from time to time about statutory authorities I always think it is regrettable that there is not a greater understanding of what the Government has done with its statutory authorities such as Qantas. No government has been better informed about the current state of statutory authorities, about what the future holds for them, about what directions they need to take to maintain viability, than this Government. There has been a systematic and total review of all these authorities. The Opposition never did that. It has never been interested in good management or in watching over the welfare of these organisations. It has a single, one-line response to statutory authorities, and that is to privatise them. If there is an automatic pavlovian response by the Opposition, it is that they should be sold off. Sometimes I wonder whether the Opposition really cares about whether they are sold off to Australian shareholders or given away-as it gave our international shipping away-to foreign shareholders. That is one of the things we ought to be concerned about in considering Qantas. We certainly do not want civil aviation to go the same way as international shipping-where overwhelmingly the vast majority of all goods sold are transported by ships flying an overseas flag. That constitutes one of the biggest drains on our deficit in invisibles and services as far as exports are concerned.

I want to run through a few statistics. Firstly, I shall demonstrate how well Qantas is going. I would like to compare prices in 1964 to those in 1987. The cost of a Sydney-London air fare has increased by 32 per cent in that period. On the other hand, the Australian consumer price index has increased by 457 per cent, a family car by 543 per cent and average weekly earnings by 759 per cent. So Qantas' prices have not risen in line with the CPI; they have been kept down.

Another thing we ought to discuss in this debate is the nature of competition within the international airlines. Many people believe that it is open slather, but since 1945 international aviation has been commercially regulated by bilateral agreements between governments called air service agreements. We cannot just go and put on an extra 20 planes or schedule extra capacity on a route. It is all subject to negotiation and agreement between the governments. I shall give an example of where Australia is currently at a disadvantage. Because no international competition is allowed against domestic carriers in the United States, when a United States airline flies out of America into Australia the portion from America to Honolulu is considered to be domestic and the Honolulu-Australia end can be charged marginally. This is a significant disadvantage to Qantas, for example. It is a far from open deregulated environment.

In case any person has taken up the cry of the Opposition, we ought to see what has happened in the United States of America. Over the past 10 years there have been about 38 mergers and takeovers and instead of there being 29 major carriers the number has been reduced to five megacarriers with enormous clout. As my good friend the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) was saying, international civil aviation is an area where we should be very careful about having extra Australian competitors on the scene. Regulating the number of Australian competitors serves Australia well. I seek leave of the House to incorporate in Hansard two tables, the first showing the export earnings of Qantas and the second its proposed aircraft purchases program.
Leave granted.
