TALK.START.PARA: —Those figures are exciting. For example, the $3.7 billion of foreign exchange earned by tourism in 1986-87 exceeded the earnings from every single export item except coal and wool, and tourism is growing faster than every other industry and will bring in an estimated $4.4 billion in export revenue in 1987-88. Revenue from tourists is very high. Some 42 per cent of tourism flew to Australia on Qantas, providing in 1987 an estimated $1.4 billion from ticket sales and spending a further $1.3 billion while here. This is approximately 60 per cent of Australia's total tourist earnings.

SPEECH.PARA: Qantas plays a critical role in trying to readjust our current account situation, and the continued strong growth of Qantas and the role it is playing are vital for Australia's future. The debt to equity ratio of Qantas has been mentioned and clearly the proposed aircraft acquisitions by Qantas, including about $6 billion over the next few years, will place a real strain on its capital balance. But, as I understand the situation, the debt to equity ratio of Qantas of approximately 80:20 is still significantly better than a number of our leading companies, for example, Elders IXL Ltd. The Government will come to grips with that challenge.

Whilst international tourism is booming-there were projections of an increase of about 3 per cent but it is more closely allied to 10 per cent-the situation is okay. The Government needs to avoid a repeat of the situation that occurred in 1981-82 of which I am so critical. The Qantas Airways Limited (Loan Guarantee) Bill does not do anything for Qantas other than give a guarantee by the Government for the purchase of three Boeing 767-300 extended range aircraft. This will significantly help Qantas, particularly on its key Tasman and Japanese routes. I am very pleased to support this Bill but, as I said earlier, I want to be on the record as saying that this Government has a proud record of caring and of being concerned about our statutory authorities. The previous Government speaker, my good friend the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow), spoke about some of the changes the Government would be introducing in relation to Telecom Australia. We have made changes in terms of Qantas; we are making them in terms of Australia Post, Aussat Pty Ltd and the Overseas Telecommunications Commission. The record of this Government is one of action, not just words, and that ought to be contrasted with all the words we have heard from the shadow spokesman and from other Opposition members and with their inertia when Qantas really wanted help back in 1981-82. I support the legislation before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Qantas Airways Limited (Loan Guarantee) Bill deals principally with the financial support given by the Government, by way of guarantee, to Qantas. The debate is wide ranging simply because of the amendment moved by the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), but it gives the opportunity to all honourable members to discuss the future of Qantas. I should like to pay tribute to Qantas. Like the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), a week ago I went to Longreach where in 1920 Qantas was founded. We were able to inspect the sales office there and the original hangar where the aircraft were housed. Honourable members should be proud in this bicentennial year to know that we have an Australian utility such as Qantas which has served the people of Australia flying on air routes throughout the world.

SPEECH.PARA: We should also pay tribute to the safety record of Qantas. That airline has had very few crashes or accidents over the years and is recognised as one of the safest and most efficient airlines in the world. The growth of Qantas is an indication of its efficiency. The Opposition believes Australia is growing up now. We are in our bicentennial year. We have to compete with the rest of the world. We want tourists to come here and we want to share in the work and the profits that may devolve from this growing industry in Australia. We want Qantas to play its part. The Opposition does not rush in and say that all public utilities should be privatised. In the future it may be necessary for the public purse, for governments, to financially support the growing utilities that we have, but we must make sure that these public utilities are efficient in every way so that they can compete with the rest of the world.

The previous speaker, the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price), mentioned the Australian National Line (ANL). I remind the House that that line will require in excess of $33m over the next year or so to be anywhere near able to compete with the other shipping lines around Australia or anywhere else in the world. We have not been able to compete in shipping because the Australian National Line is not efficient. I do not know who would want to buy it if the Government decided to sell it, because it is a non-paying project. If ANL is to pay, it has to go into competition immediately and its operation has to change.

We do not want to see Qantas reach a stage where, as Senator Gareth Evans said when he was the Minister for Transport and Communications, Qantas will be restricted in its ability to compete with other airlines throughout the world unless we are prepared to inject more capital into it. I remind honourable members that it was the Government-the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), Senator Gareth Evans, Senator Button and other Ministers-which said that it would be necessary to privatise or partly privatise Qantas. The Government has already done this to Australian Airlines, made necessary because of the competitive boost required by that utility. It is interesting to look at the story of privatisation beyond the shores of Australia. In Europe today even the socialist countries have a program of privatisation for public utilities. In Britain the Government is privatising the steel industry, the mining industry, telecommunications. A year or so ago only 900,000 to 950,000 people owned shares in public companies in England. Today, because these companies have been privatised, over 9 million people have a say in their operation. It is expected that in three or four years 14 million Englishmen will have the opportunity of being able to take up shares in their own companies.

Let us consider Australia. In our bicentennial year we should look back to the early days after the turn of the century when it was essential for governments to establish public enterprises throughout Australia. Nobody else could afford to do it. The necessary capital from overseas was not available to Australia. Perhaps overseas lenders did not have the confidence to invest in this country at that time. So the Australian Labor Party, the National Party of Australia, the Liberal Party of Australia-any of the political parties, both Commonwealth and State, that were responsible at that time-had to take the initiative and go out and establish the shipping lines, the railways and the airways in order to give people a service. It was important for the development of Australia that we should have good transport and communications throughout the country. It was therefore essential that government should initiate the establishment of these enterprises to provide services to industry and to people who wanted to travel around on holidays. We can be very proud not only of Qantas but of the railways and other public utilities that have achieved so much.

Because of our manufacturing industries, because we produce food that the world requires, because we need to provide transport and communication services for our own people, it is essential that we ensure that those services have available to them the necessary capital to carry on. We are not saying that we want to sell all of Qantas to Australians or to people around the world-certainly nobody would want to do that-but at least the Government can sell out its 49 per cent. At least it can do what members of the Opposition have suggested in this debate and give the employees of Qantas an opportunity of purchasing shares in the company they are employed by and are so proud of. We see nothing wrong with that.

It will be beyond the ability of government and the taxpayer in the years ahead to provide the necessary finance for companies such as Qantas to carry on. Why is it that some members of the Government say to the Prime Minister and the relevant Ministers, `No, you should not proceed with this; we want to protect a company whose shares are all owned by the people of Australia because it is government owned'? It is a tragedy when that kind of thing is said here. In other words, we might as well say that every industry in this country, every private enterprise, should be owned by the taxpayer and controlled by the Government. That is a philosophy that we as Australians are completely opposed to. Why can we not say that 49 per cent of the shares of Qantas ought to be sold to the people of Australia, not to people overseas?

If one looks at the history of the Government whose members sit on the right of the Speaker, if one looks at the media interests of Australia, one will see that these people have opened up the flood gates. They have opened up the flood gates to those from whom they will get some reaction and perhaps some benefit. It is a great shame to see that happening in this country. Media interests-the written media, television, and radio-have opened the flood gates for certain takeovers which will put these enterprises into the hands of very few operators. There has been some protection, but basically that is what has happened and it has happened under the very government that today says, `No, the taxpayer is going to back this great company of ours, Qantas'.

Let the Australian people back it. There are a lot of people in my electorate who would buy shares in Qantas if they had the opportunity. It has been well managed, it has been well controlled, it has been a good operator, and every Australian is proud of it. Australia has grown up, and today the Australian people, as with people in Britain, France, Spain, Germany and other parts of the Western world, want to have a share in their country's enterprises. I appeal to the Government to think about this. The Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) should not let the Left dictate what will happen with these important Australian enterprises. The Government has floated the dollar; it has done things that a lot of us support. It has done very worthy things so far as the future of Australia is concerned. To a very great degree it has looked at Australia as a country that has grown up. Maybe the Government is right about the media in these things, but it should not stop there. It should let the Australian people have these opportunities.

Qantas has done well because it has had to compete around the world. The Government will not let Qantas fly within Australia, but after 1990, when the two-airline agreement goes out, it might give Qantas an opportunity to be the third airline in Australia. I personally would support that. The fare to travel from Perth to Sydney or Brisbane is absolutely ridiculous. One can fly to Auckland or Singapore for perhaps half that fare. I have not got the amounts at my fingertips but that is an illustration. I saw in the newspaper the other day that to go to Beijing for six nights and seven days costs $799. The honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) gave us an excellent speech this afternoon on the future of Thailand and the opportunities we have in the Asian area. Of course we have those opportunities, and the Opposition strongly supports them.

Let us forget about immigration policies and the other things that we have talked about. The fact is that every Asian who has any common sense knows how we are thinking. We want to trade with them and be fair to them and they in turn would like to do the same with us. I am sure this will happen over the years ahead.

Qantas requires $1 billion in the next few years. It has said that it will need to increase its aircraft from 31 to 50 over the next few years to compete adequately with other airlines throughout the world. As I said earlier, Senator Gareth Evans said that Qantas would be restricted if it were not allowed to do this. We do not want to be the ones to restrict it.

I do not have time to say much about the tourist industry. Much has already been said about it. Every member of this Parliament supports that industry. We know that, in time, if it is not our No. 1 foreign currency earner, it will certainly be our No. 2 earner. We want to share Australia with the rest of the world. At the moment Qantas is responsible for bringing in 43 per cent of all people travelling to Australia. It has that market and it is providing that service. For goodness sake, do not let us hold it up.

Let us look a little further afield. For years the Opposition has consistently drawn the Government's attention to the fact that we do not have a good fluid flow of aircraft into and out of the airport in the biggest city of Australia-that is, Sydney. Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport is becoming a disgrace to this country. Melbourne, Brisbane or any other capital city in Australia may have the facilities, but the fact is that most airlines want to fly into Sydney and go from Sydney to other parts of Australia. The facilities that are available are not adequate to handle the situation. Certainly, money is to be spent on the terminal. We welcome that; that is excellent. I commute through Sydney from the small country town of Taree on the north coast. Often, the aircraft is put in a holding pattern for a quarter of an hour and cannot land because of the amount of traffic. International flights face the same problem. If one commutes, one faces this problem.

It will be years before this Government builds the new Sydney Airport. I know that it is acquiring land and that it has devised a program. There is a lot of money and planning involved in constructing that airport. There is chaos at Sydney Airport because planes cannot take off and land as they would wish in order to keep to their schedules.

TALK.START.PARA: —We need a third strip at Mascot.

—We need a third strip at Mascot, as the honourable member says. We need that strip urgently. It was on the drawing board when we were in government. It was going to cost $120m to construct. Had it been constructed, this chaos today would not have existed. It is a tragedy for this country and for Sydney. The City of Sydney is building itself up. It has Darling Harbour, the monorail and international hotels.

SPEECH.PARA: Once the problem was that we could not accommodate people. In every capital city we now have accommodation for international conventions. As somebody said, 45,000 members of the Lions Club will converge on Australia next year. Australia wants a share of this convention market. Europe and America have been sharing it for years. People want to visit this country, so we have a great responsibility to provide facilities for them. Airlines should know when they fly into Sydney Airport that they can take off and land quickly, that their passengers can be processed through Customs and be met by people at the airport, or be able to continue their journey to somewhere else in the country. This Government has failed to provide the appropriate facilities for Sydney Airport to allow it to operate in the way in which it should operate.

I could continue to talk about this legislation, but the fact remains that it involves a loan guarantee by the Government, by the taxpayer of Australia. Hundreds of thousands of Australians would welcome the opportunity to invest some of their capital in an enterprise that has proved itself and that Australians would like to see continue to grow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Qantas Airways Limited (Loan Guarantee) Bill 1988 is very important. I am very pleased that so many members on this side of the House have participated in the debate. I congratulate the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) for his contribution. I also congratulate the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) and the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt). The reason that we on this side of the House have contributed in such numbers to this debate is that we recognise that the debate is about Qantas Airways Ltd; Qantas is concerned with tourism; and tourism is very important for the future of this country, the future of our economy and the future of young Australians looking for a career.

SPEECH.PARA: We on this side of the House are debating the future of our country. We are not just concerned with the future of Qantas. The reason that we are so concerned is that tourism is vitally important to the development of Australia. At present tourism is our fastest growing industry. It is our second largest export earner. In fact, it is very interesting to look at the specific items that Australia exports and see where tourism stands in relation to those items. In the last financial year we brought into this country, as income from overseas, in excess of $4 billion. That figure is greater than for any other export apart from coal. I predict that it will not be many years before tourism will be our biggest earner. It also happens to be our largest employer. Almost 500,000 Australians are employed in the tourism industry. It is interesting to look at the history of employment in the industry. In 1980 about 200,000 people were employed in the industry. By 1991 we can expect to see about 630,000 people employed in the tourism industry. It offers the greatest opportunity for growth in employment, for the creation of jobs for young Australians.

The number of overseas visitors coming to this country is growing by about 27 per cent per annum. In 1984 Australia for the first time clocked up one million foreign visitors to its shores. In 1988 we will exceed the two million figure. We expect the figure to be about 2.2 million. By the end of the next decade about five million people from overseas will visit Australia each year. That represents a real challenge to airlines such as Qantas. Therefore, what the Parliament is debating today is important, because if Qantas is to meet that challenge it needs to have the financial wherewithal in order to come up with the goods, to bring those foreign tourists into Australia, so that we can create jobs and produce income for this country.

It is also important that Qantas should have the wherewithal to meet those challenges today. Every tourist operator in Australia depends, either indirectly or directly, upon Qantas's success. The reason why Qantas is so important is that it has roughly half of the airline market into Australia. In the last few years the figure has been slightly under half, Qantas has enjoyed a protected share of the market, as it is the privileged national carrier of Australia. Because it is the national carrier it is in the best interests of every Australian to see that Qantas is able to do the job, to meet those challenges for the future.

Unfortunately, last year at about this time Qantas was unable to meet the challenge of the huge growth in the number of overseas visitors. There was a tremendous shortage of seating capacity. At this time last year we debated in this House how terrible it was that many thousands of people who wanted to visit Australia could not get seats on aircraft into Australia, in order to enjoy Australia, spend their money and help to create some jobs in the process. Because of that, Qantas and other airlines have gone to great lengths to try to create extra capacity. Because of the foreign visitor growth rate of about 27 per cent per annum, one is looking at a tremendous demand for extra seats on flights into the country.

In the last few days I have done a little ring around of major travel agents and airlines to discover how we are meeting the present demand for seats into this country. It appears we are just getting through by the skin of our teeth. Qantas has given directions to its staff not to travel overseas using their airline at present because it wants to put paying customers in those seats. It does not want to leave its employees overseas on holidays unable to come back because sufficient seats are not available for them.

Of course this is just getting through by the skin of our teeth at present. A number of people within the industry are saying that when the next few weeks have gone by we will see the number of bookings increase to the point at which they will not be able to meet the full demand. This is very serious, because each 16 foreign visitors coming into Australia create one full-time position in this country. So for every 16 potential foreign visitors that our airlines cannot bring into this country, one Australian is put on the end of an unemployment queue. That is very sad because so many opportunities could be taken up if governments were prepared to meet that challenge. I was in Western Australia recently and the people of Perth say they have a tremendous number of people flying into Perth from overseas. About 36 flights a week are coming in from overseas. Each one of those flights is chock-a-block. It is almost impossible to get a seat.

Therefore, the challenge this Government has and the challenge that airlines like Qantas have, is to grow as rapidly as Australia's tourist industry is growing. We must be sure that Qantas and other airlines have sufficient seats to bring people into Australia. Qantas has enjoyed a very special and privileged position with the Australian airline industry. Not only is it our national flag carrier, but also it has enjoyed tremendous protection through the Civil Aviation Department in the past, as it does now through the Civil Aviation Authority. The Civil Aviation Authority ensures that those countries which want to bring aircraft into Australia must give reciprocal rights. Quite often Qantas has been accused of being greedy in trying to get two flights into someone else's country for every flight that that country brings into Australia. It is important that Qantas and other airlines get a fair go, but it is also important that Qantas does not try to take more than Australia is giving to the other countries. So if we are to meet that challenge, this Government, the Civil Aviation Authority and Qantas must all work together to allow more airline capacity into Australia.

In order for Qantas to achieve that challenge it must have huge injections of capital. We are not talking about $10m or $20m. We are not even talking about $200m or $300m. As the honourable member for Lyne mentioned, we are talking about $1,000m and more than that for the future. This Bill is looking at three 767 aircraft that will cost about $100m each. I understand that each 747 aircraft these days costs nearly $300m. Over the next few years, in order to meet the challenge of the growth in the tourism industry, Qantas has to nearly double its fleet of aircraft. How will it do it? Are we to be continually coming back into the House, month after month, passing Bills such as the one we are talking about today? I hope not. I hope that this Government recognises the reality of the situation and privatises Qantas. Instead of allowing Government money to be the principal source of revenue for the growth and expansion of Qantas, rather let it be private enterprise money and let private enterprise carry the growth and development of the tourism industry as well as the growth and development of Qantas as Australia's principal airline.

As so many members on this side of the House have pointed out, privatisation is the only way to go. Privatisation of Qantas will allow it to grow as the challenge requires. Unfortunately, one of the great tragedies of Australia's tourism industry today is that this Government refuses to allow Qantas to be privatised. It flirted with the idea not so long ago. We saw major headlines across the national daily newspapers saying that Senator Gareth Evans, the then Minister for Transport and Communications, was proposing that Qantas and other Government utilities should be privatised. His arguments made a lot of sense to me and they made a lot of sense to people on this side of the House; but, unfortunately, the Government was not prepared to go down that line of argument. It was not prepared because it was still left with the crazy old loony Left. The loony Left is left over from the dark ages. It is an antiquity and archaic.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are dangerous.

—As the honourable member for Gippsland points out, they are dangerous to the future growth and development of this country. If young Australians are to have jobs and a future and if this nation is to have a high standard of living with a growing economy, we must go all out to make not only our tourism industry but also other industries grow at the maximum possible rate. The only way that will be achieved is by allowing the private sector to get in there and get on with the job, and getting governments out of the way because governments hold it back. The left wing of the Labor Party is holding back the growth and development of Qantas and the growth and development of the tourism industry. It is sad that the Left is still so dominant within the Labor Party. Its members are often heard to say today that they are a new image Labor Party, they are not like they were in the Whitlam and Calwell eras. I am afraid to say they have not changed their clothing that much. The blokes in the Labor Party must get rid of them and stop them from blocking sensible ideas like the privatising of Qantas. The only thing to be done with those people is to stick them in jars of formalin and put them into every museum in this country with a little card underneath which says, `These are the left-wing members of the Labor Party. They were created in the industrial revolution of years ago and they, like the dinosaurs of years gone by, outgrew their purpose in life and now you see them on display in the museums of Australia'. That is what must be done, because if the Government is to do the right thing for Australia, that is where the left wing of the Labor Party should be-in every museum of Australia.
—Mr Cain has just formed a new government of left wingers in Victoria.

—As the Deputy Leader of the National Party points out, it is a sad day when the Left dominates the Victorian Government. If Qantas is to grow and develop, it must be privatised. We need privatisation because the airline industry around the world today is getting incredibly competitive. One has only to see the growth and development of the mega-airlines around the world to realise why it is so important that Qantas lose the shackles of government ownership and control and get out and compete with the rest of the world. Why is the New Zealand Government trying to sell off part of Air New Zealand? It realises that unless Air New Zealand can grow, and grow quickly, it will not survive. This is the picture which Qantas will face unless it is privatised.

SPEECH.PARA: So, the whole tourism industry is being put at risk because this Government refuses to allow Qantas to be privatised. The whole tourism industry is being put at risk because 60 per cent of our foreign visitors arrive through Sydney International Airport. If honourable members have been through Sydney International Airport, as I am sure so many people have, they will have realised how inadequate a facility it is. As the honourable member for Lyne and other Opposition members have pointed out, we on the Liberal and National Party side of politics are prepared to build that additional runway at Sydney International Airport to allow that airport to handle the increased growth of traffic.

People on the Labor side talk about Badgerys Creek. Badgerys Creek is a long way from being fully operational. It is painted as being some magical cure-all. It will be 20 years before Badgerys Creek is fully operational. I do not know how passengers who land at Badgerys Creek will get into the heart of the city. Where is the expressway? Where is the train system? How will they get in? No consideration is given to those sorts of problems. We are prepared to do what is necessary to overcome the immediate problems that Qantas and other airlines that fly into Sydney Airport face.

It is not only an extra runway that is required; it is also new international terminal buildings. The best way to handle that is to give the private sector a chance to develop international terminals. If that is done, not only will Sydney International Airport improve its performance but airports like Darwin and Alice Springs and others around Australia will start to be able to cater to their customers rather than being shackled by governments. That is where we are being short changed.

As the honourable member for Farrer pointed out, one of the saddest things is that the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch) was appointed by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) as the junior Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support. While the honourable member for Barton has a pecuniary interest in halting the growth of Sydney International Airport then I am afraid that that airport will never grow. He has an interest because his electorate sits right around Mascot international airport. He is trying to ensure that his constituents are not upset by having extra aircraft using the airport. By holding back the proper growth of Mascot international airport, aircraft are being stacked up in the air. As a result people's lives are being put at risk for longer periods than they ought to be. Airlines are being forced to pay millions of dollars each year in extra fuel charges purely and simply because the honourable member for Barton is trying to protect a few lousy votes.

That is the situation that the tourism industry and Qantas find themselves facing at present under this Labor Government. It is sad that this Government has very little interest in the tourism industry. I am sorry that the new Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, does not take a greater interest in the tourism industry. He spends more time talking about the environment and those other politically advantageous areas in which he glorifies. I am afraid to say that as a result of that we are not seeing tourism being promoted as well as it should be.

In the last 12 to 18 months we have seen the Labor Party continuing to put more taxes on tourism. The arrivals tax has been introduced, and what greater farce has there been than this tax? I note that the High Court of Australia has been dealing with this matter in the last few days. There has been talk of imposing a tax on airlines for the provision of anti-terrorist services and security at airports. The cost of air charges for airlines has gone up.

It is interesting to see how genuine this Labor Government is in promoting tourism. The Government has increased charges to airlines in order to get more money out of them. This year it put up the cost of terminal navigation charges by 43.3 per cent. Charges for rescue fire services have gone up by 50 per cent this year. On-route navigation charges have gone up by 303 per cent so far this year. There has been an average rate of increase in additional airline charges through the Civil Aviation Authority of 161 per cent so far this year. That is the way this Government treats our airlines and the tourism industry. It considers them as nothing more than something to squeeze money out of. I am afraid to say that, in the process, this will add to the cost of bringing people to this country. These charges will, of course, make it harder and harder for foreign tourists to be able to afford to travel to Australia.

There needs to be a change of government and a change of attitude if Sydney airport, our tourism industry and Qantas are to achieve real growth and development. I believe that the Liberal and National parties' tourism policy that I, as the Opposition spokesman launched the other day at the Australian Tourism Industry Association conference highlights the way in which the industry will properly grow under a new government. We are going to get rid of some of those bottlenecks. Indeed, we will get rid of all the bottlenecks. The Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) International Airport is probably the greatest example of what I am talking about. It is choking the proper development of the tourism industry in Australia today.

The potential for growth exists if we have a government that is prepared to meet the challenges. I think the Bill before the House and the amendment that has been proposed by the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) will at least give some short term relief to the problems that Qantas faces. It is terribly important that Qantas be allowed to grow. As I have said, the three extra 767 aircraft will cost $100m each. If we assume that this aircraft has a capacity of about 230 passengers, that the average usage is about 70 per cent per flight, that there are about 1 1/2 flights a day and that the average fare is about $1,000, each one of those aircraft will earn for Australia about $75m each year. That is an interesting figure because it indicates that these aircraft will very rapidly pay for themselves by earning income for Australia.

So the tourism industry and Qantas are vital to the development and growth of Australia. We can see the financial gains and rewards that will be realised if Qantas is allowed to get on with the job by acquiring more capital to buy more aircraft. This will be a very cost-effective exercise for this country. Let us hope that the Bill and the amendment are passed by this House. Let us hope that we do not have to come back here and continue to debate loan Bills for Qantas. I hope, as do all members on this side of the House, that Qantas will be privatised and that it can go out into the marketplace and do what any other company in a competitive world should be able to do-compete without government shackles hanging around its ankles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This very simple little piece of legislation, which gives a government guarantee to a Qantas Airways Ltd loan, has certainly sparked a wide ranging debate over quite a period. I do not think it is appropriate for me to address all of the issues that have been raised, but in summing up I would like to address a few of the key issues raised by honourable members during this debate. Of course, the major issue has been the capital structure of Qantas and the suggested need for further capital injection from one source or another. Opposition members have placed some importance on that issue. May I say at the outset that it hardly comes as news to the Government that the Opposition is telling it that there is some contentious issue about a capital injection for Qantas. We, of course, have been very much aware of the fact that Qantas will be faced with an enormous capital expenditure program over the next five years if it is to keep up with the growth in the market and remain a major player in the international air industry. If it is to maintain its place it will have to spend in the order of $6 billion on acquiring new aircraft over the course of the next five years. That is the enormous amount of money which is necessary to finance something like 28 aircraft. As has been mentioned, this will be virtually a doubling of the size of the Qantas fleet.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me make a number of points in considering how Qantas will cope with dealing with this enormous capital program. Firstly, the Opposition has been critical of the capital structure of Qantas. Opposition spokesmen have pointed to the fact that Qantas has only $149m of paid up capital and said that this is a grossly inadequate amount. The Fraser Government did not do much to improve that situation. It put $25m into Qantas. When we came into office, Qantas had $89m in capital. In the first few months of Labor taking office, Qantas was given a capital injection of $60m, taking its capital up to $149m-a very substantial increase in its paid up capital. Obviously this was a considerable improvement to its capital structure, which had been grossly neglected by the previous Government. So it ill becomes the Opposition to be lecturing us about looking after the capital structure of Qantas when it was quite clearly so grossly neglected by the previous Government.

As I said, we have recognised the need, given the enormity of the capital outlay program for Qantas over the course of the next few years, for that program to be responsibly financed. No-one in the Government has considered that we can simply say to Qantas, `Well, you will have to borrow all that money', because that would then give the airline a debt to equity ratio which would be commercially undesirable and place the future of the organisation at some risk if there were a rapid downturn in the market. So Qantas needs to have adequate interest cover and an appropriate debt to equity ratio which will ensure that the company can survive if times of downturn should arise.

There is no doubt that there will have to be considerable borrowings to finance the program. Some use will also have to be made of the capital reserves of the organisation. There is considerable scope for doing this at times when profits are high and retained profits are considerable. However, there may still be a need for further capital injection. This is a matter which is under intensive consideration by the Government at present. It is absolutely not true to suggest that the issue is being neglected. As I said, it is under intensive consideration and we will ensure that, one way or another, Qantas is able responsibly to meet its financing problem. That will be done in a way which will ensure that Qantas is able to meet its capital expenditure requirements in a commercial way. In other words, there will not be a delay in decision-making which will mean that Qantas will be unable to purchase aircraft because of a lack of decision by government. Nor is it true that, as has been suggested by at least one speaker during the course of this debate, Qantas is already being held back by Government inaction in enabling the company to acquire further aircraft. There is no truth in that whatever. Qantas is able to acquire the aircraft that it perceives it needs at present and is doing so. Of course, the Qantas Airways Limited (Loan Guarantee) Bill is part of this.

Another issue which has been raised in the course of debate and in the second reading amendment is employee share ownership in Qantas. The issue of employee share ownership in public companies, that is, government owned companies, is obviously one which raises a considerable number of issues. It is one which the Government is giving consideration to. It will have possible application to Qantas and to other government companies which will enable additions to capital and also to performance improvement which we perceive as possible in the private sector. Indeed, in my previous ministerial role as the Minister for Industrial Relations, I was strongly concerned to promote employee share ownership as part of an employee participation expansion in this country. I can see very considerable benefits in that form of participation applying also to government business enterprises of which Qantas is the major part. However, we need to overcome a number of practical problems in relation to that and they are all under consideration at present.

Another issue which was raised with some importance is debt defeasance. There has been a suggestion both in this House and by way of press release today that the Government is trying to hide something in relation to the financing arrangements for Qantas aircraft by way of the leasing arrangements which have been undertaken. It is indeed public knowledge. It does not require this debate to make it public. It has been public knowledge for some time now. Indeed, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) in the course of debate referred to a newspaper article which was months old and which covered this issue in some detail. It is the case that there have been a number of leasing transactions by Qantas which have used the so-called debt defeasance approach. They have been used on three previous occasions. It is intended that they will be used again in relation to the aircraft which are the subject of this legislation.

I want to assure the House that on each of the three previous occasions that the debt defeasance approach was used through Japan it was cleared with the Australian Taxation Office. There is no suggestion of some underhand tax avoidance approach by Qantas. Everything that has been done has been done with the knowledge and approval of the Australian Taxation Office. There is no suggestion that something hidden or nasty has been done. On the contrary, it has been done in an open manner. Qantas was assured by the Tax Office that it was not in breach of the Australian tax law.

Debt defeasance cheapens the financing arrangements for Qantas. There is a considerable reduction in financing costs by adopting this approach. It is an approach which is adopted by other airlines around the world, by private companies and public authorities in Australia. We have the situation of public companies or government authorities and Federal Government bodies such as Qantas using this approach. It is used quite widely by international airlines. Most honourable members in the debate have said that they do not oppose the legislation. Indeed, they supported Qantas using this approach as they assumed that was the approach that was used by other airlines. I can assure them that that is the case. Therefore, Qantas in terms of its competitive position is simply adopting a practice which is widely used by its competitors.

The other issue raised was a recent tax ruling on 15 September in relation to debt defeasance which it was suggested might have changed the ball game. I assure the honourable member for Richmond, who raised this matter, that it does no such thing. The defeasance practices which were the subject of the ruling of 15 September do not apply to the defeasance approach used by Qantas either in this instance or in any other in the past. There is no concern that the rules of the game may have changed and that Qantas may now be in breach. It is not. The ruling of 15 September is not relevant to the actions of Qantas.

I now move very quickly to a couple of other issues which relate firstly to Sydney Airport. It has been suggested by the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) that we have done nothing to address the problem for international passengers at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. That is a particularly unfortunate statement as we have just announced a $240m expansion of the international terminal in Sydney. It is a rather dramatic expansion enabling a considerable increase in the number of gates and a vast increase in the amount of traffic through the international terminal.

The situation of Sydney Airport traffic generally has been raised by some honourable members in the debate, but I do not think that this is really the place to discuss this. I simply say that the Government, unlike the previous Government, has bitten the bullet and decided that we should have a second Sydney airport and that that airport should be at Badgerys Creek. The Government has set in place a program of land acquisition for that airport. It has done this over the last two or three years. That program of land acquisition will continue. There is in place a clear strategy for meeting the future concerns of aviation in the Sydney basin.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you bought the land yet?
—If the honourable member had been listening he would have heard.
—I wanted to check. Did you say you had bought the land?

—If the honourable member for Kooyong does not want to listen to what I am saying and wants to chat while I am addressing that point he can do without the information until he reads the Hansard. Once we have a report from the New South Wales task force which has been set up to investigate the aviation needs of the Sydney basin-it will report back to us shortly-we will be in a position to further assess the rate of progress at Badgerys Creek.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the Brisbane International Airport which has also been the subject of discussion in this debate, the Government, of course, through the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC), has announced that it will immediately commence the planning of an international terminal for the Brisbane Airport. The Corporation has commissioned a firm of architects to undertake the development of the conceptual design. It has indicated that subject to appropriate approvals the terminal is expected to be completed by 1993. In the meantime, it has approved an almost $5m expansion of the existing terminal to look after the growth in traffic in Brisbane over that five-year period. Of course, the timing and financing of new international terminal facilities are matters for the commercial judgment of the Federal Airports Corporation. In that respect it is worth noting that there have been claims by the Queensland Premier, Mr Ahern, and the Lord Mayor of Brisbane, Sallyanne Atkinson, that there are commercial developers who are willing to develop a new international terminal within 18 months.

The Government has established the FAC for the specific purpose of developing and operating airport facilities on a commercial basis. The Corporation's legislation gives it wide-ranging powers to do just that. If there are private developers who have genuine proposals for expediting the development of a new terminal complex, they should be putting those plans to the Corporation for its consideration. If there is such a proposal around, let us hear about it. Let us not just have political statements being made by the Premier of Queensland or the Lord Mayor of Brisbane. Let their private developers who have such ideas and proposals put them to the Federal Airports Corporation. If they do that, the Corporation will assess their suitability and decide what to do in respect of the development of the Brisbane Airport. If there is a really feasible approach around, it will be properly considered by the FAC.

In relation to capacity shortages-a matter that has been raised by a number of speakers-we are concerned to ensure that we meet the enormous growth in demand of traffic to Australia from other countries. As part of the recognition by the rest of the world of the enormous growth and recovery of the Australian economy and the desirability now of Australia as a place to visit, we have had this tremendous growth in our tourism industry. As I have said, in effect it is a recognition of the success of this Government by the rest of the world in seeing Australia now as a highly desirable place to visit, and we are experiencing a tremendous rate of growth in tourism. That, in turn, is placing considerable stress on our tourism infrastructure, including our airline system and our airports.

In relation to the airlines, there is an enormous demand for available seats. In that respect we have been approving a lot of supplementary flights over and above scheduled services. So, there is a considerable increase in the number of flights into Australia which are being approved for the peak period of the next few months-between September and February. In recent months there has been approval of applications from foreign carriers for 66 supplementary flights to operate over the current peak season and there will probably be a lot more of those, particularly in the December-January period. Our own carrier, Qantas Airways Ltd, has leased two additional Boeing 747 aircraft and, at this stage, it has plans to operate in excess of 190 supplementary services between September this year and February next year. It will monitor bookings and see whether it might even propose further increases.

Hong Kong has been a particular source of difficulty. The problem there is that Cathay Pacific has rights to Australia but Australia is lacking in rights to fly through Hong Kong to north Asia or to Europe. That is a difficulty that has brought about some restriction on the number of scheduled services. However, whilst we are sorting that out, there has been approval for supplementary flights. Cathay Pacific has applied for, and has had approved, 12 supplementary flights from August through to the end of November. Today it has also applied for a further 26 supplementary flights for the period December to February, and that application is almost certain to be approved.

Qantas has had seven flights approved for operation to the end of October and has applied for a further supplementary flight to operate over the holiday period from the beginning of December; but, to my knowledge, that has not yet been approved by the Hong Kong authorities. So, I simply assure the House that we are taking the necessary steps to try to ensure that there is adequate seating capacity between Australia and the rest of the world, and particularly in Hong Kong where the problem has been most acute. Finally, we reject the second reading amendment out of hand for the reasons that I have given in the course of my summing-up.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX ASSESSMENT (No. 1) AMENDMENT BILL 1988[COGNATE BILL:SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL [No. 2] 1988]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 August, on motion by Mr Peter Morris:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Sales Tax Assessment (No. 1) Amendment Bill 1988 concurrently with the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill [No. 2] 1988. There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bills we are debating tonight are the Sales Tax Assessment (No. 1) Amendment Bill 1988 and the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill [No. 2] 1988. The coalition parties will not be opposing this legislation. These Bills follow decisions made in the Budget, but for those who listened only to the Budget Speech of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) the changes will be something of a mystery. Behind the Treasurer's rhetorical claims of a magnificent fiscal achievement lies the reality.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, we all heard that the beer excise was reduced. However, the Treasurer neglected to mention that sales tax will now be levied at a rate of 20 per cent on all goods used to wrap or secure products for marketing, delivery and household use; that is, everything from cardboard boxes to plastic wrap to masking tape. Containers for marketing biscuits, snack goods and ice-creams are now to be taxed at 10 per cent; muesli bars and similar health food bars are hit; while for those who prefer thick shakes and ice-cream mixes there will be a new 10 per cent sales tax. All prepackaged coffee, chocolate and malt-flavoured milk drinks with less than 95 per cent milk content will now be taxed at the rate of 20 per cent.

I am reading out all these items because no Government Minister is prepared to say this to the public. Instead, the increases are buried away in the Budget Papers. The Government has tried to keep the increases quite, just as it has quietly increased sales taxes year after year. They increased by 19 per cent last financial year; by 10 per cent the year before that; and by 15 per cent the year before that. Those figures represent significant real growth above the inflation rate. Bluntly put, they represent taxation by stealth. If one does not drink much beer or indulge oneself extravagantly with the use of cosmetics, one will lose from this Budget.

The Treasurer has certainly proved himself adept in one key area of economic policy-the raising of taxes. He is the biggest taxing Treasurer since the Second World War. Living standards have been hit, and hit hard, by this Government. As the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and I have said many a time before, Labor has savaged Australian living standards. A family on average weekly earnings, with a dependent spouse and two children, would need a minimum tax cut in July 1989 of $56 per week to restore household income to its March 1983 level.

Under Labor's mismanagement, inflation last financial year was 7.1 per cent, nearly double the average for our major trading partners. Youth unemployment remains at around 19 per cent. Over 2.6 million people now live below the poverty line, and of that number 20 per cent are children. Sixty thousand people now live on the verge of homelessness and 40,000 sleep in the open or in refuges. According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the share of gross income held by the top 10 per cent of the population has increased while the average income of middle income groups has fallen in real terms, particularly for young workers and older groups.

Tragically, the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) highlighted the Government's penchant for statistical misrepresentation in a speech made last week. In trying to attack our claim that living standards have fallen, the Senator used an aggregate statistic-real household disposable income per capita-in an attempt to argue that the living standard had risen. He neglected to mention that the increases in this aggregate measure have been largely due to growth in capital-sourced incomes, including those earned by Labor's rich mates. The honourable senator's paranoia about the standard of living seems to have clouded his judgment. One simply cannot bring the incomes of the very rich into a statistic that one is using to display the living standards of lower to middle income Australians. The Hawke Ministry seems to be as supersensitive about the question of living standards as its lame duck Prime Minister is about the leadership question.

While the Budget surplus is $5.5 billion, it has been overwhelmingly achieved by increases in taxation. Over and above the sales tax changes we are debating today, an extra $5.7 billion in income tax is being collected from individuals. That is a 13.6 per cent increase and it is even higher than the 10 per cent growth of the previous year. We have one more year of tax bracket creep. The Treasurer claims that bracket creep is offset this year by revenue cuts. If so, where are the offsets for the total of $7 billion in bracket creep estimated to have been collected by the Government since 1985-86? That has not been offset. However, the problem with the taxation system does not simply stem from the level of taxation. The administration of taxation is also a major concern. In the area of sales tax the Opposition has given a commitment to reform and rationalise the existing ramshackle indirect tax system. There is a whole range of inequities and anomalies, and just plain bad, inefficient administration that has to be remedied. Having said that, I note that the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill [No. 2] will exempt from tax plain soy milk currently taxable at the 20 per cent rate, and will reduce from 20 per cent to 10 per cent the sales tax on flavoured soy milk. It has been a hard campaign by various members of the Opposition such as the honourable member for Bruce (Mr Aldred), and various community groups, to have these changes introduced. I commend the Government for finally doing so.

The Sales Tax Assessment (No. 1) Amendment Bill will amend the sale value provisions of the Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 1), so that where a manufacturer sells goods only by retail or retails goods only through an agent the sale value for tax purposes is based on the manufacturer's own costs and profit. The proposed changes are aimed to simplify and rationalise one part of the sales tax system. They are designed to stop some manufacturers gaining an undue advantage from the sales tax laws. On face value there is nothing objectionable about these changes. Let us hope, however, that the Government gets them right. We should all remember the fiasco of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) the week before last when he brought in 280 amendments to his corporations legislation only four months after the original Bills were introduced.

Some of the most damaging problems with the indirect tax system remain, however, in its administration. The people who suffer are the 800,000 or so small businesses around the country and, of course, the 16 million consumers. Let us look at some specific examples. The recent House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology conducted an inquiry into the problems of small business. The submissions from various industry bodies were very similar on the question of sales tax. The Australian Chamber of Commerce noted that the major complaint was where, and I quote:

. . . businesses are required to pay sales tax before funds are actually collected from debtors. Sales tax must be paid on the twenty-first day of the following month. However, payments from debtors usually occur some thirty to ninety days after goods or services are delivered.

This sales tax provision forces many small businesses, especially those with a small overdraft, to fund short falls by taking out bank loans. This diversion of funds reduces business investment and increases the operating costs.

The same grievance was registered by the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia-COSBOA as it is called-by ASBA, the Australian Small Business Association, the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, and others. The Australian Chamber of Manufactures went on to list other problems such as the complex administration, the high compliance costs, the simple problem of businesses being inadequately informed of Australian Taxation Office rulings, and the very slow appeal procedures for disputing Tax Office rulings. As it says, the only way in which the problems associated with sales tax can be dealt with is through a comprehensive review. But, of course, reviews of the taxation system by this Government always seem to fall short of expectations. Every review of tax it has conducted has included some tinkering with the existing system; almost inevitably some new tax; and, therefore, also inevitably, a higher taxation burden on the Australian people. The latest evidence of absolute disorder in the Government ranks is over the question of tax cuts for next year-`the biggest tax cut in the history of this country' in the words of one of Labor's de facto Cabinet members, Bill Kelty.

The supposed linchpin of the Government's economic policy-the wage-tax trade-off-appears to be a shambles. The Treasurer, who does not want wage rises and still says everything is up for negotiation, is squared off against the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who says there will obviously be wage rises and tax cuts. Of course, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris) says, `No matter what the Treasurer says, the tax cuts are inevitable on 1 July next year'.

The Prime Minister called in all his economic Ministers the other day to clear up this confusion. The Prime Minister seems to be having a little problem. He wants to talk about taxes and they want to talk about his resignation. It is a pity for him that the Governor-General's vacancy has already been filled. The fact is, as Paul Kelly reported in the Australian newspaper yesterday, and I quote:
Nobody knows where the Hawke economic team is going from here. But the good old days are over. The super-optimists who think everybody can kiss and make up are in a condition of super-delusion.

The fragility of our balance of payments position certainly has implications for next year's tax cut. The Treasurer was reported as saying in Berlin only two weeks ago that next year's tax cut would go ahead, even if Australia's trade performance suffered as a result of slower world growth. In addition, in this House on 25 August he said that the tax cut would be funded from the Budget surplus. In short, the Treasurer is intent on providing next July's tax cut without cutting government spending. That would mean an increase in private sector demand with no offsetting decline in public sector demand. The effect on our already precarious balance of payments would be untenable.

This tired, confused Government simply cannot get the broader questions of tax policy right, nor can it adequately address the specific questions of sales tax reform. I therefore foreshadow the Opposition's second reading amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite the interference from the bogong moths that have invaded the chamber, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), with his usual theatrical flair, has put on one of his sterling drive-time special efforts. But perhaps it is a bit unfair to criticise him further. He has had a troubled week with his image problem. I noted that towards the end of his speech he wished to raise questions of leadership. Obviously, he is still in a quandary about the leadership on the conservative side of politics, not only in the Federal sphere but also-that hoary little annual that comes up-the leadership in Victoria. He often talks about ordinary Australians. Now that Jeff Kennett has failed yet again, ordinary Victorians are once more raising the question of whether it would be appropriate for the honourable member for Kooyong-however it might be arranged-to go down to Victoria and help the Liberal Party with its troubles.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not dwell on that proposal any longer. Suffice it to say that the legislation before us sets out to address some of the anomalies that are apparent in our present sales tax legislation. The explanatory memorandum that has been circulated with this legislation, the Sales Tax Assessment (No. 1) Amendment Bill and the Sales Tax (Exemption and Classifications) Amendment Bill [No. 2], illustrates a number of those anomalies. The honourable member for Kooyong made special mention of the Government's decision on soy milk. It will be seen in the explanatory memorandum that that is compared to the present treatment of plain milk. The proposals put forward in this legislation address that anomaly.

It is interesting to look at some of the other anomalies that are addressed in this legislation. Let us consider fish food for the use of fish breeders. The present sales tax law provides exemption for food for livestock, poultry and birds where the people who are using it are engaged in the business of breeding such stock. Of course, pet food for domestic dogs and cats is taxable. In recent years the fish farming industry has quite rightly said that it is unfair that the food it uses for fish is not exempted. So in this proposition that anomaly is addressed.

Another anomaly that has been addressed is personal care products, some of which attract the higher tax rate of 30 per cent. They are now deleted from the schedule and therefore will attract the general rate of 20 per cent. Another instance is photographs and photographic materials. Materials such as film, paper and mounts are presently taxable at the 30 per cent rate, whereas negatives, transparencies and film strips are taxed at the general rate. It is proposed to apply the 20 per cent rate to developing and the 30 per cent rate to printing. This Bill provides for consistency in the way we deal with these materials.

One of the chief aspects of this legislation which, because of the nature of the product involved, has gained a great deal of press is the treatment of beer. In the Budget speech the Treasurer (Mr Keating) referred to inflation as Australia's number one economic disease. Reductions in the excise applied to beer are part of the strategy aimed at maintaining the downward trend in the consumer price index (CPI). As a result of the Budget, under this legislation a 20 per cent sales tax will apply to locally produced beer, which constitutes 95 per cent of the market. This makes it consistent with imported beers and all other forms of alcoholic beverage which are levied at 20 per cent sales tax. Effectively this removes an advantage enjoyed by two local brewers-the Bond Corporation and Carlton and United Breweries-over imported beer, which was previously subject to sales tax in addition to customs duty. This proposal is very much about competition. It is important to see this action as part of the Government's general policy that Australian companies should stand on their own feet without the aid of import protection.

The revenue from the introduction of this sales tax, as outlined in the explanatory memorandum, will be $330m in 1988-89. It is important, however, to also see this change in the context of a simultaneous reduction in the level of excise applicable to beer. The overall effect of this reform should see a reduction in excise revenue of $730m in 1988-89. In other words, there will be a net reduction in indirect taxes relating to beer of $400m in 1988-89, which, as the Treasurer indicated on Budget night, should see the price of a carton of low alcohol beer fall by about $5.50 a carton and the price of a carton of full strength beer fall by $2.20. These details were clearly outlined in the Budget statements. The predictions of per carton price decreases were soundly based on a survey of retail outlets and information provided by brewers. In the Sydney Morning Herald of 24 August, Mr Bill Widerberg, executive director of Bond Brewing, stated that he was `delighted':

This is the first time in a lifetime that excise has been reduced . . . It was time the Government aligned its tax policy with its health policy, giving a break to low alcohol beer, especially after brewers made an effort to come up with low-alcohol beers which serve a need in the community.

Since the Budget, unfortunately, there have been attempts to cloud the issue and to mislead and misinform the public in regard to these changes to the indirect taxation of beer. The facts are clear. There has been an advantage to the producer and the retailer which should be passed on to the consumer. Prior to the Budget it is estimated that the producer's price, including all Federal tax, for a carton of full strength beer was $15.69 and the price to the retailer, once State tax and freight were considered, was $17.49. With a retail mark-up of 20 per cent, the price to the consumer was $20.99. For a carton of low alcohol beer the pre-Budget prices were: producer's price, $14.72; price to retailer, $14.96, and, with a 36 per cent average retail mark-up, the price to the consumer, $20.35.

After the Budget, the producer's price of full strength beer fell to $14.02 and the low alcohol beer to $10.61 per carton, and the price to the retailer fell to $15.66 for full strength beer and $10.84 for low alcohol beer. Assuming a constant level of retail mark-up between the pre-Budget prices and the post-Budget prices, the price of beer to the consumer should have fallen to $18.79 for full strength beer and $14.75 for low alcohol beer. Have these cuts been passed on to the consumer? The ball is firmly in the court of the retailers. There is certainly no justification for an increase in the level of mark-up. This is particularly the case, given that in the past beer prices have increased at a faster rate than both the CPI and automatic increases in excise. Since the introduction of the automatic indexation of excise, in the September quarter of 1984, excise has risen by 29 per cent. Over the same period the CPI has increased by 34 per cent and the retail price of beer has increased by 38 per cent. In his Budget Speech, the Treasurer stated that the Prices Surveillance Authority would be charged with the close scrutiny of these prices.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating cognately the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill [No. 2] 1988 and the Sales Tax Assessment (No. 1) Amendment Bill 1988. Before the dinner break I indicated that in part the Bills attempt to straighten out a number of anomalies in the application of sales tax. As the explanatory memorandum to the Bills indicates, there will be a net revenue loss of some $6.6m in this financial year and $7m in a full year as a result of those measures. Also, these Bills include the provision to place a sales tax on beer, as announced in the Budget. It should be remembered, of course, that with the decrease in beer excise the net loss from the proposal in a full year would be some $445m. In passing I also indicate to the House that I believe honourable members would be well advised to read the explanation of the broad framework of the sales tax law that is included in the explanatory memorandum. I believe it is a good summary of the sales tax legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Immediately before the break I was speaking about how retailers had carried out their requirement to pass on the decrease in taxes on beer. I had indicated that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his Budget had stated that the Prices Surveillance Authority would be keeping an eye on the price falls. In early September Hylda Rolfe, the Prices Surveillance Authority chairperson, stated that beer price falls had further to go before a complete flow-on to consumers was achieved. A survey by the Victorian Government released in mid-September showed quite clearly that the benefits of excise cuts were not being passed on to consumers. The survey showed that the price of a dozen standard bottles varied from $15.90 to $24.05. It showed further that 6 per cent of the 370 hotels surveyed were charging above pre-Budget prices and that 33 per cent charged more than the Australian Hotels Association (AHA) recommended price of $20.65, which in any case was well above the price indicated by the Treasurer's figures.

The Victorian Minister for Consumer Affairs at that time, Mr Spyker, has argued quite correctly that in the light of the Budget changes the AHA recommended price itself is still $2 too high. The survey indicated that consumers were being ripped off; that changes aimed at reducing the consumer price index (CPI) were being used to line the pockets of some entrepreneurs in the industry. In passing, Mr Spyker should be congratulated not only on being re-elected but also on being appointed Minister for Community Services in the Victorian Cabinet. Peter Spyker is a very hardworking Minister of the Cain Government and a very hardworking local member who has continued to deliver to Labor what is really a marginal seat. Although there was some scepticism about this campaign of the Victorian Government in the run-up to the State election, it appears that the message has hit home. At least I can say that of my electorate. A survey of 10 liquor outlets, eight licensed grocers and two hotels in the Scullin electorate conducted today showed that the price of a dozen bottles of full strength beer ranged from $17.50 to $18.99, well below the AHA recommended price. There is only one instance where the price is above the $18.65 forecast in the Budget, as I outlined before the break.

The price of low alcohol beer ranged from $14.89 to $17.00. In each case the price was above the forecast fall to $14.75 but also well below the pre-Budget average price of $20.35. While there is obviously room for further falls in the price of low alcohol beer, it seems that in Scullin, at least, the benefits of Budget reform to the indirect taxation of beer are being passed on to the consumer. It is to be hoped that Scullin is not the exception to the rule and I understand that my colleague the honourable member for Streeton (Mr Lamb), in his capacity as the Victorian coordinator of the national price watch network, will be making some comments on investigations that he has evidenced and the overall aspects of beer pricing in Victoria.

The reform of the indirect taxation regime relating to beer is the centrepiece of an overall reduction of indirect taxes in the Budget of over $400m. It is estimated that these changes should reduce the CPI by half a percentage point. This will lend further weight to an expected inflation outcome in 1989 of about 4.5 per cent. It is part of a strategy of economic management which has seen a prospective deficit of $9.6 billion inherited from the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and the Fraser Government in 1983 transformed under a Labor government into a $5.5 billion surplus. It is part of a strategy which has seen unprecedented job growth. It is part of a strategy that has seen the double digit unemployment and inflation rates that epitomised the failure of the Howard-Fraser Administration brought under control at the same time. It is pathetic to listen to the economic gibberish of those opposite. They complain about bracket creep and about the artificial reduction in the CPI. There was nothing artificial about the 11.5 per cent peak in the inflation rate under Mr Howard in 1982-83.

For the first time in 20 years this Government has inflation locked into low single figures. The Opposition talks about the need for immediate tax cuts. The people of Australia know who has delivered genuine tax cuts. What were the marginal tax rates when those opposite left office? What was the company tax rate? On the one hand they complain about taxation by stealth and at the same time, when the Government delivers more than $400m in cuts to indirect taxation, they claim that this is an attempt to lower the CPI artificially. The contents of their hidden agenda are almost too frightening to contemplate but we would undoubtedly find a consumption tax or a poll tax in there somewhere in combination with horrendous spending cuts. The Opposition stands condemned that, despite promises to the contrary, it is yet to deliver its tax policy. It is something that has been long awaited by the Australian public. After five years in opposition it is one of the important policies that the Opposition should address itself to and put forward so that it can be debated in the public arena to the fullest.

The second reading amendment that has been foreshadowed by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), is really inconsequential. It is higgledy-piggledy and the same trite sort of condemnation that is always rolled out by the Opposition when talking about tax matters. It is undoubted that when the Government gets down and puts its income tax relief package in place, real, genuine income tax cuts will be delivered to, to use the words often used by the honourable member for Kooyong, ordinary Australians. I think that it is clear and has been foreshadowed and indicated that those cuts will be delivered to low income earners and that there will be appropriate targeting when those measures are announced. In the context of this present Government's overall efforts in the taxation area I have pleasure in commending the two Bills before us to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Budget package of changes to Australia's complex sales tax legislation is yet another exercise in deceit by this Hawke-Keating Labor Government. It promotes the ideals of centrification and nationalisation of the sales tax system but its real effects have a great deal more to do with the perceptions of the inflation rate than reforming indirect tax law. This effort to remove so-called anomalies will only create further difficulties for small businesses and others, who will shoulder once again the burden of some of the increases contained in this legislation. If we are to believe the financial impact statement in the explanatory memorandum, the net result of these changes will be a very slight reduction in revenue. However, I want to remind the House that the Budget estimates an overall increase in sales tax revenue of 14.4 per cent during this financial year. Sales tax will represent about 10 per cent of all revenue.

SPEECH.PARA: The measures proposed in this legislation are merely designed to redistribute what is a very large real increase in total sales tax revenue. Despite forecasts of lower inflation we see further large growth in sales tax this year. That follows the huge 18.9 per cent increase in the financial year 1987-88.

The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has spoken a lot about inflation, describing it as `Australia's number one economic disease'. I agree with his diagnosis but I think, Mr Deputy Speaker, you will forgive me for doubting the Treasurer's sincerity. If it is a disease he is the carrier. Since coming to office in 1983 the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) has presided over inflation rates which have consistently trebled those of Australia's major trading partners. He has willingly lapped up the revenue benefits from inflation in terms of bracket creep, unindexed income tax brackets and indexed indirect taxes and excises. Yet suddenly all of this has become a disease. If only the Treasurer had recognised the symptoms a few years ago, Australians would not now need the bitter medicine he prescribes. Even now the best that the Treasurer can do to tackle inflation is to play sly tricks with the sales tax legislation to attempt to engineer a reduction in the consumer price index, which is of course only a statistical measure of the real inflationary pressures in the economy. Even this cynical fiddling with indirect tax does not actually represent a reduction in tax for the coming year. The Treasurer will have to make do with a mere $1,083m in extra consumption tax revenue instead of an extra $1.4 billion, which would have been the case without these amendments. So much for the tax cutting credentials of the Government.

The sales tax exercise of this year is a mirror of the deliberate deceit wrought by company tax changes in the mini-Budget and the promised income tax cuts next year. Over time, the corporate taxation changes will actually produce greater revenue whilst the promises of income tax relief can do little more than return a fraction of the taxation harvest reaped over the past five years. Some of the origins of the taxation mess being foisted upon taxpayers go back to the ill-considered tax summit of 1985. It will be remembered that the Treasurer then favoured proposals for a broadly based consumption tax, which became known as tax option C. In fact, his priority was torpedoed by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in a back-room deal with the power brokers and the bureaucrats of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Ever since 1985, the Treasurer, with the concurrence of the now lame duck Prime Minister, has gradually expanded the wholesale sales tax system by broadening its base and producing a massive increase in revenue. This was aptly described by one columnist as `introducing consumption taxes by stealth'.

If one believes in a consumption tax, as the Treasurer obviously did, then it is quite within the bounds of reasonable behaviour for the Government to announce a policy decision to extend the sales tax system, with an eventual introduction of similar taxes on services, effectively giving Australia a consumption tax based on the mess of our existing indirect tax system. The Government should have the honesty to be open about this.
