I would argue that, even if consumption taxes were considered desirable, the existing legislation, based on at least 18 separate Acts of parliament, is an entirely undesirable foundation on which to surreptitiously build. Of course, the honourable member for Blaxland, the would-be Prime Minister, does not have the intestinal fortitude to acknowledge his support for the extensive restructuring of Australia's indirect tax system. He is willing to announce the result of his policy decision which makes it effectively a `consumption tax by stealth'. His administration of Australia's tax system has seen threats, deceit and stealth used to maximise revenue.

All too often, legislation is poorly and too quickly drafted with a myriad of amendments being constantly brought before this House to fix up past mistakes. This puts an impossible burden on both those taxpayers and tax advisers wishing to comply with legislation as well as on the officers of the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) seeking to enforce the Government's taxation mess. A tax system which constantly requires legal and professional advice before ordinary taxpayers and small businesses can even voluntarily comply needs a major overhaul. Nowhere are these administrative burdens greater than in the mess which comprises sales tax legislation.

The Business Review Weekly observed that `sales tax has become the sneakiest weapon in Treasurer Paul Keating's arsenal'. It went on to observe that `sales tax is one area where courts are ruling mostly in favour of the taxpayer'. True though that observation is, it is made meaningless by sections of this legislation which change the law to reassert the legally incorrect position taken by the Commissioner of Taxation in the first place. The stance of the Commissioner seems to be: if you cannot win according to the rules as they are, then you change the rules. This arrogance is reflected in the legislation before us tonight, which gives even greater discretionary power to the Commissioner.

The Estee Lauder case dealt with the difficulties of determining a wholesale value for sales tax purposes, when the manufacturer was also involved in retailing its products. Obviously the Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 1) had provided some, albeit inadequate, guidelines as to how this should be done. The sales tax payer had some protection from the whims of the Australian Tax Office. These guidelines are now to be removed while other measures lessen the chances of broad application of the provisions of the Estee Lauder case. The wholesale value of goods will be deemed to be the price which the manufacturer could have expected to sell the goods for, if it were also a wholesaler. This will now be determined largely at the discretion of the ATO. However, anyone who understood the pricing decisions of firms would be able to point out what a difficult task that would be. As one expert in the field said in correspondence to me, the proposed law will cause more heartache and substantial cost to many sales tax payers. I might add that this legislation makes life doubly difficult for the ATO itself because it must bear the odium of people legitimately objecting to its educated guesses at wholesale prices. Yet again, the Government and the Treasurer have demonstrated through legislation that they do not understand what is a free market or a market-determined price. In the absence of a wholesale market, it is impossible to deem a wholesale price. The idea of deeming a price is as much a nonsense as the mercantilist notions of a just price which Adam Smith dispensed with a long time ago.

I now turn to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2), which introduces the changes to sales tax rates described as removing anomalies. It is these changes which, combined with other legislation, effectively reduce the price of beer and low alcohol beers and reduces the rate of sales tax on many cosmetics. However, the legislation will also increase the rate of tax on a range of items previously treated as tax exempt. Revenue from these changes will contribute to the continuing sales tax windfalls which the Government expects in the coming year and will lay the foundations for further imposts at the Government's whim.

As we have come to expect from this Hawke-Keating Government, the so-called anomalies corrected in this legislation are mostly anomalies created by the Government when increasing sales tax rates earlier. The only anomalies which we see corrected are those in which previous figures were not wide enough to cover everything which the Government intended. For instance, only recently a sales tax on snack foods was introduced. The Government is now extending the same rate of tax to containers for those foods-all, it claims, to remove an anomaly which would not have existed if not for the original tax increase. Similarly, sales tax on all bags and wrappings is being extended in a way which will produce significant costs for those providing a service to the public. For obvious reasons the Treasurer has not bothered to give us an estimate of the effects of these changes on the consumer price index, but the very direct costs of those changes to thousands upon thousands of small businesses across Australia is clear to all who take the time to look. It has been a consistent pattern that revenue estimates of tax changes under this Government have underestimated the burdens of those new taxes.

I suggest that all of the changes to sales tax on packaging will produce a good deal more revenue than we have been told. These changes will affect virtually all industries and will represent yet another convenient windfall for the Government. While revenue producing anomalies are supposedly being cleared up, the sales tax system remains a scandalous dog's breakfast. This is true in regard to enforcement provisions in the legislation, as well as the continuing anomalies which this legislation does not touch. Many of those anomalies are a feature of a sales tax fiddle which often differentiates between ostensibly similar items on the grounds of use. For example, batteries are subject to all four rates of sales tax. Small `button' batteries for use in hearing aids are tax exempt, while very similar batteries for watches or other electronic items are subject to the 30 per cent tax rate. In the case of 1.5 to 6 volt batteries, they are taxed at the 10 per cent concessional rate, while common batteries such as the 7 volt Eveready battery are taxed at the standard 20 per cent rate. To my mind, these are glaring anomalies which will be a great nuisance to the wholesalers of batteries.

The criterion of use is not applied consistently. Imported mineral water is taxed at the standard rate of 20 per cent, but other drinks attract a 10 per cent tax. Cakes are tax exempt, although some biscuits are taxed at the 10 per cent rate. Yet the use of all of these drinks, cakes and biscuits is obviously very similar; without question, all of the items end up in the same anatomical place. The total sales tax impost, far from evening out the treatment of similar goods, has been used to confer privilege, protection and advantage on the producers of some goods. The new measures in these Bills do little to alter what is a fundamental problem in the current wholesale tax regime.

The other area of difficulty is in the administration of the sales tax legislation. I have raised this matter many times in the context of our income tax system, where enforcement has been draconian. The sales tax area, which is an inherently more difficult part of the tax law, is also complicated by what appears to be a consistently poor record of interpreting the legislation by the Commissioner of Taxation. The difficulties that the Australian Taxation Office is having in the courts must arise from either poor legislation or poor judgment on the part of the Australian Taxation Office. The Treasurer has a responsibility to ensure that the problems of administering legislation in practice are cleared up. However, that is not achieved by giving the Tax Commissioner even greater discretionary power.

It is when discretion can be exercised that taxpayers have no guidance as to how they should act before the event. The ATO is likely to face both justified antipathy and unnecessary legal problems. Cricket umpires have a general rule of thumb that, when in doubt, a batsman should be given not out. You know that only too well, Mr Deputy Speaker. Sometimes in the run of the game this causes conflict, but the fielding side at least has a second chance; the batsman does not. If only the Tax Office had a similar attitude, it would have a lot more credibility and support. Instead, we see legislation and practice to the effect that the benefit of the doubt should go to the Tax Commissioner and his discretion. In cases of genuine doubt the Australian Taxation Office serves as its own umpire and, like the fielding team, rules in favour of itself. It is only when such matters go to court or to the various review panels, which all cost the taxpayer a good deal of money, that those rulings are challenged. Wherever possible, clear legislation is abundantly preferable to the ad hoc discretionary powers which this Government constantly distributes to increasingly powerful bureaucrats.

Legislation can achieve only very limited benefits. When legislation tries to deal with ambitious schemes outside its competence-the competence of either the Government or the Australian Taxation Office-it is usually ineffective and very often disastrous. The Government's Medicare mistake, which regulates the thousands of separate relationships between doctors, patients, hospitals and other health care providers, is just one example of ambitious legislation which cannot work. Sales tax legislation is equally ambitious, seeking as it does to categorise virtually all types of goods available on the market into three tax rates, or into a tax exempt category. In attempting this it is inevitable that endless anomalies will appear, and they do.

To pretend that the 10 or so specific changes in these Bills are a significant step towards rationalising the so-called sales tax system is plainly ridiculous. This legislation is a cynical attempt to manipulate the recorded inflation rate by tampering with beer prices. The Treasurer admits that quite openly. However, behind that is the picture of a huge growth in sales tax revenue which has led people to suggest that the Treasurer is well down the path towards a universal de facto consumption tax. The ultimate test of how far we are down the road to a consumption tax by stealth will be the extension of wholesale tax to areas which have traditionally been considered services.

In its administration of existing legislation there are some indications that the Tax Office is already preparing the ground for the taxation of services through the sales tax system. Those signs are not merely confined to its utterances on some of the administrative procedures that it adopts. It is also suggested by the surveys being undertaken, at the behest of the Australian Taxation Office, by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. We all know that the fringe benefits tax was an outcome of the 1984 household expenditure survey conducted by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. We can expect something along the lines of a sales tax on services if the ATO and the Treasurer have their way. If this occurs we will be burdened not only by a universal consumption tax but also by an unworkable consumption tax, based on inappropriate legislative foundations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —We heard from the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) a strong complaint-a complaint levelled at the Government-that somehow we were artificially reducing the consumer price index (CPI), that is, the cost of living. What he did not say, and what he should have said, was that there has actually been a drop in the cost of living, a drop in the CPI, due to the measure taken by this Government, including changes to sales tax. It is not simply a matter of tampering with beer prices, as the honourable member put it. It is a matter of actually reducing prices of beer. I will come back to that later tonight and give some details of how in my own area, due to the Government's reduction in excise, tempered by the imposition of sales tax on beer, and the scrutiny of the national prices network, there has been a reduction in revenue to the Government passed on to the consumer through actual reduction in beer prices.

SPEECH.PARA: The thing that really irks the honourable member for Curtin is that when the Opposition tried to reduce inflation, it did it at the expense of workers' jobs. The only formula it knew was to trade off unemployment for a reduction in the cost of living. It failed on both counts. When the Government of the honourable member for Curtin left office in 1983, the inflation rate was 10.3 per cent. We have reduced that successfully to just over 7 per cent. Over the same time, unemployment has gone down 3 percentage points. There is the crux of the difference between the Opposition when it was in government and this Government. We have managed to do what hardly any other country in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development has been able to do. That is, to rein in, to curb inflation and at the same time increase employment. The facts are there if honourable members want to dispute them further.

Let us go back slowly and educate honourable members on what the role of sales tax is about. Of course, it is a significant item of Government revenue and if applied savagely, other than marginally, it can affect the demand for a particular product. Of course, its degree of impost, whether it be zero or up to 30 per cent, reflects the community's preferences and needs for a particular consumer item.

Sales tax, as was correctly pointed out by the honourable member for Curtin, is the third highest revenue earner for the Government after tax on pay as you earn earnings, including Medicare, and the prescribed payments system, which make up 54 per cent of collections; company tax is 13.6 per cent, particularly when the fringe benefits tax and withholding tax is included; and in third place is sales tax at 10 per cent. Last year the growth in sales tax was 19 per cent. Before getting carried away with that increase, it should be realised that nearly 7 per cent of that was due to the withdrawal of sales tax exemption to Commonwealth commercial authorities. In other words, now they have to pay their way just like other private sector enterprises. Therefore, there is a significant amount. Deduct the usual level of inflation around 7 per cent, and the rest can be explained in growth in consumption and demand due to increased employment and increased spending power across the community.

So I am not particularly perturbed that it was a 19 per cent increase. It takes the pressure off other areas of tax collections. In the financial year we have just entered, we expect it to rise 14.4 per cent. Although that is above the level of inflation, it should be realised that it is due to an expanding economy; it is due to a healthy economy. We should not be perturbed by that. It is due to a stronger than anticipated consumer demand. However, with the reduction in tariffs that this Government has brought about and the removal of the 2 per cent import duty, the sales tax collection will grow more slowly than it did before. In other words, what the Government has introduced in these two Bills is part of its comprehensive anti-inflationary strategy. We can expect that to nestle down to about 5 per cent over the coming 12 months.

We need to compare sales tax with what the honourable member for Curtin was advocating and going gung ho for-a consumption tax. The `bribe' that is dangled in front of the electorate-that $56 a week reduction in tax for the average weekly earner-has to be financed from somewhere. If we are to have a so-called 52 per cent fall in average weekly earnings, which I pointed out was the greatest source of Government revenue, if we are to find this $23 billion, then one of three things will happen. First of all, there will be a huge drop in Government services. The calculations are that if the Opposition were, in Government, to carry out its bribe-and heaven help us if it did-it would have to reduce Government services by 26 per cent. More than a quarter of essential Government services would have to be reduced to finance that reckless bribe or the Budget deficit would blow out. Of course, that did not worry them in the past. When they left government, it had swollen out to almost $10 billion. But this Government, through careful and responsible economic management, has turned around the Budget deficit to a $5 billion surplus. Or the Opposition could finance those reductions in income tax through bringing in the dreaded consumption tax.

What would be the results of bringing in the dreaded consumption tax? First of all, there would be less tax equity. It is not a progressive tax. Although Opposition members might argue that those who spend more will pay more, what they forget to add is that when the small amount comes from a small income it is far harder for a family to bear than a larger amount from a huge income. We do not have tax equity with consumption tax. That is one of the reasons why this Government rejected it.

It would also bring about a big boost to inflation. Across the Tasman Sea, New Zealand's experiment with a consumption tax has brought about 19 per cent inflation. In the United Kingdom the value added tax brought about a similar jump in inflation. It was not just a one-off impact either, but one which took many years to dissipate.

We then point out perhaps one of the most adverse features of a consumption tax, which is that it applies to all goods. The honourable member for Curtin tried to convince this chamber that there was no difference between a consumption tax and a wholesale sales tax; that somehow it was a consumption tax by stealth. Nothing could be further from the truth, because wholesale tax is selectively applied, as I said at the beginning of this speech, to reflect the community's needs and preferences, but a consumption tax is applied across the board without regard to essential services and needs such as food and clothing. Every service and every product would bear this iniquitous tax on consumption if it should ever be brought in.

That is why this Government rejected it. It is not just for a happy deal with the trade unions that it was rejected. It was rejected because the community had rejected it. In public opinion poll after public opinion poll the community expressed its horror at the idea of the Opposition's consumption tax and argued effectively against it through pensioner organisations and the Australian Council of Social Service. So let us have it out in the open. Be honest. How would the Opposition finance its bribe, this $56 a week on average earnings? How would it finance a halving of personal income tax? It would do it through the back door. It would bring in that sneaky, inequitable dreaded consumption tax.

The latest changes introduced by this Government to the wholesale sales tax is to reduce inequities and anomalies and to rationalise the scales. One would have thought that maybe it should have been got right the first time-except that, we must point out, we do not live in a static commercial world. We live in a dynamic commercial world where preferences, tastes, sales leaders and the whole commercial activity are constantly under dynamic change. Therefore, a responsible government is there to review the impact of sales taxes and to adjust them according to consumer preferences, uses and needs. It is not a matter of chopping and changing. It is a matter of responsible government.

I mention just a few instances raised in my electorate. First of all, there is the 20 per cent sales tax on delivery wrappers of all types, the courier bags and so on, and caught up in this are now supermarket bags. It is very hard to know what the difference is between a plastic bag and one of the flimsy supermarket bags that are handed out. The complaint was that we have included household plastic wraps and so on that are used to wrap up kids' lunches. We have not included them at the same rate. We have included them at 10 per cent for the very good reason that the Commissioner of Taxation is not in a position to determine the final use of a product. While some household wrappings are manufactured for the purpose of wrapping lunches, they end up being used in other ways and should attract a 20 per cent sales tax. So here we have an effective and responsible compromise.

The sales tax in the photographic area was 30 per cent on films and papers and 20 per cent on negatives and film strips. Now all of these items will be taxed at 20 per cent. This will reduce the anomalies and differences which were very hard to discern. I should point out that with modern printing techniques it is becoming more difficult to distinguish between photography, printing and photocopying. Printing and photocopying materials now are to be taxed at the same rate. We have recognised the dynamic change in technology, and have changed the sales tax accordingly.

Personal care products such as shampoo, body powder, cosmetics and deodorants carried a 30 per cent sales tax whereas soaps, toothpaste and shaving creams were taxed at 20 per cent. For the life of me, I fail to see the differences. These products really cannot be treated as luxuries. Some are health items. Powders are used for excessive sweating. Cosmetics are used not only for beautifying but can give a person with some minor scars or disfigurement self-confidence. So this Government has quite rightly said, `Let us reduce all of the sales taxes to the same level of 20 per cent'. Accordingly, the cost of living has been reduced for these every day items.

The previous Government imposed a 20 per cent sales tax on soya milk because of the Liberal's inability to argue with their coalition partners, the National Party, which said that there must be some protection for dairy milk. That Government did not have any regard for people who may be forced to drink soya milk because of allergy problems. This Government had removed that 20 per cent impost from soya milk. In the case of flavoured soya milk, the sales tax has been reduced to 10 per cent. I compliment the Government on that.

I return to the question of beer prices. We have imposed a tax of 20 per cent on beer containing more than 1.15 per cent of alcohol measured by volume. That is more than offset by a reduction in excise. The net loss in the trade-off to the Government has been some $435m. The estimated drop in savings should all be passed on to the consumer. The savings are 16c for a can of light beer and 6c for standard beer; 34c for a bottle of light beer and 14c for standard; 14c for a 285 millilitre pot of light beer and 6c for standard. Prices should have fallen. But over recent years it has been reported to me, and the Government is aware of it, that wholesalers or retailers in the brewery area have taken advantage of excise increases to raise the price of their products and have then blamed the total price increase on the Government. Let us turn that round on its head. By their own logic, they should pass on to the consumer the whole drop in the price. It was pleasing in the first instance, straight after the Budget, to hear the Australian Hotels Association (AHA) recommend to its members that the full extent of the price drop be passed on to consumers. The Association apparently realised that its members could not have it both ways. But that did not last long.

Beer prices have been closely monitored across Victoria over the last month or so by the national prices network, of which I am a Victorian coordinator, to ensure that the Federal Government's Budget cut in beer excise was actually directly passed on to the consumer. All Victorian prices action groups under the national price watch network have been surveying a range of beer products in hotels, bottle shops, licensed supermarkets and other outlets. The Victorian Minister responsible for prices, Mr Spyker, also surveyed prices under the Victorian Government's prices peg. I am pleased to report that he has retained his portfolio which he has carried out effectively. He has successfully held a range of items down to a 6 per cent increase in price. But he found out that the recommendation of the Australian Hotels Association was not fully complied with. In fact the AHA should have recommended a drop in the price of a carton of ordinary beer of $2.20 but recommended only $1.68. In regard to the price of light beer, which should have fallen $5.50, the AHA recommended a fall of just $4.08. It went back on its world, its recommendation that it said it would implement immediately after the Budget. Goodwill does not last long.

We find in the survey that was carried out three weeks ago that 6 per cent of hotels are still charging pre-Budget prices and that 29 per cent are charging up to 10 per cent over the recommended AHA price; But, fortunately, 44 per cent of hotels are charging up to 10 per cent below the AHA price; 18 per cent up to 17 1/2 per cent less; and 3 per cent bravely have gone out in an attempt to capture more of the market by reducing the recommended price by more than 17 1/2 per cent.

I am pleased to report that in my own electorate, where the national prices network has been extremely active and successful, the Bayswater, Rowville, Ferntree Gully, Mitcham and Nunawading hotels have been less than 12 1/2 per cent below the recommended price. The Dorset Gardens at Croydon and Daisy's at Ringwood have been, significantly, among the leading hotels to reduce their prices. Our survey will be completed next week and we will have more to report to the public. But competition is necessary if the Government's reductions are to be passed on to the public. We cannot guarantee lower prices-we do not have price control at the Federal level. We can reduce sales tax but, ultimately, it is up to competition and organisations such as the national prices network and the Victorian Government's prices peg to ensure that lower prices get to the people. I believe that the national prices network has provided an invaluable service to Victorian consumers in encouraging competition between retail outlets. I want to place on record my thanks and congratulations to the price surveyors-the pensioners who have come forward to help us out with our surveys.

The honourable member for Curtin said that small businesses were going to have to suffer a little because of the changes in sales tax. Quite the opposite is the case. Let us take one small business-that of fish farms. The Government has decided to remove the 20 per cent sales tax on food which is used for fish breeding and for fish farmed commercially. I happen to have three or four fish farms in my electorate. One can understand that there is a ready market in Melbourne for fish grown in the clear oxygenated streams in the catchment areas outside of Melbourne. I speak here of Tommy Finn's Trout Farm at Warburton, the Australian Rainbow Trout Farm at Macclesfield and the Buxton Trout Farm at Buxton. Of course, just out of my electorate of McEwen is the Thornton Trout Farm. The Buxton Trout Farm consumes 80 tonnes of fish food at $790 a tonne. At a conversion rate of 1.6-that is, 50 tonnes of fish produced for every 80 tonnes of food-the removal of the sales tax means that that farm alone will save $12,500 in farm inputs. That is what this Government has been all about-reducing the cost of producing farm products. The Thornton farm, with an output of 400 tonnes, will save $100,000 through this move by the Government. We get cheaper fish and a lower cholesterol diet. In one fell swoop, by changing the sales tax, we get a healthier community and a cheaper product.
This is not a beer led recovery; it is not a fish led recovery. What the Government has carried out is a proper review of sales tax in a dynamic commercial world. I commend the Bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are dealing with two sales tax amendment Bills-the Sales Tax Assessment (No. 1) Amendment Bill and the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill [No. 2]. Both of these Bills contribute in the overall sense to additional revenue for the Government. It is quite interesting that they are the result of advice given to the Parliament in the May economic statement. That, of course, was one of the better exercises in creative accounting. We had a much trumpeted, much publicised tax cut for paper shufflers in big business. At the same time, we had a removal of the accelerated depreciation conditions applicable to manufacturers, farmers and all the producers in our community. When we look at year 3 when that all settles down we find the loss to Government revenue by way of the tax cuts is $1,700m. It is a gain to Government revenue from the removal of the accelerated depreciation provisions of $1,650m. In that case if he is lucky, the consumer-the Australian people-is $50m in front. That is some big saving. Of course, in terms of the sales tax measures it is no where near compensation.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Streeton (Mr Lamb) made a lot of the arguments for equity and rationalisation et cetera. I am a little fed up with his Government's arguments about equity. Every new tax we have introduced is for the purpose of equity, to overcome an anomaly, to close a loop hole and it frequently does those things. But, we never see the money going back to the people. The Government takes it in fringe benefits tax. It does not give it back in real tax cuts. The Government lowers some marginal rates after, of course, people have all stepped up into a new tax bracket and their personal tax rate does not alter.

I had this brought home to me in a very significant fashion the other day in a five-line letter to the editor. I had been on television and radio complaining bitterly on behalf of the one-time Labor constituency, those typical wage earners who earned gross about $300 a week. I want to know how those people managed because I know that I would have great difficulty at that level. A lady wrote to the West Australian asking, `When is Mr Tuckey going to wake up that it is not $300 a week; it is $300 a fortnight'. Of course, she is right. I have written back and apologised to her through the newspaper saying that I have chosen to talk gross. The person who has to use the spending powers is talking net, whether she be a welfare recipient or the wife of a husband earning money at about that level. Of course, people have this massive tax slug taken from them and to this we add all of these additional consumption taxes that we are debating tonight. She is right; she is lucky to have $150 a week to spend. The Government might wonder why it is those people are deserting it in droves. The Government is doing it to them. Of course, while the Government avoids the argument that it made originally it forgets that the tax on an item for consumption is an equal tax, numerically and nominally between the poorest consumer and the richest in most terms. I admit that the very rich will pay more consumption tax on a Rolls Royce than others on their Holden but on the basics that we consume each day it does not apply.

Let us look at what has happened to taxation in five years of a Labor Government. The last Fraser Budget collected some $44,000m in revenue. The Budget presented to this Parliament this year by the Treasurer (Mr Keating)-his latest economic miracle-raises $88,000m. That has doubled in five years. There is no evidence of the doubling of gross domestic product, the doubling of the population or the doubling of exports in that time. If we take the comparison of last year's Budget to this year's Budget, dividing the population of Australia, man, woman and child, into the gross revenue collections we find in the Government's own Budget Papers that this year the per capita taxation levied on Australians is $5,317. This is not wage earners, not profit makers. Every Australian man, woman and child is up this year for $5,317. It is up from last year's figure of $5,042, which is a jump of about $275 per capita-$1,100 per family of four. It is not a bad effort in one year.

As I have said to this Parliament before how good a Budget administrator has one got to be to balance the books or to go into surplus when one has control of the turnover and when one can just say, `Please sir, I want some more'? In the case of our arrogant Treasurer one should delete the word please. The point is that one of the great imposts of this Budget in terms of increased taxation is sales tax. The last time I looked at the monthly projections for income of the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) I recollect that sales tax collection last year were up over estimate about 20 per cent. The actual collections therefore that are recorded in this year's Budget Papers represent a substantial increase over what the Government expected to raise last year. It raised $7.576 billion in sales tax alone and it was not enough. The Government had to get more. So this year the Government is raising $8.651 billion.

Of course, when we work that out per capita-consumption taxes are only paid by people-we find that last year the Government took $462.10 from each and every Australian man, woman and child. That was nearly $1,800 per four-unit family. This year the Government proposes to pay $519.67. It is a huge burden; it is a burden the people cannot afford. But it is the only solution to this Government's sort of economic management. It is interesting because we are told that if we let up on the tax regime people will spend more. The Government's other great economic problem is the fact that Australia as a nation is overspending thousands of millions of dollars a month more than it sells to the rest of the world. This is not withstanding all of the lift in commodity prices last year. We remember the Government's tears of woe, how it blamed the rest of the world when all of its budgeting went astray because commodity prices fell. But now that commodity prices are up again has it affected Australia's overseas indebtedness or its trade deficit? No sir, it is still going up. It did not drop last year on predictions notwithstanding the huge increase in the income to this nation that we received.

As we say, `You cannot rewrite history in this place; it is all on the record'. The record says what the Government projected. It projected $11.5 billion at the beginning of the year. The Government did not take into account the increase in commodity prices. At the end of the year what was the Government's total trade deficit? It was $11.5 billion. It got extra money; it did the Government no good. The Government presumes, of course, that if it gives the people of Australia a bit of extra money through tax cuts that they will spend it on imported goods. It presupposed they may not save it for their old age and assist us with our foreign indebtedness. The Government does not know that but it is a pretty good excuse for not giving people the money.

A lot has been made in this debate about this brilliant and generous move to reduce the price of beer. If the Government were genuinely determined to help the people of Australia and if only the beer drinkers, I could support it in that. We all know what the Government is about. It is a cynical move to reduce the consumer price index (CPI) in almost an artificial way. But the Government cannot tell me why it picked on beer. I went and got the documentation to have a look at the consumer price index. In the broad categories it covers food, clothing, household equipment and operation, transportation, tobacco and alcohol, health and personal care, recreation and education. The thing that jumps out at me in all of this is transportation, personal and public. What do modes of transport consume in very larger quantities-they consume fuel. What does the Government get one of its biggest tax levies from? Fuel. Fifteen per cent of the total gross domestic product of this country-$1 in $7-is spent on transport. Why did the Government not cut the tax burden on fuel? Why did it not give everybody a go?

Let me tell honourable members opposite what is so cynical about the Government's dropping of the CPI. Hopefully, the Government can boast about it. The Treasurer can go off to another International Monetary Fund conference and boast. I suppose honourable members noticed when the television cameras zoomed around at the last conference that he was talking to about 20 people. He had as large an audience at that international conference as I have in this House. When he goes overseas he lectures Americans and others about the effects his policies have had on inflation. But if inflation drops, so does the amount of the increase in pensions because pensions are indexed to the CPI. It is too bad for the non-drinking pensioner who chooses to go out at weekends in his motor car to see his grandchildren; there is no help for him. He will get less money if the CPI is down as it will hold down his pension, but this Government does not give him any help with his fuel or with the sales tax on his tyres.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is deliberately dropping the standard of living.

—This Government will bring down the standard of living of pensioners by this deliberate move. Unless the pensioner is a person who spends his whole pension on beer, he will be behind on the arrangement. It has to be understood that that is the decision of this Government. It is not much help to the people. I guess that the Government will keep blaming small business because things have not worked out. The Government will keep blaming small business for inflation. It will have its price watch committees. The Government will pay people, as does the Government in Western Australia, $40,000 or $50,000 a year to run this price watch farce. If the Government wants to know how much small businesses, grocers and others, are making it should go and look in their garages. It should count the Rolls Royces and the Jaguars. It will find that they are not there. Those people are not profiteering on the community; the Government is profiteering on the community. The only price watch we need in this place is on this Government and the massive tax burden that it is imposing on the people.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to raise some other matters relating to my electorate, including the huge confusion that exists in the present requirements relating to tax exempt status for rural producers. To be quite honest, the situation has become a farce and it has become quite difficult. The problems are legion and nobody knows where to turn. Little by little suppliers have discovered, as the law has always provided, that they are the taxpayers. The Australian Taxation Office is not interested in pursuing the purchaser; it is too difficult to find him. The law says that the wholesaler is the taxpayer. It is his obligation to collect the tax and it is too bad for him if he makes a mistake. It is too bad for him if he gets a document or a certificate signed and it is wrong. We have a law that states that a person making a false declaration can be prosecuted. It just never happens. People have been sent broke by trusting bad advice. Furthermore, the opportunity for a simple appeal to, say, a board of review on a determination is non-existent. A person can go to a board of review on the rate of tax paid but that person cannot go and debate at that simple level whether an item should be exempt. All these ridiculous things are occurring.

Recently the National Farmers Federation put out a booklet which is excellent and helpful. In embarrassment, the Tax Office thought that it should also put one out but, of course, it is misleading mainly by omission. One of the more obvious examples happens to occur on page 13 of that document, which states:
There is no exemption for oils, greases and other lubricants purchased for use in agricultural industry.

But we find that there are exceptions. People can still buy certain tax exempt oils under the law. I would have thought that it would have been reasonable for the Commissioner of Taxation to have advised farmers when that booklet was eventually put out.

But that is not all. Let us look at some of the suggestions the Tax Office has made. A farmer might wish to buy a chainsaw and he writes in for tax exemption because he is going to use it in agriculture. What do we find the Tax Office saying? It states:

There are only two very rare occasions when chainsaws are exempt from sales tax. The first is when they are used exclusively or principally for the manufacture of goods which are exempt from sales tax, for example if they are used exclusively or principally to produce fence posts for sale or personal use. The other occasion is when they are used to a substantial extent to clear land.
These experts, sitting in their ivory towers in the city, go on to state:
It is very unlikely that the major use for chainsaws would be for these purposes as most chainsaws are put to a variety of uses like cutting firewood for domestic use or lopping and pruning trees.

The only time a person lops or prunes a tree on a farm is when he cuts it off a fence after the wind has blown it there, and that is an agricultural pursuit. The people in this place who represent rural electorates would know the extent to which farmers today cut down their trees for firewood. They have gas stoves and generally some of those benefits of life.

When a farmer wants a chainsaw he needs it for agricultural purposes and he should be entitled to the exemption provided by the law. But the reality is that we have these tax rulings. We have given so much discretion to the Tax Commissioner that he does not worry too much about the law; he just worries about how he feels each day of the week. In some of the documentation that I have is a letter which makes me shudder every time I read it. The letter has the beaut new logo of the Tax Office on it. What makes me shudder is that written across the bottom in quarter-inch letters are the words `Taxes-Building a better Australia'. Does anyone in this place believe that? Do they believe that the way to make the nation grow is by taking a bigger and bigger percentage from the people of Australia-those who might invest money in such a way as to enable us to overcome our international indebtedness? `Taxes-Building a better Australia'! This is the ethos that has been built by this Treasurer, who has handed over all power to the bureaucracy. I have always argued that the role of a politician is to be the insulation between the people and the bureaucracy. This Government has handed the Australian people to the bureaucrats and the Tax Office now has the courage to put things like that on its correspondence. It is printed on every letter that one gets from the Tax Office today.

Let me give a few more examples. People in my State are unfortunate in that when they want a truck they have to bring it all the way from the eastern States and it is not tax exempt unless it is kept on a farm, which is most unusual. It is usual for those trucks to be delivered by the manufacturer. They arrive in Western Australia with a freight component of thousands of dollars and it, too, is liable for sales tax. That is a distinct disadvantage for the people living in my State. It is wrong. It should not happen in those circumstances. If wholesale tax is involved the freight should not be included from that point.

Recently Mr Ivan Gale contacted me and said that he wanted to improve his productivity by weighing his fleeces and linking that weighing process to a computer. The weighing device would be free of sales tax but the computer that will be linked to it would not. But if he were a dairy farmer it would be. What is the sense in all of that? Mr Stan Lewis, another farmer in Western Australia, is fighting a very good fight through the Western Australian Farmers Federation to try to run down some of these things. We still have things for which we have to fill in forms.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Punch The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although I heard only part of the debate there are a number of things that I should say. The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), who has just spoken in this House talked about tax generally and about this Government's stance. It is a typical trait of any tory political party, whether it be here, in Britain or in the United States, to attempt to label the progressive party, which the Opposition opposes, as the inventors of tax. We are seeing Vice-President Bush trying to do it to Governor Dukakis at the moment. We are seeing it here again tonight. The Liberal Party speaks with all these platitudes and critiques as though the Australian Labor Party invented tax and there was no taxation in this country, direct or indirect, before we won power in 1983. That is the line that comes from the Liberal Party.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the most precocious load of rot that every tory administration in the western world attempts to paint. It will not work because everybody in this country knows that the Liberal Party and the National Party do not like the fact that the present tax regime is closing up the rorts-one rort after another-and not so that the ordinary blue collar workers, who the honourable member for O'Connor supposedly represents and is so concerned about, are disadvantaged. The ordinary wage and salary earners of this country do not have much discretion about how much tax they pay. The have to pay their way in this country the way they have always had to pay their way. We believe that that should be equal for every Australian. All Australians should pay their fair share of tax. That is why honourable members opposite do not like the fringe benefits tax; that is why they do not like the capital gains tax; that is why they do not like the curtailment of entertainment expenses in the tax regime. They do not like it because it cuts out rorts. In the next breath they have the absolute hypocrisy to stroll up and down the parliamentary floor saying, `Why don't you cut this tax or that tax'.

We on this side would like to know the answer to one simple question. We hear plenty of criticism from honourable members opposite, but where is their tax policy? Andrew came out of the swimming pool for five minutes with his serious profile the other day, saying, `The Liberal Party should release its tax policy well before the next election'. How long ago did he say that? We still have not heard anything. When will we have a tax policy from the Opposition, Andrew? When will we have an indirect tax policy? When will we have a direct tax policy?

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I wonder whether the Minister could refer to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition by his correct title and not by his Christian name.
-It does seem strange when people refer to an honourable member by his Christian name. The Minister will address his comments through the Chair.

—Only the Christian souls, Mr Deputy Speaker. I find Opposition members totally hypocritical. They do not like an even tax regime. They do not like a situation in which their arch supporters cannot meander in and out of taxation. That is what they do not like. They proclaim their rage at Bills such as the Sales Tax Assessment (No. 1) Amendment Bill and the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill [No. 2], which we are debating tonight, supposedly on behalf of the ordinary wage and salary earners, saying, `It is in the interest of their standard of living'. Where do honourable member opposite stand in relation to their standard of living? I will tell the House where they stand. Opposition members have opposed the vast majority of the last 20 or so national wage cases. Indirect tax is insignificant compared to the wage rises that they have opposed, yet they supposedly support the wage and salary earners of this country. They seek to smash trade unions and the legitimate rights of individuals to wage rises, but they supposedly represent wage and salary earners.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for O'Connor stood up on behalf of the ordinary Aussie battler five minutes ago. It was not that long ago that the honourable member for O'Connor was the shadow health spokesman trying to smash Medicare. What would that mean to the average wage and salary earner and his family? It would mean a minimum of $22 a week. When we talk about the attitude of the Opposition and that of the Government to taxation and who pays it compared with who used to pay it; to wages and salaries; to the legitimacy of trade unions in the industrial field to negotiate on behalf of wage and salary earners; and to Medicare, Opposition members come a bad last when it comes to the interests of wage and salary earners. So why do they not cut this absolute hypocrisy that we have heard yet again tonight on these sales tax Bills?

The honourable member for O'Connor mentioned the effect of sales tax on pensioners. He gave the example of a pensioner who did not drink and who drove a car. I will give him a more pertinent statistic. When his Party was in government the pension was worth 22 per cent of average weekly earnings; now it is worth about 24 1/2 per cent and we are committed to getting it up. Pensions in this country are worth more in real terms than they were under you and you know it. If you want to talk about the home and community care package--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister will address his remarks through the Chair.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, if he wants to talk about the home and community care program, about carer's pensions, or a whole range of other issues I can say where pensioners have come out better, and it is under us and not under those honourable members opposite. All the rhetoric under the sun they have got about the sales tax Bills will not hide the facts. That is their problem.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for O'Connor talked about a family earning $300 a week. Somehow, through some arithmetic-arithmetic that compares with the Opposition's tax package at the last election-we heard that this family had only $150 a week to spend and that it was the Government's fault. That is a tax rate of about 50 per cent. Just off the top of my head I would say that the tax rate for that family would be closer to 15 per cent. In addition, the honourable member ought to know that under us that family would have full family assistance; if it were renting it would have rent assistance; if the wife were not working it would get the spouse rebate and the kids would be beneficiaries of Austudy. A family of three earning under $335 a week gets the equivalent of a $106 a week wage increase under us. Those opposite proclaim to be the great guardians for wage and salary earners. They are pretty good with the rhetoric, but the reason they will not put out a tax policy is that they know it will not add up and they know that their figures will pale into insignificance next to what we have done.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is your tax policy?

—I will tell the Deputy Leader of the Opposition where our tax policy is. The top marginal tax rate is 49 per cent under us. Under the Cabinet in which he was a leading member it was 60 per cent. As well as the 60 : 49 comparison the total regime reflected very poorly on the conservatives in this country who are supposedly the parties of low tax.
—We are.
—Yes-low tax to your mates. It is optional taxation. What you do not like is that this Government has brought about an end to a whole range of tax loopholes.

—Order! The Minister will address his remarks through the Chair and I ask the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to remain silent. I also ask the Minister to ignore the interjections. It ought to be understood that the honourable member for O'Connor was heard in silence when he was making his speech.
—I will shut up.

—I have just got something that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has never got from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition: an offer to shut up. The Opposition, in debating these Bills tonight, claims that the Government is increasing indirect taxation collections. I hate to let the facts get in the road of a good story but, as has been pointed out by my colleague the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins), the measures contained in these Bills, taken in conjunction with the reduction in the beer excise, actually reduce the amount of tax to be collected in respect of the items covered. I know that Opposition members can only understand words of one syllable, so let me simplify the matter for them. Tax collections on these items go down, not up under these Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment proposed by the Sales Tax Assessment (No. 1) Amendment Bill has been criticised as providing the Commissioner of Taxation with greater discretion. The amendment is not a discretion. It recognises that costs vary between manufacturers. It will mean that the sale value on which sales tax is imposed represents the actual costs and profit of the manufacturer-not an arbitrary figure determined by the Commissioner. In any event, if a taxpayer is dissatisfied with a decision by the Commissioner, there are appropriate appeal and review avenues open to him which are not altered by anything in this Bill.

The proposed amendment will remove identified anomalies and inconsistencies in the sales tax law. The parties opposite are the parties of anomalies and inconsistencies in tax law. They ran this country for 30 of the 33 years before we gained power in 1983. We inherited a tax system from them after all that time that was full of anomalies and inconsistencies, and we are still trying to clean them up. The difference between us and them is that not only do we have the will; we have the moral courage to do what they never had the guts to do.

These Bills do not increase overall taxation. On the contrary, they reduce tax collections on these items. They do not extend the operation of the sales tax law to services, and they certainly do not foreshadow a consumption tax. Most importantly, these Bills will contribute to a reduction in inflation. I do not want to embarrass the honourable member for Kooyong yet again but I think it has to be said that the inflation rate today is marginally different-to be charitable-to what it was when his Leader, then the Treasurer, left office in 1983.

There is one killer disease which ravaged this country through the 1970s and the early 1980s which afflicts wage and salary earners, particularly those on lower incomes and those on government benefits, such as pensioners whom those opposite are supposedly so concerned about, and that is inflation. We have got inflation down while also pulling down tax rates. The problem with honourable members opposite is that they do not like us achieving results. This is a good result. They know that it is a good result. I urge the House to support the legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Punch) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL [No. 2] 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 August, on motion by Mr Peter Morris:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House:
(1) notes that this Government has presided over an increasingly inefficient and inequitable indirect tax system that abounds with anomalies and inconsistencies;

(2) calls into question the Government's misguided priorities in increasing sales tax on a number of products, especially on packaging materials, when Australians are already suffering from the highest tax burden in the peace-time history of Australia; and

This amendment mirrors the remarks I made in my speech during the second reading debate on the Sales Tax Assessment (No. 1) Amendment Bill so I will not debate the actual amendment now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) expresses its best wishes to all the members of Australia's Paralympic team who are about to commence their Paralympic Games in Seoul; and
(2) congratulates all the members of the team on their dedication and determination in the knowledge that they will make every Australian proud of them.

Just a few days ago in this House, the House unanimously carried a motion congratulating the members of our Australian Olympic team in Seoul. They had brought great credit to this country. They had won a number of medals-certainly for many people in excess of expectations. They were at the time, and have subsequently proven to be, great ambassadors for our country. We are very proud of them.

Another Olympic Games is about to occur, the Paralympics, taking place very shortly in Seoul. Australia will once again be represented by a major contingent. The members of our Paralympic team have in many ways overcome difficulties far greater than anyone else who has ever participated in the Olympics to be able to wear the Australian colours of green and gold. Their achievement is a tremendous one. They set an example to every Australian. On this occasion the House takes the opportunity to wish them all the best in their competition over the next few days. We know that they will win a number of medals but, most importantly, we know that they will bring great credit upon themselves, their families, their friends and their nation. We wish them good luck. We are going to be very proud of them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me pleasure to second the motion moved by the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp). This side of the House also expresses its best wishes to the members of Australia's Paralympic team. There are 178 athletes and 56 officials in Seoul for these Games. There are approximately 40 countries participating in 15 different sports. We have blind people, people in wheelchairs, amputees and people with cerebal palsy all participating and representing Australia in the Games.

SPEECH.PARA: It may be of interest to the public to know the effort these people have put in to support themselves in sport. The Australian Confederation of Sport for the Disabled established the 1988 Paralympics appeal in 1987 to raise the required funds to send the Australian team to both the winter and summer Paralympics. The appeal target was $2m, and the appeal was very successful. The Federal Government made a strong contribution to that appeal of $125,000 in 1987-88. The athletes have used the national sports program at the Australian Institute of Sport to assist them in their preparation for these Games.

It gives me great pleasure to support this motion, particularly because of two young people who come from my electorate and in fact from the town in which I live, Warragul. A young lad named Craig Sayers is competing over there in both basketball and the long distance wheelchair track event, and his sister Joanne is also part of the delegation as one of the team's two nurses. These young people will do Australia proud and we wish them all the best. If they can come back to Australia having put in equal effort and gained as much success as our olympic team in Seoul recently, we will all be very proud of them. I fully support the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dobie The Hon J.D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am personally very pleased to be able to speak in this debate. I speak in two capacities, firstly as chairman of the Opposition sports committee and secondly as someone who has attended similar games and sporting events for the disabled over the last 25 years. At a moment like this we should be reminded that these activities started in Stoke Mandeville, in England. That gave a tremendous impetus to those who were physically disabled showing that they could compete internationally as well as nationally.

SPEECH.PARA: I also pay tribute to the work that was done in the lead up by the people involved in the rehabilitation unit at the Prince Henry Hospital in Sydney. Dr George Burniston, CMG, OBE, who created that great unit, was part of the movement to see that these sports should be played in competition, first of all at a municipal level, and then a State level and a national level. For some years now we have had the interesting and fascinating situation of there being a `paralympics'. The House should bear in mind at this stage that we now have three major olympic sports functions-the Olympic Games themselves, which provide inspiration for all; the paralympics which are for the physically disabled; and, in recent years, the special olympics which are basically for the mentally disabled. Each inspires the others.

Anybody who regularly goes to these games and sees such things as the wheelchair basketball matches will understand how inspired these people are at their individual level by the achievements of our people who compete at the Olympic Games. I am very pleased to inform the House that my dinner guest tonight, and he is sitting in the gallery, was Mr Phil Smyth. He captained our successful basketball team which showed that basketball in Australia is now up among the giants. Getting into the top four countries in the world is a tremendous achievement for Phil, for Adrian Hurley and for all the team and I can assure the House, attending as I do the wheelchair basketball matches, that those people who partake in those matches receive inspiration from the success of the olympic athletes. We wish the people who are playing in those games great success.

To see these people striving not for their own satisfaction but in the hope that it will inspire other disabled people back home is something we should be very proud of and conscious of in this place. Whereas the olympic sports people achieve, inspire their country, the paralympic people go away and when they return their inspiration is to the physically disabled, who become disabled very often in adult life, helping them to realise that there is a life for them beyond the confines very often of wheelchairs. Tonight I wish them success. I hope, more importantly, that they enjoy themselves and that when they come back to Australia, whether they come with medals or not, they will prove to be an inspiration to that vast number of disabled people we have in our country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to join with my colleagues the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham), the honourable member for Cook (Mr Dobie) and the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) in supporting this motion. It is an appropriate motion to be moved in this House and I am sure the general spirit in which this motion is being debated would please those who are listening to this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to observe that the mascot for this Eighth International Paralympic Games is two bears with their arms around each other, running with legs tied together to indicate the degree of cooperation and support that is required in olympics such as this. There will be 888 competitions covering the sports that my colleague the honourable member for McMillan has mentioned, and Australia is represented in many of those sports-sports such as basketball, swimming, soccer, table tennis, judo, weightlifting and fencing. It is also appropriate to say that the paralympic team is short of some funds and it has made some acknowledgment that the corporate sector to this stage has been a little slow in providing support. It is worth noting that in this discussion.

We ought to emphasise what has just been indicated by the honourable member for Cook-that the inspiration they provide is inspiration for others in the community who are disabled. That is a very important element. I note the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) is acknowledging that. It is significant, when we look at the wide range of sports covered, that we realise that with great human commitment it is possible for people to achieve a huge number of things despite certain physical handicaps, and it is significant that this is occurring. As we saw with out own olympians recently in Seoul, and I note that the honourable member for Cook has indicated the role of Phil Smyth, these people produce enormous inspiration for others in the community who perhaps due to lesser circumstances have not been able to achieve such heights. Similarly they provide that level of inspiration for disabled athletes. For those of us here who from time to time tend to see things in negative terms, it is perhaps a timely reminder that those people have to see everything in positive terms to make this level of achievement and commitment possible.

To conclude, I note that a message will be sent tomorrow to our paralympic athletes by our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and our Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson), and that will convey very much the spirit that this motion conveys-that we wish them well, we wish them enjoyment and we certainly admire their ability and determination against all odds. I am sure they provide a great inspiration for all of us in the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not normally the task of the Chair to take part in debates, but I express my personal feelings on this matter by saying I take particular pleasure in putting the question that the motion be agreed to.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 September, on motion by Mr Peter Morris:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill we are debating is the States Grants (General Revenue) Bill 1988. The Opposition will not be opposing the Bill. The purpose of the Bill is to put in place the Commonwealth general revenue assistance arrangements with the States and the Northern Territory for 1988-89 following the expiry of the State Grants (General Revenue) Act 1985. As a result it will implement the decisions taken at the May 1988 Premiers Conference and Loan Council meeting.

SPEECH.PARA: The payments of $12,400m provided for in the Bill account for about 15 per cent of estimated Commonwealth Budget outlays for 1988-89. That, of course, is very large expenditure. Add to this payments under the States (Works and Housing) Assistance Act and specific purpose payments, and payments to the States account for around 30 per cent of Budget outlays. We are told about that figure very clearly in the Budget Papers. What is not quite as obvious from those papers is that the Commonwealth Government has been cutting its Budget payments to States quite progressively over the term of its office while at the same time it has not seen fit to match the extent of those cuts with reductions in its own purpose payments. A brief calculation from figures in Budget Paper No. 1 will show that well over 70 per cent of the reduction in outlays this year is accounted for by general purpose payments to the States. In fact, general purpose assistance will decline by about 4.6 per cent in real terms in 1988-89 following a real decline of 5.1 per cent in 1987-88. Those figures, of course, do not include the expenditure cuts in a myriad of specific purpose payments to the States which are hidden throughout the general functional headings of the Budget Papers tables.

I am not criticising the Government for the reductions in payments to the States. I am criticising the Government, however, for the hypocrisy it has shown in demanding spending restraint from all other levels of government while at the same time not matching the bid it asks the States to accept. I shall therefore be moving an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bill at the conclusion of my speech.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) give pious sermons to the States at the Premiers Conference on the need for expenditure reductions to meet the country's economic difficulties. But sermonising is not action. They are prepared to ask the States to pull back outlays but they are happier to be easy on themselves. It is just this sort of lax attitude that the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, has been frightened by. As he told us last year, `We are on the road to Argentina'. Alongside that road is a sign that points to Labor's debt-to the $88 billion net foreign debt which this Government has given us. That foreign debt has quadrupled during Labor's time in office. As the ever helpful Senator Walsh commented this year, just prior to the Budget: `The Opposition can quite legitimately argue that the pace of adjustment might be faster'. However, the Government cannot force the pace of adjustment because, in the same senator's words, it lacks the `political courage' to cut spending.

This Government is tiring. It is suffering badly from fatigue, as can be seen in its performance in this place every day and in its gyrations on economic policy, both from within the economic Ministries and particularly by the Prime Minister himself. In such tiring governments it is typical to see sniping between leaders and would-be leaders as their minds wander from their jobs and concentrate on their own personal ambitions. They forget about Australians and they forget about those struggling. They just look after themselves and look after their mates. That sums up the way in which this Government governs today. Political operatives', political party members' snouts are in the trough. Average Australians are ignored while they look after their own. A caricature of the Labor politician today is of a snout in the trough, the left hand in the till, and the right hand in the cookie jar. They are all looking after themselves. That is summed up by what has been going on this week-the division, the personal ambition being played out, while the grand tours are going on.

The Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) directed the attention of the Parliament to this matter. I can tell honourable members, having served in a fair number of governments and Ministries through the 1960s, the 1970s and the 1980s, that when Ministers wanted to go on overseas trips Liberal Prime Ministers would demand that, save and except for, say, the Foreign Minister and, say, a Treasurer attending a one-off function, they had to be here when the Parliament was sitting. Not with this Government. It is the taxpayers' money; it is the gravy train. They just get on it and they use it. Off they go, with hardly a person here to answer questions. There has been the most inadequate performance by Ministers; snout in the trough and hand in the till. As I say, it is typical to see the sniping between leaders and would-be leaders as they pursue their own personal animosities.

The Budget, which is a significant proportion of what we are debating here now-oft forgotten by so many people in Australia now, seven weeks after it was brought down-has simply failed Australia. It is well to recall what the Australian Financial Review editorial said about the Budget, and I will quote elements of it:
. . . in short, the economic foundations of this Budget may be built on quick sand and even a slight fall in commodity prices could send the whole scenario into disarray.
It then went on:
There is an eerie feeling of tightrope walking about the whole strategy.

How correct. The evidence that this is so includes the fact that net exports are expected to make a negative contribution to gross domestic product yet again in 1988-89, the fact that imports of capital goods as a share of total imports fell again in 1987-88, and the fact that investment in mining and manufacturing is projected to show little, if any, real growth in 1988-89.

The current account deficit is unbeliev- able. The current account deficits recorded in July and August highlighted the extreme vulnerability of the Australian economy today to any downturn in commodity prices. In the first two months of this financial year Australia notched up a current account deficit of almost $3 billion. The Treasurer predicated the Budget on a current account deficit of $9.5 billion. Almost a third of that has been achieved already in two months. One-sixth of the financial year has notched up one-third of what was predicated as the current account deficit for the whole year.

The Government's Budget strategy is based on continued strength in commodity prices. However, the recent decline of 17 per cent in the State Bank of Victoria commodity price index since 10 June hardly augurs well. One reaches the conclusion, regrettably, that the Government's Budget strategy is unravelling. The fact is that instead of cutting expenditure to get the house in order, to get the $5.5 billion Budget surplus, the Treasurer has simply raised taxes yet again: get the surplus by more and more revenue rather than by cutting expenditure and putting the economic house in order.

The Treasurer's own Budget papers show that this is the highest taxing Government the country has known. An extra $5.7 billion in income tax has been collected from individuals. That is a 13.6 per cent increase. It is even higher than the 10 per cent growth of the previous year. The share of individual taxes in total tax revenue has now jumped to over 54 per cent. The harsh reality is that, as the very poor are properly looked after by welfare, as they ought to be, at the other end of the spectrum the rich have become the super rich. In the middle are the lower and middle income earners, who under this Government are just being squeezed out.

Government members know, because of their surveys, quite apart from their personal dealings as they move around this nation, that one of the major contributing factors to the massive swings against them in by-election after by-election is that their constituencies can see that they have sold them out. The long term consequence for Australia will be a shattering of the near egalitarian society that we had. It was never completely egalitarian, but until recently the country was made up of a very significant band of middle income earners. Those people's conditions are not improving if one asks them what they have left at the end of the day. The Government has allowed those who had money to amass fortunes beyond belief. The consequences for this nation down the line are very significant.

I am not a socialist. I do not believe in concentrating on the redistribution of income. I also do not believe in creating a society in which a small group of people can so advantage themselves in a short period because of the regulatory mechanisms with which the Government plays. The Government has fiddled with regulations. It has put them down, changed them, imposed them and taken them away. It has created an unfair society in which the great bulk of people, at the end of each week, because of high rates of taxation and high interest rates, are finding it extraordinarily difficult to get by.

I would like to say that the massive swings in the recent by-election were for other reasons. Sure, we have been attracting a lot of support, but the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has been the first to admit that Labor's arrogant attitude, its inability to come to terms with the needs of average Australians and the reduction of their living standards, has caused people to say, `We, as blue collar workers, as former supporters of yours, will turn away from you'. There has been some short term gain in political donations for the Government, but long term harm has been structured into the community; not because the Government has advocated that people who invest, work hard and do well ought to reap the benefits but because it has fiddled with the mechanisms of government and allowed people to capitalise on that.

I see, at the end of the term of this Government, a vastly different Australia from the one that it inherited when it was first elected. I have absolutely no doubt that, as a consequence, with the chardonnay socialists being seen increasingly for what they are-essentially, as rip-off merchants for their rich mates, essentially squeezing those who never even aspire to make fortunes but who just want to improve the lot of themselves and their families-people will turn on the Government in droves.

When Oxley, one of the Government's 12 safest seats in the nation, experienced the swing that occurred last weekend, members of the Government, instead of having looks of smug indifference on their faces as we talk about the hurt of Australian people today, should engage in what contributes to human beings becoming a little better-a degree of introspection; stepping back and looking at these matters-but they will not do so. One would think that the Government would have learnt its lesson after it nearly lost Mick Young's seat. Have a look at the nature of the seat of Port Adelaide. My God, there had never been such a swing to the Liberal Party. We also picked up the seat of Adelaide. One would think that by now the message would be starting to be contemplated. But no; we have just had continuing greed, the infighting has wound up and the Acting Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) has been exposed as seeking to bring down the Prime Minister. A personal play of ambition has been going on.

I am not a despairing type, but I have thought from time to time that the conscience of those members of the Australian Labor Party who, in the past, found loathsome the concept that some people could cream it off others would strike them and that they would seek to make it easier for that great bulk of Australians who are now finding it tough. But no; the same old message is there. Honourable members know what it is; we hear it every day. The Government says that it is the greatest government in the history of the nation. The Government is made up of mugs because they are starting to believe it. It is not true, and no one else believes it, but they are starting to believe the public relations slogans themselves. Once they start to believe the slick message, they are in trouble. They then start to create the impression that the Opposition is nothing but a divided house. The irony of it all! When the Treasurer is telling the Prime Minister not just to go but to go now; the Acting Treasurer is telling the Prime Minister to go and to go now; the Finance Minister, the other crucial element amongst the economic portfolios, is wringing his hands and telling his colleagues that he wants to quit, one can see that, whilst people in this community are suffering, all that Government members can do is play with their public relations slogans and give voice to their personal animosities and ambitions. All the time, as I have said, the low and middle income earners are being poleaxed by what is nothing but a Labor tax rip-off. It is the highest taxing Government in the history of the nation.
