This Budget will be looked upon as one of the great disappointments of the bicentennial year. There have been a few of those, because of the way in which the Government has tried to play the bicentennial year. Boy, have there been a few disappointments! I do not know what the bicentenary has done for the fairly normal person living at home with his wife and family, other than to increase his taxes. If one is not a fairly normal person, there might have been some engagements or parties to attend. But there has been nothing in this bicentenary but more taxes for the normal, average Australian who has been poleaxed by taxes and who is trying to look after his kids and his wife. It has been some year for the average Australian trying to get ahead! An estimated $7 billion has been ripped from Australians through what is called bracket creep, or tax creep, since 1985-86. The Government smugly tells us that it is one of the greatest governments in the history of the nation, yet it has ripped off $7 billion by people moving, through the inflationary mechanisms in their wages and salaries, into higher tax brackets.

The Treasurer, the Prime Minister, the Finance Minister and the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris) have all given the nation differing views over the last week alone on how, when and why we should get tax cuts next year. If we get them, it will be typical of the Government to say that those Australians who get the tax cuts ought to be grateful. I have a bit of news for the Government: Australians will not be grateful. They are demanding them now, despite the fact that the Treasurer says that Australians do not want tax cuts now. They are demanding them now, they need them now and they deserve them now.

An advertisement for a Victorian bank, the State Bank, talks about how a person ought to have a bit of control over his money. It has a nice little line. A wife turns to her husband, wanting to know how the money is earning interest and whether they can get it out. I do not mind telling this anecdote because it sums up what I want to say. She turns to him and says, `It's your money, Ralph'. The Government should remember, when it tries to make Australians grateful for the tax cuts, that it is not its money. It is just not its money. Every man and woman who earns income in this nation, it is their money. So do not come in here with sanctimonious statements that Australians ought to be grateful for the tax cuts they have not yet been given or the nature of which has not been determined, because it is not its money. The more the Government thought of that concept and recognised that more and more has been taken from Australians in the time this Government has been in office, the more support the Government may get in the community rather than the diminishing support it has been getting in by-election after by-election.

TALK.START.PARA: —And in Victoria.

—I am talking about the Federal Government but now that the honourable member mentions Victoria, I might remind him that yet again in that election the majority of Victorians did not vote for Labor. I congratulate Labor members, as a Party, on winning the election but if they want to talk about majority support-they are yet another minority government because they did not get the majority of votes in Victoria. So do not start that nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to a few other points that the Bill prompts me to discuss. One of the consequences of the undue emphasis of this Government on cutting expenditure to the States has been the large reductions in capital purpose payments. Generally, capital infrastructure expenditure was only 4.4 per cent of total Budget expenditure in 1987-88. That compared with 95.6 per cent for current outlays. This is in contrast with capital outlays sharing over 9 per cent of expenditure in the last year of the Fraser Government. It also compared with 19 per cent back in 1975-76, although the spreading of functions of budget to government-owned enterprises may have accounted for a large part of the decrease since then. Nevertheless, the general trend away from infrastructure expenditure is worrying. The Commonwealth Government should take the lead in restructuring the priorities if the necessary structural adjustment in the economy is to take place.

Another point I wish to raise is one that was mentioned in the Minister's second reading speech on the Bill. Consequent upon the Government's decision to remove the payroll tax exemption for certain Commonwealth business enterprises from 1 July 1988, 90 per cent of the additional revenue available to each State and the Northern Territory from this source is to be recouped by an additional reduction in their financial assistance grant.

I acknowledge that the levying of payroll tax will put authorities like Telecom and Australia Post in an analogous position to private sector enterprises and will therefore tend to contribute to their efficient operation. However, I do note the pleasant little bonus for the Commonwealth-that is, that the removal of the payroll tax exemption for certain Commonwealth business enterprises has been used by the Commonwealth as a means of reducing payments to States. Therefore, total Commonwealth Budget expenditures are seen to decrease. Notwithstanding this, however, it is expected that the business authorities will boost their prices and charges so that taxpayers, as consumers, will hardly win from the changes. In fact, we heard only yesterday that the charges for some Telecom services will be rising.

Lastly, I simply want to raise again a point I made in last year's debate, I think, on the States Grants Bills. I noted that during the calamitous days of Mr Whitlam-and there is more than a whiff of Whitlam in the air again today-the Commonwealth assumed a right to intervene in all manner of activities once seen as solely the province of the States. In health, in education, in road building and innumerable other activities, the Commonwealth has established huge bureaucracies. Last year I gave an example that while the Queensland Health Department's 6,700 or so staff operated the State's entire public hospital and health system, prior to last year's portfolio reorganisation the Commonwealth Department of Health employed some 4,100 public servants, not one of whom, according to the State Government, provides any direct health service to patients.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shameful!
—Absolutely shameful. Just build them up and have them there bleeding the taxpayers, because once again this Government does not worry about the utilisation-
—It is out of touch.

—This Government is arrogant, out of touch and has no idea about the average Australian. Basically, nothing has changed on the figures that I gave since I said that last year. There is certainly a case for the Commonwealth to review its activities and avoid costly duplication with State functions. It is more appropriate for States, which employ the teachers, the nurses and the road builders, to be allowed to take the responsibility of conducting their own programs. This does not mean I am advocating a wholesale removal of Commonwealth funding to States. For example, in many cases block grants would be more efficient than Commonwealth meddling in State affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, the Bill highlights the Government's hypocrisy in calling for belt tightening across the community. Contrary to the Government, we maintain that it is possible to address living standards at the same time as addressing our external economic troubles. Integral to our policy is the need for personal tax cuts. Earlier in my speech I dwelt on the absolute need for the overwhelming majority of Australians to get tax cuts to stop the decay in the living standards of so many low to middle income earning Australians. The expenditure cuts can be made to fund those tax cuts.

Unlike the Government, we will deliver genuine tax cuts. We have given the shape of our tax policy. Honourable members all know the direction in which we are heading. All we hear from the Government are different sounds as to whether there will in fact be any tax cuts at all. The Prime Minister is saying there will be a wage increase and a tax cut. The Treasurer is saying there will be no wage increase but there will be a tax cut. The Finance Minister, Senator Walsh, is threatening not to allow either of them anyhow. There is total confusion; but the higher rates remain. Unlike the Government, we will deliver genuine tax cuts because those tax cuts are essential to the task of restoring the living standards of Australia.
Mr Deputy Speaker, I move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House notes that:

(1) this government's prospective 1988-89 budget surplus is mostly based on increased taxation, and over 70 per cent of the expenditure cuts in budget outlays comes from reduced payments to state governments;
(2) this government has been found wanting in the need to bear its share of expenditure restraint by cutting its own direct expenditure; and

(3) the arrangements outlined in the Bill reflect policies that discourage the incentive to invest and work productively and therefore facilitate the restructuring of the Australian economy to address the nation's net foreign debt of some $88 billion.'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given the theatrical heights which the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) reached during that delivery, I am a little disappointed that there was not a better audience amongst the Opposition benches. However, given the hour, I am sure that many hundreds of thousands of Australians out there are listening to the arguments of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition tonight. When I heard the Deputy Leader of the Opposition saying that Australia used to be a fairly egalitarian society a few years ago, I suspected he was suggesting to the house that Australia was a fairly egalitarian society when he was in the Fraser Cabinet and when he was helping to make the decisions which affected Australia's economy. He thought that Australia was a fairly egalitarian society during the Fraser years, a fairly egalitarian society when the pensioners were receiving only 22 per cent of average weekly earnings. He thinks Australia was a fairly egalitarian society when the Government of which he was a member drove Australia into its worst recession since the 1930s. He thought Australia was a fairly egalitarian society when there was a wages blow-out for which the Cabinet in which he served was responsible. They simply decided to take no further role in the setting of wages. They abandoned their economic responsibility to the people of Australia and, as a result, we had the recession of 1982. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition claims that that was a period when he thought Australia had a fairly egalitarian society. When we had a massive number of Australians thrown onto the unemployment scrap heap, he thought that was a fairly egalitarian society. He thought we had a fairly egalitarian society when people on the top rate of income tax were paying over 60c in the dollar.

SPEECH.PARA: Given that the honourable member for Kooyong comes from the toffy-nosed area of Melbourne, I can perhaps understand that from his background life in the Fraser years was fairly egalitarian. But I can tell him that the people in my electorate, the pensioners who now receive not 22 per cent of average weekly earnings as they did in the Fraser years but 24 1/2 per cent today, know that Australia is--
An interjection having been made from the gallery-

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think the honourable member should interject from the public gallery. I think Australia has a more egalitarian society. I would make the point that perhaps the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is totally out of touch.
—As he has been for a long time.

—As he has been for many years. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition moved an amendment tonight in which he claimed that over 70 per cent of the reduction in expenditure in this Budget comes from reduced payments to State governments. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition went on to claim that he was not against those reductions in assistance to the State governments. He simply said that the Federal Government should have cut Federal outlays as hard as it had cut State outlays.

SPEECH.PARA: I find that hard to reconcile with the performance of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition during this Government's period of office. Who was it who campaigned around Australia against the assets test? Who was it who went around Australia whipping up a scare campaign, saying that pensioners would have the gold in their teeth valued and that they would lose their pensions? It was the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. Who was it who went around Australia saying that the changes that we made to the Veterans' Entitlements Act were wrong, that we should not cut back in the veterans affairs area and that this Government was cutting government expenditure back too hard? It was the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. Who are the honourable members running around Australia today saying that our Government has cut road funding too much? People such as the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) are doing this.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.

—The honourable member interjects and says, `That is right'. I would not be surprised if the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) thinks that we should be providing bigger subsidies for dairy farmers. He has a smile on his face but refuses to acknowledge the claim. I am sure that back in his own electorate he is telling all the dairy farmers that they deserve more assistance from the Federal Government. That is just typical of the Opposition's hypocrisy. Members of the Opposition come into this House one day claiming that they are the responsible economic managers, that they are the people who want to cut back government spending so that they can reduce taxation, yet when they are out in their electorates they show the other side of their split personalities and say to people, `Yes, we will deliver you more grants for road funding; yes, we will give you more assistance for health care; yes, we will give you a full pension even if you are a millionaire'. Really, they have zero credibility.

SPEECH.PARA: Although the Deputy Leader of the Opposition now claims to be an expert on economics and reads the speeches that someone has prepared for him in the back rooms, he simply does not understand the realities of economic life in Australia today. It has been this Government that has taken the tough decisions on Australia's economy. The people opposite did not take the difficult decision to float the Australian dollar when they were in government, when the Deputy Leader of the Opposition was part of the Cabinet. The people opposite were not in power when this Government took the historic decision to free up the banking sector. They were not in power when this Government reduced tariffs so that our manufacturing industry could be leaner and more efficient. The people opposite were not in power when this Government introduced its historic changes to ensure the Australian economy is reformed and is able to compete on the world market.

It is sometimes interesting to compare the performance of Liberal and National Party governments at the State level. I represent an electorate in New South Wales. Of course, we now have a Liberal-National Party Government in New South Wales. I can assure honourable members that the New South Wales Government headed by Mr Greiner and Mr Murray is not going very well. Of course Mr Greiner, who was elected on a dry economic policy, has sought to establish his economic credentials by cutting expenditure everywhere. Yet we have already seen that he has gone weak at the knees, the same as Phillip Lynch did in the early 1970s. Mr Greiner was going to introduce a $50 fee for all the children who travelled more than several kilometres on private buses. What happened? He went to water. Mr Greiner was going to make all of these rapid changes.

TALK.START.PARA: —He should have backed down.

—I admit, as the honourable member suggests, he should have backed down. But the point I am making is that history shows that the Liberal and National parties have never been able to follow through on any Budget cuts. They always back down. They have no backbone at all.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps we should think back to what happened under the razor gang which was formed by the last Liberal-National Party Government. In 1976 that Government had a majority in both Houses of Parliament. But what did it do? It sent Phillip Lynch away with a group of public servants to come up with all the areas that it wanted to cut back. Phillip Lynch came back with a massive program of expenditure cuts-not $5,000m, not $1,000m but a measly $600m. After the weak-kneed Liberal and National Party backbenchers had gone to the Ministers and said, `You cannot make these cuts because this will affect my electorate; you cannot touch the subsidies that are given to my farmers; you cannot hurt my friends who are in business', less than $200m worth of savings were left from the Lynch razor gang recommendations. So the record of honourable members opposite when in government is that they cannot hold the line. Whenever there is any community opposition to savings measures which they seek to introduce, they back down.

What has been the performance of this Government? We have had to make some pretty tough decisions, some of which have not been easy for people such as me and other Government backbenchers to defend. But we have been prepared to explain the Government's position to the community. I believe that there is support out there in the community for governments that take tough decisions which are in the long term economic interests of Australia. There are people opposite who seek to be all things to all people. I know that the Australian people when next given the chance to pass judgment on those opposite will repeat the judgment that they made just over one year ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last weekend in Oxley.

—The honourable member says, `What about last weekend's judgment in Oxley?'. I admit that there was a big swing in Oxley. But I ask him to think about the election result in Victoria. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition said that his side of politics received a majority of the votes and therefore it should have won. I would seek to explain to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that in Australia we have a system of voting called preferential voting. Because someone votes for the National Party, that does not necessarily mean that he is going to give his second preference to the Liberal Party. In fact, honourable members opposite might be interested to learn that often there is a leakage of around 10 per cent of the National Party's preferences to the Australian Labor Party. That means that when we look at the two-party preferred vote, the Liberal and National parties did not get a majority in Victoria. The Labor Party had a majority of the two-party preferred vote. Honourable members opposite do not understand the voting system. It is hard to believe that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition was almost Prime Minister of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I would make in this debate on general revenue assistance grants to the States is that some reforms have been introduced in these measures which are being considered by the Parliament tonight. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has announced that we are abolishing the payroll exemption for certain government business enterprises. That will result in the States receiving an extra $178m. I believe that that will put those government business enterprises on a more private enterprise footing. That is something which I thought would have had the support of honourable members opposite.

In addition, the Government has announced that in future funding to the States for the provision of public hospital services will be reformed. We have had indications from the current New South Wales State Minister for Health, Mr Peter Collins, who I hope gets a move in the near future, that he will be seeking to encourage an expansion of the private hospital sector at the expense of the public hospital sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —Outrageous! What has he done in Bulli and Kiama?

—The honourable member says that he is already closing down maternity wards at Bulli and at Kiama. I am concerned that perhaps the New South Wales Liberal-National Party Government has a hidden agenda.
—To clean up the mess you left them.

—I will tell the honourable member what it is about. It is about shutting down public hospital beds. That is what they are doing. I can imagine what the honourable member's view would be if the Victorian Cain Labor Government shut down public hospital beds in his electorate. He would be screaming. Let me tell him what the Liberal Government is doing in New South Wales. It has shut down half the beds in Wyong hospital, which services a large part of my electorate, and it has granted approval for a new private hospital to open at Berkeley Vale. This is all part of the New South Wales Government's policy of encouraging the growth of the private hospital sector at the expense of the public hospital sector in New South Wales, which has an excellent reputation of providing top service to Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned that if there is an expansion in the private hospital sector at the expense of district hospital beds, people in my electorate will be forced to use private hospital beds against their will. That will mean that they will be forced to pay the extra fees and exorbitant charges which often occur in private hospitals. What the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) has done is place a minimum floor on the number of patients who are treated at public hospitals in each of the States. Therefore if the New South Wales Liberal Government seeks to wind back the public hospital sector that will result in a reduction in a Federal grant that is provided to New South Wales to provide its public hospital sector. That is something which I totally support.

In addition, I mention one other action which the New South Wales Government has taken. I raised this two days ago in the debate on the estimates for the Department of Veterans' Affairs. The New South Wales Government receives more than $27m to provide a legal aid service to the people of New South Wales. Included in that $27m is half a million dollars to provide a legal aid service to veterans and their dependants irrespective of means. In New South Wales veterans, war widows and their dependants have always had the right to obtain legal advice in matters such as appearances before the Veterans' Review Board, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Federal Court of Australia.

What has happened under the New South Wales Liberal and National Party Government in its typical anti-veteran attitude is that it has introduced a means test for advice through the Legal Aid Commission in New South Wales. It still demands to receive the extra half million dollars from the Federal Government but it is not providing the service that this Government is funding it to provide. I will be calling on all of the veterans in New South Wales to lobby the New South Wales Liberal and National Party Government to overturn the New South Wales Legal Aid Commission and to restore to New South Wales veterans their right to obtain legal aid on matters such as appearances before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. These matters are so complex that veterans and war widows have a right to legal aid. When the veterans in my electorate realise what the Liberal and National Party Government of New South Wales has done they will take their retribution out at the ballot box at the next chance they get. I am very pleased to be able to support the legislation which is before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously I have a sterling speech to make. I am hoping that the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) will not adjourn the debate but let me finish. This is a very important debate tonight. It has been pretty heavy going as it is one of the main financial arrangements the Commonwealth makes with the rest of the States. Under our federated system, of course, we bring the States to heel every 12 months. All of the Premiers have to come to Canberra and have funds dealt out to them under the arrangements of the Act which replaces the States Grants General Revenue Act 1985. This amount of money is taken out of our taxes, both indirect and direct. It amounts to $12.4 billion, which is quite a slice-15 per cent-out of the total taxation revenue which is now running at the horrific figure of $83 billion. It is a record, of course.

SPEECH.PARA: We have never seen in this nation so much taxation collected by any government in our whole history. We have seen excessive taxes placed on the people. We have been talking tonight and commenting on the Oxley by-election result. Obviously, that must bring home to roost to the Australian Labor Party the reaction of the general populace in Australia and particularly in Queensland, which is the State that I represent in this House-Maranoa is in the great State of Queensland-where we have seen people tell the Government of this because there was a 12 per cent swing in that electorate against the Government. The Government nearly lost the seat. It was one of the safest seats which was vacated by our incoming Governor-General-God help Australia. He was at one stage the Leader of the Labor Party and Leader of the Opposition. He is, of course, one Bill Hayden. He held that seat for 25-odd years. When he departed we saw this massive swing, which was a massive kick in the pants for the present Labor Government.

We have seen the increase in taxation that is involved. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has put a global borrowing limit on the States. This is another form of restriction and centralisation that the Commonwealth is imposing on the States. In actual fact, the people of all the States in Australia should realise that if States borrow over the limit which the Treasurer has imposed they will get less grants next year. The States want to be sure that they do not borrow over their limit. Otherwise they will not be compensated or recompensed on a per head of population basis by the Commonwealth.

The other thing that has changed slowly but surely since this Labor Government has been in office is that the criterion has been changed back to a pure population basis. The same thing has happened with local government. Under the general purpose grants in local government the Government has done the same thing. We see that this country does not govern as a national government should. It does not see that areas of Australia get some extra funding to help them in their development of this great nation. We are stagnating under this Labor Government. The Australian nation is coming to a screaming halt. We are seeing that the money is now being poured back into--

TALK.START.PARA: —Turn it up.

—It is true. The honourable member should give us the Government's balance of payments figures for the last three years. The honourable member should give us the Government's borrowings overseas figure for the last five years. The honourable member should tell me what the Government's current balance of payments figure is. The honourable member should tell me how much work we are doing as a nation at present. It is a disgrace. Financially it is one of the worst governments in the world at present. It is an absolute disgrace. We are running at horrific monthly trade deficit figures. It is the worst in our history. We have never seen such a performance as we are seeing now under this Hawke Government. It is absolutely disgraceful. It is a $12m a year debt. We cannot even get off our butts to do enough work to balance our books. Yet honourable members opposite sit over there and tell us what we should be doing. The only way they keep going is by borrowing funds. They borrow billions of dollars again. They borrow a million dollars a day just to keep themselves sitting on those benches. It is a disgrace. They ought to be ashamed of themselves. The honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) should sit in his seat properly if he is going to interject.

SPEECH.PARA: I will now get back to the Bill. As a good, hardworking Australian it concerns me that we are paying this amount of taxation. We see another new indirect taxation measure. We have had the management of Telecom Australia in here today telling us how it will tighten its belt and move its manager out of Roma to centralise things. It does this with the encouragement of this socialist Government. That is all it wants. It wants centralisation. It wants to split Telecom up into three sectors and there is complaint about a bit of cross-subsidisation. We will see this Government come down hard on all of the people of inland Australia who try to get a telephone. Most Australians in inland Australia do not have a telephone yet. We are working towards that so that hopefully by 1992 they will have one. The Government has stretched out that figure by imposing sales tax on Telecom; by imposing payroll taxes on Telecom.

The absurd situation now is that Telecom will be forced to pay taxation. Can honourable members believe that? They will have to pay company tax on their profits: talk about creeping socialism and creeping taxation. When Telecom was initially set up it did not cost the Australian public anything. Australia Post was the same. It was paid for out of Consolidated Revenue and we now see it as a taxing arm of the Commonwealth Government. Telecom, Australia Post, the Civil Aviation Authority, the Federal Port Authority, the National Railways, the Pipeline Authority are now being asked to pay payroll tax by this Government. The Government is collecting by stealth $179m a year from this indirect taxation. That is all it is. We have seen this happen from the time that this Labor Government came to office. What is it doing now to the State rural disaster scheme? What did it do in the Budget? It is now charging the States 4 per cent interest on the grants that it gives them. From the time that fund was set up the States were not expected to pay any interest. Now they are paying 4 per cent. It is another form of indirect taxation. There is no doubt in my mind that the rest of the Australian population--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr ACTING SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., the debate is interrupted. I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already spoken twice this week in the House on matters to do with veterans. It seems to me that, despite however many facts I give to the House, we are continually berated by the Opposition in its attempt to belittle the very good works that this Government does for veterans. So, I will take the House through the Opposition's policies for veterans and show how inadequate they are and how they fall short of current government programs. Firstly, the coalition platform states in this general area:

SPEECH.PARA: the commitment of the Liberal and National Parties is to provide to the Veteran the greatest understanding, recognition and support-
here we go-
that responsible government can afford.

That is equivocal at best. We are in government doing it, spending the money, putting the money in the pockets of veterans, and all honourable members opposite can say is `that responsible government can afford'. In other words, it is an opt-out clause. I do not think veterans ought to trust in the Opposition's promises.

Secondly, as I said earlier today, we have taken up many of the recommendations of the Veterans' Entitlements Act Monitoring Committee. We have already moved to accept 28 of the recommendations and we are about to put those into practice. Again the Opposition is almost silent on those recommendations. Again there is no action.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish! We adopted the EDA.

—Yes, and we put it into practice. The third point to do with the Veterans' Entitlements Act is that the Opposition has this suspicion that there has been a tightening-up of the criteria for the totally and permanently incapacitated pension which attempts to play on the fear that there is in the veteran community that somehow we have tightened up on the TPI. By contrast, we have made it clear, as a result of recommendations of the monitoring committee, that we will now accept that, where a veteran has 70 per cent general incapacity, we can look at the question of TPI. That is a marvellous breakthrough.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us have a look at a fourth policy-disability pensions and other benefits. We have adopted the notion of an extreme disability adjustment. Again the Opposition has accepted that. Good on it! But the fact is that that is the plum, the very guts, of its policy. We have already done it, thank you very much. We have wiped the Opposition out of the ring. A fifth Opposition policy states:
The Liberal and National Parties will abolish the statutory patient contribution on nursing home care for World War I and T&I Veterans.

In other words, the Opposition seeks to distinguish between World War I and TPI veterans. We do not distinguish between them. We have to have it either for all or for none. I believe that it ought to be equitable. Prior to 1 January 1988, the Repatriation Commission accepted financial responsibility for the patient contribution of those beneficiaries specifically admitted to nursing homes as a result of war-caused disabilities. We now take on the charging of board and lodging, but we most definitely leave those veterans well off.

In a sixth Opposition policy, on service pensions, there is an unequivocal statement that it will regard service pensions just like any other pensions and, where we impose an income and assets test, it appears that the Opposition will also impose at least a modified assets test and, of course, it certainly will not state the actual money value of its assets test. So, again we have to take it on trust that no assets or incomes test will be imposed by the Opposition should it-God forbid!-come to power.
A seventh Opposition policy on defence service home loans, states:

The Liberal and National Parties will ensure that the transfer of the Defence Service Home Loan Corporation to the private sector . . . is completed and does not disadvantage those already holding a mortgage.
Bad luck, too late, we have done it. We are looking after the veterans again.

Finally, the shadow spokesman has given a commitment to the Returned Services League that repatriation hospitals would not be taken into the general system of hospitals, at least until the end of the next coalition government. Were that to occur, that would be in about 1992. The fact is that we have promised we will not do that until at least 1995.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to reject the comments made by the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns). It is interesting that he finds the need to get up and dissect the coalition's veterans' affairs policy. The reason is that that policy is being well accepted in the veterans constituency and the war widows constituency right around Australia, because it is all about a fair go for veterans after three years of cutbacks and complex changes imposed by this Federal Labor Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me spell out some of those cutbacks and complex changes. How can we justify, for example, the decision in the May 1985 mini-Budget which imposed a $300 limit on several categories of dental treatment, with no consumer price index adjustment, with the result that a number of veterans have suffered directly in terms of their dental health care and have been denied that dental care to which they are truly entitled? That is just one cutback. What about the halving of the country travel allowance by the stroke of a pen, from some 27c a kilometre to 11c a kilometre with just a slight upward adjustment since 1985? Again that is a real cutback on veterans. As my colleague the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) has pointed out, they are just two of the many cutbacks imposed since May 1985 which have hit hard at the veterans, the war widows, the ex-Service personnel and indeed the serving personnel ahead of their retirement.

I will track back through some of the other cutbacks to refresh the memory of the honourable member. Look at the 2 per cent cutback on Defence Force retirement benefits pensions, the one the Government said it would fix up. It still has not fixed it up, not even in the most recent Budget. What we have had over the last three years and five months is a range of cutbacks and a range of complex changes which are bitterly resented by the veterans. One has only to meet with the Returned Services League, with war widows organisations, with the Australian Veterans and Defence Service Council and other organisations to get the real thinking of these people. That is why the Liberal and National parties came out with a policy entitled `A fair go for veterans', one which provided a series of initiatives which it ill becomes the honourable member to rubbish, because those initiatives are in accord with and arise from discussions with veterans' organisations, and are in accord with and arise from in part, in fact in anticipation of, the report of the Veterans' Entitlements Act Monitoring Committee.

During the winter recess I finalised, and shadow Cabinet and a joint party meeting approved, the veterans' affairs policy. I launched that during the winter recess, to very strong acclaim I might add from a wide cross-section of veteran office bearers. A month later came the independent Monitoring Committee report which was in accord with, and picked up, our policy centrepiece of the extreme disablement adjustment, which has subsequently been picked up in the Budget. So our policy was the catalyst for the introduction of the extreme disablement adjustment, and it is merely a step along the path to rectifying that totally and permanently incapacitated pension anomaly which this same Labor Government created in the May 1985 mini-Budget.

I totally reject what the honourable member for Petrie has told the House tonight. I believe our policy represents a very careful, constructive and responsible alternative to the approach of the Federal Labor Party over the last three years in particular, and one which is welcomed by veterans at large right across Australia.

The Government made the announcement this week about `Westpacing' the defence service home loans scheme. It said, `Wait until we spell out the details and ramifications associated with that announcement next week'. In making that announcement the Government failed to provide portability to all existing loan holders-another centrepiece of the alternative coalition policy on veterans' affairs. Clearly, the honourable member for Petrie has failed in making out his case here tonight. We are all about a fair go for those who have served their country in time of war. I take this opportunity to salute and to wish well all those veterans who are gathering in Melbourne for the Vietnam veterans international reunion which is being held this weekend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that any veterans who read this debate-none of them would be listening-will turn back a few pages of the Hansard to read the speech made earlier by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). The Deputy Leader was not saying that we need to spend more on veterans; he was criticising this Government for not cutting Federal expenditure enough. I wonder why the shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs claims that this Government has done all these terrible things to veterans. I would be interested to know whether the shadow Minister obtained a commitment from his shadow Cabinet, when he was drawing up the policy, as to whether a coalition government would restore all of these allegedly terrible cutbacks which our Government has implemented. The shadow Minister listed a whole series of changes which he says were wrong. I will not bother to repeat the claims that he has made.

SPEECH.PARA: Is he suggesting to this House that a future Liberal-National Party government would overturn the changes that were made in the May 1985 mini-Budget? He studiously seeks to ignore my comments because he knows as well as I do that no future Liberal-National Party government would reverse those decisions. The truth is that the Liberals and Nationals voted in the Senate for those changes in 1985. Yet they run around the country seeking to whip up a frenzy amongst veterans when their own senators voted for those changes in May 1985. The shadow Minister knows that he cannot give veterans a commitment that there will be any change because people such as the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) will ensure that there is no money for veterans. In fact, veterans will be pretty lucky if there is any Department of Veterans' Affairs under a future Liberal-National Party government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—Well, I wish he would tell us whether he can give veterans a commitment that the decisions, which he has complained about tonight will be reversed. Now he turns his back to me because he knows he cannot give that guarantee. He cannot tell veterans that there will be any change at all in all those decisions which he listed tonight if there is a future Liberal-National party government. Yet he has the hide to claim that his policy, which was released during the winter break, was the catalyst to this Government's adoption of the extreme disability allowance (EDA).
—That is right.

—He interjects and claims that the Opposition was responsible for the adoption of the EDA. Why does the honourable member not get off his backside and talk to his colleagues in the New South Wales Liberal and National Party Government and get them to change the decision they made in July this year to take away from New South Wales veterans their right to legal aid?

SPEECH.PARA: I would have thought that the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) was interested in the rights of veterans in his electorate to obtain legal advice when appearing before repatriation bodies. He probably is not aware that the Legal Aid Commission of New South Wales has taken away from veterans in his electorate their right to legal advice when they are appearing before the Veterans Review Board, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Federal Court. The Legal Aid Commission of New South Wales has taken upon itself the decision to take away from veterans that automatic right to obtain legal aid. In New South Wales the Legal Aid Commission has decided to impose a means test on veterans. New South Wales veterans have always had an automatic right to obtain legal aid in the past. I would have thought that if the honourable member for Farrer thinks that his policy was responsible for our Government adopting the EDA allowance, he could use a little of the magic catalyst he has in his pockets to get his Liberal and National Party colleagues in New South Wales to overturn the decision to take away from veterans the right to obtain legal aid.

What is an even more important question is what has happened to the money, because the New South Wales State Liberal and National Party Government has received more than $27.5m to provide legal aid to New South Wales citizens, including $500,000 for New South Wales veterans to give them the automatic right to this legal aid. I put the question to the shadow Minister: if the Federal Parliament is allocating $500,000 to his friends in New South Wales to give this legal aid to veterans and now they are no longer receiving it, where has the money gone? What has happened to that $500,000 which should be providing New South Wales veterans with that legal advice? The silence on the other side of the chamber is the real thing that I hope my veterans understand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite the late hour, I would like to raise a matter which needs urgent attention from a number of authorities if we are to avoid a national embarrassment. But before I do, can I assure those on the other side of this place that we, in government late next year and early in 1990, at least can assure the Australian people that we will retain a discrete Department of Veterans' Affairs rather than move the way the Government is obviously moving under the social security umbrella.

SPEECH.PARA: The Lions International convention to be held in Brisbane in mid-1991 will create the biggest international traffic peak in the history of Australian air travel, including the present World Expo, where tourist levels have been spread over six months. It is anticipated that 45,000 international attendees from 150 countries will arrive in and depart from Brisbane over seven days from 16 June of that year, with a daily peak of about 15,000 delegates. Economic benefits will flow across the nation and $100m would be a conservative estimate of the overseas funds inflow for that period.

However, the key to the success of that convention will undoubtedly be the ability of Brisbane International Airport to handle the projected levels of passenger travel. In 1987 in Taipei 35,000 Lions delegates were handled, albeit with substantial difficulties, by Taiwanese authorities using 22 available airport gates; whereas earlier this year in Denver about the same number of Lions delegates were handled by United States authorities with few problems through the 100-plus gates available at that airport.

Regrettably, under present international air terminal arrangements in Brisbane an expected 50 per cent increase in delegates on the Colorado level-that is, from 30,000 to 45,000-will need to be catered for through Brisbane's six gates. I think it is worth repeating those figures, Mr Deputy President: In Taipei, 35,000--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The title of the person in the chair here is Deputy Speaker and not Deputy President.
—I apologise.
—I do not mind being called many things, but Deputy President is a title I think someone in this House would object to.

—I apologise. In Taipei, 35,000 through 22 gates, with problems; in Colorado, 30,000 to 35,000 through 100-plus gates, with minor problems only; and in Brisbane, potentially 45,000 through six gates only, with obviously adverse results. It will therefore call for something more substantive than Australian ingenuity to correct a drastically inadequate situation unless early action is taken on the construction of a new international terminal at Eagle Farm.

SPEECH.PARA: I urge all three levels of government involved-the Atkinson Brisbane City Council, the Ahern State Government, and the Hawke Federal Government-to resolve any differences quickly if Australia in general and Brisbane in particular are not to suffer a major international reputation reversal from the highly favourable tourist climate that is being generated by the people of Brisbane and the Expo of 1988. Why can we not bury the party political hatchets for once in this matter, and why can we not in the broader national interest exercise a measure of good old fashioned bipartisan support for what is clearly a national need?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker--
—Who is this idiot?
—Order! The honourable member for Gippsland shall not interject.
—Mr Acting Deputy Speaker, the honourable member for Gippsland has a long way to go.
—The honourable member for Calwell might not respond to the interjections.
—I want to talk about some of the factors involved in the magnificent result of the Victorian election, which was handsomely won by the Australian Labor Party. It was an excellent result.
—It was a result for the Socialist Left.

—It was a result for the Labor Party. It was a win in the difficult economic circumstances faced by this country. A number of the honourable members opposite, including the honourable member for Gippsland and the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson) were saying before the Victorian election that the Opposition was guaranteed of a sweeping victory. The Leader of the Opposition in Victoria, Mr Kennett, was suggesting that he was going to win enough seats to govern in his own right-15 seats. In the end the Opposition picked up only one seat. Even that was lucky. We nearly picked up the seat of Berwick. One of the things we must ask is why there was not a swing to the Opposition in the so-called marginal electorates in Victoria.
—Because you bought them off.

—We bought them off according to the honourable member for Gippsland, who would not know what he was talking about because he does not live in Melbourne and he does not know about the situation in the Melbourne metropolitan area. One of the reasons why there was not a swing to the Opposition in the marginal electorates in Victoria was that the Labor Party picked up a significant number of votes from certain ethnic communities in the eastern suburbs of Melbourne which had never voted for the Labor Party before. The reason the Labor Party picked up those votes, which made up for some votes that might have been lost by the Labor Party, is the Federal Opposition's disgraceful performance in relation to its immigration policy.
—How do you know that, Andrew?

—This is not just my view; it is the view of a number of senior people in the Labor Party. There is no doubt about it. A significant group of people-I am referring particularly to people from Asian backgrounds-clearly voted against the Liberal Party because they were absolutely disgusted by the discriminatory attitude adopted by the Federal Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and the Leader of the National Party (Mr Sinclair) on immigration.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no question about it. This was a significant factor in Labor's win. It is evident from the responses recorded at polling booths during election time and from the number of people from these backgrounds who came and talked to our people. In fact, many people of Asian background worked for the Labor Party for the first time in the Victorian election and played a significant role in convincing their communities that their only future in this country is with the Australian Labor Party-which is true.

I remind the House that the Federal Leader of the Opposition has not changed the discriminatory policy which was adopted by the Liberal Party or its offending clauses. It continues to reject multiculturalism, the most important philosophy in terms of the cultural unity of this country that has been adopted in the last 20 to 30 years. While the Liberal Party persists with this policy it will lose votes across the board, not only from the Asian communities, but from all the ethnic communities. Amongst the people who have come to this country from all migrant backgrounds there is definitely a backlash against the Liberal and National parties. In my view, it was the policy of the Federal Leader of the Opposition on multiculturalism and immigration which lost the Opposition the election.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will certainly address the points raised by the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) both on immigration and the impact of the socialist left on Victorian politics at a later and much more appropriate time. Tonight I take this opportunity to warmly and sincerely congratulate Phillip Honeywood, the successful Liberal candidate for the electorate of Warrandyte at the recent Victorian State election. He is a fine candidate. At 10.30 tomorrow morning the declaration of the poll will take place and Phillip will officially become the new member for Warrandyte.

SPEECH.PARA: The seat of Warrandyte crosses the boundaries of two Federal electorates-Casey and Streeton. The majority of the electorate, however, comes within the borders of Casey. It covers, in whole or in part, the most important areas of Chirnside Park, Croydon, Croydon North, Mooroolbark, Park Orchards, Ringwood North, Warrandyte, Warranwood and Wonga Park.

Phillip and I share more than the important and challenging responsibility of representing many of the same constituents in the State and Federal parliaments respectively. In December 1984 when I defeated Peter Steedman in Casey, it was the only Victorian lower House seat to be won from the Government at that election, and it was the first time the seat had not been held by the government of the day. When Phillip Honeywood defeated Lou Hill on 1 October, he achieved the same `double'. What is more, he achieved it with a swing of 3 per cent to the Liberal Party.

Phillip won this vital marginal seat because he deserved to do so. There is absolutely no question of a victory by default in the case of Warrandyte. The voters were well aware of the issues and of the qualities of the respective candidates. They recognised Phillip to be a dedicated, intelligent, mature and sincere young man, committed to the ideals and philosophies of the Liberal Party and to providing active and effective representation for an area which is-to use the in term-hurting badly under the socialist left-controlled Cain Administration. That Administration is likely to perpetrate even more unnecessary depredations on the Victorian people.

On 1 October 1988 when the electors of Warrandyte chose this energetic and enthusiastic young family man to represent them as their Legislative Assembly member in the Victorian Parliament, they chose wisely and well. Phillip is more than adequately equipped to handle his new responsibilities. He has considerable experience as an employee relations and industrial relations officer with a leading company. He could best be described as a `people person' who genuinely cares about others and is anxious to share and understand their problems and concerns and to assist them in practical and constructive ways. He puts great emphasis on traditional standards and moral values-something that is sadly lacking on the Government benches both in Victoria and Canberra.

He and his delightful wife, Gabrielle, are expecting their first child within the next few days; so they will be embarking on two significant and exciting challenges in a very short space of time. The first is political life. The second is far more important, far more demanding and-I speak from considerable experience-far more rewarding in every way. That, of course, is parenthood. I am sure that members on both sides of the House will join me and all his Federal and State colleagues in wishing Phillip Honeywood a bright and rewarding career in politics.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In reply to some of the issues raised by the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), I should on behalf of the Opposition warn the people of Victoria that they are now saddled with a socialist left-dominated government. Those opposite should not try to pretend that it is not dominated by the socialist left. We on this side can count as accurately as those opposite.

SPEECH.PARA: A few leading lights of the socialist left faction in this place have been gloating about their victory in Victoria and in asides in corridors and in interjections across the floor of this chamber they are at pains to stress their strength, and indeed their control, of the Government down in Victoria. If only the true nature of a future Cain Government had been revealed to the voters of Victoria before they went to the poll on 1 October, the result would have been very different. But it was skilfully-a better word is probably `cunningly'-deliberately and dishonestly covered up to show the dominance of the left faction; so much so that it is the only State in Australia which has a Labor Government dominated in both Cabinet and caucus by the socialist left faction. It has waited a long time for such dominance and to be able to pull the strings of government, to make the Premier jump through the hoops at will. It will now call in the chips. It has been patient enough, and now is the time for reckoning.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 23 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the distribution of grants to organisations under the Disability Services Act been running behind schedule; if so, (a) why and (b) to what extent.
(2) Are grants to the North Queensland Society for Crippled Children behind schedule; if so, (a) why and (b) by what sum.
(3) How does his Department envisage that organisations dependent upon these grants cope with late payments.
(4) Does he propose to provide additional financial grants to cover interest costs on overdrafts and loans made necessary by the late payment of operating grants.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A small number of 1988-89 Disability Services Program grants are yet to be finalised, because the required contracts are still being negotiated with service provider organisations, or due to a delay in the return of signed contracts by organisations. July 1988 payments were delayed in the case of those nursing homes for disabled persons that transferred to the Disability Services Program, with effect from 1 July 1988. There was also a delay until 14 July in the payment of the July-September quarter grants to existing Disability Services Program services in North Queensland due to a payment system malfunction. This is regretted.

I fully appreciate the cash flow situation of grant recipients. Every effort is made by my Department to release grant monies on the earliest possible date. The exceptional breakdown which occurred in this instance was rectified as soon as possible, and no delay is expected in future payments.

(2) (a) and (b) The North Queensland Society for Crippled Children was one of the organisations affected by the delay, which involved a sum of $96,970 in relation to the Society's nursing home and $79,543 in relation to other services.

(3) and (4) Many organisations operate overdraft facilities in the normal course of their business, and it is not the practice to invite supplementary claims for overdraft costs which may be incurred pending receipt of grant monies. In any event, those costs may not be due exclusively to the timing of the payment of grants, as has been explained in (1) above. It should also be noted that the grants involved were of a prospective nature-that is, they were advances in anticipation of outlays, rather than reimbursements due in respect of previously incurred expenditure.
